HEADLINE: Incumbent Snubbed by Her Party

SERIES: NEW YORK PRIMARY: 37th Assembly District

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
As she strode about the tables at the Sunnyside Senior Center in Queens on a recent morning, Assemblywoman Catherine T. Nolan was greeted by the crowd, mostly women, as though she were their favorite daughter. They asked about her 2-year-old son, they admired her necklace and they cheered lustily as she asked for their continued support.
But when Ms. Nolan was asked by one smiling woman how she was doing, the assemblywoman's own smile vanished briefly. "To tell you the truth," she answered, "I'm a little bit nervous." 
 Ms. Nolan, the eight-term incumbent assemblywoman, the chairwoman of the Assembly's Committee on Labor, and a veteran Queens politician, is facing a political challenge in Tuesday's primary in the 37th Assembly District.
Her opponent is Patrick T. O'Malley, 33, a former Queens prosecutor who placed his private law practice aside to undertake his first foray into elective politics. But Mr. O'Malley is no ordinary political neophyte. He is the brother of Martin O'Malley, the mayor of Baltimore, and he has raised a sufficient amount of money to cause Queens Democratic leaders, Ms. Nolan foremost among them, to take his candidacy seriously.
Apart from the $70,000 he has raised, Mr. O'Malley was endorsed this week in a joint appearance by a past mayor of New York City, Edward I. Koch, and the current mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani. Ms. Nolan has long had a tenuous relationship with the Democratic Party organization in Queens, which took the unusual step of declining to endorse the incumbent in this Assembly race.
Ms. Nolan, 42, has had little in the way of well-financed, competitive races since she was elected to the Assembly in 1984. "I have to take this race very seriously," she said. "I have to stress my record with regard to education, and programs that have really helped people in this community."
Mr. O'Malley, in discussing the race, said he decided to run because of what he described as the lackluster job Ms. Nolan had done in representing the district. His major complaint was that Ms. Nolan is so out of touch with her constituents that she voted in favor of repealing New York City's commuter tax for state residents who work in the city -- a position that has also made her the target of attacks by the mayor. The tax was abolished for in-state residents effective last July and for out-of-state commuters earlier this year.
Mr. O'Malley said that this deprives the city of the tax revenue from commuters who work in New York City. "That is a move that has robbed the city of $500 million each year," Mr. O'Malley said. "That's not the vote of someone who cared about this city and this community."
Ms. Nolan explained her vote on the commuter tax as being based on her view of the regional nature of the New York area economy. She further said that by voting to reduce taxes for suburban residents, legislators from New York City could call upon their suburban colleagues for cooperation. "I don't think the repeal of the commuter tax will have long-term negative consequences," Ms. Nolan said. "We have to look at ourselves as being in a regional economy."
Ms. Nolan was quick to point out other aspects of her record. A vocal abortion rights advocate, Ms. Nolan mentioned, for example, how she secured financing for several programs, including the first occupational safety and health clinic in Queens, and how she sponsored legislation to increase the minimum wage.
Ms. Nolan described her opponent as someone "who seems perfectly nice," but as a political newcomer who was prompted to run in part by the invitation of the Queens Democratic organization. Last year, Ms. Nolan incurred the wrath of the Queens Democratic Party chairman, former Representative Thomas Manton.
When Mr. Manton resigned from Congress and engineered the selection of his hand-picked successor on the ballot, Ms. Nolan was harshly critical. She broke with other Queens Democratic leaders by refusing to endorse Mr. Manton's successor, Representative Joseph Crowley. Instead, she endorsed City Councilman Walter McCaffrey, who undertook a short-lived challenge to Mr. Crowley earlier this year.
Mr. O'Malley, a member of the Anarac Democratic Club -- of which Mr. Manton is the most prominent member -- insisted that the former congressman had offered no assistance or encouragement to his campaign. "My campaign is not dependent on anyone's support," he said. Mr. Manton echoed that view, saying that he had not endorsed either candidate and that he had offered no assistance to Mr. O'Malley's insurgent race.
Indeed, Mr. O'Malley has put together a team of volunteers and a busy, if crowded campaign headquarters on the second floor of a building on Queens Boulevard. His campaign literature notes his work as a volunteer in teaching English in a village in Peru and his former job as a fifth-grade teacher in the Bronx.
On the issues, Mr. O'Malley discussed the need to obtain more state money for schools in the district. He said he favors "new educational techniques," including vouchers. On abortion rights, Mr. O'Malley said he generally opposes abortion, particularly the late-term procedure that its critics call "partial birth abortion."
The 37th Assembly District is a stretch of western Queens, including Sunnyside, Ridgewood and parts of Woodside and Long Island City. It is a mainly working-class area that still has a large Irish-American population. But the district has in recent years had a growing population of Korean and Hispanic residents.
Ms. Nolan has raised about $150,000 for the race and has years of incumbency and a network of Democratic supporters and field soldiers at her disposal. Nonetheless, she said she is taking nothing for granted.
"I'm having to get out there and work," she said, before leaving the Sunnyside center for another campaign event. "But having a race like this makes you spend time getting your message out. And, actually, that's a good thing."

HEADLINE: SUMMIT IN NEW YORK: THE CUBAN LEADER;
Friendly Crowd Provides Castro With a Soapbox

BYLINE: By EDWARD WONG and CHRIS HEDGES

 BODY:
President Fidel Castro of Cuba stepped away from the formalities of the United Nations summit meeting and back into his familiar battle fatigues last night to address a crowd of flag-waving supporters who hung on his every blistering criticism of the world's superpowers.
"We shall be entering the 21st century, and that will happen in extremely hard conditions for the world," Mr. Castro said in a hoarse voice to about 2,400 listeners at Riverside Church in the Morningside Heights neighborhood in Manhattan. "The world is undergoing a catastrophic situation. Don't believe the experts who feign optimism and ignore the cruel realities of the developing world." 
 Mr. Castro called the United States' economic sanctions against Cuba a "criminal embargo" and "a violation of human rights."
He arrived shortly after 9 p.m., an hour later than scheduled, and began his speech around 10 p.m. Dressed in his signature olive military uniform, he strode confidently to the lectern, surrounded by guards in dark suits. Cheers and screams rose to the dark heights of the church, and hundreds of arms fervently waved Cuban flags. In some ways, the scene echoed the mass rallies that took place in the streets of Havana during the international struggle over Elian Gonzalez last spring.
In his lengthy lecture, Mr. Castro decried the globalization of economic markets and criticized what he called a lack of effort by wealthy nations to battle disease in poorer countries. He pointed to the doctors that Cuba has sent to developing nations like Angola, and said Cuba is ready to offer inexpensive medical training to 250 Americans each year, as long as they return to the United States to practice in poor areas.
Citing a series of figures that show a decline in living standards in much of the world, he said, "As time passes, the rich nations become richer, and the contribution they make to the huge numbers of poor decreases."
The organizers of the event called it "an evening of solidarity with the Cuban people." Those political sympathies were worn on sleeves, collars and T-shirts, as pins of the Cuban flag and of Che Guevara, the guerrilla leader who became a symbol of the Communist revolution, abounded. Outside the church, dozens of protesters waved placards and shouted anti-Castro slogans.
Most of those who attended the speech, including Representative Jose E. Serrano, Democrat of New York, and Representative Maxine Waters, Democrat of California, denounced United States policies toward Cuba. The United States imposed the economic embargo shortly after Mr. Castro took power in 1959.
"The American people view Cuba very differently from its government," Mr. Serrano told a group of reporters in Spanish. He said he and those present only wanted Cuba to be "treated equally."
"If Cuba discovered oil tomorrow, my country would be its greatest ally," he said. "If Cuba had, and I don't want it to have, military arms that could create terror in the world, we would be allies."
Mr. Castro had visited Harlem and surrounding neighborhoods twice previously since 1960. He was invited by the New York Welcoming Committee for the Cuban Delegation for the Millennium. People wanting to attend were asked to fax requests. Last night, about 2,100 of them sat in the main chamber, while 300 sat in a side room watching on television.
The organization, made up of various grass-roots groups, asked Riverside if they could use the church.
"We hope to show tonight how many people there are who oppose the embargo," said Aleeka Wade, a spokeswoman for the group.
Mr. Castro was in New York this week to attend the United Nations summit. On Wednesday, he stirred the political winds when he shook hands with President Clinton during a luncheon -- the first time that Mr. Castro, 74, had ever locked hands with a sitting American president.
Describing the moment, Mr. Castro said he was walking along a hallway to have an official photograph taken when he saw President Clinton ahead of him shaking the hands of several world leaders. "I couldn't run away," he said. "In two minutes or less, I arrived at the place where he was standing. I stopped for a second, and with great dignity and courtesy we shook hands. He did exactly the same thing. It would have been rude for me to act differently. It all lasted for 20 seconds."
Last night, as she was waiting for Mr. Castro to arrive at Riverside, a supporter named Ellen P. Bernstein reflected on the Communist leader's role in the world even as she sang the Cuban national anthem.
"The U.S. people need to hear that he is not a devil, not the devil he is said to be," she said. "They need to hear he has important ideas for the same goals we all aspire to: world peace and security and the proper treatment of the poor."

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Riders Few, Delta to End Portland-Japan Flights

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., Sept. 8

 BODY:
Stung by low ridership and high operating costs, Delta Air Lines is discontinuing its last two direct flights from Portland to Japan starting next April, ending 13 years of service. 
 Mac Armstrong, executive vice president of operations for Delta, said on Wednesday that the airline had lost $10 million on the Portland-Japan routes in the last 12 months.
Delta plans to replace its Portland-Japan service with one daily round-trip flight between John F. Kennedy Airport in New York and Tokyo and one daily round-trip flight between Los Angeles and Nagoya, Japan.
Mr. Armstrong said problems with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, which has been accused of detaining and deporting a disproportionately large number of foreign travelers at the Portland airport, were "not an economic factor in our decision."
But he acknowledged that the Portland airport's reputation in Asia, where some call it "Deportland," did play a role in the decision.
"The situation certainly was a factor from a customer-service point of view," Mr. Armstrong said.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
The Long Road From Whoville to Broadway

BYLINE: By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
FOR the Broadway of right now, the notion seemed irresistible: an original musical out of the pages of Dr. Seuss that would turn Horton the Elephant and the Cat in the Hat into theater animals.
But one look at the characters onstage in Boston and the creators of "Seussical" knew the show had identity problems. Catherine Zuber's costumes for the eagerly anticipated production, based on the work of one of the world's most popular children's writers, were simply too stylized, too whimsical -- too, of all things, Seussian. 
 It was not that Ms. Zuber, a highly regarded designer in her own right, had failed her aesthetic mandate. It was just that the producers, authors and director of the $8.5 million production, a show blessed with some of the best pre-Broadway buzz in years, were worried. If taste-setting early audiences sensed too much fluff and preciousness, would the musical be categorized -- and marginalized -- as kids' stuff?
"We had beautiful costumes individually, but as soon as we put more than half a dozen out there it became such a feast for the eyes that we lost focus on the people and the storytelling," said Gary Gunas, who is producing "Seussical" along with such Broadway and Hollywood powerhouses as SFX Theatrical Group, Barry and Fran Weissler and Universal Studios. "Catherine and the rest of us just sort of stared up there and said, 'O.K., we've gone astray.' "
So, mere days before performances were to begin late last month for the show's Boston tryout, Ms. Zuber and her designs were out. William Ivey Long was brought in to replace her, with the idea of dressing the Seuss characters more realistically. Such substitutions are not unheard of in a show's trial-and-error phase out of town. But the last-minute turmoil was more than a struggle over how Dr. Seuss' exotic creations should look. It reflected the serious artistic and commercial conflicts arising ever more frequently these days as Broadway becomes more preoccupied with the needs of an age group that in the past it rarely catered to -- children -- while holding on for dear life to the adult audience that has sustained it.
Once upon a time, George Bernard Shaw or Thornton Wilder served as the inspiration for a season's major Broadway musical. Today, that role has shifted to the likes of Disney cartoon animators -- and the creator of "Green Eggs and Ham." From the New Amsterdam Theater on 42nd Street, where "The Lion King" reigns as the biggest Broadway hit in years, to the Royal National Theater in London, where "Honk!," a show based on "The Ugly Duckling," snared the Olivier Award for best musical this year, it is the fantasy world of the youngest theatergoers that has captured the imagination of the conceptualizers and bankrollers of lavish entertainments.
The evolution can be traced through shows like "Cats." When it began life on Broadway 18 years ago, it was touted as an innovative grown-up musical. But over the years, the marketing seemed to shift. Where once the show's dominant image was of that lithe dancer framed by a pair of cat's eyes, the television commercials became filled with the images of children having their faces painted to resemble the characters onstage.
"When I was a child in the suburbs of New York, the big event was to go to the theater and see the thing that all the adults were excited about," said Leonard Marcus, a children's book historian and critic. "I went to see 'My Fair Lady' and 'The Music Man' and 'Bye Bye Birdie': that's a reflection of how child-adult relationships were in those days. These days, there's a lot more interest in what the child wants to do. Doing things for the child's sake."
"Seussical," scheduled to open Nov. 9 at the Richard Rodgers Theater, was clearly created with the hope of tapping into the changing demographics of Broadway, a shift mainly brought about by three factors: the culture's obsession with youth, a nostalgia craze among baby boomers with children and an appetite for pricier family entertainment fueled by the robust economy.
But in engaging such known Broadway quantities as the lyricist Lynn Ahrens, the composer Stephen Flaherty and the director Frank Galati, all of "Ragtime" fame, along with the choreographer Kathleen Marshall ("Kiss Me, Kate"), the producers of "Seussical" found themselves faced with a difficult question: could an ambitious show that tells the story of an elephant who hatches an egg and a microscopic boy who lives on a speck of dust and a homely bird who just wants to be loved add up to something that grown-ups would buy tickets to, even if they didn't have children?
Barry Weissler, a co-producer of "Chicago" and "Annie Get Your Gun," joined the production team with his wife after he saw a workshop version last summer in Toronto that witnesses report had many a hard-bitten producing type in tears. Mr. Weissler said the success or failure of "Seussical" at overcoming preconceptions of how adult a show about Seuss could possibly be might be the ultimate test of its theatrical power.
THE magic numbers, say the producers of "Seussical," are 7 and 77. That is the age range they are seeking to attract; indeed, it is the range they believe they have to draw to approach the success of the show that radically changed perceptions of children's musical theater, "The Lion King." With its heart-stopping masks and visual effects, overseen by the avant-garde theater director Julie Taymor, on whom the Walt Disney Company took a chance, "The Lion King" demonstrated that a big, commercial family show could have artistic aspirations: that it could be more than a cartoon with Equity actors cast as dessert plates (Disney's "Beauty and the Beast") or the kind of clunky spectacle doomed to be made sport of by critics (Frank Wildhorn's "Jekyll and Hyde").
The powers behind "Seussical" believe that some of its strengths -- a melodic Ahrens-Flaherty score; an emotional narrative; a potential star in Kevin Chamberlin (a Tony nominee last season for his role in "Dirty Blonde"), who plays the hapless Horton -- make it a worthy example of old-style Broadway values, and thus perhaps an even likelier candidate than "The Lion King" for crossover appeal. Though Ms. Taymor's production received generally glowing notices, some critics, like Ben Brantley of The New York Times, pointed to the show's weaker elements -- for example, a book that seemed undramatic and characters that were essentially opaque.
Indeed, "Seussical" strives to be unlike "The Lion King" everywhere but at the box office. "We are a different animal," Mr. Weissler said, the pun unintentional. "Julie Taymor is a genius at what she does with masks and costumes. But that's the opposite of what we're doing. That's why the costumes had to go. Because they weren't allowing us to be the opposite."
Six weeks ago, in a fourth-floor studio at 890 Broadway, rehearsal central for musical theater in New York, Mr. Galati and Ms. Marshall watched as the company ran through the ensemble number "Here on Who." Whoville is an important destination in the nearly sung-through "Seussical." The inhabitants of "the tiniest planet in the sky" are beset by war and environmental disaster: some of the books by Dr. Seuss, a k a Theodor Geisel, are virtual parables of modern human perils. But the most affecting problem facing the Whos is that no one knows they are alive.
When the number was over, Mr. Galati seemed pleased. "There's no sense of cartoon," he told the company, and he meant it as a compliment. "It's absolutely real and specific. Just as long as it stays that way, the arc of the number will work."
That adult sensibility is intended to inform every movement. For example, when the denizens of Who, hoping that Horton will protect their little planet, end their serenade of him with "We're tiny little people/ Saying thanks in advance," Ms. Marshall devised a tip-o'-the-hat gesture on "thanks in advance" that is an homage to Broadway choruses of the past.
"Like any good theater, the theme reveals itself," she said. "The universality comes from the specifics."
The interwoven tales of "Seussical" amount to a musical convention of Seuss characters, presided over by the Cat in the Hat (played by David Shiner, half the mime team of "Fool Moon," in his first professional speaking role). It is Horton alone, as the famous story goes, who hears the Whos, and in particular one of the littlest Whos, a boy named JoJo (Andrew Keenan-Bolger and Anthony Blair Hall alternate in the role) with a vivid imagination and a feeling of being all alone in the universe.
It becomes Horton's humanitarian (elephantarian?) mission to have their innocent voices heard in the brutally cynical Jungle of Nool, where Horton himself is an outcast, a lonely figure of fun. He too has his blind spots, though; he is oblivious to the attentions of Gertrude McFuzz (Janine LaManna), a sorry-looking bird with only one pathetic tail feather.
With its deep investment in the rhyming nonsense of Seussian language -- "Think a Trip on a Ship/ To the Vipper of Vipp/ Or to Solla Sollew," the cast sings in the opening, "Oh, the Thinks You Can Think!" -- the musical is a manifesto on the liberation of the mind. It is also about the dignity of individual expression, the struggle to be noticed -- and accepted -- for who you are.
"It's really been Lynn's and my vision of Dr. Seuss," said Mr. Flaherty, who has been writing musicals with Ms. Ahrens for nearly 20 years. In addition to "Ragtime," their Broadway collaborations include "My Favorite Year" and "Once on This Island."
"Stephen forced me to read the books," Ms. Ahrens added. "The little Whos are like Earth: we're adrift, looking to save ourselves. We tried to be truthful to the innocent anarchy in the books. There is a deep concern in them for the planet, for human beings and how we should behave toward one another, and it plays out in all this zany stuff."
The songwriting team was recruited for the project by Livent, the Canadian theatrical production house founded by Garth Drabinsky, which produced "Ragtime" and obtained the rights to the Seuss anthology from Geisel's widow, Audrey. Following Mr. Drabinsky's dismissal after questions about Livent's bookkeeping practices, the shepherding of "Seussical" became the responsibility of SFX, the entertainment giant that had acquired Livent. Signing on as co-producers were Universal -- which is bringing out a big-screen version of "How the Grinch Stole Christmas" starring Jim Carrey, scheduled to open the week after "Seussical" -- and the Weisslers.
Initially, Eric Idle, a member of the Monty Python comedy team, was to write the book, but he dropped out well before last summer's Toronto workshop, the event that kicked "Seussical" into high gear. Even Audrey Geisel was there. "I was completely captivated," Mrs. Geisel said in a recent interview. "And if I had to be narrowed to one single word about the production it would have to be 'seamless.' " Though she had been wooed "many, many times" for the rights to musicalize her husband's works, she said, what persuaded her to yield on this occasion was the run-the-gamut approach.
"No one had ever hit on that bouquet of all the characters, and said 'I want to take all of them,' " she continued. "And before, none of it was enchanting enough that I wanted to give the critters up."
From that successful workshop, many actors were retained for Broadway. None are household names, but the most troubling loss was that of Andrea Martin, who won a Tony Award for "My Favorite Year" and was to play the Cat in the Hat, until she decided, the producers said, that she could not be away from her family in California for the length of a Broadway run. It was then that the producers approached Mr. Shiner, whose skills as a clown with a mean streak were thought to encompass just the sort of danger required for the major-domo-like role of the Cat.
Even more dangerously, though, the Cat in the Hat is ubiquitous in "Seussical," assuming various personalities, commenting on the action and, gulp, singing his heart out. And Mr. Shiner has absolutely no professional experience in a musical.
"I've never sung a note onstage in my life," he said. In fact, the thought of singing for the cast, let alone an audience, terrified him. "I just kept getting in a room and singing and singing and singing until I started feeling comfortable with it," Mr. Shiner added. "I started taking voice lessons, learning ways to deepen my voice and to relax, and I slowly discovered that my voice wasn't that bad."
In a sense, Mr. Shiner has become the embodiment of the show's attempt to defy expectations, the clown who is not just for children in a musical that is not meant just for them, either.
What he and everyone else associated with "Seussical" are banking on is Dr. Seuss's uncommon common touch.
"The essence of this piece is very universal and it connects in a deeply emotional way," Mr. Shiner said. "Horton and JoJo sing of being alone in the universe, of the notion that 'I have wings and I can fly.' There is a part of everyone that feels alone -- and the feeling we all have of something in us that is much, much deeper, that feeling that we can fly."

HEADLINE: FILM: PERIOD PIECES;
A Filmmaker Both Promising and Forgotten at 64

BYLINE: By DAVID THOMSON; David Thomson is the author of "A Biographical Dictionary of Film."

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
FEW authentic American filmmakers have done as much to absorb and employ non-American ways. Yet Philip Kaufman deserves to be regarded as an American filmmaker. "The Right Stuff" examined our power, our progress and all our brands of heroism. And it had that old American acid -- irony. But America didn't really enjoy that movie: the taste for irony had faded. So Phil looked farther afield: he made "The Unbearable Lightness of Being," a Czech film done in France; he did "Henry and June," about Americans in Paris and that stranger country called Sex. Again, America managed not to be impressed. But now, I think, he's got it: he has an Australian playing the Marquis de Sade in a picture made in England. Now only the dunces can miss the irony and the charming way in which "the English movie" has become the equivalent of an American genre.
"Quills" is wickedly funny, impious, blasphemous, very sexy, very tender, very frightening -- for it shows that prison may be a basic state -- but also mischievous, subversive and liberating. It's Phil's best work yet, and don't be surprised if it's a dark-horse hit of the season and best-picture material -- "The Marquis de Sade in Love"? 
 All of which is more than welcome from a director who will be 64 when "Quills" opens in November, and who hasn't had a picture since "Rising Sun" (1993), a smart adaptation of the Michael Crichton novel about the conflict between American and Japanese business practices. It was an effective, streamlined thriller, good enough to dispel foolish claims that it was anti-Japanese, but not as personal as many of Kaufman's movies.
I should admit that Phil Kaufman and I are friends. How close? Well, I've never quite known. But since before "The Right Stuff" (1983). His son, Peter, in a very gentlemanly way, once took out one of my daughters. I'm likely to bump into Phil at the Saturday morning farmers' market, where he gives good but gentle advice on the corn to pick, and we'll talk about jazz, basketball, soccer, having children and grandchildren, and so on. It's a San Francisco thing: we live only a few blocks apart and have the same couple clean our houses. I'm mentioning all this because I still remember the awful day, in 1990, when he showed me "Henry and June." This was well before the film opened but at a time when he was in shock and dismay, having heard that the film would be branded with the kiss of death, an NC-17 rating.
Anyone could tell Phil needed support -- just as America deserved and still deserves to be allowed to grow up and live happily with the NC-17 rating. There ought to be films no one under 17 should see. There ought to be some space for grown-up ideas, for intimacy and danger.
Well, I didn't like "Henry and June" -- it doesn't matter why now. But I told him. It was part of my being too proud or too stupid, or too much the critic, to find other things to say. Not that he was going to fall for evasions. Still, it showed me that filmmakers and critics have their own adjoining prisons. It cooled us, I know, and I hope we both regretted that.
"Henry and June" flopped: no film can survive NC-17 commercially in these hypocritical times. And his previous movie, a stunning mix of sex and politics taken from Milan Kundera's "Unbearable Lightness of Being" (1988), was more admired than seen. There was some talk in the business that Phil Kaufman, who had been offered nearly every interesting project in the 80's, had gone into a corner in the 90's. Did he want to make European, art-house pictures?
The fact was that although "The Right Stuff" had been a box-office disappointment, Hollywood had thrilled to its facility, the dance of adventure and slapstick, the paean to flight and the satire on hype and bureaucracy. It was also a picture that introduced a clutch of eccentric new actors, Kaufman types: not just Sam Shepard as the Gary Cooper-like Chuck Yeager, but Dennis Quaid, Ed Harris, Fred Ward, Lance Henriksen and Scott Glenn. The director's deft handling of "The Right Stuff," which cost far less than anyone thought it had because so many locations and sets were cooked up in the Bay Area, was noticed and appreciated.
But facility, allied with evident intelligence (educated at the University of Chicago, he reckoned once to be a lawyer), could be read as a maverick spirit, an outsider's aloofness. Kaufman had let it be known some years earlier that he preferred to live in the Bay Area, with his wife (and sometime co-writer), Rose. He had done his time in Los Angeles, but he was unconvinced that a director needed to stay close to the source of power. That independence had its downside. As the writer and first director on "The Outlaw Josey Wales" (1976), Phil had had a showdown with his producer-star, Clint Eastwood. Eastwood said Phil couldn't make up his mind. Kaufman had said there were scenes where more than one or two takes might be justified: work longer with a thing and you might find more depth.
PHIL had been fired and Eastwood took over as director on what proved a very successful picture -- which might have been better still, and might have punctured the absurd myth that Eastwood is a great director instead of just a very effective, rather brutal producer. A few years later, after he had had hopes of being its writer-director, Kaufman ended up with only a story credit (and a nice little percentage) on what turned into "Raiders of the Lost Ark."
Some said he was too stubborn or suspicious of the business, too sensitive or too fixed on a private vision. You could see such traits in his early films -- "The Great Northfield, Minnesota Raid" (1972), a screwball western about the James gang; "The White Dawn" (1974), a story of whalers stranded off Alaska; "Invasion of the Body Snatchers" (1978), a wonderful, cool, scary remake all done in San Francisco, in which the paranoia of Jack Finney's novel lapped over into the neurosis of New Age people; and "The Wanderers" (1979), a romantic gang movie, taken from the Richard Price novel.
Kaufman can be wry about being both promising and forgotten at 64. His modest company, Walrus -- which is him; Rose; their son, Peter, who is now Phil's co-producer; and a secretary -- is based in the North Beach of restaurants and cafes. For economy's sake, they did some of the editing on "Quills" there in the office, with the editor, Peter Boyle, brought over from England. One afternoon this summer, we talked there, and I asked Phil to explain the gap since "Rising Sun."
"Two solid years of my hiatus," he said, "was a thing called 'The Alienist.' A wonderful period novel by Caleb Carr. It had very dark material. But when I set out on it, I said to Sherry Lansing at Paramount, 'Are you really going to do a story about a boy whore who is killed?' And she looked me in the eye and said, 'You bet we are.' We worked on the script, the locations, everything. Two years -- no exaggeration. It was ready to go when the studio said, 'Well, no, perhaps we're not.' There has been a crazy indecision over material. You can do anything if it's violence or horror, but get into the depths of real behavior and they lose confidence.
"There have been other things. Eric Roth wrote a script about the C.I.A., 'The Good Shepherd,' with James Jesus Angleton as the central character. Zoetrope was going to do that, then changed their policy. That was another year. I did a John Grisham novel, 'Runaway Jury,' and though there hasn't been a Grisham film that hasn't made money, they didn't want to do that. Cecil Brown did a script for me about Mezz Mezzrow, a white jazz musician in the 30's who was also a drug dealer. 'What's jazz?' they said.
"And there were other things."
The Walrus office is crowded with books and research materials, to say nothing of scripts. There was a plan for a movie about the Marvel Comics character Sub-Mariner; the story of Lana Turner and Johnny Stompanato, with David Peoples doing the script; a film about the spy Aldrich Ames. And as Phil comes out of "Quills," he is talking about two very different projects -- a life of Liberace and a screen version of Saul Bellow's novel "Henderson the Rain King," maybe with Jack Nicholson.
Who would have thought, then, that the project to come through would be the one concerned with the imprisonment of the Marquis de Sade?
"Fox Searchlight sent it to me a couple of years ago; it was a script by Doug Wright, taken from his own play, which had done well off Broadway. I never saw the play, and I've never read it. But I knew his script could be something. I didn't know much more than the vague outline of de Sade's life, but this was a parable about freedom of expression and, in his case, the inability not to be expressive. It was about sexual urge and hypocrisy, and it meant more to me because I came upon it at the time of Clinton, Monica and Kenneth Starr."
PHIL read a lot about de Sade -- from Simone de Beauvoir to Angela Carter -- and was startled to see how respectable a literary figure he has become in France. But he wasn't so concerned with the real figure: fat, over 60, astonishingly selfish and probably impotent. In casting Geoffrey Rush, he wanted a modern satyr, a dangerous rascal, yet an inescapably attractive figure whose most insidious act is to whisper new ideas in innocent ears. Some will be outraged at the presentation; others may see a crucial, modern example of the artist as sick man.
The drama of "Quills" is contained in an asylum where de Sade is at first happily confined. Behind bars, he writes his pornographic books, which are smuggled out by the laundress (Kate Winslet). De Sade has an eye for her, and she is attracted to him, but the conditions of prison allow for their delicious frustration. The abbe at Charenton (Joaquin Phoenix) is an idealist and a humanitarian, but he is in love with the laundress, too. It is his liberalism as a leader that brings a new, vengeful superior, a Starr in excelsis (played by Michael Caine). Thus the scene is set for the final confrontation between regulator and writer. But the regulator is doomed, for this author is ready to write when quills and paper are gone, in the very material of his body.
The ending is tragic and blasphemous, and it involves an extraordinarily luminous necrophilia scene. Obviously, this is tricky material, the more easily shot in England, where bits and pieces of many noble buildings served to make the asylum, and where the dedication of Kate Winslet, who was the first performer to commit to the film, inspired a cast that includes such actors as Patrick Malahide and Billie Whitelaw in smaller roles. The movie looks and talks like the 18th century, but the sense of nobility and self-destructiveness in the sex and the writing are utterly modern. And the whole thing ripples with comedy. You marvel at the sustained lightness of touch in a film that could have turned preachy, and may yet be forbidden in certain unironic places.
In the longer view, you can see de Sade as one more of Kaufman's outsider heroes, dangerous to themselves and alarming to society. I wonder where he will go next -- I could still see him finding his kind of saintliness in a Liberace or a James Jesus Angleton. But there's something else odd: Phil loves stories of adventure, remote settings and voyages, but he is an uncommon family man among filmmakers. I can think of no one else who works so closely with wife and son.
Yet the Phil I try to know is also a touch distanced from even his beloved family. I think he has a profound sense of being alone. It is the perfect basis for a subject he hasn't really tried yet -- the family, the real American family, like O'Neill's Tyrones, and the way in which they sail on another dark sea from the one floodlit with "family values." Above all, what Phil has done with "Quills" is help us see our kinship with monsters, demons and those divine surgeons who know the quill can be sharper than the sword -- and so much more enjoyable if pointedly applied to soft skin.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 57; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

HEADLINE: FILM;
Enough About Angels: The Devil Gets His Due

BYLINE: By JAMIE MALANOWSKI; Jamie Malanowski's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about Chris McQuarrie, writer-director of "The Way of the Gun."

 BODY:
ANGELS have been gracing pop culture fairly ostentatiously these last several years -- "Touched by an Angel," "City of Angels," "Angels in the Outfield," "Angels in America," John Travolta spectacularly spreading his wings in "Michael," the elevation of "It's a Wonderful Life" to a basic text of American civilization. But lately, and almost unnoticed in the seraphic swell, the Devil has been getting his due.
Date the current surge to 1997, when Al Pacino was so charismatically diabolical in "The Devil's Advocate." Since then, the Devil has been a featured player in three television series, "G vs. E," "Brimstone" and "God, the Devil and Bob"; had a big part last year in the Arnold Schwarzenegger action picture"End of Days"; prominently appeared in the Johnny Depp vehicle "The Ninth Gate"; was the prime mover of the plot of the Kim Basinger movie "Bless the Child" this summer; and had the key supporting part -- the best part, really, and one in which he showed a surprising comic touch and a long-hidden singing voice -- in "South Park: Bigger, Longer, Uncut," last summer's animation hit. 
 I know what you're thinking: with as many people in Hollywood headed for hell as the religious right seems to think, why such an uneven output? All three television series tanked. The big "Ninth Gate" reunion of Roman Polanski and the Devil turned out to be less a reimagining of "Rosemary's Baby" than leftovers on the order of "The Odd Couple II." And "End of Days," dramatically speaking, fell short of apocalyptic. But the Devil must have an awfully good agent: this fall will have no fewer than five movies featuring Old Nick.
"Bedazzled," a remake of the Peter Cook-Dudley Moore classic, stars Brendan Fraser as a nerdy young man who, in exchange for the fulfillment of seven wishes, surrenders his soul to a very seductive Devil played by Elizabeth Hurley. "Little Nicky" is a comedy in which the casting seems half the attraction: Adam Sandler as Satan's good son, Harvey Keitel as Satan and Rodney Dangerfield as Satan's father. In "Lost Souls," a thriller, Winona Ryder plays a devout schoolteacher who becomes aware of a Satanic conspiracy against a New York journalist (like, only one?). "Simon Magus," a British film by Ben Hopkins set in 19th-century Europe, is about a young man seemingly possessed by the Devil (Ian Holm, who, making sure that all his bases are covered in the afterlife, played a Satan-fighting priest in "Bless the Child"). And the granddaddy of them all, "The Exorcist," will be rereleased with additional material never shown before -- perhaps scenes where the poor girl stops spewing pea soup and moves on to beef barley and chicken with stars. Not to give anything short shrift, hovering somewhere in straight-to-videoland is "G-Men From Hell," in which the Devil is portrayed by Robert Goulet.
While this does seem to be an especially verdant crop full of stellar performers, Devil movies have always been with us. A search of the Internet Movie Database (imdb.com), in a highly unofficial but still usefully suggestive count, yields 290 movies about the Devil, starting with Georges Melies's "Cabinet de Mephistopheles," which was made in 1897, but more than half the films have been made since 1980. Among the more provocative items on the list: "Inflation" (1942), in which the Devil, in response to a telephone call from Hitler, begins wrecking the American economy by encouraging people to cash in their war bonds, to hoard and to spend too much money (no doubt an impressionable Alan Greenspan attended repeated showings); "Santa Claus" (1959), in which Santa has to battle Satan's minions before delivering his Christmas Eve rewards; "Satan's Cheerleaders" (1977), in which the members of a high school cheerleading squad turn out to be -- as many have long suspected -- ringleaders of a satanic cult; "Fertilize the Blaspheming Bombshell" (1990), in which a comely lass is menaced by Satan worshipers en route from New York to Las Vegas, and "Girlfriend from Hell" (1990), in which the Devil, fleeing one of God's agents, hides in the body of a young woman on a blind date. Perhaps this is based on a true story.
Although we missed these films, we've seen plenty of others. Some general themes emerge.
 
1. HOLLYWOOD CAN'T AGREE ON WHAT THE DEVIL CAN DO. Moviemakers are pretty consistent about the Devil's being the source of all evil in the world, but there's a range of opinion on other matters, beginning with whether he's the Devil at all. Sometimes the character we see is clearly Satan (Mr. Pacino in "The Devil's Advocate," the Beast in "Rosemary's Baby"), sometimes he is the Devil in human form (Gabriel Byrne in "End of Days"), and sometimes he's the Devil's son (Sam Neill in the "Omen" sequels). Sometimes, for whatever reason, the Devil is more reclusive, and we meet his emissary or servant (Rufus Sewell in "Bless the Child"). Sometimes it's not clear whom we're seeing. Emmanuelle Seigner may be the Devil in "The Ninth Gate," but the whole movie is about how complicated it is to summon the Devil, and she's been hanging around the whole picture. In "Damn Yankees," is Ray Walston the Devil or just his field representative in Washington? And why isn't his office on K Street?
Other questions remain. Sometimes the Devil can be thwarted by faith -- in "The Evil" (1978), when the psychologist played by Richard Crenna uses a crucifix to stab Victor Buono, playing Satan as a grouchy neighbor who won't give back your baseball, it stymies Satan long enough for Mr. Crenna to escape. Rediscovering faith helps Mr. Schwarzenegger thwart the Devil in "End of Days." But they're stars. Faith is fairly useless to secondary characters, like the elderly priest in "The Omen" whose function in the movie is to warn a skeptical Gregory Peck that he really shouldn't be worrying about getting his son into a good prep school, and then to die gruesomely. Sometimes faith has nothing to do with it: in "Crossroads" (1983), the hero's classical-music training enables him to win a blues-guitar showdown and beat the Devil.
There are other discrepancies. Usually the Devil has extraordinary demonic powers. But at other times he seems weaker, resorting to agents -- a dog in "The Omen," street kids in "Bless the Child" -- to wreak havoc. Occasionally he goes to great lengths to avoid suspicion: in "The Omen," he kills a character by causing him to be decapitated by a runaway cart -- nothing a veteran police officer hasn't seen before; in "Bless the Child," the Devil proves as inept as a Bond villain -- instead of just offing Kim Basinger, he tries to kill her by causing her to drive off a bridge, and she gets away. All this is very confusing. Is the Devil who causes a lighting bolt to break a shaft off a church and then sends it ripping through the air to pierce a cleric in "The Omen" the same Devil who relies on sweaty spells, deal-making and the drug-dispensing ministrations of Ruth Gordon just to get a young woman pregnant in "Rosemary's Baby"? Can the Devil who blows up restaurants on a whim in "End of Days" be the same fussy businessman who patiently waits for Mickey Rourke to track down Johnny Favorite in "Angel Heart"? Why does Mr. Pacino's Devil let his minions spend so much time shredding documents to thwart a government investigation if he's perfectly capable, as he demonstrates, of just killing the investigator?
Well, maybe he is -- the big source book is hardly consistent. Professor Elaine Pagels, the Harrington Speare Professor of Religion at Princeton University, points out in her book "The Origin of Satan" that the first few times Satan appears in the Old Testament, he's just a servant of God sent to obstruct human activity -- on God's orders. Gradually, Satan's role evolves. He prods God to test Job; later, Satan is blamed for pushing King David into an unpopular tax plan. Only in Isaiah do we finally get the 411 about the rebellion of the angels who sought to elevate themselves above God. And in the New Testament, Jesus arrives to redeem the world from Satan, who aims to stop him. In the first gospels, Satan tempts Jesus personally; in the last gospel, Jesus is tempted by people. If the Bible isn't consistent about what the Devil does, how can we expect Hollywood to be?
 
2. THE DEVIL IS CURIOUSLY ENCUMBERED BY RULES, BOUNDARIES, BUREAUCRACY. In "The Evil," he is stuck in the basement of an old, spooky house and would never get out without the help of some well-meaning social workers (secular humanists!) who move in. In "The Ninth Gate," Satan can be summoned only with secret incantations recited in the right order -- placing the film at odds with all the movies in which he roams around at will. In "End of Days," Satan has to assume human form, and impregnate a certain woman by a certain date to establish his realm; he may be the Prince of Darkness, but punctuality counts. In "Crossroads," a blues singer signs his soul away on paper. In "Damn Yankees," the contract has an escape clause. In "Angel Heart," all the Devil wants is the soul he was promised. Maybe one day we'll get an Arthur Miller version, Satan Loman, his feet aching, wearily pushing his temptations on an inattentive world.
 
3. IT DOESN'T PAY TO WORK FOR THE DEVIL. Although the Devil seems to have cast a kindly glance at the old folks who served him in "Rosemary's Baby," elsewhere he is literally the Boss From Hell. In "Omen III," "Angel Heart" and "The Devil's Advocate," useful, loyal retainers are crisply eliminated the moment they cause Satan any trouble. In "Damn Yankees," when his assistant, Lola, gets too sweet on her intended victim, the Devil makes her ugly. When you go to work for the Devil, think in terms of immediate payoffs; his pension plan is weak.
 
4. THE DEVIL IS ALWAYS PUTTING CHILDREN FIRST. A surprisingly large number of movies have to do with Satan's wanting to be a father. Obviously, there's "Rosemary's Baby." But "The Omen" is about the Devil's son, "End of Days" about the Devil wanting to sire a son, and "The Devil's Advocate" about Satan wanting his son to sire a son. You can't really say that "The Witches of Eastwick" is about the Devil's wanting to sire a son, but in the end he winds up with three. "Little Nicky," clearly, is going to fall somewhere in this tradition. Also clearly, these plot lines are a reaction to the story of Jesus, the Son of God. But the impulse isn't the same: Jesus comes to redeem humanity by his death, a sacrifice no son of Satan is being asked to make. Why does Satan need an heir? Is he going somewhere? Does he have expansion plans? Who's going to mentor the kid? And if he spends his apprenticeship drinking, taking drugs and chasing women, doesn't that constitute learning the business?
 
5. EVERYBODY LIKES TO PLAY VILLAINS. Jesus has been played by Max von Sydow, Jeffrey Hunter and Willem Dafoe. But look who has played the Devil: Mr. Pacino, Jack Nicholson, Robert De Niro, George C. Scott, Billy Crystal, Claude Rains, Donald Pleasence, Sam Neill, Vincent Price, Terence Stamp and Mickey Rooney. That's a lot of awardware on hell's mantelpiece.
 
6. IT'S HARD TO BE TEMPTING. Devils in the movies generally come in two forms: destroyers and tempters. The destroyers are fairly easy to place -- you just have to be bad. It's harder to be the tempter -- for the scene to work, Satan really has to be persuasive. You can see how hard it is in last year's mini-series "Jesus," in which Jeroen Krabbe, a capable actor, had to persuade Jesus to renounce his mission. Mr. Krabbe was about as convincing as a car dealer; far better at the art of closing are Mr. Nicholson and Mr. Pacino. In "Eastwick," Mr. Nicholson's Devil plays on each woman's vulnerability, teasing out her small resentments and places of self-pity to bring her along. In "The Devil's Advocate," Mr. Pacino goes one better: he actively encourages the Keanu Reeves character to do the right thing, knowing that he has so cleverly stacked the deck that Mr. Reeves will reject the virtuous alternative. In the end, he still overplays his hand, and Mr. Reeves thwarts him by killing himself -- which seems to be the method of choice for thwarting the Devil (see Mr. Schwarzenegger in "End of Days" and Jason Miller in "The Exorcist").
But surely these are only temporary setbacks. That's the thing about the Devil -- he's always practicing.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 32; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 4697 words

HEADLINE: THE ANNOTATED LIST;
Ken Burns, Napoleon and Plenty of Pseudo 'Sex'

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:

September
 
"ON OUR OWN TERMS: MOYERS ON DYING" Not a title calculated to drive ratings, that's for sure. Four 90-minute reports on end-of-life journeys, with those on the road as well as their loved ones and caregivers. PBS, starting tonight at 9. A related article is on Page 27. 

"GIRLFRIENDS" A series whose name may be the most-used word in comedies with mainly black casts. It's built on the relationships among four young black women -- and yes, that is the same number as "Sex and the City." UPN, Mondays at 9:30, starting this week.
 
* "ONE DAY IN SEPTEMBER" The Oscar-winning documentary about the attack on Israeli athletes at the 1972 Munich Olympics comes to television. It covers the events from the hostage-taking through the futile negotiations to the violent conclusion. It includes an interview with the only surviving Arab terrorist, Jamal al-Gashey, who has been in hiding for 28 years. HBO, tomorrow night at 8.
 
* "TWO-MINUTE DRILL" What does Michael Davies, the production mastermind behind "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire," do for an encore? He does a sports quiz show, with Kenny Mayne as host and with three contestants showing off their arcane knowledge in an effort to win cash prizes that escalate -- but slowly. And only up to $200,000, not a million. As a producer put it: "Hey, we're cable." Then again, how much should you get for knowing things like who has the Kansas City Royals' season record for home runs? (O.K., I know, it's Steve Balboni, 36.) ESPN, Mondays at 7, starting this week.
 
"THE ELIAN GONZALEZ STORY" And the winner in the latest rush to make a ripped-from-the-headlines movie is: Fox Family Channel, which beat out CBS, whose movie of the same title is not yet scheduled. Here a child actor named Alec Roberts plays Elian, with Esai Morales as his father and Laura Elena Harring as Marisleysis Gonzalez. The events should be rather familiar. Fox Family, next Sunday at 8.
 
"FEAR" "Blair Witch" meets "Survivor." Young contestants compete to survive in a setting with a horrifying background while they are constantly harassed and scared out of their wits. They all have cameras attached to their vests. MTV, Sept. 21 at 10.
 
"DIRECT EFFECT" An effort to link online fascination with video fascination: viewers vote online for the next video they want to see, mixed in with the usual guests and live performances. It sounds a bit like Total Online Request Live. The host is the one-named Teck, of "Real World" fame. MTV, starting Sept. 25 at 5:30.
 
* "AMERICAN MASTERS: CLINT EASTWOOD" One of the most reliably fascinating PBS series takes a look at the now esteemed actor and director as he hits 70. PBS, Sept. 27 at 8.
 
October
 
"JACKASS" An off-beat show with silly pranks and antics performed by Johnny Knoxville, exploring the underground world of skateboarders. MTV, starting Oct. 1 at 9.
 
"THE NEXT BIG THING" Dean Olsher, host of this weekly one-hour radio variety show, wants it to be "a show about anything." Planned segments range from an accordion lesson delivered in French to a matchmaker's interrogation of a septuagenarian reporter. WNYC (93.9), starting Oct. 1 at 11 a.m.
 
"DEADLINE" Nobody in television makes better crime dramas than Dick Wolf of "Law and Order," but here he is trying a hybrid: crime and journalism. Oliver Platt plays a famous of-the-street columnist for a New York tabloid; he also teaches journalism, and he and his team of young students investigate crimes on the side. The cast includes such familiar names as Bebe Neuwirth, Lili Taylor and Tom Conti. NBC, Mondays at 9, starting Oct 2.
 
* "FRONTLINE: THE CHOICE" In what is now something of a tradition, the documentary series takes a close look at the men running for president. Reported by Peter Boyer, the program promises to avoid pundits and stick to friends, mentors and historians. PBS, Oct. 2 at 9.
 
"TUCKER" In television, no good show goes unparroted. In this case, "Malcolm in the Middle" seems the obvious inspiration, though this is clearly a less-inspired version. A teenage boy finds his life in disarray after his parents' divorce, and he and his mother are forced to move in with his strident aunt and her slug of a son. Katey Sagal ("Married With Children") is the aunt, while Eli Marienthal ("American Pie") plays Tucker. NBC, Mondays at 8:30, starting Oct. 2.
 
"YES, DEAR" A comedy less notable for its premise -- two couples who are close friends differ about approaches to being parents -- than its cast, which features not one, but two former stars of famously failed "must see" Thursday-night comedies on NBC: Mike O'Malley of "The Mike O'Malley Show" and Anthony Clark of "Boston Common." CBS, Mondays at 8:30, starting Oct. 2.
 
"BUILDING BIG" A five-hour look at some of the most spectacular structures in the world, including the Channel tunnel, the Golden Gate Bridge and the Toronto Skydome. The host is the author and illustrator David Macaulay ("The Way Things Work"). PBS, starting Oct. 3 at 8.
 
* "DARK ANGEL" This is the first creative work undertaken by James Cameron since "Titanic," and while not quite as ambitious, it is a highly polished piece of science fiction entertainment with a young star, Jessica Alba ("Can't Hardly Wait"), who commands the screen. She plays a superwoman type who has escaped a genetic experiment in a post-apocalyptic future, when the world's economic system has collapsed, and teams with a streaming-video journalist to expose the bad guys. Among her other amazing talents, Ms. Alba manages to support lips that look like they're been stung by a whole hive of bees. Fox, Tuesdays at 9, starting Oct. 3.
 
"THE GEENA DAVIS SHOW" Truly a star vehicle, this show wants to be "Sex and the City" crossed with a family comedy, a tall order. But then Geena Davis is a really tall actress. She plays a Manhattan career woman who marries a divorced guy (Peter Horton of "Thirtysomething") with kids, making her an instant mom. It's a well-positioned show that will do well if it's well executed. ABC, Tuesdays at 9:30, starting Oct. 3.
 
* "GIDEON'S CROSSING" The season's most serious drama, with the estimable Andre Braugher of "Homicide" moving into medicine at a teaching hospital that takes on desperate cases. It's heavy going, especially with many patients facing terminal illnesses, but Mr. Braugher has big acting shoulders. Reuben Blades co-stars. ABC, Wednesdays at 10, starting Oct. 4.
 
"TITANS" The season's standout in terms of sheer silliness, the latest soap opera from Aaron Spelling seems unsure itself whether its hilarious hokiness is intentional. It's about the usual stuff: the members of a rich, venal family scheme to ruin one another, mainly through sex. Yasmine Bleeth has the juicy vixen role, though her supposedly venomous lines draw mostly laughs. But Mr. Spelling has mined this territory successfully before. Victoria Principal of "Dallas" makes a comeback as an older-generation vixen. NBC, Wednesdays at 8, starting Oct. 4.
 
"GILMORE GIRLS" A gentle, quirky multigenerational drama with a light touch about a mother and her daughter in a Connecticut town. Lauren Graham stars as the mom, with Alexis Blendel as the other Gilmore girl. WB, Thursdays at 8, starting Oct. 5.
 
"C.S.I." A crime drama with a heavy emphasis on forensic science, this hour has a number of things going for it, including a reasonably intelligent approach and a cast headed by Marg Helgenberger ("China Beach") and William Petersen ("The Rat Pack"). The producer is Jerry Bruckheimer, who usually blows things up in the movies. CBS, Fridays at 9, starting Oct. 6.
 
"FREAKYLINKS" Inevitably, we have a show about a Web site. This one has ties to the makers of "The Blair Witch Project" and tries to make a similarly scary name for itself. A team of young hunters of the paranormal traces strange links to the death of a team member's brother. There is, of course, a real Web site to feed the hoped-for frenzy of interest. Fox, Fridays at 9, starting Oct. 6.
 
"THE FUGITIVE" What's it been? Forty years? It's actually been 37 since the original series made its debut, and it's already been updated once as a movie, but the old chase is back. Dr. Richard Kimble, convicted of murdering his wife, runs from Lieutenant Gerard, while simultaneously seeking the one-armed man who did the deed. Tim Daly gets the David Janssen/Harrison Ford part, with Mykelti Williamson stepping in for Barry Morse/Tommy Lee Jones. In case anybody's still wondering, Dr. Kimble didn't do it. CBS, Fridays at 8, starting Oct. 6.
 
"MADIGAN MEN" Another show with roots in "Sex and the City." This one would like to take a look at the male side, as long as that means men with Irish roots who share a Manhattan apartment and spout cute Irish aphorisms. Gabriel Byrne, a true potential television star, is the newly single man with a teenage son and a dad from the old sod, played by Roy Dotrice, who also played opposite Mr. Byrne on Broadway in "Moon for the Misbegotten." ABC, Fridays at 9:30, starting Oct. 6.
 
"THE TROUBLE WITH NORMAL" What does that title mean? No, there is no character named Normal; instead, there are two paranoid characters who think their neighbor is spying on them. Jon Cryer, who has had numerous shots in television comedies in the past, plays the neighbor who is equally paranoid and actually is spying on them. They all go to a therapist. Many people have paranoid tendencies, which perhaps sets up a sizable audience, but do people who are paranoid find paranoia funny? ABC, Fridays at 8:30, starting Oct. 6.
 
"THE DISTRICT" A crime drama that aims to be edgy, but may be asking for trouble: a white police chief, played by Craig T. Nelson, moves to Washington to clean up a town where black leaders have failed. Some genuinely gripping moments could get lost in the potential controversy. CBS, Saturdays at 10, starting Oct. 7.
 
"STAGE ON SCREEN: THE MAN WHO CAME TO DINNER" A live performance of the current Broadway production of the Kaufman and Hart play, with Nathan Lane and Jean Smart. PBS, Oct. 7 at 8.
 
"THAT'S LIFE" Another show looking to duplicate the "you can go home again" premise of "Providence," this quirky-funny hour has some nice character work from Heather Paige Kent ("Stark Raving Mad") as a woman in her 30's who dumps her fiance and goes back to college, and from Paul Sorvino and Ellen Burstyn as her parents. CBS, Saturdays at 8, starting Oct. 7.
 
* "ED" The one new NBC series that seems to be getting an affectionate response, this gentle, likable hourlong comedy is not big on laughs but it works because of its sweet characters. Tom Cavanaugh ("Providence") reacts to the misfortune of losing his job and his wife (to the mailman) in the same day by fleeing to his hometown, a recurring theme this season. There he essentially resurrects his adolescence, reuniting with high school friends and even chasing the unattainable girl from those years. To accomplish that, he buys a local bowling alley, where he also dispenses legal advice. Even though it's from two of David Letterman's longtime writers, Rob Burnett and John Beckerman, it's a show that could give warm and fuzzy a good name. NBC, Sundays at 8, starting Oct. 8.
 
"HYPE" A cast of newcomers tries to bring the sketch comedy formula up to date in a weekly series of fast-paced parodies of youth-oriented movies and music. WB, still sticking to the recipe that built the Fox network, tries to re-create the magic of "In Living Color." WB, Sundays at 9, starting Oct. 8.
 
"NIKKI" Looking for new venues and new characters, Bruce Helford, the creator of "The Drew Carey Show," goes all the way to Las Vegas to build a comedy around a dancer on the Strip, played by Nikki Cox of "Norm," who is married to a big lug who wants to be a wrestler. WB, Sundays at 9:30, starting Oct 8.
 
"OLIVER TWIST" The big "Masterpiece Theater" effort of the season, a three-part adaptation of the Dickens book with Robert Lindsay, Julie Walters and Michael Kitchen. PBS, starting Oct. 8 at 9.
 
* "BETTE" The most anticipated new comedy of the season, with Bette Midler playing a version of herself, in the throwback style of "Burns and Allen" or "The Jack Benny Program." Actors play the other members of her family, as well as her manager and accompanist, but the show is all about Ms. Midler, with a lot of her brand of broad comedy mixed with regular bursts of music. That has always been a winning formula for her, and it should be here, too. CBS, Wednesdays at 8, starting Oct. 11.
 
* "WELCOME TO NEW YORK" A comedy with most of the conventions intact -- a fish out of water shines in a new work environment -- but in this case the writing makes it exceed the preconceptions. Jim Gaffigan plays an Indiana guy brought in to be a weather reporter for a television show in New York by the brassy producer, played by Christine Baranski. Watch for an unusual clash between Mr. Gaffigan's character and the entrenched anchorman, played by Rocky Carroll. CBS, Wednesday at 8:30 starting Oct. 11.
 
"CURSED" For how many years now has NBC tried to make comedies hits by slotting them in the ideal location, Thursdays at 9? So many that the title of this one seems all too apt. Steven Weber ("Wings") plays a man whose comfortable life falls apart after a bad date, when the woman puts a curse on him. Yeah, and then what happens? That's the part that nobody seems to know. NBC, Thursdays at 9:30, starting Oct. 12.
 
* "CURB YOUR ENTHUSIASM" One of the wildest and most promising new series of the season. It is the creation of Larry David, the comic mind behind many of the greatest episodes of "Seinfeld," and is improvised from basic story lines. Mr. David plays himself as a stand-up comic surrounded by dysfunctional, loony friends. It sounds like "Seinfeld," but it's much different -- after all, it's on cable. HBO, starting Oct. 15.
 
"AMERICAN EXPERIENCE: THE ROCKEFELLERS" A two-part biography of the rich American family, from the early days of Standard Oil to the current generation. From producers who previously chronicled the Kennedy family and Ronald Reagan. PBS, starting Oct. 16 at 9.
 
"SPIDERGAMES" The first original daytime soap opera on cable, about a family investigating the murder of the most hated man in town. Everyone is a suspect and an heir to his video-game empire. MTV, starting Oct. 16 at 4:30, repeating at 11 p.m.
 
"THE FEARING MIND" Here's the concept: Stephen King and his New England family in a sitcom. A horror novelist named Bill Fearing has real-life horrors, including a mother-in-law who said she had one month to live five years ago -- and other wacky stuff like that. The British actor Harry Van Gorkum, whose name sounds like a Stephen King character, stars, with Susan Gibney. Fox Family, starting Oct. 20 at 9.
 
"BOSTON PUBLIC" A drama about life in a high school would not sound too promising if it were not coming from David E. Kelley, who has made "Ally McBeal" and "The Practice" into two of the best series of the last five years. Here the challenge is making daily high school life dramatic and funny, and it's a bit of a stretch. A plot in which a teacher fired a gun in a classroom drew instant protest, and Mr. Kelly promised changes. As usual, his writing is of a high quality and so is much of the acting, led by Chi McBride as an intense principal. Fox, Mondays at 8, starting Oct. 23.
 
* "HATE.COM: EXTREMISTS ON THE INTERNET" A documentary about how hatemongers have used the Web to find new recruits, spread their messages and in some instances even set up hate crimes. HBO, Oct. 23 at 8.
 
"THE MICHAEL RICHARDS SHOW" Here is NBC's great comedy hope, the first new series starring a "Seinfeld" grad. And what's happened? It has been one stumble after another, not unlike the ones that used to afflict Kramer. Except that those were funny. The original pilot was totally scrapped. No one knows much about the new one except that Mr. Richards is still playing a bumbling detective. He does have co-stars now, including Tim Meadows ("Saturday Night Live") and William Devane ("The Hollow Man"). NBC, Tuesdays at 8, starting Oct. 24.
 
"FREEDOM" More apocalypse mongering from the producer Joel Silver, who hit it big with "The Matrix." Much about this one is "Matrix"-like, including the premise of a resistance unit fighting an evil military elite that has taken over humanity. UPN, Fridays at 8, starting Oct. 27.
 
"LEVEL NINE" Crime fighting goes totally cyber in this hour about a secret group created to fight Internet villains, like hackers who blackmail airlines by threatening to crash airplanes. Created by John Sacret Young ("China Beach"). UPN, Fridays at 9, starting Oct. 27.
 
"FALLING IN LOVE AGAIN" Valerie Bertinelli, who was once in every other TV movie, returns to play a romantic role in another generation: now she's the mom with the teenage children. The kids plot to bring Valerie and Jeffrey Nadling, who plays the dad, back together in a story that is set on a tourist ranch in the wilds of Alaska. CBS in October.
 
"SECOND HONEYMOON" Roma Downey and Tim Matheson star in another movie about a couple that just can't seem to break up. Here the soon-to-be-divorced pair get a surprise 20th-anniversary gift from the family: a tropical vacation. It works wonders. CBS in October.
 
November
 
"NORMAL, OHIO" A troubled comedy that still has a great asset, John Goodman, as star. Mr. Goodman plays a father who happens to be gay; he moves back to his hometown and comedy is meant to ensue. But this is an all-new premise -- a first pilot was totally remade -- so the result is harder to predict than usual. Fox, Wednesdays at 8, starting Nov. 1.
 
* "THE STREET" The true heir to "Sex and the City," because it comes from the same creator, Darren Star. This hour is full of similar steamy touches as it traces the overheated lives, both professional and social, of a group of young Wall Street brokers who are on the make -- in more ways than one. The clothes, the music and the moves are all designed to reveal the male side of the sexual play featured in Mr. Star's HBO hit. Adam Goldberg ("Saving Private Ryan") and Tom Everett Scott ("That Thing You Do") are among the big, talented, attractive cast. Fox, Wednesdays at 9, starting Nov. 1.
 
"TIME TO CHOOSE: AN NPR/PBS VOTER'S GUIDE" National Public Radio and PBS collaborate on a live three-hour broadcast just before election day. Jim Lehrer will be the anchor in Washington, with correspondents from both organizations posted in Atlanta, Chicago, San Francisco and New York interviewing voters, campaign advisers and journalists. NPR and PBS, Nov. 1 at 8 p.m.
 
"STUDIO 360" A weekly one-hour show covering culture, high and low, produced by WNYC and slated for national distribution through Public Radio International beginning in February. Kurt Anderson, the novelist, journalist and co-founder of Inside.com, will be host of a program offering stories and conversation about the world of art, from opera to comic books. WYNC-FM (93.9), starting Nov. 4.
 
"JACQUELINE BOUVIER KENNEDY ONASSIS" Yet another Kennedy family mini-series, of which so many already exist that they could fill their own cable channel. This one promises the whole story of Jackie, in four hours, based on the biography by Donald Spoto. Joanna Whalley, who has one other high-profile television role on her resume ("Scarlett"), here will try to impersonate perhaps the most famous woman of the 20th century. CBS, starting Nov. 5 at 9.
 
* "NAPOLEON" A four-hour documentary biography of the French general and emperor, directed by David Grubin, whose previous films for PBS include "F.D.R.," "L.B.J." and "Truman" in the "American Experience" series. PBS, Nov. 8 and Nov. 15, at 9.
 
"NPR CELEBRATES AARON COPLAND" Marking the 100th anniversary of the composer's birth, National Public Radio will present a series of Copland concerts, talks and documentaries. The centerpiece is a live broadcast and cyber-cast from Coolidge Auditorium at the Library of Congress, where Copland's "Appalachian Spring" was first performed. NPR, starting Nov. 13.
 
* "AMERICAN TRAGEDY: THE UNCENSORED STORY OF THE SIMPSON DEFENSE" Destined to be one of the most talked-about projects of the season, for better or worse, this adaptation of the Lawrence Schiller book has already been threatened with an injunction by new lawyers for O. J. Simpson. It is an account of his defense strategy and the cast of characters includes those familiar names Johnnie Cochran (Ving Rhames), Robert Shapiro (Ron Silver), F. Lee Bailey (Christopher Plummer) and Barry Scheck (Bruno Kirby). Told over four hours -- if no restraining order is issued -- by a production team led by Barry Levinson and Tom Fontana. CBS, Nov. 12 and Nov. 15 at 9.
 
* "AMERICAN EXPERIENCE: RETURN WITH HONOR"A two-and-a-half-hour account of the sufferings and ultimate victories of a group of American airmen shot down in Vietnam and subjected to years of torture before their release. It includes film from the Vietnamese government archives. Introduced by Tom Hanks. PBS, Nov. 13 at 9.
 
"DAG" David Alan Grier is a talented, funny guy, but this is his third try at sitcom success and it's not the charm. Here he plays a bumbling Secret Service agent banished to cover the president's wife (Delta Burke, who may look too much like a certain young lady in a beret for some people's comfort). The idea is to make the comedy extremely broad, but that will require generating a lot more laughs than the pilot did. NBC, Tuesdays at 9:30, starting Nov. 14.
 
"NOVA: HITLER'S LOST SUB" About the 1991 discovery of a sunken World War II U-boat, found only 60 miles off the coast of New Jersey, with its unexploded torpedoes and the bodies of its crew still aboard. The documentary follows the efforts of the diver John Chatterton and his crew to identify and explore the boat, a quest that cost three more lives. PBS, Nov. 14 at 8.
 
"LOOKING FOR LOST BIRD" A story of a woman, adopted as an infant, who searches for her biological parents, discovers they were Navajo and seeks to learn of their culture. Mercedes Ruehl is the star, with Jamey Sheridan as her husband. CBS, Nov. 19 at 9.
 
"THE MOVING OF SOPHIA MYLES" Della Reese of "Touched by an Angel" plays yet another heartwarming role: the widow of a cherished pastor who duels with an evil real estate maven played by Rue McLanahan. CBS, Nov. 26 at 9.
 
"FOR LOVE OR COUNTRY: THE ARTURO SANDOVAL STORY" The story of the brilliant Cuban trumpet player Arturo Sandoval, who refused to defect after the Castro takeover because of his love for a woman, but later did so, with the help of Dizzy Gillespie. Andy Garcia stars in a cast that includes Gloria Estefan and Charles S. Dutton. HBO in November.
 
"GROWING PAINS: THE REUNION"At first glance this seems like a project conjured up solely to get Leonardo DiCaprio into a television movie. But he didn't show up for this reunion, of course, so fans of the series will have to satisfied with Alan Thicke, who did. ABC in November.
 
"IN THE BEGINNING" Religious stories have been unexpected hits in recent years, so why not go right to basics. It's the familar roster, including Adam and Eve, Abraham, Isaac, Joseph and Moses, with a lot of special effects to enhance the telling. Among the interesting casting choices: Martin Landau as Abraham, and Billy Campbell of "Once and Again" as Moses. NBC in November.
 
"IN HIS LIFE: THE JOHN LENNON STORY" A lot of Lennon's early professional life was covered in the feature film "Backbeat," and that R-rated material seems unlikely for a network television movie. This one includes a bit of his troubled childhood, but shifts quickly to his efforts to form a skiffle band, his meeting with a mate named Paul, and so on. NBC in November.
 
"THE MIRACLE WORKER" Yet another version of the famous play, which has already been a television special and a movie. Now it's back to television, almost solely as a vehicle for Hallie Kate Eisenberg, who in her ubiquitous Pepsi commercials has not demonstrated quite the acting depth that this part has pulled out of the likes of Patti Duke. ABC in November.
 
"UNFORGETTABLE: THE NATALIE COLE STORY" A television movie biography of the singer, who endured several rises and falls before her hit "duet" with her dead father. NBC in November.
 
"WIDOWS" Three women with extremely different backgrounds come together after their husbands are killed trying to pull off an art heist. Over four hours, on two days, they team up to search out the killer. Mercedes Ruehl is the middle-class housewife, Brooke Shields is the low-rent actress and Rosie Perez is the used-car saleswoman. Lynda LaPlante, the creator of the great "Prime Suspect" series, also created the original of this story, which was a hit in England. ABC in November.
 
December
 
"THE CHRIS ISAAK SHOW" The singer-songwriter plays himself in a semi-fictional story about a lead singer for a band who is very much like Chris Isaak. The musicians are real; many of the backup characters are not. The show has as much music as comedy. Showtime, starting in December.
 
* "QUEER AS FOLK" In Britain, this brutally frank drama about gay life was a sensation. Rather than simply import it, Showtime decided to make an American version. Pittsburgh steps in to approximate blue-collar Manchester, and Hal Sparks, who was once the host of "Talk Soup," stars as Michael, who is secretly in love with his childhood friend, a drug-addled advertising executive. The show is steeped in character complications, some comedic, some heart-tugging, all fiercely realistic. Showtime, starting in December.
 
"SANTA WHO?" The old guy crashes in New York, of all places, days before Christmas and suffers amnesia. Panicked elves have to hunt him down. Santa falls in with a Christmas-hating reporter and, of course, he lands a job as a department store St. Nick. Will Santa recover his memory in time to save Christmas? Leslie Nielsen, who already has the hair, if not the girth, stars with Tommy Davidson of "Booty Call." ABC in December.
 
January
 
*"JAZZ"Potentially the outstanding program of the television season, the latest series from the much-decorated historical documentarian Ken Burns examines the roots, glories and influences of the one true American art form, with an emphasis on the role of race, in 10 parts over 19 hours. PBS, starting Jan. 23.
 
"BREAKING NEWS" ABC tried to turn sports news into comedy with "Sports Night." This effort turns to real news in a series about a 24-hour news channel where the cranky reporters never go to sleep. It stars Tim Matheson and Rowena King. TNT, starting in January.
 
"NERO WOLFE" The rotund, brilliant detective who never leaves his New York townhouse comes to television, a long while after he became famous as a descendant of Sherlock Holmes. Rex Stout created the character and gave him lots of odd puzzles that he and his legman partner, Archie Goodwin, could solve. Last season's television movie inspired this series, which A&E hopes will snatch up the crowd that loved its Poirot adventures. Maury Chaykin is the portly, orchid-loving Wolfe, with Timothy Hutton doing the hard labor as Archie. Mr. Hutton also did the hard labor of writing and directing. A&E, starting in January.
 
"OZ" A special mid-season edition of the summer hit, serving as the sub for "The Sopranos," which put its third-season premiere off until March. So Tom Fontana stepped in with eight new episodes of his riveting, often brutal prison series. HBO, Sundays at 9, starting in January.
 
March
 
"101 CENTRE STREET" A New York night court is the focus of this series created by the film director Sidney Lumet. The show will be fictional, but Mr. Lumet will try to make it look real by shooting entirely with handheld video cameras. A&E, starting in March.
 
Compiled with the assistance of Anna Bahney.
