The New York Times

 

PUB-DATE: September 10, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 13; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 7140 words

HEADLINE: THE ANNOTATED LIST;
Puppets, the Trojan War And Tallulah Times Three

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER

 BODY:

September
 
"LYPSINKA! THE BOXED SET" Camp and vamp. A show by the lip-synching drag-queen diva John Epperson. Opens tonight. Westbeth Theater. (SmartTix)
 
"HUNCHBACK" The Redmoon Theater of Chicago renders the Victor Hugo classic "The Hunchback of Notre Dame" as a symphony of puppets, masks and costumes. Part of the Henson International Festival of Puppet Theater. Tuesday through next Sunday. Joseph Papp Public Theater/Newman Theater. (Ticket Central) www.hensonfestival.org 

"NIGHT BEHIND THE WINDOWS" A media mix of film, music and puppetry, this eerily atmospheric show by the performance artist Janie Geiser deals, in an elliptical narrative, with the death of a mysterious woman. Is there a limbo between life and afterlife? Part of the Henson International Festival of Puppet Theater. Tuesday through next Sunday. La Mama Experimental Theater Club.
www.hensonfestival.org
 
"DEAD END" "A medium for social betterment that is tremendous and forceful." So raved the noted theater critic Mayor Fiorello La Guardia of New York City in 1935, after seeing the Broadway production of Sidney Kingsley's cautionary tale about the lure of a life of crime, set among teenagers in Depression-era Lower Manhattan. The film starred Humphrey Bogart as the not-to-be-emulated thug. Here he is played by Dominic Fumusa, best known, perhaps, as a pal of the Sopranos. Nicholas Martin directs in his inaugural offering as artistic director of the Huntington Theater in Boston. In previews. Opens Wednesday. (617-266-0800) www.bu.edu/HUNTINGTON
 
"THE BEST MAN" An election-year revival of an election-year (1960) play about an election, it could only be a comic melodrama or risk its credibility. The making of the president, as envisioned by Gore Vidal. A starry cast that includes Charles Durning, Spalding Gray, Chris Noth, Elizabeth Ashley, Christine Ebersole and Michael Learned. Directed by Ethan McSweeny. In previews. Opens next Sunday. Virginia Theater. (Tele-Charge).
 
"THE SYRINGA TREE" A one-woman show by Pamela Gien, who plays 28 characters in a story about a mixed-race household in South Africa under apartheid. In previews. Opens Thursday. Playhouse 91. (Ticketmaster).
 
"A LESSON BEFORE DYING" An adaptation, by Romulus Linney, of the Ernest J. Gaines novel set in Louisiana in the 1940's about the friendship between a man unjustly condemned to die and the schoolteacher who helps him face his fate. Directed by Kent Thompson and featuring Stephen Bradbury, Isaiah Whitlock Jr. and John Henry Redwood. This is the first production of the Signature Theater Company's two-year series of new plays by playwrights to whose work the company has, in the past, devoted whole seasons. In previews. Opens Sept. 17. Peter Norton Space. (244-7529) www.signaturetheatre.org
 
"FOUR GUYS NAMED JOSE . . . AND UNA MUJER NAMED MARIA" Four men -- a Mexican, a Dominican, a Puerto Rican and a Cuban -- try to impress a woman with their renditions of Latin American pop classics, in the process sending up Hispanic stereotypes. A high-energy musical revue, produced by Enrique Iglesias and Dasha Epstein. With Philip Anthony, Henry Gainza, Lissette Gonzalez, Allen Hidalgo and Ricardo Puente. In previews. Opens Sept. 18. Blue Angel Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"STOWAWAYS" A performance piece by France's Compagnie Philippe Genty, combining dance and puppetry to create surrealistic stage images. Part of the Henson International Festival of Puppet Theater. Sept. 19-24. Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Ave. (Ticket Central)
 
 "THE BUTTERFLY COLLECTION" Brian Murray is a blocked novelist and Marian Seldes his wife in this drama by Theresa Rebeck about a family in crisis and the young woman, the novelist's new assistant, who is in the middle of it. (The two stars, by the way, will be paired again later in the season in Edward Albee's "Play About the Baby.") Directed by Bartlett Sher ("Waste"). In previews. Opens Oct. 3. Playwrights Horizons.
 
"LIFEGAME" Shy? Keep your head down and your mouth shut or you might end up watching your life unfold in front of strangers. Semi-improvisational theater from an accomplished British troupe, the Improbable Theater; each performance is based on the life story of an audience member. Actually, there's nothing to worry about; the subjects are preselected, and willing. Previews begin Tuesday. Opens Sept. 28. Jane Street Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"WHERE DID VINCENT VAN GOGH?" Let's hope the lines are cleverer than the title. A one-man show about an actor, his character (the famous painter) and a space alien, written and performed by Homer Simpson, er, Dan Castellaneta. Previews begin Wednesday. Opens Sept. 20. Chelsea Playhouse. (Ticket Central)
 
"THE BALLAD OF LITTLE JO" Mike Reid, who wrote the score for this new musical, may be the only theater composer ever to have played professional football; he was once a lineman for the Cincinnati Bengals. The book, by Sarah Schlesinger, is set in the American West during the California gold rush and concerns a 17-year-old Boston girl banished by her father after she gives birth out of wedlock. Ugly adventures ensue, then redemption. Previews begin Thursday. Opens Sept. 24. Steppenwolf Theater Company, Chicago.
 
"TANTALUS" This is, as the Greeks might warn, hubris. A retelling of the Trojan War written by John Barton and directed by Sir Peter Hall, this collaboration between the Denver Center Theater Company and London's Royal Shakespeare Company is the world premiere of a 10-play cycle, 15 years in development, 10 1/2 hours in performance. Will it launch 1,000 revivals? Previews begin Friday. Opens Oct. 21. Through Dec. 2. Denver Performing Arts Complex. (800-641-1222) www.denvercenter.org
 
"THE IN-GATHERING" The premiere of an Off Broadway musical set in post-Civil War America, about an emancipated slave in search of the wife from whom he was separated when she was sold. The book is by John Henry Redwood ("The Old Settler"), the music by Daryl Waters ("Bring In da Noise, Bring In da Funk"), and the cast will have at least one big voice: that of Anne Duquesnay. Choreographed by Hope Clarke ("Jelly's Last Jam"), who also directs. The inaugural production of a new theater on West 42nd Street. Opens Sept. 19. The Duke on 42nd Street. (Tele-Charge)
 
"TALLULAH HALLELUJAH!" Old divas never die, they reincarnate on the stage. This season features three shows based on the life of Tallulah Bankhead. This one is a solo performance with music, set in 1956 and starring Tovah Feldshuh, who also wrote the script (with Larry Amoros and Linda Selman), which has the stage and film star standing in for Ella Fitzgerald as the headliner of a benefit for the U.S.O. Previews begin Sept. 19. Opens Oct. 10. Douglas Fairbanks Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"THE BUNGLER" An early Moliere comedy, rarely if ever presented in the United States, in a new verse translation by Richard Wilbur. Directed by Doug Hughes. Previews begin Sept. 20. Opens Sept. 27. Long Wharf Theater, New Haven.
 
"THE BEGINNING OF AUGUST" Ah, family. In this new play by Tom Donaghy ("Northeast Local"), a man's wife abruptly departs, leaving him to forge a new home life involving his infant daughter, his stepmother, a house painter and a neighbor. Wouldn't you know it? The wife comes back. Directed by Neil Pepe. With Mary Steenburgen, Mary McCann, Ray Anthony Williams and Garret Dillahunt. Previews begin Sept. 27. Atlantic Theater Company.
 
"STRANGER" In this new play by Craig Lucas ("Prelude to a Kiss"), a man and a woman, one of them a recently released felon, meet on a plane. Starring Kyra Sedgwick and David Strathairn. Directed by Mark Brokaw ("How I Learned to Drive"). Previews begin Sept. 27. Vineyard Theater. (353-0303) www.
vineyardtheatre.org
 
* "THE FULL MONTY" With its setting shifted from Sheffield, England, to Buffalo, N.Y., this musical adaptation of the surprise hit film about unemployed millworkers who decide to strip to make a quick buck lands on Broadway after a sold-out run at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego. Terrence McNally wrote the book, toughening up those sweetheart characters for an American audience; a newcomer, David Yazbek, wrote the score, which has some sock. Jack O'Brien directs. Previews begin Sept. 26. Opens Oct. 26. Eugene O'Neill Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"TEXTS FOR NOTHING" The marvelously serious clown Bill Irwin, directing and performing in a one-man show that is adapted from the prose works of Samuel Beckett. If this sounds familiar, it's because Mr. Irwin first took on the material at the Joseph Papp Public Theater in 1991. Previews begin Sept. 28. Opens Oct. 15. Classic Stage Company.
 
"DOLL" Theater Couture, which specializes in campy and far-fetched send-ups of popular culture (its last production, "Tell-Tale" in 1997, took on Edgar Allan Poe and B-movies), steps a little out of character here with its version of the Ibsen classic "A Doll's House." Starring Sherry Vine (a k a Keith Levy), one assumes, as Nora. Previews begin Sept. 29. Opens. Oct. 5. P.S. 122, 150 First Ave., at 9th Street. (477-5288) www.ps122.org
 
"ARABIAN NIGHTS" An adaptation for children, by London's Young Vic Theater Company, of the legend of Scheherazade, the brave enchantress who distracts a wrathful king with seductive stories. Opens Sept. 29. New Victory Theater, 209 W. 42nd Street. (Through Friday, 563-2266; from Saturday, 382-4020) www.newvictory.org
 
October
 
"THOROUGHLY MODERN MILLIE" A new musical in a pre-Broadway run (well, the producers have their fingers crossed) based on the 1967 film about women in the jazz age. Starring Erin Dilly as Millie (tabloid headline writers: n.b.), Tonya Pinkins and Pat Carroll. Directed by Michael Mayer. With music from the movie and additional songs by Jeanine Tesori. Previews begin Oct. 3. Opens Oct. 15. La Jolla Playhouse, Calif. (858-550-1010) www.lajollaplayhouse.com
 
"THE DINNER PARTY" Neil Simon rides again; his first new play on Broadway since "Laughter on the 23rd Floor" is a six-hander involving marriage and divorce, aging and French food. The cast includes the television veterans John Ritter and Henry Winkler and the Broadway veterans Len Cariou, Veanne Cox, Penny Fuller and Jan Maxwell. Previews begin Oct. 3. Opens Oct. 19. Music Box Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"WAR OF THE WORLDS" The auteur gets the auteur treatment: a stage biography of Orson Welles that examines Welles in the manner in which Welles examined William Randolph Hearst in "Citizen Kane." Conceived and directed by the avant-garde veteran Anne Bogart. Oct. 4-8. Next Wave Festival, Brooklyn Academy of Music.
 
"OEDIPUS REX" Grecophiles, alert! A production of Sophocles' tragedy by the 100-year-old National Theater of Greece, in modern Greek (with English supertitles). Directed by Vassilis Papavasiliou, with Grigoris Valtinos in the title role. This summer the production was presented in the Colosseum in Rome, the first show seen by an audience there in 1,500 years -- no kidding, not since lions were dispatching gladiators and ostensibly vice versa. Performances are Oct. 4-8 at City Center, not so historical but a nice place. (City Tix)
 
"GAME SHOW" Be forewarned: Set during the broadcast of a game show, this play by Jeffrey Finn and Bob Walton uses audience members as contestants. Previews begin Oct. 10. Opens Oct. 25. 45 Bleecker Street. (Ticketmaster)
 
"BIG POTATO" A Third Reich officer is discovered hiding in a Queens beauty parlor; this comedy by Arthur Laurents, produced by the Jewish Repertory Theater, sounds a bit like "Judgment at Nuremberg" meets "All in the Family." Previews begin Oct. 14. Opens Oct. 22. The Duke on 42nd Street. (831-2001)
 
* "THE UNEXPECTED MAN" This one should create ample buzz, particularly for an Off Broadway show. To begin with, Alan Bates is making his first New York stage appearance since he won a Tony Award in Simon Gray's "Butley" almost 30 years ago. Opposite him, no slouch herself, is Eileen Atkins. The two play, respectively, a writer and literary fan who meet on a train. The director is Matthew Warchus, who directed last season's "True West" and the Tony winner of the year before, "Art," by Yasmina Reza, who, not incidentally, is the author of this one as well. Previews begin Oct. 10. Opens Oct. 24. Promenade Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
* "PROOF" The Broadway premiere of last season's Off Broadway hit about mathematics, love and the nature of genius. Written by David Auburn and starring the estimable Mary-Louise Parker as a young woman who seems to know everything except how smart and sexy she is. With Larry Bryggman as her father. Directed by Daniel Sullivan. Chicagoans: note the perfect back-porch set by John Lee Beatty. Previews begin Oct. 10. Opens Oct. 24. Walter Kerr Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"THE TALE OF THE ALLERGIST'S WIFE" Two Broadway transfers in the same week is quite a coup for the Manhattan Theater Club, which last season presented "Proof" and this comedy by Charles Busch about a witty and whiny woman (Linda Lavin) who lives on the West Side and is afraid life is passing her by. Enter her childhood friend. Oy! Also starring Tony Roberts and Michele Lee. Directed by Lynne Meadow. Previews begin Oct. 11. Opens Nov. 2. Ethel Barrymore Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"NOCTURNE" The debut of a highly touted young playwright, Adam Rapp; his play is about a teenager who accidentally kills his sister, and the tragedy's lingering effect on the family. Previews begin Oct. 12. Opens Oct. 15. American Repertory Theater, Cambridge, Mass. (617-547-8300) www.amrep.org
 
"LES MIZRAHI" A new series of cabaret performances presented by the Off Broadway company the Drama Dept. is inaugurated by the fashion designer Isaac Mizrahi, who sings, dances and sews, accompanied by the Ben Waltzer Trio. Mr. Mizrahi, not surprisingly, designed the sets and costumes. Previews begin Oct. 13. Opens Oct. 19. Greenwich House Theater. (Tele-Charge) www.dramadept.com
 
"MATTERS OF THE HEART" An evening with Patti LuPone, accompanied by piano and string quartet. Vivian Beaumont Theater at Lincoln Center. Selected Sundays and Mondays beginning Oct. 15. (Tele-Charge)
 
"SEUSSICAL" Even if you do not like green eggs and ham, you might be curious. David Shiner as the Cat in the Hat -- they have the same neck, after all -- seems reason enough to look forward to this musical adaptation of the work of the famously lyrical children's author a k a Theodor Seuss Geisel. Kevin Chamberlin portrays Horton the Elephant. Directed by Frank Galati, with a score by Stephen Flaherty and Lynn Ahrens, all of whom collaborated on "Ragtime." Choreographed by Kathleen Marshall. Previews begin Oct. 15. Opens Nov. 9. Richard Rodgers Theater. (Ticketmaster) A related article is on Page 4.
 
"FORBIDDEN BROADWAY 2001: A SPOOF ODYSSEY" A new edition of the long-running (18 years!) satire. Opens Oct. 20. Stardust Theater (inside Ellen's Stardust Diner), 1651 Broadway at 51st Street. (Tele-Charge)
 
"MAQUINA HAMLET" Known in English as "Hamlet Machine," this 1997 play was written by the German playwright and director Heiner Muller, who imagined Hamlet witnessing the crumbling of the Berlin Wall. The production, however, is by a Buenos Aires troupe, El Periferico de Objetos, and features photo projections, disembodied voices and puppets -- and echoes of the politics of Argentina. Oct. 18-21. Next Wave Festival. Brooklyn Academy of Music. Harvey Theater.
 
"DAHLING!" Tallulah II. The life and loves of Lady Bankhead as envisioned in a play by Nan Schmid, with 55 characters portrayed by eight actors. Previews begin Oct. 19. Opens Oct. 26. Grove Street Playhouse. (358-5812)
 
"THE ROCKY HORROR SHOW" No dress code. A revival of the campy stage musical that became a cult film classic, it arrives with an intriguing cast -- Joan Jett and Dick Cavett, plus the Broadway veterans Lea DeLaria, Alice Ripley, Jarrod Emick, Daphne Rubin-Vega -- and, one would assume, a core audience of predisposed enthusiasts. Previews begin Oct. 20. Opens Nov. 15. Circle in the Square. (Tele-Charge)
 
"BARRIO BABIES" A musical satire by Luis Santeiro and Fernando Rivas about the stereotyping of Latinos in Hollywood. Previews begin Oct. 21. Opens Nov. 12. John Houseman Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"COMIC POTENTIAL" The American premiere of a show-biz black comedy by Alan Ayckbourn set in a future world where robots and film actors are difficult to tell apart. Previews begin Oct. 24. Opens Nov. 16. Manhattan Theater Club.
 
"ALICE IN BED" Susan Sontag's only play is based on the life of Alice James (sister of the writer Henry and the philosopher William), and has never before been seen in New York. Directed by Ivo van Hove. Previews begin Oct. 25. Opens Nov. 5. New York Theater Workshop.
 
"FAME TAKES A HOLIDAY" A play, with music, about comedians on the verge of fame. Written by Cassandra Danz and Mary Fulham, two members of the troupe High-Heeled Women, whose routines are featured in the show, and Warren Leight, the author of the Tony-winning play "Sideman." With original music by Tracey Berg, Dick Gallagher, Cliff Korman and Marc Shaiman. Opens Oct. 26. La Mama Experimental Theater Club.
 
"TOKYO NOTES" The Seinen-dan Theater Company of Tokyo performs a play by Oriza Hirata about the values of contemporary Japan. Written in 1995, it is set in 2004, during a war in Europe, in the lobby of a Japanese art museum that has been receiving great works from European museums for safekeeping. In Japanese, with English supertitles. Oct. 26-28. Japan Society. 333 E. 47th Street. (752-3015) www.jpnsoc.com
 
"COBB" With the aid of a surprising angel -- Kevin Spacey -- Lee Blessing's estimable stage biography of the legendary ballplayer and misanthrope Ty Cobb, produced last season by Melting Pot Theater, not only got a reprieve from an early closing, it is being reprised Off Broadway. Directed by Joe Brancato. With Michael Cullen, Matthew Mabe, Michael Sabatino and Clark Jackson. Previews begin in late October. Lucille Lortel Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
November
 
"RICHARD III" The resident classical theater company brings Shakespeare's evil hunchback to the East Village. Opens Nov. 2. Pearl Theater Company. (598-9802) www.pearltheatre.org
 
* "THE LATE HENRY MOSS" And now, the award for starriest production of the season: Woody Harrelson, Sean Penn, Nick Nolte, Cheech Marin and James Gammon in a new play about brothers, a larger-than-life father and the mythical American frontier by -- guess who? -- Sam Shepard, who also directs. Previews begin Nov. 7. Opens Nov. 14. Magic Theater, San Francisco. (415-441-8822) www.magictheatre.org
 
"JANE EYRE" Who's that singing in the attic? A musical based on the Charlotte Bronte novel. The music and lyrics are by a pop composer new to the theater, Paul Gordon, but there are some substantial pedigrees involved as well. The book is by John Caird ("Les Miserables"), who directs (with Scott Schwartz), and the set design is by John Napier ("Les Miz," "Cats," "Miss Saigon"). With Marla Schaffel as Jane and James Barbour as Mr. Rochester. Previews begin Nov. 7. Opens Dec. 3. Brooks Atkinson Theater. (Ticketmaster)
 
"REQUIEM FOR SREBRENICA" Conceived by the French director Olivier Py from a compilation of documents and testimony, this theater piece for three women is a response to the July 1995 massacre of thousands of Bosnian Muslims by Serbians engaged in ethnic cleansing. Nov. 8-11. Next Wave Festival. Brooklyn Academy of Music. Harvey Theater.
 
"GOLDEN BOY" A semi-revival, semi-adaptation -- a revisal? -- of the 1964 musical about a Harlem boxer. The composer, Charles Strouse, has written new songs to complement his original score, and the book (originally by Clifford Odets and William Gibson) has been given a contemporary skew by Keith Glover, who directs. Previews begin Nov. 8. Opens Nov. 15. Long Wharf Theater, New Haven.
 
"OLD MONEY" Quite a year for Wendy Wasserstein -- first a new baby, now a new play. The latter is a meditation on the history of manners in 20th-century New York, concerning an elderly historian who attends a party in the East Side mansion where he grew up, now occupied by a hedge fund analyst. But when did she have time to write it? Starring John Cullum. Directed by Mark Brokaw. Previews begin Nov. 9. Opens Dec. 7. Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Lincoln Center.
 
* "ARSENIC AND OLD LACE" Voices!, a new series of one-night-only staged readings of rarely revived plays -- in the manner of the Encores! musical series -- begins on Nov. 11 with Joseph Kesselring's macabre comedy from 1941 about two sweet and murderous old ladies. Alec Baldwin stars as their nephew, the role played by Cary Grant in Frank Capra's 1944 film adaptation. Mr. Baldwin is producing the season of readings, which will include "Little Murders," Jules Feiffer's black comedy (Jan. 30), and "The Devil and Daniel Webster" by Stephen Vincent Benet (March 13). City Center. (City Tix)
 
"THE SEARCH FOR SIGNS OF INTELLIGENT LIFE IN THE UNIVERSE" Fifteen years after their first visit to Broadway, Trudy, the bag lady who talks to space aliens; Agnus Angst, the teenage performance artist; and Chrissy, the eager if misguided human potential devotee, are back in the person of Lily Tomlin. A one-woman show, written and directed by Jane Wagner, that will make early fall stops in Seattle and Princeton, N.J. Previews begin Nov. 11. Opens Nov. 16. Booth Theater. (Tele-Charge)
 
"BOOK OF THE DEAD (SECOND AVENUE)" A performance treatise on spirituality by the music-theater artist John Moran. The title refers to two of the show's settings -- ancient Egypt and modern New York City. Previews begin Nov. 14. Joseph Papp Public Theater, Martinson Hall.
 
"MAMMA MIA!" A huge hit in London and Toronto, this is the first American appearance of the musical about a girl searching for her father on the eve of her wedding, set to the music of the Swedish pop band Abba. Opens Nov. 15. Orpheum Theater, San Francisco. (415-512-7770)
 
"TINY ALICE" Edward Albee's allegorical play about an emissary of the church who is sent to negotiate the terms of a mammoth gift from the world's richest woman. Richard Thomas, as the emissary (in a role first played in 1964 by John Gielgud), teams up once again with the director Mark Lamos; the two joined forces in a Hartford Stage production of the play in 1998. Previews begin Nov. 16. Second Stage.
 
* "JESUS HOPPED THE A TRAIN" A tough and lyrical prison drama by a young writer, Stephen Adly Guirgis. This production, by the tiny Labyrinth Theater Company, had an overflow word-of-mouth crowd for 10 days of workshop performances this summer, and it now has independent backing for a commercial run. Directed by Philip Seymour Hoffman, who gets crackling performances from a cast that includes John Ortiz, Ron Cephas-Jones and Elizabeth Canavan. Previews begin Nov. 21. Opens Nov. 28. At the Classic Stage Company, 136 East 13th Street. Ticket information to be announced.
 
"A DREAM PLAY" The theatrical surrealist Robert Wilson turns to August Strindberg's complex and mystical work from 1901, which traces the education of a Hindu goddess about human life on earth. Nov. 28-Dec. 3. Next Wave Festival. Brooklyn Academy of Music. Howard Gilman Opera House.
 
"BETRAYAL" What sounds like a sexy revival of Harold Pinter's backwards-in-time-moving drama about the disintegration of a marriage. Starring Liev Schreiber, Juliette Binoche and John Slattery. Directed by David Leveaux. Opening date to be announced. Roundabout Theater Company. American Airlines Theater. (719-1300) www.
roundabouttheatre.org
 
"THE PLAY ABOUT THE BABY" Edward Albee's most recent work concerns two couples, an older and a younger, and an infant who may or may not exist. Sound familiar? If a production later this season of "Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?," directed by Robert Falls, makes its way from the Goodman Theater in Chicago to Broadway (as is the hope), New York stages will have a provocative set of Albee bookends. "Baby" will land off Broadway, in a theater to be announced, and its opening date could fall anywhere between November and February. David Esbjornson will direct, and when they finish with their first play together this fall (see "The Butterfly Collection"), Marian Seldes and Brian Murray will star.
 
December
 
"THE WAX" A wedding at a seaside hotel, with writers and scientists as the randy guests. This new bedroom farce by Kathleen Tolan is directed by David Petrarca, who, in the deliciously nutty "Fuddy Meers" last year, showed he has a deft touch with whimsy. Previews begin Dec. 12. Opens Jan. 7. Playwrights Horizons.
 
"FORCE CONTINUUM" The Atlantic Theater Company commissioned this play by Kia Corthron about a three-generation family of black cops in which the youngest member is both accused of and victimized by police brutality. Previews begin Dec. 13. Opens Jan 4, 2001.
 
January
 
"HUMAN EVENTS" A barbed observer of Yankee pretense, A. R. Gurney puts a skewer to the academy in this play set in the stodgy humanities department of a small New England college. Directed by David Saint. Opens Jan. 6. George Street Playhouse, New Brunswick, N.J.
 
"TIME AND AGAIN" The second full production (the first was at the Old Globe Theater in San Diego in 1996) of a musical based on Jack Finney's atmospheric fantasy novel from 1970 -- part mystery, part romance and very New York -- about a time-traveling advertising illustrator. Book by Jack Viertel, music and lyrics by Walter Edgar Kennon. Directed by Susan Schulman ("The Red Shoes"). With Laura Benanti ("Swing!") and Julia Murney ("The Wild Party," Off Broadway version). Previews begin Jan. 9. Opens Jan. 30. Manhattan Theater Club Stage II.
 
"OEDIPUS THE KING" A new adaptation set in contemporary urban Africa by Adrienne Kennedy. Directed by Jonathan Wilson. Previews begin Jan. 11. Hartford Stage.
 
"DIDO, QUEEN OF CARTHAGE" The idiosyncratic Target Margin Theater, as is its wont, unearths a rarely performed work. This Elizabethan drama, by Christopher Marlowe, is based on the Greek myth of Dido and Aeneas and set on the Mediterranean in northern Africa. Directed by David Herskovits. Previews begin Jan. 17. Opens Jan. 24. Ohio Theater, 66 Wooster Street. (358-3657)
 
"CELLINI" An appealing match: a stage biography of the egomaniacal Florentine sculptor by John Patrick Shanley ("Danny and the Deep Blue Sea," the film "Moonstruck"), who generally has a good time with florid passions. Previews begin Jan 23. Second Stage.
 
"THE RHYTHM CLUB" Good luck, boys. The composer, Matthew Sklar, is 26; the book writer and lyricist, Chad Beguelin, is 30, remarkably young to have created a Broadway musical. Particularly striking is the fact that it is not a contemporary story, and not based on a contemporary musical idiom. Set in Germany in the 1930's, it tells the tale of two swing musicians, one gentile, one Jewish, and the female singer they hire to front their band. Sex, religion, the Holocaust -- that's enough conflict for any musical. Directed by Eric Schaeffer ("Putting It Together"), the artistic director of the Signature Theater in Arlington, Va., where it is being staged now. Its pre-Broadway run at the Ford Center for the Performing Arts in Chicago begins Dec. 9. Previews begin Jan. 26 at a Broadway theater to be announced. Opens Feb. 15.
 
* "BOY GETS GIRL" Sex and the city, not-so-glamorous division, from Rebecca Gilman, the author of the recent "Spinning Into Butter." After an unpromising blind date, a young woman is stalked by the hopeful young man, whose unwillingness to take no for an answer grows increasingly threatening. Previews begin Jan. 30. Opens Feb. 20. Manhattan Theater Club.
 
"JUDGMENT AT NUREMBERG" Abby Mann's stage adaptation of his own screenplay and teleplay about the Nuremberg war trials. Directed by John Tillinger. The first production this season by Tony Randall's National Actors Theater. Date to be announced.
 
February
 
"DAVID COPPERFIELD" Granted, the title character is a bit of a drip, but the poisonously creepy Uriah Heep and the gentle incompetent Mr. Micawber should provide great fodder for the stage. Plus, every eighth-grade teacher in America will bring the class. Adapted and directed by Giles Havergal. Previews begin Feb. 1. Opens Feb. 11. Steppenwolf Theater Company, Chicago.
 
"RASHOMON" The Pan Asian Repertory Theater revives the 1959 drama by Fay and Michael Kanin (based on the sterling film of 1951 by Akira Kurosawa), about a violent encounter in the woods involving a samurai, his wife and a bandit -- and their conflicting perspectives on the events. Performances begin Feb. 8. The West End Theater at the Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew, 263 West 86th Street. 212-505-5655.
 
 * "LOBBY HERO" Kenneth Lonergan is staking a claim as the playwright laureate of New York City. After two recent successes -- "This Is Our Youth," set on the Upper West Side, and "The Waverly Gallery," in Greenwich Village -- he now adds a third contemporary urban drama, about two policemen and a security guard and his supervisor who encounter one another in an apartment house lobby after a murder. Previews begin Feb. 16. Opens March 13. Playwrights Horizons.
 
"WHO'S AFRAID OF VIRGINIA WOOLF?" Like Arthur Miller, Edward Albee is seeing his past work resurface with a vengeance even as he continues to produce new plays. This revival of his 1962 masterpiece, set on a college campus, about a bitterly hostile professor and his wife and their unsuspecting young pair of dinner guests, is uncast as yet, but the director is David Esbjornson, who directed Mr. Miller's "Ride Down Mount Morgan" on Broadway and is scheduled to direct Mr. Albee's "Play About the Baby" off Broadway this season as well. This is likely to be the third major regional production of "Virginia Woolf" this season, following one at Trinity Rep in Providence in the fall and one at the Goodman Theater in Chicago in January. (The Goodman production, to be directed by Robert Falls and possibly starring Patti LuPone, was teetering on the brink of confirmation at press time.) Previews begin Feb. 24. Opens March 2. Guthrie Theater, Minneapolis. (877-447-8243). www.guthrietheater.org
 
"I WILL BEAR WITNESS"The premiere of an adaptation of the diaries of Victor Klemperer, a German Jew, kept during 12 years of the Third Reich. This is a solo performance by George Bartenieff, who, with Karen Malpede, adapted the stunningly detailed diaries, which were published for the first time in English just a year ago. Previews begin Feb. 25. Opens March 11. Classic Stage Company.
 
"BIG LOVE" The playwright Charles Mee takes a fable by Aeschylus about 50 sisters promised in marriage against their will to 50 brothers, and turns it into a virulent battle of the sexes. In its premiere production in the spring, at the Humana Festival of New American Plays in Louisville, it was so physical for the actors that it was staged on an enormous wrestling mat. Previews begin Feb. 28. Opens March 7. Long Wharf Theater.
 
"DOGEATERS" Jessica Hagedorn adapts her own novel of reminiscence about life under Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines in the 1980's. Directed by Michael Greif ("Rent"). Joseph Papp Public Theater. Opening date to be announced.
 
March
 
"COYOTE BUILDS NORTH AMERICA" Tales of sex and heroism from Native American myths, based on stories by the writer Barry Lopez, adapted and set to music by John Luther Adams. Part of the 50th-anniversary season of the Arena Stage in Washington. Previews begin March 2. (202-488-3300)
 
* "FOLLIES" This goes in the high expectations department: the first Broadway revival of the Stephen Sondheim-James Goldman musical since it opened in 1971. The show, which tells the story of a reunion of dancers in the crumbling theater where they once performed, has one of Mr. Sondheim's most pungent and best-loved scores; the show won seven Tony Awards -- and flopped financially. A very of-the-moment creative pair, Matthew Warchus ("True West") and Kathleen Marshall ("Kiss Me, Kate"), will, respectively, direct and choreograph, filling legendary shoes (Harold Prince's and Michael Bennett's) from the legendary original. Presented by the Roundabout Theater Company. Previews begin March 6. Opens April 5. Belasco Theater. (719-1300) www.roundabouttheatre.org
 
"TEN UNKNOWNS" Jon Robin Baitz ("The Substance of Fire") is drawn to collisions between artistic high-mindedness and real-world morality. His new play is about an octogenarian painter living in Mexico as a recluse and several unexpected visitors. Directed by Daniel Sullivan. Previews begin March 8. Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Lincoln Center.
 
"TUVA OR BUST!" Alan Alda portrays the iconoclastic physicist Richard Feynman in a new play by Peter Parnell, directed by Gordon Davidson. Previews begin March 11. Opens March 22. Mark Taper Forum, Los Angeles. (213-628-2772)
 
* "THE PRODUCERS" Nathan Lane and Matthew Broderick are on the wish list to star as the lovably, ineptly corrupt theater producers Max Bialystock and Leo Bloom, in this stage adaptation of Mel Brooks's film (with Zero Mostel and Gene Wilder) about a show that is supposed to flop -- and doesn't. Mr. Brooks wrote the book as well as the score, which of course includes the title song of the doomed-to-succeed musical-within-the-musical, "Springtime for Hitler." Susan Stroman choreographs and directs. Previews expected to begin in late March. St. James Theater (Tele-Charge)
 
"THE AMEN CORNER" A revival of James Baldwin's 1954 play, set in Harlem, about jazz, faith and family. Directed by Chuck Smith. Previews begin March 16. Opens March 26. Goodman Theater, Chicago.
 
"THE INVENTION OF LOVE" The New York premiere of Tom Stoppard's play about the poet A. E. Housman in confrontation, at the end of his life, with his youthful self. Presented on Broadway by Lincoln Center Theater. Directed by Jack O'Brien ("The Full Monty," Mr. Stoppard's "Hapgood"). Cast, theater and opening date to be announced.
 
"TOP DOG/UNDERDOG" A black family with brothers named Lincoln and Booth; such is the barbed comic perspective of the playwright Suzan-Lori Parks ("In the Blood"), teaming up here with a director, Charles S. Dutton, who is not likely to shy away from wicked wit. Joseph Papp Public Theater. Date to be announced.
 
"BRIGHTON BEACH MEMOIRS" A Broadway revival of the first volume of Neil Simon's autobiographical trilogy, set in Brooklyn in 1937. A search is on for the next Matthew Broderick, who played the 15-year-old Eugene (read: Neil) in the original 1983 production. Directed by Jerry Zaks ("Laughter on the 23rd Floor"). Date and theater to be announced.
 
* "STONES IN HIS POCKETS" This two-handed comedy by a Belfast playwright, Marie Jones, has been a crowd-pleasing hit in London, largely because the unheralded actors -- Conleth Hill and Sean Campion -- are so marvelously facile in portraying more than a dozen characters: the Irish extras hired for a Hollywood movie, and the presumptuous Americans who invade their home turf. Theater and date to be announced.
 
April
 
"TROILUS AND CRESSIDA" It seems Sir Peter Hall can't get enough of the Trojan War. After mounting John Barton's 10-play "Tantalus" in the fall, he takes on Shakespeare's tragedy, directing off Broadway for the first time in a long career in a production by the Theater for a New Audience. Previews begin April 1. Opens April 3. American Place Theater. (Tele-Charge) www.tfana.org
 
"CRIMES OF THE HEART" Cross-cultural dysfunction! The stage adventures of Beth Henley's nutty Mississippi sisters won the author the Pulitzer Prize in 1981. They are being directed this time by the Irish director Garry Hynes, whose handling of Martin McDonagh's play "The Beauty Queen of Leenane," with its viciously curdled Irish stage family, won her a Tony Award in 1999. Performances begin April 3. Second Stage.
 
"KIMBERLY AKIMBO" David Lindsay-Abaire, whose pleasantly cockeyed comedy "Fuddy Meers" was one of last season's great surprises, returns with a tale about another loopy family -- they live in Teaneck, N.J. -- some of whose members are oddly afflicted, semi-drunk and/or criminally inclined. Kimberly is the 16-year-old daughter, poor kid. Previews begin April 6. Opens April 13. South Coast Repertory Theater, Costa Mesa, Calif. (714-708-5555) www.scr.org
 
"CLAUDIA LAZLO" The indefatigable Arthur Laurents, who knows something about what goes on backstage, checks in with a backstage drama about a domineering, passionate diva. Or is that redundant? Starring Cigdem Onat, the Turkish actress so well received last season as the pension owner in Lincoln Center Theater's revival of Mr. Laurents's "Time of the Cuckoo." Opens April 21. George Street Playhouse, New Brunswick, N.J.
 
"TOM SAWYER" A new musical based on the Mark Twain classic, with music by Don Schlitz (a country songwriter best known for the Kenny Rogers hit "The Gambler") and a book by Ken Ludwig ("Crazy for You," "Lend Me a Tenor"). Directed by Scott Ellis. Who knows? Broadway opening on April 26. Theater to be announced.
 
"THE SEAGULL" Chekhov's play, adapted by Regina Taylor ("Oo-Bla-Dee"), set in the Gullah Islands, off the coast of South Carolina. Previews begin April 27. Opens May 7. Goodman Theater, Chicago.
 
"A THOUSAND CLOWNS" Does anyone else but that lovable old eccentric Tom Selleck come to mind to play the lovable old eccentric Murray Burns? Well, maybe. Nonetheless, Mr. Selleck has signed on to make his Broadway debut in a revival of Herb Gardner's 1962 comedy about a nonconformist who drops out of the workaday world to raise his nephew. Theater and opening date to be announced.
 
 * "KING HEDLEY II" The latest installment of August Wilson's lyrical, decade-by-decade probing of the 20th-century black American experience takes place in Pittsburgh in 1985, among the urban poor. Directed by Marion McClinton, whose superb Off Broadway production of Mr. Wilson's "Jitney" transfers to the Union Square Theater on Sept. 19. "King Hedley II" has been in development in productions in Boston and Seattle, and will make stops in Chicago and Los Angeles before arriving in New York. Theater and opening date to be announced.
 
"BELLS ARE RINGING" "Just in Time" -- for the Tony deadline. Faith Prince stars as the answering-service operator who falls in love with a client -- a playwright, of course -- in the first Broadway revival of the 1956 musical by Jule Styne, Adolph Green and Betty Comden. Tina Landau ("Floyd Collins") makes her Broadway debut as director. Jeff Calhoun ("Annie Get your Gun") choreographs. Opens late April. Theater to be announced.
 
"TALLULAH" And once again, ladies and gentlemen, Miss Bankhead. A one-woman play by Sandra Ryan Heyward starring Kathleen Turner as the flamboyant actress on a night in 1947 as she plays hostess at a party for President Harry S. Truman. A multi-city pre-Broadway tour ends in Columbus, Ohio, on March 11. Broadway theater and date to be announced.
 
"HOMEBODY/KABUL" Information is scarce about this new play by Tony Kushner ("Angels in America"), but New York Theater Workshop claims it will present it beginning in late April or early May.
 
May
 
"SORROWS AND REJOICINGS" Two women -- one white, one black -- in love with the same man. The South African playwright Athol Fugard revisits his homeland again in the wake of apartheid; he also directs. Opens May 1. McCarter Theater, Princeton, N.J. (888-278-7932) www.mccarter.org
 
"WONDER OF THE WORLD" Yet another cache of idiosyncrasies from David Lindsay-Abaire ("Fuddy Meers," "Kimberly Akimbo"), the play is set in Niagara Falls and involves a young woman, an alcoholic bent on suicide, a sea captain and a large jar of peanut butter. Manhattan Theater Club. Previews begin May 1. Opens May 22.
 
"CHAUCER IN ROME" A new play by John Guare ("House of Blue Leaves," "Six Degrees of Separation") about Americans in Rome at the end of the millennium. Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater. Lincoln Center. Previews begin May 10. Opens June 7.
 
"THE GENERAL FROM AMERICA" Corin Redgrave plays Benedict Arnold in a new historical drama by Richard Nelson ("Goodnight Children Everywhere," "Some Americans Abroad") about the most famous defection in American history. Directed by the playwright. Opens May 18. Alley Theater, Houston. (713-228-8421) www.alleytheatre.com
 
June
 
"IN THE PENAL COLONY" Maybe wonderful, definitely weird. A music-theater piece by Philip Glass based on the Kafka story and directed by JoAnne Akalaitis. With earlier stops at A Contemporary Theater in Seattle and the Court Theater in Chicago. Previews begin June 7. Opens June 14. Classic Stage Company.

HEADLINE: In Chicago, an Attempt to Upgrade a Neighborhood

BYLINE: By ROBERT SHAROFF

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
A NEW housing development rising on the city's North Side is the first step in what city officials hope will be the transformation of one of Chicago's most notorious public housing projects into one that mixes the economic classes and makes the area more like Old Town or Lincoln Park, two gentrified neighborhoods it borders.
The public housing project is Cabrini-Green, which sits on a 70-acre parcel of land a stone's throw from tony areas like Michigan Avenue and the Gold Coast, but which for years has served as a symbol of urban blight and the failure of public housing policy. 
 City officials say the new project, called North Town Village, will be a model for other cities looking to redevelop blighted public housing projects.
"We feel we're at a critical point where we can move ahead with what is truly a great vision for redeveloping outdated public housing," said Christopher R. Hill, Chicago's commissioner of planning and development. "If it works here, it will work in other places. But this is the first."
The new project, which occupies seven acres that abut the northwest corner of Cabrini-Green, is to consist of 261 residences in a variety of low-rise buildings, mainly two- and three-story town houses and condominiums, with a few larger buildings. Some of the units will be for sale, and some for rent.
The building materials are mainly brick and stone and the architectural details in the Victorian or neo-Classical style. The architect is Todd Main, a principal with Bauhs, Dring & Main Ltd. in Chicago.
Renderings show a design similar to a number of other housing developments, public and private, that have been built downtown in the last few years.
What is different is the location and the prospective tenant base. Although there are other new developments in Chicago neighboring large tracts of public housing, North Town Village is the largest, and the first to include three distinct components: market-rate units, "affordable" homes with income ceilings for tenants and public housing. The land, which is steps away from several of Cabrini-Green's high-rise towers, was sold by the city to the developers, Holsten Real Estate Development Corporation and Kenard Corporation, at a reduced price of about $5.5 million in exchange for their commitment to go along with the city's plans for the area. That price is about half of the market price of similar property.
THE development is designed to have 50 percent market-rate units, 30 percent public housing units and 20 percent low-income units. (The 40 low-income rental units are intended for families that make no more than 60 percent, or $40,000, of the city's median income, and the 12 low-income units for sale are intended for families that make 120 percent, or $81,000, of the median income.)
In a change that reflects the city's new approach to public housing, the Chicago Housing Authority will lease the public units from the developers but not manage them. Instead, the project will be managed by a private company. "We're getting out of the business of running and managing programs," said Terry Peterson, the authority's chief executive officer.
Prices for the 93 market-rate units that are for sale start at $146,900 for a one-bedroom condominium and climb to almost $500,000 for a three-story town house. "We have mixed all three income groups completely throughout the development," said Peter Holsten, president of Holsten Real Estate. "Every building has all three income groups in it. You'll have an expensive town house with a public housing family next door."
Harold Lichterman, president of Kenard, added: "There's no difference at all between the market rate and the affordable and public units. If the the market rate gets a fireplace, the public unit gets a fireplace."
The project is expected to cost about $65 million; about half of the financing is being provided by grants and subsidies. "It's a very expensive project," Mr. Holsten said. "We're really trying to build a brand-new community here, and it's more than just bricks and mortar. We're putting a lot of energy into the people part."
The "people part" includes an extensive screening program for public housing families that includes drug testing, and a program designed to ease their entry into the private housing market, with neighbors from different economic classes. "For many of them, this will be their first private housing experience," Mr. Holsten said. "The program will teach them how to take care of their unit and what it's like to live in a private housing community."
Construction on North Town Village began last spring, and the project is expected to be completed in mid-2002. Some units will be ready for occupancy by next spring.
Reaction from buyers of the market-rate units has been positive. The sales office opened in mid-June and all but six of the 93 market-rate units have been snapped up. One of the early sales was to Kevin and Jennifer Hardman, who currently live west of the downtown Loop business district.
"The location is wonderful," said Mr. Hardman, a marketing manager at a suburban manufacturing company. "It's an area with a lot of potential. We didn't jump into this for altruistic reasons. It was a financial decision. We wanted the best home we could find for the money."
He added, however: "We're excited to be a part of the experiment. I'm a big believer in mixed-income communities."
The split between market-rate, public and low-income units is one the city sees as key to its larger goal of redeveloping the area. Cabrini-Green, built over 20 years beginning in 1942, has been a major trouble spot on the North Side for many years.
THE heart of the complex is a series of 14 brick high-rises -- many of the "open gallery" variety, meaning that there are no internal hallways -- along with several blocks of row houses and smaller buildings. At its peak occupancy, the complex housed as many as 15,000 low-income tenants and was a hub of gang and drug-trafficking activity in the city. Things got so bad in the late 70's that Jane E. Byrne, then the mayor, lived in the complex for about a month in 1981 in an effort to restore order. Eight years ago, Cabrini-Green made national headlines when a 7-year-old boy who lived there was shot and killed by a sniper on his way to school.
Development in the area around the Cabrini-Green houses stagnated in the 80's, but in the 90's, as the downtown housing boom gathered force, developers began taking another look at the blocks surrounding the complex. "It's some of the best land in the entire city," said Harry Huzenis, a principal with Jameson Realty Group, a residential brokerage firm in the neighborhood. "It's more affordable than Old Town or Lincoln Park but it has a lot of the same advantages in terms of location," he said -- about 10 blocks from the Loop.
The sticking point for many developers and prospective homeowners, however, remains Cabrini-Green. In the mid-90's, the city unveiled a plan to redevelop the area that included demolishing many of the largest high-rises and turning over some of the land to private developers. It also moved ahead with an aggressive public works program for the neighborhood that included building a park at the intersection of Division and Orleans Streets; two schools, including an elite, $35 million magnet school; a library; and a police station.
Two high-rises had already been torn down and several others had been boarded up when work came to a halt in the wake of a lawsuit filed by the Cabrini-Green Local Advisory Council, a tenants' group. The suit challenged the city's right to tear down the buildings without first guaranteeing residents equivalent or better housing in the neighborhood.
The lawsuit was resolved with the signing of a consent decree last month in which the city promised to build 700 units of public housing, including those in North Town Village, in an area bounded by North Avenue, Wells Street, Chicago Avenue and the Chicago River in exchange for the right to demolish three more high-rises.
"We got a good settlement," said Cora Moore, 62, president of the Local Advisory Council and a 40-year Cabrini-Green resident. "We want to live right here on the same land we've been living on all the time. We want a decent, sanitary place to live. Our goal has been accomplished."
If all goes according to plan, the units will be contained in low-rise buildings similar to those of North Town Village. "For the last 30 to 40 years," said Mr. Peterson of the Chicago Housing Authority, "we've isolated public housing residents socially and economically. But the residents are ready for a change. We want to integrate them back into the fabric of the community."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS;
A Designer Who Lives Like Her Clients

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: IRVINGTON

 BODY:
IT is a fashion cliche for designers to say they design for themselves, but in Eileen Fisher's case, it's true.
As a working mother of two -- an 11-year-old son and a 7-year-old daughter -- who does the afternoon car pool, works from home to be with her children and takes part in charities and fund-raisers, Ms. Fisher really does live her clients' lives. 
 Small wonder, then, that her spare designs, expressed in simple shapes like kimono jackets, sleeveless shells, loose tunics and elastic waist skirts and slacks, which are made from fabrics like Irish linen, silk crepe or velvets, have become a uniform of sorts for Ms. Fisher's peers.
It is not uncommon for stylish women here to check with one another to find out which "Eileen" has been selected for the coming wedding, bar mitzvah or charity event, so they don't duplicate outfits. In fact, Ms. Fisher, who recently turned 50, said, "We have parties where the staff shows up in the same clothes."
Perhaps it's not surprising that Ms. Fisher has developed such an identifiable look.
As a child growing up in suburban Chicago, she attended parochial schools, where a uniform was required. She never thought she would actually be a clothes designer: she began her college career as a math major. Her roommate was in visual design, and as Ms. Fisher became more disenchanted with higher mathematics, design seemed more and more appealing. By the time she reached New York City, the daily routine of getting dressed for work proved the impetus to a new career.
"Just getting dressed in the morning was overwhelming," said Ms. Fisher, who admitted that she can't really draw and relied on someone else to help sew her clothes when she started to make her own designs.
"Shopping would turn my stomach," she said. "I felt a longing for my school uniform, a tweed jacket and textured skirt -- even though I hated it because my uniform didn't make me feel special."
Pared down to essentials, Ms. Fisher observed, the story of her company is "a school uniform story."
"What we do is keep what's good about the school uniform, but not that limited," she said. "It's a simplified system, like a Lego system, where it's simple pieces used in different ways."
From a sleek building between the Irvington train station and the Hudson River, Ms. Fisher presides over a company that generated $100 million in revenue last year. Ms. Fisher, who owns more than 80 percent of the company, started it in 1984 by borrowing money from friends.
The decision to move here reflected Ms. Fisher's philosophy not only as a designer but also as a parent and an executive.
"I had lived in TriBeCa and SoHo for 12 years," she said. "I had had a loft space in a renovated warehouse and liked the idea of being in a warehouse by the river. I've always loved water and loved sunsets.
"When we moved from the city, we wanted to keep the people we had, and I liked Irvington because people could come into the community, and they didn't need a car. Being here, people could have a little fuller life. We're close enough to the city, and I go to the showroom there once a week. I pick my kids up from school three days a week, and I can work from home, so I can spend time with them."
Her employees, too, are encouraged to balance family responsibility with community involvement. Even some employees who live in Manhattan are members of the Irvington volunteer ambulance corps, going out on calls during the work day.
In many ways, the Eileen Fisher company reflects Ms. Fisher's beliefs and values. Her designs mirror Ms. Fisher's attitudes toward life.
"It's not about money," she said. "It's about people, friends, family and community and how people treat each other. There has to be natural growth. It can't be something you force."
In fact, the company's latest advertising campaign features employees who are self-described in their various roles (bookkeeper, wife, illustrator, mother) wearing Eileen Fisher designs.
Community matters to Ms. Fisher. In 1999, the company donated 3 percent of pretax profits to charitable organizations, of which one-third are based in Westchester.
For several years, the company's annual warehouse sale was a major charitable event, with 25 percent of the sales going to local projects, including the public schools and a women's shelter. Most years, there was a surplus of volunteers, lured by the chance to get first crack at the clothing.
With the arrival of its own outlet stores, the company no longer holds a warehouse sale, though its donations continue.
The company even has a manager of social accountability, Amy Hall, who had previously spent six years in public relations and community relations.
"This position didn't even exist two years ago," Ms. Hall said. "It grew out of the desire to address human rights issues in our factories.
"One of Eileen's fundamental philosophies is that clothing should simplify women's lives. It felt natural to extend that to how we work with the community. It encompasses women who are facing crises in their lives, dealing with economic independence, domestic violence and health crises. We get about 40 requests a week and meet every eight weeks to discuss the requests."
As Ms. Fisher explained: "What we do with trying to help women get dressed is bigger than their clothes. It's not about dictating, and it's not about just a business to sell fashion. It grew out of what I was looking for. I have no time, so I want to make it simple."

HEADLINE: Debating a Bridgeport Casino's Impact

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
A CASINO in Bridgeport would create 7,500 full-time and temporary construction jobs, pump $650 million of revenue a year into the Fairfield County region's already vibrant economy, and would create a demand in ancillary industries of $350 million.
If run by a Native American tribe, as at Foxwoods and the Mohegan Sun, a 150,000 square-foot casino in Bridgeport with 5,000 gaming positions, 125 table games and 3,500 slot machines would also generate nearly $100 million for the state of Connecticut. 
 But it would also result in an additional 29,700 vehicle trips traveling along the already congested I-95 on a typical Friday during the worst time period possible -- the 4-8 p.m. evening rush hour -- and extend that heavy traffic by several more hours.
A Bridgeport casino would also have a devastating impact on air quality -- with pollution becoming so bad it would be tough to comply with acceptable levels of pollution under the Federal Clean Air Act.
Those were the two conflicting views presented to about 75 realtors, bankers and businesses executives at a seminar last week in Stamford by the local branch of the Real Estate Finance Association on how a Bridgeport casino would help Fairfield County's economy, but hurt its over-burdened infrastructure and surrounding environment along the coast. Over the years, there have been a handful of proposals to build a casino in the city, none of which have been approved.
Entitled "Native Americans, Gaming and Fairfield County," the breakfast seminar brought together a panel of casino supporters and detractors, as well as a Native American chief from Kent who explained his tribe's quest for federal recognition and what that could mean to its chances to someday operate a casino.
"The decade of the 90's saw Native American gaming come full circle. During that 10-year period, Native American casinos evolved from high stakes bingo with pull tabs, some card rooms and some slot machines -- legal or illegal -- to the successful development of some of the largest casino resorts in the United States," said Mickey Brown, former president and chief executive of Foxwood Resorts Casino in Ledyard and now a lawyer in Atlantic City.
"The distinction between Indian casinos and the commercial casino industry is fading and becoming less and less obvious," Mr. Brown said. "But I want to tell you how the development of another Native American casino in Connecticut would impact the present economy and its overall affect upon western Connecticut."
Mr. Brown said a casino in Bridgeport would likely result in annual gross revenues of $660 million for the casino, and stimulate the region's economy with sales of items such as food and beverage purchases, marketing, utilities, entertainment, repair and maintenance and administration. He said all costs excluding wages would be in the range of about $170 million. He said employees would be paid more than $136 million in annual wages and benefits.
"Casino jobs are new jobs created where none previously existed," said Mr. Brown. "Because the business is highly labor intense and operates 24 hours a day, seven days a week, the casino business becomes a substantial employer immediately. To sum up, casinos import money. At Foxwoods we did over $1 billion in revenue during my last year there."
Joseph McGee, vice president of the South Western Regional Planning Agency, said he told the group that a casino in Bridgeport would greatly worsen an already existing daily traffic nightmare along Interstate 95 and the Merritt Parkway.
"In just 10 years the number of vehicle miles per day on I-95 has increased 30,000 miles to 128,000 vehicle miles per day," Mr. McGee said. "And even without a casino those numbers are going to keep increasing by nearly 2 percent a year. With a casino, all of these problems -- traffic, air pollution, the deteriorating infrastructure -- will be greatly exacerbated."
Richard L. Velkey, chief of the Schaghticoke Tribal Nation in Kent, said just as the more well-known Golden Hill Paugussetts, his tribe continues its long quest for federal recognition so that it may one day operate a casino in Bridgeport. But Mr. Velkey said because of a complex system regarding the federal tribal recognition process, he is not sure the region or state is ready for another casino.
"Here in Fairfield County and across Connecticut municipalities have no way of properly planning for future development," Mr. Velkey said. "This broken process is not only a source of frustration for the Schaghticoke, but it raises serious questions as to how many tribes will win federal recognition, when it will happen, and how state local federal and tribal leaders can work together to assure that the end result will benefit citizens and not create a situation that will negatively impact our community." 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Dissolving a Suburban Marriage

BYLINE: By AL BAKER

 BODY:
THE Christmas tree went up that year. Pictures were taken, too, and despite the breakup of Kim Manghisi's marriage, no one could tell from the photos how miserable things were.
The snapshots failed to show how Ms. Manghisi cried nearly every day after, she said, her husband backed a rental truck into the driveway of their new house in Yorktown Heights one Saturday in November -- six weeks after the birth of their second child -- and carted away much of their six years of life together. 
 "I thought when I got married that I was going to have this normal life: the two kids and the suburban home and the nice vacations, and we were achieving all of that," Ms. Manghisi, 42, a nurse, said, sharing her story in a Mount Kisco church one August night with others trying to recover from divorce.
"It was like the shattering of the dream."
Ms. Manghisi is one of the faces of divorce in Westchester, a place where, amid the well-educated residents and expensive houses, there is a steady population of couples heading to court.
Of the 68,147 statewide divorce filings in 1997, the year of Ms. Manghisi's split, almost 3,000 were here. Divorce in Westchester declined slightly the next year, but marriages fell, too, by more than 50 percent in the same period, from 12,121 to 5,848, according to the State Health Department.
The county's divorce rate is almost half the national average, because, historically, divorce is most common in poor areas, according to experts and figures from the National Center for Health Statistics.
But while the numbers may be lower than in other areas, like the South, divorces here are often more complicated and contentious because they tend to be among people who have been married longer and have acquired more, experts said.
No issue is too small when dismantling a suburban household. Who gets the chocolate Labrador retriever (or in some cases, its ashes), the Lenox china or a favorite rocking chair is argued on the seventh floor of the County Courthouse in White Plains.
"Couples who divorce in Westchester are much wealthier than on average, so divorce tends to be more difficult, there is more to fight about," said Marsha Garrison, a Brooklyn Law School professor who has compared divorce outcomes in Westchester with those in New York City and in Onondaga County.
Little has changed in the nine years since she wrote her study: more couples hire separate lawyers in Westchester; more women receive alimony, and child support payments are higher -- because people are more affluent.
Nationally, people typically divorce after seven years of marriage, but here, lawyers say, it is more likely to be after 18 to 20 years. And while people around the country tend to be 31 to 33 when they divorce, Ms. Garrison said that in Westchester, "you're likely to be talking about people who are older." The reason, she said, is: "People who are highly educated tend to marry later. So, because you have a fairly well-educated group in Westchester, these are people typically who married later in life."
What is new here in recent years is that the cast of characters has expanded; in addition to the lawyers, there are divorce financial planners and real estate agents marketing condominiums or apartments to the newly single. Divorce mediation services, long popular in other parts of the country, are also expanding here. And support groups continue to thrive in churches, community centers and private homes, helping divorcees recover emotionally.
If litigated, divorce is usually very costly. But it rarely goes to trial here. The number of cases begun in court fell to 109 last year from 121 in 1997. Just a fraction of those finish with a verdict, judges in Westchester said, because the process is too grueling and too costly to see through.
Ms. Manghisi was lucky: she survived the anguish -- and $16,000 in legal fees -- to tell her story inside the fieldstone St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Mount Kisco. As she spoke, a group of 50 divorced and separated men and women sat quietly on metal folding chairs arranged in a circle around her.
Later, a handful in the group gathered down the road at the 24-hour Mount Kisco Coach diner to dissect Ms. Manghisi's story. The divorcees, including the group's founder and leader, Micki McWade, admitted that they had had suicidal or murderous thoughts in the wake of their marital splits.
But that is just one of the complex sorts of emotions divorce can bring.
"I felt myself becoming my losses," said Bette Samuel, 43, of Briarcliff Manor, who was in the church that night. She did not feel suicidal, but her divorce four years ago was more painful than the recent death of her mother or a miscarriage she suffered just before the divorce, she said.
"I sat in a dark room and cried for six months," Ms. Samuel said. "A lot of it was like: 'Why me? Why is this happening to me?' "
A few blocks away from the support group, at a bar in Mount Kisco, a 41-year-old man told how he found his wife in bed with another man, "put the guy in the hospital" and got drunk for a year. Ten years later, he still feels sad.
A middle-age woman with dark hair said she split with her husband when the passion ran out of their 15-year marriage. Simple as that.
"My ex is my best friend," the woman said, poking at a plate of sesame-crusted tuna. "But would you want to sleep with your best friend?"
Another woman said that she and her husband split up for a year, looked over the so-called cliff of divorce and retreated back to marriage.
"Our two marriage counselors told us to learn how to fight," she said. "You get married for reasons."
In a suburban enclave like Westchester, divorce puts an abrupt end to sharing a home and two cars, raising a family and establishing roots. It is a middle-age father, James M. McLernon of Millwood, still blaming himself six years after he left his wife. His biggest worry is that his children, ages 9 and 12, "are the ones that got clobbered."
To others, divorce is a geographic and economic headache.
It is David J. Lord, 51, of Armonk, divorced once and separated from his second wife since 1996, who has two sets of children, on Long Island and in Westchester, and accounting offices in each county. It is Eddie Wirchansky, 42, of Peekskill, barely able to afford a baby sitter, never mind pay back the thousands of dollars in legal fees his father provided for a divorce a year ago.
It is a 49-year-old radiology technician from Larchmont who hopped over the border to Connecticut and filed because, unlike New York, divorce is no fault there.
Ultimately, experts and those going through it say, divorce is about isolation. And in a bedroom community where families are the norm, they said, it is especially hard to meet people after a divorce.
"I think that suburbia is so built on family life, so built on Saturday barbecues, the kids' baseball games, the whole trying to make a Norman Rockwell life, that people in suburbia are hit so hard," said Monica S. Getz, who is herself divorced and founded the National Coalition for Family Justice, based in Irvington. The organization educates people heading for divorce and supports people who feel unjustly treated in matrimonial or family court.
When they separated after 10 years of marriage in 1997, David and Donna Gage of Scarsdale were determined not to disrupt the lives of their 6-year-old triplets, Matthew, Robert and Allison. The couple never wanted them to have to leave their childhood home. So, they each found separate apartments nearby and swapped nights in the old Stratton Road homestead.
For nearly two years, the adults shuttled in and out of the white split-level house. They were the ones forced to pack and unpack their bags. They had to change their phone numbers and rearrange their mail. They kept their problems from fracturing their children's lives. The children. happily, could still play soccer, ride on the swing-set or bounce on the trampoline in their backyard. Their live-in nanny also stayed with them in the home.
"It was comfortable for them," Ms. Gage, 37, said. "They were in their same bed. They had the same schedule. Everything was nondisruptive."
The parents found the arrangement ideal, if unusual. They could afford two rents and a mortgage. In her $800-a-month studio, in Harrison, Ms. Gage was always five minutes away. In his $1,300-a-month condominium in White Plains, Mr. Gage was always three miles up the road.
"I got a lot of flak for it in the beginning," Mr. Gage, 48, said of the idea. "People gave me a hard time. They said, 'It should be more of a traditional split,' and, 'Don't look back. It is not good to be in-between.' But it worked out great." With the divorce final, Ms. Gage is in the house with the children full time now. Visits with dad require overnight trips. But the children are older, Ms. Gage said. It is less of a shock.
The Gages' solution was more the exception than the norm. Most cases are fought in courtrooms or legal offices. Ms. Getz said the legal system is fraught with problems and needs to be more family friendly.
One remedy divorcees are turning to more and more, many said, is mediation.
The Office of Court Administration in Albany wants divorce cases to be speedier and less adversarial, and efforts at reducing conflict have led to more mediators.
In the county, Amelia T. DelVecchio was appointed recently to head a new program that offers couples alternatives to the legal wars over custody, visitation or future earnings potential. The program has 41 mediators, and the service is free and does not delay the proceeding, Ms. DelVecchio said.
Complicating matters in Westchester, said Jacqueline W. Silbermann, administrative judge for matrimonial matters in New York, is that the two full-time judges who hear cases, John R. LaCava and Adrienne Hofmann Scancarelli, are leaving by year's end. That means that new judges, unfamiliar with cases that have already begun, will have to step in, Judge Silbermann said.
A program that educates parents about custody and the impact of divorce on children is expanding, and a similar program for children will start in the fall.
But mediation programs are not popular with everyone. If one spouse is abusive or fiscally domineering, it should not be attempted, most lawyers and judges said. Others say mediation adds an unnecessary layer to an already complex process.
"The mediation process can be beneficial," said Martin T. Johnson, chairman of the Family Law Section of the State Bar Association, whose law offices are in White Plains and Pearl River. "But it presupposes that both parties have an absolute handle of what their rights are, which is not always true."
Marcia Smithen Cohen's office in her Katonah home has a 40-inch round table, four identical chairs, a box of tissues and enough privacy to untangle complex domestic issues. Ms. Cohen, a lawyer, has traded dark pinstripe suits and heels for pants and sweaters; she's swapped advocacy for neutrality. She is a full-time mediator.
"The mediator is required to be impartial and neutral," she said, adding that mediators "empower people to make informed choices about their lives."
Westchester is home to many sophisticated business people, Ms. Cohen said, and they see mediation as a viable option.
"The most important reason to consider a mediated divorce for people who have children is the realization that, like it or not, they are going to have to deal with each other through the children's lives," Ms. Cohen, 54, said. "There will be events, school events, graduations, marriages, births when the parents who are ex-spouses will find themselves in close quarters."
Mediation provides training in how to cope with uncomfortable encounters.
Ms. Cohen often receives referrals from therapists. She charges on a sliding scale, depending on a couple's income. Prices start at $200 an hour.
Sometimes spouses patch up their differences after seeing her.
"They will come to you not necessarily knowing what they want, so you have to help them find their voice," Ms. Cohen said. "We frame issues and discuss how they might be resolved."
Two of the major issues in a divorce in suburbia are where to live and how to divide the assets while the divorce is winding its way through court. The economics can be so tight that couples are often forced to find creative, if tense, solutions. One idea is sharing a home.
That is what Susan W. did when her marriage fell apart in 1996. She and her husband of 28 years, Michael, were born in New York city but moved to Westchester to take jobs as social service caseworkers.
They bought their house in Rye Brook for $100,000 in 1979, and paid $1,200 a month for their mortgage on a combined $70,000 annual income. When their relationship died, they couldn't afford a second rent. So they split the house in half.
She stayed in the master bedroom in a section of the house built in the 1700's. He moved 30 feet away into a section added on later. They shared the kitchen, split the utility bills, hired one lawyer instead of two and tried to ignore each other.
"You are trying to make completely separate lives," Susan said. "But you are in close quarters with a part of your life that fell apart. And you can't move on emotionally."
It is such a forbidding scenario that most people end up in any housing they can find.
"Mostly they go to condos," said Maryellen Walsh, a broker for Houlihan/Lawrence, Westchester's largest residential realty concern, who usually gets a few calls each year from customers who bought houses from her as newlyweds and are now divorcing. "Sometimes a temporary rental unit until they figure out what they are going to do. If they have a more expensive house, they downsize to a smaller home."
New living arrangements spur new household budgets, and divorcing couples often need financial planning, experts say.
That is where Mary Prior steps in. Her one-year-old divorce financial planning service, Financial Priorities, of Valhalla, is what she said she needed while going through her own divorce in 1996 after a 25-year marriage.
"So many times people don't understand the finances and, well, everyone is in a fog," she said. "A lot of people just say 'I want it to be over with,' and then a year later they are in financial difficulty and are sorry."
Because women tend to be hit harder economically, Ms. Prior said most of the roughly 50 clients she has seen have been middle-age women.
"A lot of times," she said, "the women will want to keep the house because there are children involved, and the children are established in the school district and they don't want to disrupt their lives."
Other times, the financial and social hardships are so great in suburbia that some couples opt against divorce despite troubled marriages.
"Divorce is a very high-risk strategy for making your life better," said Maggie Gallagher of Ossining, director of the marriage program at the Institute for American Values, a Manhattan research organization that favors marriage and family. "It will certainly create another large and imposing set of problems."
As a matrimonial lawyer, with offices across the street from Family Court in the Bronx, Alina R. Rosenthal had seen her share of terrible divorces: the domestic violence and sex abuse that clients endured; the adultery, abusive or cruel behavior and the couples "out for blood" in contested cases.
By comparison, her own marital problems were small. And yet, her problems still propelled her to leave her husband, Shalom Zellingher, twice.
The first time, six years ago, she traded her husband of 13 years, their two children, their two cats, their housekeeper and their Ardsley-on-Hudson home for an apartment in Queens and an imminent divorce. There were deep differences over religion and the schooling of the children. But eight months later she moved back home.
Then, in November 1996, she tried to leave her husband and their problems behind again. This time everyone but her husband joined her in a nearby apartment. But again everyone returned to the Ardsley home eight months later.
"In 16 years, our lives are inextricably intertwined," Ms. Rosenthal said. "You can't erase that."
The couple lived the realities that divorce entailed, and it scared them. They went to counseling. They read books. They thought of the emotional and economic toll their daughters would suffer. A move, a change of schools and problems brought on by what Ms. Rosenthal calls the "inherent sadness of knowing mom and dad are not together and it's not because one of them is gone or dead."
Today, despite the same issues over religion (he's an Orthodox Jew and she is a Conservative Jew), the couple is still together. They are far from perfect, Ms. Rosenthal said, but divorce is not the answer.
"We both realized that apart is not necessarily better," Ms. Rosenthal said. "Life alone was not necessarily better."
