HEADLINE: JERSEY;
The Problem Is, Allan Has Solutions

BYLINE: By DEBRA GALANT

 BODY:
SOME people have lots of ideas. Writers think of stories. Mathematicians come up with proofs. Financial planners find practical solutions for life's basic problems -- like making sure you don't have to eat cat food in retirement.
My husband's second cousin, Allan Caan, a financial planner in Fair Lawn, must have a lots of time on his hands because he has more than his share of ideas. 
 I see Allan once a year, at a family reunion in the Catskills. One morning at our latest reunion, the conversation turned to golf, and Allan explained how several years ago golf had given him an idea for paring the long lines at New Jersey's vehicle inspection stations.
"I was driving in the car and it just came to me," Allan said. "Tee times."
From Allan's lips to Christie Whitman's ears. The State of New Jersey finally introduced scheduled car inspections this summer.
But that's kid stuff to Allan Caan. In 1996, Allan came up with his Big Idea: a plan to save Social Security.
"I tossed the current Social Security System out the window and decided to start from scratch and see what I could come up with," Allan said. "Within a half-hour, I came up with a plan that I actually thought would work."
Before you laugh, consider this. Allan's suggestion that I refinance my mortgage a several years ago was so well-timed that I got an interest rate of 6 1/8 percent.
It would take more space than I have here to do real justice to Allan's plan. But the gist has to do with what economists call the time value of money: the earlier you invest, the less money you have to put in. Allan argued that if we contributed to Social Security when people were born -- instead of waiting until they start working, as is done now -- Social Security taxes could be reduced by 97 percent. For a baby born in 2000, Allan has calculated, it would take a one-time contribution of just $3,552 at birth to generate the same benefit that would require $250,000 of contributions under the current system.
"We're wasting that first 18 or 22 years of the person's life," he said.
For the past several years, Allan has pushed his plan on anybody and everybody in power: his Congressman, other Congressmen, Jon Corzine's campaign staff. He once approached Christie Whitman at a Devils' game and handed her an outline. This summer, he had lunch at the Forum Diner in Paramus with Linda Mercurio, who is running for Congress in the Fifth District.
"On its face, it really does make sense," said Ms. Mercurio, a law professor and former tax attorney. "The biggest problem with it is selling it."
"Tell me about it," Allan said.
The furthest Allan has gotten was to have a business columnist for The Washington Post write about his idea in 1997. He was also invited to Washington by Representative Sue Kelly, a New York Republican, in 1996 to talk to her staff, but never got past the waiting room. Many people in or near power have claimed to be fascinated by Allan's idea, but so far all it has really generated are polite thank-you notes.
"The thing is," Allan said, "if you call a congressman with a problem, they know exactly what to do. But if you call them with solution, they're at a loss."
I decided to run this by the office of Allan's congressman. Chuck Young, the chief of staff for Representative Steven Rothman, confirmed that constituents' problems outnumber solutions by 3 to 1, but he insisted that the congressman took "whatever they have to say seriously."
"We have him in our computer," Mr. Young said
The thank-you letter, that is.
But you can't stop a thinker. Allan also has ideas for renewing urban slums without raising taxes and is pondering health reform. I posed some problems myself. What would he do about Lincoln Tunnel traffic? Or the Chicago Cubs?
"E-ZPass is a great system," Allan said with a shrug. "I didn't come up with that." As for the Cubs, he sighed, "Some things are just impossible."
But it seems likelier that the Cubs will win a pennant than that somebody inside the Beltway will seriously consider an idea for saving Social Security from a financial planner in Fair Lawn.
"The system doesn't completely shut out ideas," said Cliff Zukin, chairman of the public policy department at Rutgers. "But it is closed to people who are not already powerful."

PUB-DATE: September 10, 2000

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2558 words

HEADLINE: From Front Office to Front Desk

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
MAGNESIUM white by day, coral red by night, the letters P S F S float over Center City as they have for 68 years. But they no longer mark the Philadelphia Saving Fund Society.
Instead, they signify Loews Philadelphia Hotel, the newest in a chain run by the Tisch family of New York. Loews took an aesthetically pioneering but economically obsolete 36-story office tower and, at the cost of $115 million, turned it into a 583-room hotel, preserving much of its cool, serene International style character. 
 Loews is in good company. Any number of landmark office buildings around the country are becoming hotels. In New York, Philip Pilevsky is turning the American Radiator Building, 40 West 40th Street, into the 130-room Bryant Park, which will open in late October. A week later, the Guardian Life Building at 201 Park Avenue South will be reborn as the 270-room W New York-Union Square, developed by the Related Companies and operated by Starwood Hotels and Resorts Worldwide.
The appeal of such conversions is obvious. Beleaguered or abandoned landmarks are returned to economic use, enlivening surroundings that are often undergoing a renaissance of their own. Sumptuous spaces, tattered and long neglected, are opened again to the public. And rather than struggle to create a distinctive presence, hotel operators can slip into the identity of well-loved civic icons.
These developments, however, are not for the faint of heart. Or the formula-minded. Although projects may qualify for historic tax credits covering up to 20 percent of eligible costs, the expense is substantial of retrofitting a structure that was never meant to lodge overnight visitors. And winning approval from federal and local preservation authorities adds time and unpredictability to the process.
Much of the money goes into engineering that guests will never see, though they will pay for it. (Room rates at W will run from the upper $300's to the lower $400's and start at $500 at the Bryant Park. At the Loews, which is geared to group travel, the rates average $170 to $180 a night.)
Among the intrinsic problems in converting an office building are plumbing risers, which are typically concentrated at the core of the structure to serve common restrooms. Hotels need plumbing for each guest bathroom, requiring many new risers to be opened throughout the building.
Another headache is the spacing of window bays, which typically do not correspond to a standard 12- or 13-foot hotel module, forcing the creation of larger-than-normal room sizes and unusual layouts that please guests but confound efficient, standardized operation.
And yet, as in the case of the Bryant Park, how else would a hotelier find a building designed by Raymond M. Hood (the McGraw-Hill Building on West 42nd Street, the Daily News Building on East 42nd Street and Tribune Tower in Chicago were among his other commissions) and depicted by Georgia O'Keeffe? "We're creating a landmark in a landmark," said Mr. Pilevsky, chairman and chief executive of the Philips Hotel Group.
It has taken a lot of money to do so, about $50 million, although the 24-story tower came somewhat cheap: $15 million.
As striking today as it was on completion in 1924, the American Radiator Building is like a stalagmite of gold-trimmed ebony; black bricks fired in manganese, topped by shimmering finials. It caught the eye of Mr. Pilevsky, whose office is only two blocks away. During the 1980's, he had been a partner in the innovative Morgans, Paramount and Royalton hotels. When the American Radiator Building came up for sale in 1998, he bought it.
The Bryant Park, designed by David Chipperfield Architects of London, is to be the first in the new Philips Hotel Group, which will include hotels in Miami Beach and Great Neck, N.Y. The chief operating officer is Robert P. Colombo, former senior vice president of Fairmont Hotels, in which role he managed the Plaza Hotel.
Because the Bryant Park will cater to the entertainment industry, it has a 73-seat sub-basement screening room. This was created by digging 45 feet into bedrock, a task rendered especially difficult because the water table in the vicinity is quite high, displaced by the subterranean stacks of the New York Public Library, stretching beneath Bryant Park itself, across 40th Street.
"We had to incorporate a series of pumps and all kinds of underground drainage systems in order to have a movie theater and not a swimming pool," said Constantine Fotos, the project manager. Mr. Pilevsky said the excavation contributed to the seven-month delay in opening.
IN another significant structural alteration, the passenger elevator shafts were extended the full height of the building. Originally, they ran only to 16. Passengers bound for higher floors had to transfer to another elevator. Clearly, this would not do for guests paying $500 a night.
American Standard Companies, formed by a merger in 1929 of American Radiator and the Standard Sanitary Manufacturing Company, is now based in Piscataway, N.J. But it will play a small role at the Bryant Park. Guest bathrooms have custom-designed sinks made in Italy by Ideal Standard, a division of American Standard. "It's only appropriate that they come back as an element in the building," Mr. Fotos said.
Even as Mr. Pilevsky prepares to open the Bryant Park, he said the demand for office space would make such a conversion less likely in the future. With annual office rents of $50 to $60 a square foot, he said, "it doesn't pay to make this a hotel."
When the Related Companies went to contract two years ago on Guardian Life, it envisioned condominium apartments, said Jeff T. Blau, the president. But it concluded that a hotel would be the best use for the property and brought in Starwood, a giant whose brands include Sheraton, Westin and W, a two-year-old business boutique line.
Related paid $45 million for the 20-story landmark tower at Park Avenue South and 17th Street and an adjacent, modern three-story annex, which it has since net leased to MarchFirst, an Internet company. Guardian moved to 7 Hanover Square in 1999.
Under the $100 million makeover of the Union Square building, the ground-floor interiors are being recreated with offbeat touches like topiary columns that change seasonally and a front desk covered in grass. "Our concept was to try to pull the park into the lobby," said Edmond Bakos, a principal at the Rockwell Group, which is designing the renovation with Brennan Beer Gorman and the Starwood Design Group.
Some spaces were too good to alter. On the second floor is an imposing hall, two stories high, 66 feet long and 35 feet wide, where the public once bought insurance. It is to become the ballroom of the W. "What's better designed for a hotel?" asked Brad Wilson, the general manager. "It's exactly how you'd program a hotel, but with details that you could never afford to put in."
These details include decorative ligatures with the initials GLIC; not for Guardian Life but for the Germania Life Insurance Company, which built the tower as its headquarters in 1911, to designs by D'Oench & Yost. (The company renamed itself Guardian in 1917 -- "Germania" was not exactly a public-relations plus during World War I -- but, of course, it did not have to change any of the ornamental initials.)
The grand hall, which served as the company cafeteria in recent years, is ringed by a dozen richly veined marble pilasters and columns, as thick as oak trees, under a deeply coffered ceiling with 105 wreath-encircled light fixtures. "The room just screams, 'Wedding,' " Mr. Wilson said, both to parents who want the soigne ambiance of the Pierre and to young couples looking for a slightly hipper locale.
The preservation of the ballroom's clear span posed a challenge to the designers, since the new risers serving the floors above had to be redirected around the space. Apart from that, the guest rooms generally fit well into the existing tower. "It wasn't a perfect layout but it was a lot easier than we thought it would be," said Guy Hensley, the vice president of operations for W Hotels.
The conversion got off on the wrong foot in January with preservation-minded neighbors when crews began dismantling the red neon sign atop the four-story mansard roof without the city's permission. The work was halted for a time, leaving a truncated version -- "Guardian Li " -- on the skyline.
The Landmarks Preservation Commission later approved a plan to replace the sign with one reading "W Union Square" in the same size, color and typeface. "The proposed signage change, essentially a substitution of one corporate name for another, would not alter the character of the building," the commission concluded.
Jonathan M. Tisch, president and chief executive of Loews Hotels, faced a similar issue with the 27-foot-high sign atop the PSFS tower at Market and 12th Streets, two blocks east of Philadelphia's City Hall.
For about a week, there was discussion of projecting the Loews name at night in silhouette behind the existing letters. But that idea was scrapped. "I said, 'No, it's not worth tampering with an icon on the Philadelphia skyline,' " Mr. Tisch recalled.
His judgment was vindicated at the news conference with Mayor Edward G. Rendell in 1997 when the project was announced. With hundreds of jobs and tens of millions of dollars involved, the first question from the press corps was, What's happening to the sign? "I was very proud to say, 'We're leaving it alone,' " Mr. Tisch said.
That philosophy carried over to the rest of the project, in which the bank's most memorable public interiors were restored, beginning with an entrance hall off Market Street, almost 50 feet high, where a monumental flight of stairs and pair of escalators rise up to what was the main banking room. The walls are vast expanses of Belgian black and Bardiglio gray marble, unornamented by anything but a thin, four-foot metal ring that serves as a clock. The temptation for almost any hotelier would have been to lighten and brighten this austere space. But Mr. Tisch told the designers, "Anybody who touches this hallway is off the job."
"All you can do by tinkering is something that isn't appropriate," he said. "Philadelphians truly have a sense of ownership of PSFS. It was incumbent upon us to recognize that bond."
In fact, the chief architect of the restoration and renovation, Arthur W. Jones of Bower Lewis Thrower, can trace his family's connection to the site even farther back than the bank tower. His father attended the William Penn Charter School, which the PSFS Building replaced.
The Philadelphia Saving Fund Society, founded in 1816, was America's first savings bank. There was nothing traditional, however, about the building it commissioned in 1929 from the architects George Howe and William Lescaze, whose own startlingly modernist town house at 211 East 48th Street is a New York City landmark.
To contemporary eyes, the PSFS Building looks as if it had been built in the 1960's, with its strongly expressed grid of limestone columns and brick spandrels framing ribbons of glass and aluminum. The design was so innovative that in 1932, before construction was even finished, Henry-Russell Hitchcock and Philip Johnson included the tower in their enormously influential exhibition, "The International Style: Architecture Since 1922," at the Museum of Modern Art.
Turning their backs on Greek temples and Florentine palazzi, Mr. Howe and Mr. Lescaze created rooms of intersecting, asymmetrical planes polished to a highly reflective gleam. The stark lines and somber monotone of black, gray, silver and white were broken by surprising accents: red ceiling panels, blue tile floors and curving mezzanine walls made of a golden yellow French marble as savory as an omelet. In the 33rd-floor board room, the view toward the statue of William Penn atop City Hall was framed by one wall of Macassar ebony and another of book-matched walnut.
"This building has such richness in its concept," Mr. Jones said. "It's been like getting to know Beethoven."
All the tower's attributes could not save it from economic obsolescence, however. By 1992, it was 85 percent vacant. (And PSFS, after a troubled turn as the Meritor Savings Bank, had been acquired by the Mellon Bank Corporation from the F.D.I.C.)
What changed its prospects was the opening in 1994 of the Pennsylvania Convention Center just across Market Street. That turned a marginal office location into a prime spot for a hotel. The conversion project was begun by the developer Ronald Rubin of the Rubin Organization, who first approached Hyatt Hotels and then Loews, which later bought out his interest.
The PSFS Building did not have nearly enough of the meeting and mechanical space needed in a modern hotel, and there was no way to shoehorn it in. A rooftop cooling tower, for example, would have compromised the sign, which serves as a screen for the existing equipment.
FORTUNATELY, there was a large parcel adjoining the PSFS tower, which the Rubin Organization and Loews bought from the F.D.I.C. for the purpose of building a four-story hotel annex, with ballrooms, mechanical equipment, truck bays and offices. "Having that piece of land made this whole thing work," said Robert M. Powers of Powers & Company, an architectural preservation firm involved in the project.
As it happened, the quality that made the tower floors less desirable for office tenants -- a narrow, 60-foot span -- yielded an almost ideal hotel layout, with rooms along either side of a central corridor.
In the guest rooms, as in the new restaurant and lobby, the interiors firm of Daroff Design borrowed from the more exuberant and ornamental Art Deco vocabulary.
"Our first instinct was to stay with the minimal design of the International style but we did need to soften it," said Karen Daroff, president of Daroff Design. "We took almost a cinematic approach, using Hollywood's view of the 20's and 30's, juxtaposed with the abstract geometry."
The hotel opened in April, housed the Florida delegation during the Republican convention and is now running at about 65 percent occupancy, which is as expected six months into operation, Mr. Tisch said.
Three blocks from the Loews Philadelphia, the Girard Trust Company banking hall and tower by McKim, Mead & White, are now a 330-room Ritz-Carlton. In New York, another landmark in which McKim, Mead & White had a hand, the former Merchants' Exchange and National City Bank at 55 Wall Street, has reopened as the 144-room Regent Wall Street.
In Chicago, the Reliance Building, a crystalline tower by D. H. Burnham & Company, is now the 122-room Hotel Burnham, operated by the Kimpton Hotel and Restaurant Group. Kimpton plans to convert the former Tariff Commission headquarters in downtown Washington, an antebellum marble temple, into the 172-room Hotel Monaco.
Tom LaTour, the president of Kimpton, said the conversion of derelict landmarks makes economic sense. "If the building is empty or in disrepair or underutilized," he said, "implicit is that it can be acquired at below-market or advantageous costs, which allows you to do a few extras that you wouldn't otherwise do in a new enterprise. We think more and more that people who travel want to have a unique experience."

LENGTH: 883 words

HEADLINE: ART;
Rise, Fall and Rise of Glassmaking

BYLINE: By FRED B. ADELSON

DATELINE: MILLVILLE

 BODY:
WITH automation, the World Wars, the Great Depression and the rise of plastics, the 20th century was almost the worst of times for glassmaking. However, over the past few decades, glass has enjoyed a renaissance. Now it seems like the best of times. Gay LeCleire Taylor, the curator of the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Village here, has organized an exhibit surveying American glass since 1900
The exhibit illustrates the most significant developments that have affected glass during the 20th century. Ms. Taylor stated that over the past 100 years glassmaking "has undergone dramatic changes in style and production methods." This thoughtful tribute to American ingenuity and creativity weaves together technology, aesthetics and economics. 
 Star treatment is awarded to a "Blue Daffodil" leaded glass and bronze table lamp made around 1900 by Tiffany Studios and a "Venetian Series" vase, which was designed by Dale Chihuly and made by Lino Tagliapietra at Wheaton Village in 1991. Louis Comfort Tiffany and Mr. Chihuly are, indeed, the most recognized names in American glass.
Since Tiffany opens the 20th century and Mr. Chihuly closes it, these pieces are the exhibition's benchmarks, each presented in its own free-standing showcase. The other pieces are arranged chronologically by decades.
In spite of the years that separate Tiffany and Mr. Chihuly, they make an interesting and complementary pair. Both artists have been inspired directly by nature. Tiffany was a designer, not a glassblower. Assistants executed his decorative concepts. Since a car accident in the 1970's, Mr. Chihuly no longer blows glass; he directs others to bring his expressive drawings to fruition.
When Michael Owens invented the bottle-blowing machine in 1903, it was a critical turning point for the glass industry, especially in South Jersey. The machine could make 16 bottles per minute. This eliminated the need for skilled glassblowers and the opportunity for workers to make end-of-workday decorative glass as a personal diversion. The industry went into a slump.
But then Pyrex was patented on May 27, 1919. This heat-resistant glass dramatically changed the way Americans cooked. One of the earliest dishes made of Pyrex by the Corning Glass Company is displayed. An iron with a Pyrex body that dates from the early 1940's looks like a handsome ice sculpture. Offered for sale in a choice of three shades, this red iron was the most popular. Ms. Taylor admitted that she could not resist plugging it in to see if it heated up. It did.
During the 1930's and 40's, the glass industry continued to struggle, but some manufacturers used innovative modernist designs to attract consumers. The decanter from the Ruba Rombic line, which was designed by Reuben Haley, epitomizes the spirit of Art Deco. This faceted and angular yellow (marketed as "sunshine") glass bottle with its elaborate stopper looks like something from a Cubist still life. Representing a different modernist aesthetic, the ivory-colored cremation urn is fashioned from Carrara Glass, which was developed as a building material. Its stark geometry, smooth surface and lack of ornamentation suggest a strong Bauhaus influence. These memorial urns were advertised as "everlastingly beautiful."
Studio glass artists began to emerge in the late 50's and early 60's. Frances and Michael Higgins created stylish accessories, like the "Barbaric Jewels Ashtray." It is easy to imagine this object sitting on an amoeba-shaped coffee table in a living room with pleated, fiberglass drapes. Harvey Littleton, a former ceramist, helped to inaugurate the studio glass movement with the creation of his expressionist-likevases that could be made in the newly engineered furnaces fit in an artist's studio.
By the early 1970's, a few pioneering dealers, like Sally Hansen, Ferdinand Hampson and Douglas Heller, began to sell contemporary art glass to an emergent group of collectors, affirming that glass had become an artist's medium.
At the same time, glass entered the museum world. The first public institution dedicated to glass is the Corning Museum of Glass, established in 1951. The museum houses the world's most comprehensive collection of glass objects, dating back to ancient Egypt. In 1973, the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Village was founded. With approximately 12,000 works of industrial and studio art glass, it is the largest museum devoted to American glass in the country.
One of the most recent objects on display is the "Millennium Champagne Flute," a production piece made by Durand International in Millville. With its molded stem that is a vertical arrangement of "2000," this commemorative item became an immediate commercial success and brought a flurry of manufacturing activity back to the sputtering local glass industry.
There have certainly been major changes in the world of glass since 1904, when Carl Sandburg wrote: "Down in southern New Jersey, they make glass. By day and by night, the fires burn on in Millville." This exhibition demonstrates that "glass continues to enrich and enhance our everyday lives."
 
AMERICAN GLASS:
1990-2000

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
Word of Warning on Camden From Someone Who Knows

BYLINE: By Iver Peterson; Iver Peterson reports from New Jersey for The New York Times.

DATELINE: CAMDEN

 BODY:
It has been 10 years since Randy Primas left office, but the people up in Trenton still call him from time to time. They ask him what it was like when he was mayor here, what he thinks they should do now that the city is prostrate once again, and what the chances are for the state's most desperate city to recover some semblance of prosperity.
Melvin R. Primas was the mayor of Camden from 1981 to 1999, but he was more than just that. As the man who followed Angelo J. Errichetti into office -- Mr. Errichetti, you'll remember, was on his way to prison for corruption -- and having been followed by two mayors who were subsequently indicted, Mr. Primas is known around Trenton as the last good mayor of a city that sorely needed one. 
 Mr. Primas will no doubt be called on to talk some more about Camden this fall, when the State Legislature goes back into session and its members take their first hard look at the Whitman Administration's Municipal Rehabilitation and Economic Revitalization Act, also known as the Camden takeover bill for the power it gives the state to assume full authority over the elected and administrative powers of the city.
What will he tell them? First, that the problems of Camden have been a long time coming, and could be seen clearly 19 years ago when, as a new mayor, he began forecasting the city's yawning budget deficit into the future. Two, that the state's most lamented but politically inviolate system of financing schools and municipal administrations with real estate taxes will never raise enough money to make a poor city like Camden self-sufficient. And third, that the crisis of Camden is not going to be Mrs. Whitman's problem much longer, and that the people jockeying to be elected governor next fall should be thinking about their policies for cities like Camden sooner rather than later.
"The key was that we were able to sit down with the people in Trenton and to make a case for our problems," Mr. Primas, who is now an investment banker, said in an interview. "As soon as I got into office, we projected out our budget deficit four, five, six years, and we could show them that the need for aid was going to increase exponentially over the next 10 years. It wasn't at 80 percent of the budget then, but we showed that it was going to be."
The reason for Camden's crash are by now familiar: the big factories moved out and the middle-income people followed. Today, every census tract in the city qualifies for federal poverty programs. Harder to understand is why it has stayed so poor while at the same time Jersey City, Hoboken, Newark and Trenton have shown some improvement during the long boom years. If the curious legislators ask Mr. Primas that, he will tell them to look across the Delaware from the Camden's waterfront.
"The Philadelphia economy never heated up the way New York City's did," Mr. Primas said. Without a sharp difference in real estate costs between the city and its neighbor, Philadelphia never spun off the millions in new office development that has transformed the once decaying Hudson River waterfront across from Manhattan into a new urban landscape.
Milton Milan, the current mayor of Camden, has complained to anyone who will listen that the city needs help with economic development before it can pay its own bills. But since Mr. Milan is also under indictment for selling his office, his pleas have tended to be dismissed. But ask Mr. Primas, and he will tell the legislators the same thing: Just plugging the budget gap is not enough.
"As I look back on it, I realize that we managed to fill the gap but we never had the extra dollars to set the stage for growth," he said. "Every year we were holding on by our fingernails and getting just enough money to get through the year, and that's tough. That's tough. You never see any discretionary dollars and you never get a chance to set the stage for development."
That is the second message to the Legislature: Will the takeover prescription simply mean another decade of giving Camden just enough to scrape by, or will there be the enough additional money to allow the city to invest and blossom? The state has already poured millions into the city, of course, and new roads -- the Entertainment Center and the state aquarium are all evidence of that. But as Mr. Primas pointed out, what the city needs is employers with good jobs.
"Ronald Reagan was president during my tenure," Mr. Primas went on, "and he pointed to Cherry Hill as a community that worked, that didn't need any federal help. And I thought to myself, there we are two miles away, one of the poorest cities in America and one that can't survive without help."
Reformers in New Jersey have complained for years that the reliance on local real estate taxes -- the kind that Cherry Hill is rich in and that Camden lacks -- is unfair to children who attend underfinanced schools. And as Mr. Primas points out, it is unfair to municipalities that are kept in a continual straitjacket of low revenue while being urged by their suburban neighbors to do more for themselves.
There is a good argument over urban policy in all of those issues. Will the legislators and the candidates listen?

HEADLINE: The Slide Into Poverty

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Working Harder, Longer," by Bob Herbert (column, Sept. 4): 
 I was glad to see Mr. Herbert raise the issues of indebtedness and the invisibility of the poor in discussing the status of working Americans. What are working Americans using their credit cards for: food, junk or e-trades? How often do we see TV programs giving people tips on how to handle credit more carefully? Is there a connection between credit-card debt and the 19 percent of children who live below the poverty line?
If America's booming economy depends on people's using consumer credit beyond their means, thus creating poverty, do we really have a healthy economy?
Let's ask Al Gore and George W. Bush.
 
BARBARA COMMINS
San Francisco, Sept. 4, 2000

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: OFF THE SHELF;
The Human Side of a Hedge Fund's Tumble

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES; Diana B. Henriques, a financial writer at The Times, is the author, most recently, of "The White Sharks of Wall Street: Thomas Mellon Evans and the Original Corporate Raiders," a business history published by Lisa Drew Books, an imprint of Scribners.

 BODY:
ON Aug. 21, 1998, a little-known investment partnership in Greenwich, Conn., lost $553 million. The loss on that single sunny Friday left the behemoth fund with $2.9 billion in capital, down from $4.67 billion just months earlier.
The fund, of course, was Long-Term Capital Management, which was born in the brain of an enigmatic Wall Street bond trader named John W. Meriwether. By September 1998, with world markets already roiled by a Russian bond default, the enormous fund was teetering at the edge of failure, with many of the world's biggest banks and brokerage houses shackled to it by countless links of leverage. 
 If the hedge fund failed, who else would be pulled down with it? And how would a market already nearing the thin edge of panic react? Faced with those questions -- and with the impossibility of receiving reliable answers in the time available -- the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York called the fund's top creditors, the chieftains of Wall Street, to an emergency meeting at which they ultimately agreed to bail out the fund with fresh capital.
That dramatic and still controversial rescue, and the events that let up to it, are the threads that Roger Lowenstein weaves into "When Genius Failed: The Rise and Fall of Long-Term Capital Management" (Random House, $26.95). This richly textured and lucid account is not the first book to try to parse the secrecy that shrouded those events. "Inventing Money: The Story of Long-Term Capital and the Legends Behind It," by Nicholas Dunbar (Wiley & Sons), added a wealth of financial history and market theory to the core story.
But Mr. Lowenstein, a former Wall Street Journal reporter, has taken a completely different path, examining the events primarily through the prism of human nature. The results are a riveting account that reaches beyond the market landscape to say something universal about risk and triumph, about hubris and failure.
Central to the story is Mr. Meriwether himself, an accountant's son who grew up in a close-knit neighborhood in Chicago. An honor student with a mathematical bent, he parlayed his passion for golf into a college scholarship. Even as a teenager, he was an avid but cautious gambler, holding his cards -- and his ambitions -- close to his chest.
After college, he taught high school mathematics for a year, then enrolled in the University of Chicago's business school, working his way through as an analyst for a large insurer. In 1974, at 27, he was hired by Salomon Brothers, one of the leading bond-trading houses on the Street. Three years later, after making millions for the firm speculating on government and municipal bonds, he formed the arbitrage group, which used Salomon's own capital to exploit tiny disparities in bond prices.
To help him find these opportunities, he recruited a band of mathematical scholars, young academics whose awesome intelligence gave Mr. Meriwether the edge he sought in the increasingly competitive markets. The group was remarkably isolated from the rest of Salomon Brothers, and Mr. Meriwether protected them from even the normal human interaction of the workplace. "The professors were brilliant at reducing a trade to pluses and minuses; they could strip a ham sandwich to its component risks; but they could barely carry on a normal conversation," Mr. Lowenstein says.
They were a remarkable band, and most of them became permanent acolytes at Mr. Meriwether's altar, following him at every step of his career: Eric Rosenfeld, an M.I.T.-trained assistant professor at the Harvard Business School; Victor J. Haghani, a graduate of the London School of Economics; and the rigidly rational Lawrence Hilibrand, who has two degrees from M.I.T. Mr. Meriwether left Salomon Brothers after a brush with scandal -- he was the supervisor of a trader caught manipulating Treasury securities. He then started his own hedge-fund replica of the arbitrage group, adding three high priests of finance: Robert C. Merton and Myron S. Scholes, Nobel laureates for work relating to options pricing, and David W. Mullins Jr., who had been vice chairman of the Federal Reserve.
These men all possessed an unswerving faith in the notion that markets are fundamentally rational and efficient, and that every price generated in that marketplace is the correct one. Among economists, this so-called efficient market theory is just that, a theory, reflecting a Platonic ideal of the marketplace. Moreover, the theory assumes that trading in any market is more or less continuous and that prices move smoothly from one level to the next nearest level, giving everyone a chance to adjust portfolios rationally to reflect the changes.
Through Mr. Lowenstein's compassionate eye, we watch as these fascinating coddled geniuses discover what any dedicated flea-market shopper already knows: in real life, people buy and sell things for reasons entirely unconnected to rationality. As he notes, the mathematical laws governing a coin toss rest on the fact that "the coin doesn't remember that it landed on tails three times in a row; the odds on the fourth flip are still 50-50."
"But markets have memories," he says. "Sometimes a trend will continue just because traders expect (or fear) that it will."
He adds: "After three bad 'flips' in the market, the fourth flip may no longer be completely random. Some traders may have taken losses and be forced to sell; other investors, looking over their shoulders, may panic and decide to beat them to it."
And that is pretty much what happened in the galloping climax to the Long-Term Capital story. "The partners believed that, over time, investors would become more rational, more steady, more efficient -- more like they were," Mr. Lowenstein concludes. Instead, as the story unfolds, Mr. Meriwether's brilliant followers became more irrational, greedier, more oblivious to their own flaws -- in short, more like the rest of us.

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: COPING;
My Kid's Never Bad and Other Sandbox Tales

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE

 BODY:
MY son and I were playing in Riverside Park, reveling in the sunshine and the green, when a shriek rang out. From the corner of my eye I saw a mother in distress, muttering wildly. She had grabbed her toddler and bent down to admonish a small boy of maybe 3.
"No meat," she was saying to the child, her voice quavering and loud. "She doesn't eat meat. You cannot, cannot give her meat." 
 As my heart rate turned to normal after listening to her screams, I quickly assessed the situation.
The two toddlers had been playing. The little boy had given the little girl a piece of his hamburger, perhaps in a courtly gesture of friendship. Big mistake. This mommy and this baby could not, would not, should not eat meat.
Somebody on the park bench, presumably an acquaintance, murmured something about their being a family of committed vegetarians.
The little boy's chagrined and red-faced mother silently walked over and took his hand. The two women exchanged not a word. The evil meat was wrested from the hand of the tiny vegetarian. She looked about 2 years old and seemed none the worse for her ordeal.
I call it "the hover factor." In New York, especially Manhattan, people often monitor and maneuver so many aspects of their children's lives that it becomes ridiculous. And nowhere is this neurosis more apparent than on the playground, when children are thrown together with strangers from many different backgrounds.
Think of the possibilities for intrigue and confrontation. The sand in the face. The errant softball. The tricycles, dolls and play strollers to be fought over. The jockeying for the swings or the slide. The lures of forbidden food and drink.
Most parents and their children operate with a certain kindness and live-and-let-live atttitude. But I have seen or heard tales of parents' chasing children who casually picked up a toy belonging to their child. Or parents who chastise children whose parents or caretakers are nearby but are outraged by the suggestion that their child is misbehaving.
These superparents, among the many irritations of city life, are back in full force after the summer lull, fretting simultaneously about private school acceptances and the ownership of Elmo dolls.
"I think people do get overinvolved," said my friend Anne, a novelist, the mother of a 2-year-old boy and a 5-year-old girl and a veteran of playgrounds around the city.
"There are these overprotective Manhattan parents who think of their kids as gods or goddesses and don't even see other children," Anne said. "It's very ideological. It's like joining an intense sect. Everyone has their own ideas about discipline and sharing and diet. So there's no agreement on what playground etiquette is.
"I think in New York kids become a fetish object," she said. "I think parents want to give their children the perfect childhood: no missing toys, no accidents, no hitting."
The other day, I saw a father bark at a toddler who curiously approached his child's empty carriage. Then there was the time when a father stood by silently when a boy of 9 or 10 repeatedly shouted that my 2-year-old was trying to steal his bike. When the boy asked his father if he had overreacted, when he realized that I was right there telling my son not to touch the bike, the father replied, "I don't know."
"I'd say it's split 50-50 between people trying to teach their kids to be nice and people who are hovering, overprotective and nasty," said my friend Lisa. She lives in Inwood and her daughter will be 3 in January.
"A little boy hit my daughter in the head with a book and took away the book she was reading," Lisa recalled of a recent incident on the Upper West Side. "I said, 'I'm sure he didn't mean to hurt you, sweetie.' His father came marching over and said, 'Of course he didn't mean to hurt her,' and picked him up and walked away."
"I think children are trophies," Lisa said. "They're not children anymore.
"I call it the 'have it all syndrome.' It's all about, 'I had my career and now I have a child, too.' "
It is children as trophies and fetish objects, but it is also just old-fashioned stress.
Studies are trickling in showing what a lot of us already know: the price for the robust economy is that people are working like dogs. They are spending it as fast as they make it, they do not have enough time with their families and they still want everything to be perfect. So even an outing on the swings becomes a situation of watching and worrying.
Maybe in a gentler time, the clash between the meat family and the vegetable family would have been at a lower volume. The two mothers could have used the opportunity to talk about differences and how to say, "No thank you."
What a thought. A playground without attitude.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Those Raises, Adjusted for Oil Inflation, Are a Mirage

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
HARDLY any description of the booming economy fails to include this upbeat observation: Wages have been rising faster than inflation for most workers since January 1996. The boom has lifted all boats, and that is its great social gift.
But this year, hardly noticed until now, the lifting stopped. Wages are still rising, but no longer faster than inflation. 
 That is a troubling development. Nothing has seemed more important in the economic boom than the wage gains it has conferred. High-end workers, those earning more than $80,000 a year, always gain ground. But the pay of nearly everyone else went nowhere for a quarter-century, until the rising prosperity of the 1990's -- and a falling unemployment rate -- finally brought relief.
Wages have risen 3 to 5 percent a year since 1996, with the precise figure depending on the measure used -- average wages, median wages, hourly wages -- and the particular group of workers measured. The $7-an-hour worker has done as well as those earning $18 or $25. And even now, these "nominal" wages, unadjusted for inflation, continue to rise at a fairly steady pace, according to Labor Department data tabulated by the Economic Policy Institute.
The problem is inflation. A dollar's worth of nominal wages does not buy as much when prices rise. Inflation must be subtracted to know the "real" rate of wage growth. A 4 percent nominal raise becomes no raise at all if inflation is also 4 percent. And that is roughly what has happened. The Consumer Price Index, which rose less than 2 percent a year in 1997 and 1998, is now climbing at an annual rate of more than 3.5 percent, nullifying all or most of this year's wage gains.
"There is no question that you have had constant nominal wage growth, yet slowing real wage growth, which over the last two quarters has been just about flat," said Jared Bernstein, an economist at the Economic Policy Institute.
The oil shock is the culprit, and there is hope that it will end soon, with OPEC increasing production enough to bring down the prices of heating oil, gasoline and aviation fuel, and with them the inflation rate. The decision to step up output could even come this weekend at a conference in Vienna. But the oil crisis is in its second year, and an earlier production increase didn't pull prices down.
If inflation sustains its present pace, American workers will be in a bind. Either they must agitate for bigger nominal wage increases -- making better use of the leverage they have from a very low unemployment rate -- or they will have to accept that the longest economic expansion in American history has lost its lifting power for them. "We are at a moment of testing," said Peter Hooper, chief domestic economist for Deutsche Bank North America.
MANY forecasters and Wall Street economists argue that the necessary bargaining power is still there. If the inflation rate stays up, workers will indeed start to fight for raises large enough to keep ahead of inflation or, failing that, they will jump to jobs that pay more. The struggle has not begun yet, this argument goes, because most people believe that inflation in the longer run will subside to less than 3 percent, and nominal wage gains will turn back into real ones.
Such thinking ignores accumulating evidence that American workers are more passive than in the past, and much less able, when inflation erodes their wages, to take advantage of market demand for their services. A host of reasons are cited: globalization, job insecurity, the decline in union membership, mass extinctions of higher-paying factory jobs, an influx of low-wage immigrants, companies that are quick to relocate to lower-wage regions, the disappearance of cost-of-living adjustments. The list continues, with two new observations.
The 86,000 workers who struck Verizon so effectively last month settled for a 12.5 percent wage increase over three years, plus less tangible stock options and profit sharing. Many nonunion workers have been getting similar wage increases since 1996.
And the old corporate practice of splitting productivity gains with employees -- often at the insistence of unions -- is fading. Labor productivity has been rising more rapidly over the last two years, meaning that workers generate more revenue and income for their companies. But the fruits have gone mainly into profits, not wages. Corporate profits rose in the second quarter to 9.7 percent of gross domestic product, from 9.34 percent in the fourth quarter last year.
"Workers have not yet recognized the extent to which their rising productivity has not yet been matched by increases in nominal wages," Mr. Hooper said.
The great concern, in sum, is that the lift for wage earners from the booming economy is fading, and in danger of disappearing entirely if the oil shock lasts.

HEADLINE: How an Unpretentious Family Car, the Passat, Got So Hot

BYLINE: By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
FAMILY sedans generate big sales, but seldom do they create a buzz. The Volkswagen Passat, however, has gained most-wanted status, thanks to glowing reviews from automotive writers, high ratings from consumer publications and positive word-of-mouth among owners.
In the last year, Consumer Reports has given high ratings to the Passat. In its July issue, the magazine rated the Passat GLS
V-6 first among midsized sedans, over the Toyota Camry, Nissan Maxima and Honda Accord. The magazine had previously ranked the four-cylinder Passat above comparable models. 
 A top ranking from Consumer Reports, or even its more common "recommended" rating, is coveted, given that many car shoppers come to dealerships clutching copies of the magazine's reports, which some regard as gospel; some auto marketing executives have estimated that its recommendation can result in 25,000 added sales.
The Passat has also received uniformly favorable notices in enthusiast magazines and newspaper reviews, and it has won industry awards. This summer, for instance, J. D. Power & Associates named it the "most appealing family car."
As a result, Passat sales are soaring, setting records for much of the year. And if sales continue at the torrid first-half pace, VW is likely to sell nearly 90,000 Passats in 2000, well above last year's record of 68,151, said Tony Fouladpour, a spokesman for VW. The Northeast is a particularly hot market, accounting for 15 percent of Passat sales nationwide, Mr. Fouladpour said.
The car is attracting interest among consumers who might never have considered VW's lineup before. In Grand Rapids, Mich., buyers often arrived at Betten Imports with copies of Consumer Reports in hand, said the former sales manager, Jeff Leckta. Used to selling Volkswagens to repeat customers, he said, "I've seen people in here that I've never seen before." Several recent buyers traded Camrys for Passats.
He and other salespeople complain about a lack of cars to sell. As early as May, some dealers were telling shoppers that if they wanted a Passat, they would have to order a 2001 model, due in October.
The car's popularity means that VW has not offered special lease deals, discount financing or rebates, although the Passat is priced above its rivals. The base GLS is $21,725, compared with $18,980 for a Honda Accord LX and $20,843 for a Toyota Camry LE. The Passat GLS V-6 starts at $24,325 versus the Honda Accord LX V-6 at $22,390 and the Toyota Camry LE V-6 at $22,813.
The success of the Passat, a descendent of past VW models like the Quantum and Dasher, is quite recent. The previous-generation car suffered from quality problems and boxy styling. "You had to have a real appreciation for Teutonic German design," Mr. Fouladpour said of the 1990-97 model. Sales slipped as low as 11,021 in 1994.
Everything changed with the redesigned 1998 model, whose roofline is a graceful arc that mimics the look of the New Beetle. The restyled Passat has won praise for its interior comfort, adept handling and responsive engine. Many of its parts are shared with the more expensive Audi A4 and A6.
Fans include Ron Pinelli, founder of the Autodata Corporation, a statistics and marketing firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J. This year, he bought a silver GLS with a turbocharged four-cylinder engine and promptly spent another $3,000 for custom wheels.
"Accord and Camry are wonderful products, but the Passat has more passion behind it," Mr. Pinelli said. He said the Passat's popularity was a symbol of VW's sales comeback in the United States. "It wasn't many years ago that VW was basically out of business in this country."
Passat has brought Volkswagen a sought-after group of buyers. Their average age is 38, compared with 43 for the last Passat. More are women: 43 percent, compared with 38 percent previously. And their household income tops $83,000, up $13,000. Three-quarters are college-educated, compared with two-thirds for the previous car.
Many auto companies would put on a full press to attract additional buyers, but VW's goal is eventually to sell 100,000 Passats a year in the United States. Mr. Fouladpour said VW could not hope to steal more business from the Accord and Camry, which each have more than 400,000 sales annually, because of production constraints and a relatively small network of dealers.
And VW insists that the Passat, with its decidedly German ride and handling characteristics, was never intended to appeal to the mass American market.
"It's still not a car for everybody," Mr. Fouladpour said. "It has a personality that attracts a certain type of buyer. Toyota and Honda do vanilla and bland better than everyone else. We intend to be a wakeup call."

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for BOB WRIGHT;
Going Not for the Gold, But for the Cachet

BYLINE: By BILL CARTER

 BODY:
BOB WRIGHT, the president of NBC, is wrapping up a few last-minute details stateside this week before he heads off with about 800 of NBC's biggest advertising clients for Sydney, Australia, and his network's biggest production of 2000, the Summer Olympics.
With agreements to broadcast the Games in the United States for every Olympiad through 2008 -- a total of five -- NBC has become the network of the Olympics. 
 Mr. Wright said he would be spending a chunk of his time in Sydney Harbor, aboard the same ocean liner the network took to Barcelona in 1992 to wine and dine the biggest commercial spenders.
He said he was increasingly confident that the 2000 Games, even at a fee of $705 million for American television rights, would prove to be an unqualified success, at least in programming if not quite in profits. Following are excepts from a phone conversation on Friday.
 BILL CARTER
 
Q. How did the advertising industry respond for this Olympics, in light of the bribery scandals at the International Olympic Committee?
 
A. That was certainly a concern to us but it does not seem to have affected any business issues. The I.O.C. handled it as best they could. They made a conscientious effort to clean things up and get the bad guys out. We hit our target in advertising sales of $900 million. This was a situation, when we went into those Olympic deals, where we hoped to enhance NBC's reputation and not lose too much money. We hit very good economic circumstances, which we were counting on. So this is not a money-losing situation for us this year. But it's not going to be much of a profit center.
 
Q. Will this year's coverage differ much from previous Olympics?
 
A. The biggest programming difference is 279 hours of Olympic programming on our cable networks, CNBC and MSNBC. There will be a total of 70 hours on the network. The cable exposure presents opportunities for other sports, especially for a lot of team sports that have never been seen, like soccer and softball. We're also going to have a full program of boxing on CNBC, starting every night at 5 p.m.
 
Q. You were able to use the Olympic coverage on cable in negotiations to extend your agreements with cable operators for your cable channels. How significant are these new deals?
 
A. We have been very interested in extending our carriage agreements with cable operators, and the Olympics were certainly an important part of that. We've used everything to gain the extensions, including retransmission consent agreements and some opportunities for improvements on the digital side when we reach that stage. Many cable operators were interested in extending through the end of our Olympic commitments in 2008 and some of them even went beyond that, to 2012. It means that CNBC and MSNBC are guaranteed carriage in the U.S. to a point as far off as 2012, That's enormously significant for us.
And by the time we get to the Salt Lake City Games in 2002, the distribution for MSNBC will expand from 62 million homes to about 70 million, another very significant advance. The biggest television stations we own have always taken great advantage of Olympics years. Between the Olympics and the political advertising this year, it will be the biggest financial year ever for the stations we own.
 
Q. You have committed almost $3 billion more for the rights to the Games in 2002, 2004, 2006 and 2008. Given that, how crucial is it that you perform well in ratings from Sydney?
 
A. Our performance in Sydney is very crucial. If some tragedy were to strike and we put up terrible numbers, it would certainly impact us negatively. But having said that, the reality is that Salt Lake City, as a domestic Olympics, stands on its own, has a cachet all its own. The impact of whatever happens in Sydney will be felt on Athens in 2004. But I'm confident we're going to do very well.
 
Q. Much has been made of how big events, like "Survivor" on CBS, have helped bring viewers back to the networks. Does having the guarantee of an Olympics every two years provide NBC with a built-in advantage?
 
A. It's important that we are able to say that we are the Olympic network, and we can keep on displaying those rings as part of our identity. Those rings have great recognition. That was a really important factor in helping us decide to take on this economic obligation. There is a debate about how valuable events like this are as promotional vehicles for future programming. It is hard to assess their promotional value, especially in the fall when the baseball playoffs will cause a lot of disruption of schedules. But the ability to have the most-watched programming to display your new shows is clearly a benefit. And we're already setting up for Salt Lake City. Those Games start only 13 months after we leave Sydney.

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH: Rajeev Bhaman;
Oppenheimer Developing Markets Fund

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
RAJEEV BHAMAN was born in Bombay, has lived in England and was educated in the United States. As a teenager, he traveled the world with his father, the captain of a cargo ship. So he is not fazed by the travel required in his job, running the $170.8 million Oppenheimer Developing Markets fund.
"I find it exhilarating," Mr. Bhaman said recently from his office in the World Trade Center in Manhattan. "Exploring the differences and similarities among cultures, new places and new ideas is like being a detective. I'm sort of like Carmen San Diego." He has managed the fund since its inception in November 1996. 
 His travels have paid off for the fund's investors. The fund returned 11.88 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Sept. 7, putting it in first place among diversified emerging-markets funds, according to Morningstar Inc. Over all, the group had a 3.84 percent loss, annualized.
Mr. Bhaman, 36, uses a bottom-up approach to investing, looking for companies with strong growth prospects in emerging foreign markets. He screens the 15,000 companies in that universe down to 1,000 by focusing on market and industry trends that he thinks will fuel global growth over the next 20 years.
His most important theme is what he calls "mass affluence," which, he said, is grounded in the increasing consumption of brand-name, personal-care and disposable products, as well as appetites for entertainment and education. "It's incredible how quickly emerging markets have become consumer-driven economies," he added.
Two more key themes are new technologies and restructuring. "Most of Eastern Europe is a restructuring story, the transformation of unprofitable, state-owned enterprises to cash-generating, profitable companies," Mr. Bhaman said. "We think of it as a caterpillar that metamorphoses into a butterfly."
He owns a mix of value and growth stocks of all sizes in many industries around the world. The diversification helps reduce the volatility of emerging markets and other risks like currency fluctuations. The fund's prospectus says it can hedge its currency, but he said that is unnecessary for long-term investments.
His investments are concentrated in Latin America and in Asia outside Japan (36.6 percent each) and Eastern Europe (14.7 percent).
To pick the fund's 60 to 80 stocks, Mr. Bhaman uses fundamental research to find what he calls "good companies with good businesses at good prices." A good company, he said, fits one of his themes and has returns that exceed its cost of capital over the next three to five years.
A good price lets him double his money in three years, Mr. Bhaman said, or triple it in five.
Equally important is a shareholder-friendly environment. "The emerging markets are characterized by poorer shareholder protection laws than in the developed markets," he said, "and less efficient information flow."
He spends at least 25 percent of his time on international travel, he said, visiting more than 300 companies a year. He talks to local suppliers, distributors and customers to evaluate whether a company's stock price reflects what he thinks is its potential.
Many investments are in companies with operations focused on their home countries, Mr. Bhaman said, because they are generally better aligned with local consumer desires and specific cultural attributes than large multinational corporations.
He pores over financial statements, particularly focusing on a company's free cash flow, as well as its ability to generate cash in the future. He also reviews returns on equity, assets and capital.
Mr. Bhaman sells shares when they become fully valued, or when a company's fundamentals start to deteriorate.
MR. BHAMAN'S biggest holding is preferred shares of Embraer S.A., of Sao Jose dos Campos, Brazil. The company, which makes small regional jets and was formerly owned by the government, was privatized and recapitalized in 1995. He bought shares in March 1998 at 1.76 Brazilian reais, or 97 cents.
The company's growth prospects are strong, he said, because more countries are building smaller airports and need smaller airplanes. "Smaller planes are better suited for lower-volume traffic at cost-competitive prices," he said.
On Friday, shares closed at 11.9 reais, or 10.8 times his projected earnings of 1.1 per share this year.
Another favorite is Grupo Televisa, a Mexico City television broadcaster with a substantial Spanish-language publishing operation and satellite and cable TV businesses. It is also a leading supplier of Spanish-language programming to the United States.
"As the level of affluence increases, the company is well positioned to take advantage of increased advertising rates on television," he said, "and to sell programming to other parts of the world at higher prices." A recent cost-cutting program, he added, should increase profit margins.
He bought shares in July 1997 at $30. They closed on Friday on the New York Stock Exchange at $67.25 each, or 44.8 times his 2000 earnings estimate of $1.50 a share.
He also likes LG Home Shopping, the larger of two Korean home shopping networks. Although many Koreans are comfortable using the Internet, Mr. Bhaman said, "most of the people who buy are women over 30, and TV is a friendlier medium than computers for this group."
In June, he bought shares at 90,000 won ($81.42) each. On Friday, they closed at 185,500 won, or 37.1 times his 2000 earnings projection of 5,000 won a share.

HEADLINE: Righting United Airlines: Nine Flight Plans

BYLINE: By JULIE EDELSON HALPERT

 BODY:
TO say that this year has been difficult for James E. Goodwin, the chief executive of the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, would be a vast understatement. During his one-year reign, United has been hit with problems that might well sink many a company.
The trouble began in April, with the expiration of its contract with the Air Line Pilots Association. As negotiations dragged on, pilots began refusing to work overtime. In June, the union voiced opposition to UAL's planned merger with U S Airways, concerned that the deal would jeopardize jobs. 
 From May through August, United canceled 4,800 flights -- 4 percent of its total -- because of worker shortages, leaving many passengers stranded in airports for hours, sometimes days, with no easy routes to their destinations. And weather-related delays compounded the problem.
Though the airline has reached a tentative pact with its pilots, it faces another potential contract battle with the International Association of Machinists.
UAL's convoluted corporate structure has not helped matters, either. The board includes, in addition to insiders and outside executives, members chosen by union and nonunion workers. Employees gained board representation and majority stock ownership in exchange for pay cuts in a 1994 restructuring.
Since reaching a 52-week high of $79 in January, UAL's stock has plummeted; it closed at $46.63 on Friday.
What can be done to repair United? Money & Business asked nine experts who track the airline industry to offer their insights; the advice ranged from improving customer service to canceling the pending merger.
The airline's officials are scrambling to repair the damage, and some relief may be in sight. The pilots agreement is scheduled for a vote in October, and Matthew Triaca, a spokesman for the airline, said that the negotiations with the machinists union were well under way and that he expected an agreement soon on that contract, too, helping to smooth labor relations and get flights back on track.
United is also trying to win back customers with bonus frequent-flier miles. And it is banking that a dose of humility will help, too. In August, Mr. Goodwin appeared in a 30-second television commercial apologizing for United's poor service. The company has also taken out full-page ads in newspapers. "We are working hard to bring the operation back to normal and restore the confidence of our customers," Mr. Triaca said.
That is no easy task. No one envies the challenge Mr. Goodwin faces in turning around United. Here are excerpts from the experts' comments.
 
SAM BUTTRICK
Airline analyst at PaineWebber.
At the root of the problem is the simple fact that labor has excessive structural leverage.
Any union group has a large bag of tricks it can rummage through when it wants to express itself. There has been a statistically significant change in behavior with the unions, which, while consistent with the letter of the contract and letter of the law, enables labor to hold management hostage with tens of thousands of customers daily -- and that's not right.
We're very concerned by the implications that the recent tentative agreement has on cockpit crew costs. It is total capitulation by United Airlines management. I wouldn't have agreed to a contract that gave the pilots the opportunity to work overtime, but did not require them to take it on. That leaves management at the mercy of the pilots' willingness to work overtime.
At the core of all this is that labor has significant leverage over the quality of the operations. Management needs to be empowered more, to curtail job actions. Managing labor expectations is a very tricky part of running an airline.
I don't see an intractable problem with customers. Getting customers back is very easy. An airline business is a network business, and United has a terrific network. People use the airline based on its schedule and network.
If you look at the last decade of on-time performance, United has never been an on-time airline, yet its financial returns are near the top of the pack. They should have frequent-flier inducements, and as fall-season loads decline from summer peaks, we could see fall sales. They could toy around with some performance guarantees, providing frequent-flier miles for excessive flight delays or cancellations. It may be administratively tricky, but it has an intuitive appeal, providing customers remuneration for substandard operations.
If they made me C.E.O., I would call off the U S Airways merger. It's time for United to focus on getting its own act together, instead of embarking on highly risky operations with integration issues that will exceed problems that United saw this summer. I don't think they're up to the task of merging. If they can't handle their own pilots, they're not up to the task of acquiring another airline.
 
GERALD MEYERS
Professor of organizational behavior, University of Michigan Business School.
They've got multiple crises going on: industrial and human relations. None of them are easy to solve. The first one that is amenable to treatment is the public perception crisis. They realize that what customers, the public and regulators think of them requires a full-blown, singular, all-out initiative, not just something that tags onto other things. It requires a crisis team, a crisis plan.
They need training in the organization on how to deal with this and experts to help them -- an effort by itself. Included in that are crisis communications people. They should bring them in. In my view they need to look at themselves from the outside and say they're going to do better. They have to see themselves as other people see them. They're in the public service business. They need to keep customers happy.
United should drop the ESOP employee stock ownership plan, created in the restructuring six years ago . It saved the airline, but it doesn't have a future. They should let the unions see they will get their money back and return the company to the managers. You can't change the management if the unions run it. The board of directors is useless. They can't talk about cost reduction.
ESOP's have their problems, and very few are successful. It's a source of the current problems. Once the ESOP is dissolved, the anger begins to diminish and the internal stuff on who's running the company will be minimized. You will have a schedule for how the current problems will be resolved over time and make clear there is a plan to make the company profitable and distribute the wealth. United is not a backward airline. They've got awful labor relations. Once that's solved, they will run a good airline and get people happy and satisfied and excited.
 
BARBARA BEYER
President of Avmark Inc., aviation consultants.
They desperately need to rebuild their image. At this point, everybody's really mad at them, including me. I fly 30,000 to 40,000 miles a year with them. I think what they desperately need to do is have better control over delays and send their flight attendants back to charm school.
If you think about it, the airline is a public utility. The only thing that makes it different is passenger service. When it's bad, you want to go to another airline. They need to teach employees manners. They've lost sight of the service attitude.
They aren't practical about the fact that they are having delays. If there's a delay, they should take full-fare passengers off the airplane and rebook them. They need more staff at counters.
 
ROBERT ROACH Jr.
General vice president of the International Association of Machinists.
We went to a meeting called by Transportation Secretary Robert Slater, and the one thing that came out of it was that airline carriers need to better communicate with passengers.
We need to better use technology to better communicate with passengers at airports. We should advise customers about delays so the customer can't scream at an agent. Also, if a customer comes to an airport to get on an airplane and pushes employees, he should be arrested and not be allowed to fly that aircraft.
And we should make people aware of what they'll confront when they start their journey from home. There is anxiety built into flying: nervousness, packing, the fear people have of flying. The airlines need to start educating you when you buy the tickets about the delays. Expect that weather delays are possible.
Agents should make frequent announcements about reasons for delays, so people won't get mad. Today, people assume that if anything happens, it's labor's fault. That's not the case.
We are negotiating an agreement with no efforts to disrupt United. Once the contract is swiftly resolved, it eases the tension. We need to move the process very quickly and that's what we intend to do. Then there will be no unsettled labor issues and no tension between labor and management. There is not a bad group of employees creating this. The problems are built into the system.
 
PAUL HUDSON
Executive director, Aviation Consumer Action Project, an airline-passenger advocacy group.
The biggest problem is they have a credibility gap with their customers.
They have not been meeting their schedules. If you know you have no resources to make the flights, cut back the schedule. If you can't fly planes on time, change published times to be more accurate and reflect the reality.
We've petitioned the D.O.T. Department of Transportation for a truth-in-scheduling regulation. For flights that are chronically delayed, there would be mandatory disclosure of on-time statistics by fax or telephone. If most people knew the on-time statistics for a lot of these flights, they wouldn't book them. Flights delayed over 80 percent of the time would need to be scheduled accurately or wouldn't be flown. They would cancel the flight until it could be scheduled to run on time.
Lack of spare airplanes and over scheduling are the biggest reasons for chronically delayed flights, not labor disputes or equipment failures or air traffic control or weather.
They are booking more flights than airplanes and crews can handle. I also feel that the government should require mandatory reserves of airplanes and flight crews of 3 percent. They are operating with less than 1 percent now. They're expecting that 99 percent of pilots will show up and that 99 percent of planes will be operating.
They should also stop overscheduling, especially at their hub, Chicago O'Hare. They schedule more airplanes to take off than the airport has capacity to allow. There's no way that can work.
And stop holding people in the airplane for excessive amounts of time. This is not necessary.
It also burns a lot of fuel and causes other problems. Most passengers would rather be in the airport for excessive waits.
 
STEPHEN A. GREYSER
Professor of marketing and communications at Harvard Business School.
At the end of the day, the bottom line for the consumer is that company behavior is far more important than whatever public relations or advertising the company may put out. I'm not suggesting that advertising and public relations are unimportant. But by themselves, they aren't going to do the job.
What the company has to do is improve the reality of the customer service, and that includes the scheduling. That includes handling on the telephones. That includes what happens in the departure lounge, and that includes what they do by way of keeping their customers who are in the lounge area informed about the truth of what's going on.
Many times they are not forthcoming in terms of providing truthful information, especially when there's an opportunity for a customer to go to another airline. Obviously they hate losing customers, but that's short-term thinking. The customer will remember she wasn't treated like a customer.
Dealing with the schedules is complicated, but thinning out the schedule is something they can do on their own. The first step is to reduce the schedule overload. Obviously they've got to fly planes to make money. But having large numbers of passengers complaining is not good for the company's image or reality.
They also need more people on telephones handling customer complaints. From a marketing point of view, they have to focus on frequent fliers. They have to develop a statement of fulfillable promises backed up by the commitment at all levels of management and the airline's operating group, a commitment to true customer service.
 
RANDY PETERSEN
Publisher of Inside Flyer magazine, a publication for frequent fliers.
The first thing I would do is I would probably resign. I believe they mishandled the crisis control. They thought that if they ignored it, it would go away. Customers don't go away anymore. I would hire another crisis control adviser.
I still fly United and think they're a good airline. But I would get all the people who work for the company on the same page. I think I would owe an apology to the employees who were put on the firing line. I would go back to employees and let them know we let them down as a company and make them happy. If you take care of employees, they take care of the customers. There needs to be a lot of healing. I would spend every single day on the job with my employees and the people on the front line, not giving away miles or discounts. Those are pacifiers for passengers. It's just bribery. That doesn't heal what's wrong with United.
United won't be ready for Thanksgiving or Christmas unless they heal themselves. The guy who works the checkout counter in Denver, the customer service manager in San Francisco. Those are the people I think I would talk to, and as C.E.O., I would not sleep until I talked to them all.
 
SANJAY DHAR
Professor of marketing, the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business.
The key thing is getting consumer retrial -- the people who left United for other airlines. Management should feel confident that problems are being addressed and share information that the pilots are the highest paid now and that the operations are being streamlined.
They should continue using Jim Goodwin but use a more solid message to say "these are the things we've done" and come up with very tangible things, like what Jacques Nasser did with Ford to respond to the Bridgestone tire crisis.
Goodwin has the biggest stake in the company, and he should communicate the message. United's top brass have a role to play in building confidence within their ranks. They should say, 'This is a company you should be proud of.' That's reassurance-building among customers.
Then you have to get people to try the airline. There could be financial incentives, or "buy two fares, get the third one free," or a sharp discount for flying on major routes. They could figure out how to recapture a dominant position in routes lost to other airlines, and offer a steep discount on those routes. That won't start a price war, because you're only offering it on specific routes.
 
ALFRED KAHN
Professor emeritus of political economy, Cornell University, and chairman of the Civil Aeronautics Board, 1977-78, during airline deregulation.
United's problems are a result of excessive congestion at particular airports at particular times. There are two major remedies that are obvious. First, we have to get some system for providing air traffic capacity that is sufficient. So the question is whether the F.A.A. and air traffic control system are ideally set up to respond to needs for additional capacity. And there have been various commissions recommending corporatization of control.
The second is correct pricing. Excessive congestion at certain times and places means you are undercharging. All airlines should charge more when it's more congested and less when it's not. Charges for phone calls are different at peak times than in the middle of the night.
