SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 21; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine

LENGTH: 3006 words

HEADLINE: Greece At Its Most Greek

BYLINE: By Phyllis Rose; Phyllis Rose is working on a sequel to "The Year of Reading Proust: A Memoir in Real Time" (Counterpoint).

 BODY:
I believe that a traveler in a new place should buy something, preferably through bargaining. Buy something, make a friend, get information. It's the human contact, not the acquisition, that counts. Consequently, and not to satisfy any low material desires, I was bargaining for a hand-woven cotton tablecloth in Nafplio.
Even in Greece, even in Nafplio (or Nauplion, as it is also called), even in a souvenir shop where hardly anything sells for more than $40, we had all entered this new May week in a state of anxiety about Wall Street. The store owner, while spiritedly taking part in our negotiation, was keeping an eye on the television above the counter. CNN was about to report on how the American stock market, seven hours behind us, had opened. The previous week had been disastrous, and this was either a real crash, if the market opened low, or yet another hard ride, if it rallied. 
 When your grins bin sniff, Mr. Roussos, the shop owner, said with a conspiratorial twinkle that suggested I should understand his allusion and appreciate his savvy.
Pardon me?
What they say: When your Mr. Grinsbin sniff, the rest of world go to hospital.
When Greenspan sneezes, the rest of the world gets pneumonia, and Nafplio's tourist business gets even worse than it is. The armies of tourists from various nations in bus-size battalions of 80 have left the field here. This is a blessing for the independent traveler, if hard on local businessmen.
Nafplio is the prettiest and most lovable city I've seen in Greece. The setting of the red-roofed Old Town, on the Bay of Argolis, backed by the rocky heights of Acronauplia and even higher Palamidi, is spectacular. For centuries, Venetians and Turks took turns ruling Nafplio, leaving behind palpable layers of elegance and exoticism. At one end of the immense, marble-paved piazza, Constitution Square, is an arcaded brick building constructed by the Venetians in the 18th century (now the Archaeological Museum); at the other end is a converted Turkish mosque. Bougainvillea grows through the wrought-iron balconies of many neo-Classical mansions and spills overhead on narrow streets. In the evenings, tavernas put out tables and chairs in these alleys, so you can eat and drink beneath the stars and flowers.
Here, in 1821, Greeks won independence by storming the fortress at the top of Palamidi, taking it from the Turks after a siege of more than a year. Nafplio became a center for philhellenic political activity. The first Greek parliament was here, and for six years, until 1834, this was the capital of Greece. I have an easy time here imagining I'm in the freedom-seeking, passionate, semibarbaric, Western, Eastern, silk-and-velvet, early-19th-century Greece that Byron fought for.
I am thinking of the famous painting of Byron in what he called his Albanian outfit, a red-and-yellow striped silk bandanna around his forehead. That morning my husband, Laurent, and I saw many costumes of even greater splendor at the Folk Art Museum (formally the Peloponnesian Folklore Foundation), dresses to make Christian Lacroix frantic with envy, embroidered velvets on top of silks, silks on velvet, gold embroidered vests, silver embroidered waistbands, coin necklaces, metal breastplates, life-size mannequins swathed, wrapped and decorated as vividly and imaginatively as ever I've seen outside the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The Folklore Foundation specializes in weaving, embroidery, clothing and jewelry, making it -- along with the Nafplio Archaeological Museum, with its fantastically patterned Mycenaean pottery -- a design inspiration. For me, it helped people the city with fantasy figures in colorful clothes uniting to throw off the yoke of oppression.
After my negotiation for the tablecloth was completed, Mr. Roussos and I advanced quickly from matters of world economy to where to eat, swim, stroll and sleep in Nafplio. For strolling, he recommended the walk along the base of Acronauplia to the beach of Karathona. For swimming, he recommended the Arvanitia beach. For sleeping, he recommended the Pension Marianna. Quiet as the grave.
We, however, were staying at the Xenia Palace hotel, according to my information the only luxury hotel in town, set sensationally atop the Acronauplia, looking over the roofs of the Old Town to the bay and distant mountains of the Argolid. An elevator, I'd read, takes you down from the hotel through the heart of the rock and deposits you in the center of town. That sounded great. When I made the reservation, I imagined a grand old converted structure, like the San Domenico in Taormina.
But our arrival was unpromising, even disconcerting. First, few people seemed able to tell us how to find the hotel. When our Athenian driver, Kristos, finally found the right road and a hotel that said "Xenia," it looked derelict and was, in fact, closed. The Xenia Palace was farther up the mountain, a modern building aging badly. A thick cable blocked us from pulling up to it. We had to leave the car about 100 yards from the entrance -- no porters or bellboys in sight -- and walk through an empty, graceless lobby to the front desk.
Greeks usually care about the quality of hospitality. A cordial reception has been valued since Homeric times. We'd gotten used to better welcomes. I was so unnerved by our reception that I demanded to know if there were any good reason we could not drive to the front door. At first the man at reception avoided the question, but finally he admitted there were "structural problems." No more than five cars could be in front of the hotel at any one time without danger of road collapse. They weren't taking any chances.
I don't want to dwell on the strangeness of the Xenia Palace, where we and our traveling companions, Ron and Joanne, seemed to be the only guests. Joanne and I both took a Wildean dislike to the avocado-colored bathroom fixtures ("Either this wallpaper goes or I do," was Oscar Wilde's dying quip) and, especially, the sinks, which looked like urinals. The lighting in the rooms was too dim for reading. The elevator down to town deposited us at the end of a tunnel, on the ceiling of which were stuck what seemed to be Styrofoam blocks painted green (to deaden screams?); the walls looked like high-school lockers and shelves had been ripped off them.
This creepy, until recently government-run hotel, with its spectacular placement and views all squandered, is the town's biggest problem. As I was too dumb to understand immediately, no more than five cars at the front door means no buses, and no buses means no tour groups, and no tour groups means few guests. Add the avocado bathroom fixtures and the urinal-sinks and you have a real disaster, a supposedly high-end hotel that appeals to no one. With the luxury-class Xenia Palace empty, the first-class Xenia down the hill closed and the other first-class hotel, the Amfitrion, also closed, it was no wonder Nafplio seemed light on tourists. Groups visiting Mycenae and Epidaurus, who might use Nafplio as a base, stay at the Amalia, miles out of town, or in Tolo, farther down the coast.
This situation won't last long. The Xenia Palace, the Xenia and the Amfitrion have all been bought by the hotel group that owns the world-class Elounda Beach Hotel in Crete. They and the town are ripe for renovation. So if you like the authenticity and charm of semiabandoned places, go to Nafplio quickly.
You are likely to find unexpected pleasures. For example, the Komboloi Museum, around the corner from the Folk Art Museum.
The Greeks have quickly picked up the connection between museums and museum shops, and the Komboloi Museum looked like a bead store. One man was at work stringing beads under a sign that said "Workshop." A younger man stood behind the counter.
Can you tell me what komboloi would be in English? I asked him.
He waved his hand around the store in reply.
Beads? I said.
Not beads. Special beads. Beads for this, he said.
He picked up a strand of amber beads loosely strung on a red silk thread and started pushing them to one side. Worry beads!
Where's the museum? I asked.
He pointed up some narrow stairs and to a sign asking the equivalent of $1.50 for admission. Stairs and price seemed steep, but we were intrigued: what would a worry-bead museum consist of?
It was an extensive collection of prayer beads -- Buddhist, Hindu, Muslim, Catholic -- with an explanation of how they evolved one from the other: Muslim traders brought prayer beads from Asia and adapted them to Islam; in the late 12th century, Crusaders brought them back from Constantinople to Catholic Europe, where they metamorphosed into rosary beads. Buddhist strands have 108 beads; Muslim beads track the 99 identities of Allah, usually with 33 beads for three prayers each, and rosaries most often consist of 5 groups of 10 small beads with larger beads separating them. From these prayer beads, the strictly secular Greek worry beads evolved, having no specified number of beads to a strand, chosen for aesthetic considerations like feel and look, a combination toy and meditation device. We didn't see many in use in present-day Nafplio, but they proved popular presents for harried Americans upon our return to the United States.
In the afternoon we took the walk Mr. Roussos had recommended. Just beyond the pier where fishing boats tie up, the walk under Palamidi starts. A wide, flat, stone-paved pathway heads around the other side of the rocky peninsula, between cliff and water. We passed a seaside taverna, an abandoned swim club and the entrance to the nearly 1,000 steps that lead up to the fortress, from which there are spectacular Santorini-like views of an immense sea, distant land and dwellings far below. Quickly, we were beyond any buildings, walking between red cliffs and blue water. Birds, roosting in the cliff face, flew over our heads and their song filled the air. An old woman, her hair in a gray bun, gathered herbs growing from the rocks. We exchanged a kalispera ("good evening"). At any point, we could have walked out onto rocks and gone for a swim. Farther along, men were fishing and others swimming at what must have been Karathona Beach.
Returning, we stopped to watch the sunset at one of the dozens of cafes lining the waterfront and looked across the Bay of Argolis toward hazy blue mountains massed in receding rows. A tiny island in the bay, close to the port, bears the picturesque remains of a fortress. It's called Bourtzi and is festooned now with bougainvillea. (Funny how charming military installations can look with the passage of time; they seem to age better than hotels.) Boats leave every half-hour for Bourtzi -- the trip takes five minutes -- and you can witness the sunset from there. But we preferred the cafe.
We sat shaded by market umbrellas big and high enough to seem like ceilings and birds flew underneath them. We sipped our Scotch-and-sodas and observed neighbors who were talking on cell phones and handling paperwork as they consumed enormous pastries and coffees in what for them was midafternoon. Again, the comparison that presented itself to me was with Santorini, where we had recently been. It is a fact universally acknowledged that the sunset seen from Oia in Santorini is the most beautiful sunset in the world. But the sunset seen from a waterfront cafe in Nafplio seemed to me every bit as beautiful and vastly less attended.
Greeks eat late, 9 p.m. at the earliest. So we had time to investigate the restaurants Mr. Roussos had suggested. We had no trouble finding the Omorpho Tavernaki, two streets back from the waterfront, in a relatively empty part of town. People, all Greek, were eating and talking vivaciously at tables set up in the street. Basilis, another place Mr. Roussos recommended, was more of a challenge because it's on a street with many tavernas whose customers were eating outside. It was hard to tell where one taverna ended and another began. My husband and I performed the restaurant-scouter stroll, eyeing menus, checking out ambience, glancing into people's plates as they ate, all the while trying to look as if we were on some other mission entirely. Unfortunately, my husband turned on his heel and, pretending not to look at anything, walked straight into me. The waiters could not keep from laughing. Thus we made up our minds where to dine.
We waited in the middle of Constitution Square for our friends to rejoin us. They had gone to the island of Hydra for the day. The square has white marble paving, and many children were trying to ride bikes on the slippery surface. They fell and were brave or cried and were comforted. It seemed strange and a pleasure to watch people living their everyday lives. In Athens's Syntagma Square, you see fake folk dancing. In the Piazza Navona in Rome, there's nary a native in sight. Local people come to this square in the evening with their kids. Waiting, we watched them and also indulged in the peculiarly satisfying task of deciphering a non-Roman alphabet. From ENNIKH TPABEZA we made out ETHNIK TRAPEZE and from there it was a short but exhilarat-ing step to National Bank. This building's architectural style is one you don't often encounter: neo-Mycenaean. Yet there is a fully functioning A.T.M. just inside the door, which opens to the same card that opens the door of our Citizens Bank in Connecticut.
Ron and Joanne, wearing white cotton shirts they'd acquired on Hydra, joined us soon, and we had a terrific dinner at Omorpho. There was no table free when we arrived, but that was not a problem: they put another table and four chairs on the street for us. We ate croquettes of a green vegetable resembling spinach, stuffed zucchini, grilled local sausages and veal chops. We ate, as is normal in Greece, exactly as much as we wanted, got our food quickly and were waited on efficiently and with no pretension. We drank two bottles of Nimea, an excellent red wine that comes from vineyards we had passed on our way to Nafplio. The bill was $37, service included. We had a sticker-shock moment of a novel sort. Anyway, we were feeling flush because the stock market had rallied.
My husband and I were heading from Nafplio to Olympia, a three-hour drive, but Ron and Joanne had decided to go right on to Delphi. Kristos found a Nafplio cabby who would take them there in a comfortable car at a reasonable price. So we left separately the next day, Laurent and I in a yellow Athens cab, Joanne and Ron in a red Nafplio one.
When Telemachus, in search of Odysseus, arrived at a new castle, he would usually be given dinner before he was expected to impart his lineage and his purpose in traveling. We stopped for gas a mile or so outside of town. The gas station owner, while filling the tank, said to Kristos, I know who you are. You are driving one of the two American couples who were staying at the Xenia Palace. Are you the ones headed to Delphi or to Olympia?
So our herald revealed our identity and destination.
 
Getting There, Staying There
Nafplio is a three- or four-hour drive south of Athens. We wanted to tour the Peloponnesus by car but were worried about driving in Greece, which is nerve-racking at best. TAXIS are a good alternative. The cost is about $260 a day, and four people can fit in one cab, which is often a Mercedes. Kristos Exarhopoulou, the cabdriver who took us to Nafplio, Olympia and Delphi, proved to be an excellent driver, a tactful and intelligent companion and a resourceful representative; his telephone number is 30-197-68557.
There are pleasant, though not luxurious, places to stay in Nafplio. Perhaps the most highly recommended is the BYRON HOTEL, 2 Platonos Street (telephone: 30-752-22351; fax: 30-752-26338), in the heart of the Old Town; there are 18 rooms, with showers, air-conditioning and excellent views; prices range from about $50 to about $60; breakfast costs about $2.75; no restaurant.
Also in the Old Town, near Constitution Square, is the ILION HOTEL, 6 Kapodistriou Street (30-752-25114; fax: 30-752-24497), which has 10 uniquely decorated suites; all have baths and air-conditioning; prices range from about $55 to about $110, including breakfast; no restaurant. The KING OTHON HOTEL, 4 Farmakopoulou (telephone and fax: 30-752-27595), is inexpensive and the rooms somewhat cramped and basic, but the neo-Classical building is recently restored and the hallways and exterior are beautiful. There are 11 rooms, and a double, with bath and air-conditioning, costs from about $50 to about $60, including breakfast; no restaurant. Farther up on the Acronauplia and a little outside of the central (and perhaps noisy) heart of the Old Town, is the MARIANNA PENSION, 9 Potamianou Street (30-752-24256; fax: 30-752-21783), recommended by Mr. Roussos; all 14 rooms have bathrooms and air-conditioning; a double is about $45, including breakfast. The XENIA PALACE, where we had a less than ideal stay, is under new ownership and scheduled for renovation.
 "Give us this day our daily squid" was Joanne's assessment of Greek food. Among other wonderful fried fish specialties, I especially liked the whitebait, tiny and consumed by the dozen. Squeeze on lemon, and, by a miracle of timing, they stay crisp until you've reached the last mouthful, only then becoming sodden and inedible. Greek salads are also predictably good, as are olives, feta and stuffed grape leaves. Forget about butter when you're in Greece. They don't understand it.
The Napflio restaurants that we checked out all had menus similar to that of the Omorpho Tavernaki, 1 Kostonopoulou Street (30-752-25944), where we had a meal that included stuffed zucchini, grilled local sausage and veal chops; the prices were extremely reasonable, often less than $10 a person.
One last thing: eat yogurt and honey for breakfast. Greek yogurt tastes more like sour cream than it does like our yogurt, and with Greek honey, it's the food of the gods. Phyllis Rose

PUB-DATE: September 10, 2000

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 47; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine

LENGTH: 3427 words

HEADLINE: Nantucket, Aglow In Shades Of Gray

BYLINE: By Lisa Fugard; Lisa Fugard is a fiction writer.

 BODY:
The roses and foxgloves were muted splashes of color in the evening's last light, and I wandered through the town of Nantucket a little in awe. I'd never seen so many gray houses. The term "weathered gray siding," frequently used to describe their restrained beauty, doesn't do them justice. Nantucket houses seem to know weather: they've been intimate with rain squalls gusting off the Atlantic and the fog that periodically enshrouds the island, with winter's northeasters and, of course, resplendent sunny summer days.
Winding lanes led me past traditional saltboxes and handsome early Federal-style homes crowned with austere roof walks. On the cobblestone streets I saw elegant brick mansions with delicate balustrade trim on their roofs, grand Greek Revival houses with pillars and porticoes and a few flamboyant Victorians. There are hundreds of authentic 18th- and 19th-century houses in the town, but the one I fell in love with, on reaching the top of Sunset Hill Lane, predates all of them. The Oldest House, as it's called, was built in 1686, just 27 years after Nantucket Island was settled. With its tiny diamond-pane windows and huge sloping roof, it looked more like a landlocked ark than a house, and on my first evening on Nantucket it stood stoic on its hillock as a light rain nuzzled its shingles. 
 I visited Nantucket, Mass., in late June of this year, but my initial encounter with the island -- which lies 30 miles at sea from the south shore of Cape Cod -- happened several years ago, through literature.
"Be it distinctly recorded here," wrote Herman Melville in "Moby-Dick," "that the Nantucketers were the first among mankind to harpoon with civilized steel the great Sperm Whale; and that for half a century they were the only people of the whole globe who so harpooned him."
My new understanding of how whaling is woven into the island's history began when I checked into the Anchor Inn for my five-day visit. The house was built for Archibald Hammond, a ship's captain. The rooms are named after Nantucket whaling ships, and I fell asleep to the two-toned bleat of a foghorn.
The first settlers on Nantucket had planned to raise sheep but eventually began hunting whales, first from the shore and then from whaling boats. When Nantucketers invented the tryworks, a brick furnace built on deck that turned whaling ships into small factories capable of processing blubber, the oceans of the world opened up to them.
Ocean voyages that lasted for years? Women pacing roof walks, searching for signs of their husbands' ships? It seemed rather romantic to me, until I set foot in the Whaling Museum on Broad Street, one block away from the harbor. Doug Burch, a staff member at the museum, was giving a talk on the gruesome business of whaling, and I took a seat in the back of Sanderson Hall, the walls of which are lined with a fierce array of harpoons, lances and flensing knives.
"Thar she blows!" Mr. Burch cried, and he strode over to an authentic 30-foot whaleboat in which six men once pursued sperm whales that could reach 100 feet in length. For the next 45 minutes he took me on a heart-thumping journey, peppering his talk with evocative whaling terminology such as "Nantucket sleigh ride" -- once harpooned, the enraged whale often surged across the ocean for hours, dragging the men on a wild, bucking ride.
The museum's collections include dramatic oil paintings of anatomically dubious whales flipping boats into the air, the skeleton of a 43-foot finback whale and intriguing artifacts like the harpoon head that once belonged to Peter Paddock. While captain of the Lion he harpooned a whale that got away; 13 years later, he successfully harpooned the same whale and found his harpoon head buried in the animal's flesh. The scrimshaw collection conjures up images of more tender moments at sea. On the days when they weren't being dragged across the ocean by furious sperm whales, the sailors carved whale ivory. These men were homesick. How else can one explain the rolling pins and pie crimpers that they fashioned? My favorite display was of pictures of women etched on sperm whale teeth. Were they wives? Fiancees? Was the half-naked woman reclining on a sofa someone's fantasy?
Leaving the museum, I found myself in a crowd of people with suitcases and bicycles and dogs and babies. To my left was the harbor where the last whaling ship docked in 1870 to unload its barrels of rendered oil. Now, almost hourly, ferryboats arrive from Hyannis and unload visitors. Nantucket's year-round population of more than 9,000 swells to more than 50,000 in July and August.
I suppose we visitors are as valuable to Nantucket's economy as sperm whales used to be, I thought ruefully. The cobblestone streets and lanes leading away from the harbor are lined with shops filled with fine merchandise, and though I tried to be the noble tourist interested only in history -- surely I shouldn't be shopping on my first day? -- I succumbed.
Besides, I had a mission. My father, Athol, wanted a scrimshaw pocketknife. When he was 20 he worked for a year on a merchant ship, the S.S. Graigaur. He was the captain's personal steward, or "tiger," and the only thing he managed to carve for himself was an extremely uncomfortable pair of wooden sandals.
I visited several antiques shops, two of my favorites being Nina Hellman Marine Antiques and Leonards Antiques, with its inviting four-posters. I bought my father a beautiful knife at another shop, Craftmasters, and then spent the rest of the afternoon traipsing in and out of nearly every boutique. I now own a pair of fancy Japanese-looking flip-flops that just might be as uncomfortable as the sandals my father carved out of wood.
As wonderful as the shops were, something quite magical happened at dusk when most of them closed and the day visitors departed. The town seemed to wobble in time, and I experienced a delicious sense of dislocation. I was a 21st-century woman strolling through the 18th century, as long as no S.U.V.'s and Jeeps rumbled past. I wandered from one narrow lane to the next, peeping into the riotous flower gardens of the grand gray houses, billowing with hydrangeas and cosmos, with lilies and brilliant yellow coreopsis and, of course, roses.
Eventually I returned to the harbor. During the day, it's bustling with people visiting the galleries and restaurants on the wharves, but in the evening hours it quiets down. Reflections from the lights of the gray-shingled rental cottages on the piers winked in the dark water as a few boats glided into the bay for moonlight cruises. Nantucket is often referred to as "the little gray lady," and on this early summer evening I had found her to be particularly beautiful.
Was this what those homesick, rolling-pin-carving sailors pined for, I wondered. I had a vivid impression of the life of a Nantucket whaler; now I wanted to know about the women of the island, those wives and fiancees and lovers so tenderly etched on the teeth of sperm whales. What were they doing while their men were at sea?
Women shaped Nantucket's history as much as the men, starting with Mary Coffin Starbuck, who, around 1702, was instrumental in introducing Quakerism, with its belief in the equality of the sexes, to the island. While their husbands were at sea -- the longest whaling voyage lasted 11 years -- many Quaker women in coal-scuttle bonnets and homespun dresses took care of their children, launched themselves as independent businesswomen and participated in town government.
The woman who intrigued me the most was unmarried, the astronomer Maria Mitchell. On the night of Oct. 1, 1847, she excused herself from a dinner party being held in the Pacific Bank building, where she lived with her family; her father, who was an amateur astronomer, worked at the bank. She climbed to the roof and, using a Dolland telescope, became the first American and the first woman to plot the course of an unknown comet. The following year, she was the first woman elected to the American Academy of Arts and Sciences (it took the academy almost a century to elect another woman). In 1865, when she was hired by the newly founded Vassar College, she became the first woman professor of astronomy in the United States.
En route to her birthplace on Vestal Street, I walked up the shady reaches of upper Main Street past some of Nantucket's finest 19th-century mansions: the John Wendell Barrett house, white clapboard with looming chimneys and an enclosed cupola; the Three Bricks, three identical houses with handsome porticoes built by the whaling patriarch Joseph Starbuck for his three sons. The Hadwen House, an imposing Greek Revival mansion built in 1844 for William Hadwen, a candle manufacturer, is open to the public. Its large, impeccably furnished parlors feature carved Italian marble fireplaces and gilded chandeliers, while upstairs the Chinese grass mat in Eunice Hadwen's bedroom whispers of the China trade and ships docking in exotic ports.
The house in which Maria Mitchell was born and lived until she was 18 is a fine example of late 18th- to early 19th-century Quaker design and reveals how people of more moderate means lived. While the Hadwen House has carpeted floors, here two of the floors feature the original floor painting. No brilliantly colored wallpaper brightens the small parlor, and the kitchen walls, constructed from various pieces of wood -- maybe even a few boards from a shipwreck -- and plaster, are grain-painted to resemble knotty pine. Most moving to me, and atypical for a Quaker house, was the tiny study, no larger than a broom closet, that William Mitchell created for his 10 children. When Maria, the third oldest, closed the door on her siblings and worked at her mathematical calculations it became her "room of one's own" in miniature.
Maria was as passionate about the earth as she was about the cosmos, and the Maria Mitchell Association continues her work in science education. The Loines Observatory, on Milk Street Extension, offers lectures and public telescope viewing.
The Hinchman House, on Milk Street, is a small natural science museum that includes displays of whale and dolphin bones, wildflowers, tropical drift seeds that wash up on Nantucket's beaches and a unique hands-on exhibit: an owl-pellet dig. "Is this for kids?" I asked the young volunteer. "No-o, not really," he said with a smile that made me think I wasn't the first adult to ask this question. Owl pellets are composed of regurgitated hair, feathers and bits of bone that the owl couldn't digest. Using tweezers, forceps and probes I carefully took apart a barn owl pellet that resembled a tightly packed gray oval dust ball and found at least a dozen tiny bones. A bone-sorting chart helped me identify a rodent's jawbone and several small vertebrae .
That evening, I ate in one of the island's fine restaurants, Black-Eyed Susan's. It used to be a diner and is now adorned with three Italian glass chandeliers. The Afghan jerked chicken was delicious.
I felt satiated in more ways than one. Not only had I dined well but I was also fat with history -- whaling ships and mansions and a bold woman staring at the heavens. Of course, there were historical sites that I hadn't visited: the old jail; the Atheneum, the Greek Revival building that houses Nantucket's library, where Maria Mitchell worked as the first librarian and, rumor has it, read every book; and the Quaker Meeting House. But I decided that on the following day I would plunge into the natural world.
Beautiful beaches rim Nantucket. More than 40 percent of the island is protected conservation land, and there are several nature preserves in which to hike or go birding. (Sadly, the rest of the island is being developed at a brisk pace, and huge summer homes are sprouting on the bluffs and moors.) Six bike paths, totaling approximately 25 miles, fan out across the island, and in a day one can easily cycle from the beaches of Madaket at its western tip to the village of Sconset at the eastern end. I wanted to do something a little more adventurous, and so I visited the scalloped barrier beach that forms the western flank of Nantucket's natural harbor. The Coskata-Coatue area, as it's known, consists of several adjoining wildlife refuges and encompasses sand dunes, pristine beaches, salt marshes and an old maritime red cedar forest. It is accessible only by four-wheel drive or by boat. I went in a raspberry-colored fiberglass kayak rented from Sea Nantucket on Francis Street Beach.
I felt like a poor relative as I made my way past the fancy yachts and speedboats bobbing in the choppy waters of the harbor. From a distance, the barrier beach didn't look like much more than a spit of sand, and I girded myself for disappointment. Half an hour later, as I paddled closer -- glided really, because the headwind had died down and the water was limpid and glasslike -- my heart quickened. There wasn't a soul around. For the next three hours I kayaked from one beguiling bay beach to the next. I had several swims, walked inland to view a colony of nesting egrets and dodged an enormous horseshoe crab. Rosa rugosa, the salt-spray rose, was in bloom, and I decided that there is nothing, absolutely nothing, more sublime than roses on a deserted beach.
Except, perhaps, the roses at Sconset. The heart of this village, perched on a bluff overlooking the ocean, was settled in the 17th century and has many enchanting seaside cottages. They began as one-room shacks built by fishermen from Nantucket town who came to the village for cod-fishing season. Soon enough, their wives wanted to join them and tiny bedrooms or "warts" -- was it a disgruntled husband who came up with this name? -- were added to the shacks, creating the higgledy-piggledy look of the some of the oldest ones. And the rambler roses adore them, up and over the cottages they clamber as if in competition with the giant hollyhocks to see which species can put on the most impressive display.
On my last afternoon on the island I stood in one of Sconset's sheltered narrow lanes until a most bewitching sense of stillness came over me. Surely I had entered a fairy tale. I was almost as tall as some of the cottages, yet some of the flowers were taller than I. I wanted to curl up on the nearest wooden doorstep like a cat. Not acceptable behavior for a visitor, so I strolled down to the beach known as Codfish Park and napped on the sand. The Atlantic was restless when I awoke, and the least terns were fishing close to shore, folding their wings until they resembled origami birds and plummeting into the waves. Sconset is short for Siasconset, an Indian word meaning "place of bones," and thought to be a reference to the bones of right whales that used to wash ashore. As I watched the whitecaps tearing off the indigo swells, it pleased me deeply to know that I was looking at whale country. Their numbers have greatly diminished, but they're still out there -- humpbacks and finbacks, sei and pilot whales and a few hundred right whales. Breaching and sounding and filling the waters with their songs, they migrate from ocean to ocean on journeys as epic as those of the Nantucket whaling ships that pursued them hundreds of years ago.
 
PORT OF CALL
I made calls for accommodations a week before I visited Nantucket in June and almost didn't find a room. It's wise, particularly in summer, to book well in advance.
ANCHOR INN, 66 Center Street (telephone: 508-228-0072; e-mail: anchorin@nantucket.net), was built in 1806. Its 11 rooms, with private baths and air-conditioners, are named after Nantucket whaling ships. "Cyrus," my room on the third floor, was a little small; those on the first and second floors are larger. Ann and Charles Balas, the owners, went out of their way to help me during my visit. In late September and October, midweek prices range from about $115 to $125, $165 to $175 on weekends, with Continental breakfast. No smoking. Children old enough to stay in their own room are welcome. Usually closed for six to eight weeks in the winter.
SHERBURNE INN, 10 Gay Street (508-228-4425; fax: 508-228-8114), a quiet place just a few minutes' walk from the center of town, is where I shall stay when I return to Nantucket. Built in 1835 as the headquarters for the Atlantic Silk Company, its rooms tend to be a little larger than those in the private houses that have been converted into inns. Eight exquisitely appointed bedrooms all have private baths and air-conditioning. Rates range from $150 to $250 until Columbus Day, after which they drop to around $95 to $150, Continental breakfast included. Special packages are offered from mid-October through mid-May. No smoking. Children older than 6 are welcome. Open all year.
I loved dining in BLACK-EYED SUSAN'S, 10 India Street (508-325-0308), with its funky decor. The menu changes almost weekly, and tuna tartare and Malaysian barbecued pork are popular dishes. They have no liquor license and do not take credit cards. Open for dinner every night except Sunday; reservations accepted only for the 6 p.m. seating. A two-course dinner for two averages around $80. Also open daily from 7 a.m. to 1 p.m. for breakfast.
AMERICAN SEASONS, 80 Center Street (508-228-7111), is a lovely, rather romantic restaurant with a terrace. Open for dinner seven nights a week, its
menu changes every six weeks and features American regional cuisines: pan-roasted wild striped bass in saffron butter from New England, perhaps, while the South might be represented by applewood-smoked sweetbreads. A two-course dinner for two, with a bottle of wine, costs about $130.
TOPPER'S AT THE WAUWINET, 120 Wauwinet Road (508-228-8768), is in a restored old inn at the western end of Nantucket harbor. A tasting menu is served on the terrace, and I feasted on scallops, grilled calamari, yellow-fin tuna tartare and a lobster club sandwich. The tasting lunch averages $25 a person. During the spring and fall, a six-course wine-tasting dinner, with each course accompanied by a wine, is $175 a person. Topper's provides a complementary launch service to and from town; if you miss the boat you can always take a taxi from town. Open daily for dinner, Monday through Saturday for lunch, Sunday for brunch.
I rented something called a sit-on-top kayak from SEA NANTUCKET, at Francis Street Beach at the end of Washington Street Extension, about a five-minute walk from the harbor (508-228-7499). Expect to get wet. If you take a camera or a picnic lunch, wrap it securely in plastic. The kayaks have drainage holes in the bottom, which also let in water, and you will spend your time sitting in about half an inch of water. It's worth it. The rates are $15 an hour for a single, $30 for a half-day; $30 an hour for a double, $50 for a half-day. Only cash and checks accepted. Open from May through October. Lisa Fugard
 
MUSEUMS AND SHOPS
MARIA MITCHELL BIRTHPLACE HOUSE, 1 Vestal Street (telephone: 508-228-2896), is open from mid-June through mid-September, Tuesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; call for fall and winter hours. Admission: $3.
NANTUCKET WHALING MUSEUM, 13 Broad Street (508-228-1736), is open daily from Memorial Day to around Labor Day, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; from then until Columbus Day, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; limited hours in winter. Admission: $5; visitor pass for museums and sites operated by the Nantucket Historical Association, $10.
HADWEN HOUSE, 96 Main Street, run by the Nantucket Historical Association (508-228-1894), is open daily from Memorial Day to around Labor Day, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; from then until Columbus Day, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m.; closed in winter. Admission: $5; visitor pass, $10.
HINCHMAN HOUSE NATURAL SCIENCE MUSEUM, 7 Milk Street (508-228-0898), is open from June 15 through Labor Day, Tuesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; reduced hours in September and October; closed in winter. Admission: $3.
NINA HELLMAN MARINE ANTIQUES, 48 Center Street (508-228-4677), is open June through the end of September, Monday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 10 p.m, Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; call for fall and winter hours.
LEONARDS ANTIQUES, 31 Washington Street (508-228-0620), is open from the end of April until mid-December; in summer, Tuesday through Saturday, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Sunday, 1 to 5 p.m.; call for fall hours.
CRAFTMASTERS OF NANTUCKET, 7 India Street (508-228-0322), is open daily, April through October, 10 a.m. to 11 p.m., November through March, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 15; Column 1; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine

LENGTH: 2505 words

HEADLINE: Crossing The Oresund

BYLINE: By David Margolick; David Margolick, a contributing editor at Vanity Fair, is the author of "Strange Fruit: Billie Holiday, Cafe Society and an Early Cry for Civil Rights" (Running Press).

 BODY:
One day, perhaps, the Oresund Fixed Link, the newly opened bridge, tunnel and road that has reunited Denmark with Sweden after a 7,000-year hiatus, will find its Hart Crane, who will rhapsodize about it in the way the American poet sang the praises of the Brooklyn Bridge. But probably not. While it is an engineering marvel, one bringing to fruition nearly 100 years of dreaming and planning and politicking, aesthetically speaking at least, the new span is not the stuff of verse. It is too long (10 miles) and too much of it -- nearly the first 4 miles heading east out of Copenhagen -- is under water. When it does surface from its tunnel, most of what's visible is an elevated causeway. Its middle section looks like a bridge, but its simple concrete towers, the tallest in Sweden, and the cables strung from them, are more elegant than mighty. And since the raised span is so far from shore, for all its size it seems small and slight, a few strokes from a finely pointed pen. If it inspires poetry, it will be less for its looks and more for what it portends: a Europe whose borders are slowly evaporating.
"To forget swearing and cursing/ And drink a toast to each other/ So that They and We are becoming Us/ That's better than fighting," the Danish poet Benny Andersen wrote recently, upon the bridge's opening. It's also better, he added, than getting seasick going between the two countries -- something that apparently happened regularly to him on the old ferry crossing. 
 To the Danes and Swedes, the opening in July of the long-anticipated crossing has been both unifying and, at least temporarily, amicably divisive. The journey between Denmark's capital, Copenhagen, and Malmo, Sweden's third-largest city, which formerly took 45 minutes by ferry, has now been cut in half, whether by car on the upper span or on the train directly below. As limousines carrying the two countries' royalty cut through the various ribbons strung across the bridge on opening day, some of the air was filled with talk of how borders had ceased to matter, of the new megalopolis of three million people that had been born and of the cultural and economic cross-pollination, not only between Denmark and Sweden but also throughout unified Europe, to come.
At the same time, there was plenty of telling talk about the differences between Danes and Swedes, and how they would outlast the diminishing physical barriers between the two countries. People argued over which side would profit more handsomely from the bridge, whose $3 billion price tag was borne equally by the two countries and will be recouped from hefty tolls: at the outset, about $30 a car (payable by cash, credit card or the Scandinavian version of EZ-Pass), though less for frequent travelers. These discussions invariably degenerated into analyses of which side needed the bridge more desperately to escape its own inadequacies, all of which fed stereotypes going back nearly as far as the ice age, which originally separated the two countries. To cite one example of the badinage, the Copenhagen City Museum staged an exhibition entitled "Boring Swedes and Drunken Danes."
Some Danes will cross into Sweden for its beaches and wide-open spaces, but most predicted that, at least at first, the bulk of the traffic would head westward, Swedes in search of cheaper alcohol or the greater cultural and corporeal pleasures of a world-class capital. (In fact, early reports indicate that while traffic across the Oresund is up 75 percent since the bridge opened, it is pretty even both ways.) Danes grumble that, even visually, the Swedes made out better: from their end, after all, one gets to see the bridge, and against the sunset to boot.
To Americans, largely oblivious to the nuances of Danish-Swedish relations, unconcerned with the economic possibilities of what promises to become a powerhouse of European commerce and unlikely to want to save a few kronen on liquor, the Oresund Bridge represents something else.
To a people whose mass transit projects are perpetually mired in regulations and red tape -- consider New York's much talked about subways to its airports -- it is a reminder that such an ambitious project can actually be built, ahead of schedule, within budget and with no environmental disasters or lawsuits left over. The Oresmund Bridge opens up the virgin territory of southern Sweden, beginning with the city of Malmo and continuing into a largely undiscovered land of fishing villages, forests and bicycle trails, the home of Absolut vodka and the birthplace of the smorgasbord. And the crossing -- the 10th-longest bridge in the world, and Europe's longest rail bridge as well as one of its longest tunnels -- will surely become a destination in its own right.
From a distance, the bridge looks unimposing, like a row of dominoes with a roadbed on top and two sets of chopsticks in between. Crane's Brooklyn Bridge has two majestic, cathedral-like granite towers, nestled between two proximate pieces of land; it looms imposingly from either shore. Andersen's bridge possesses no such magic. And even if the topography lent itself to something more epic 1/4 this is a more understated age, when expectations are more modest. Georg Rotne, the Danish architect who designed the bridge, said that it was made to look timeless, as if it had always been in place. Moreover, as bridges have gotten sturdier, they've also come to look more fragile. One Swedish journalist I spoke to said that it actually looked feminine. (But then, the Swedish landscape architect on the panel reviewing the bridge design complained that, in its stark angularity, it seemed positively masculine to her. Mr. Rotne himself is agnostic about the bridge's sex. "I think about sex all the time, but we didn't put it into the site," he said.)
Closer up, the bridge is sleek and handsome in its own understated way; one reporter compared it to a Bang & Olufsen stereo. Originally envisioned by the politicians as a straight line, it was given a graceful curve by Mr. Rotne, the better to see the sea, the coastline and the bridge itself, as one drives across it. That pleasure will be enjoyed by car passengers only; while some 90,000 people bicycled, skated, ran and walked across the bridge in the days before it officially opened, there are no provisions for them now. Many Danes and Swedes will continue to take the ferry, which is cheaper and more leisurely; there, unlike in a car, one can enjoy a cold, duty-free beer while crossing the Baltic Sea.
Talk of spanning the Oresund goes back more than a century. In 1888, there was a proposal to install a railway tube on the ocean floor between Elsinore, 30 miles to the north of Copenhagen, and Helsingborg, on the Swedish coast. That came to naught, as did a proposed bridge 50 years later. War -- specifically, the German occupation of Denmark -- and politics stalled the project until 1991, when the governments of the two countries agreed upon a combined road-rail link. The portion closest to Copenhagen would be under water, so as not to interfere with the city's busy new airport at Kastrup. The tunnel would surface at a new, man-made island, nearly two miles across. It was christened Peberholm, or Pepper Island; the entirely natural Saltholm, or Salt Island, is nearby.
For the next nine years, construction proceeded; at one time, 5,500 people were working on the project. Along with such natural problems as dredging enormous mounts of material and building an island, workers had to contend with 15 British bombs left over from World War II that were found on the ocean floor. The project epitomized the new Europe: apart from the workers and materials from Denmark and Sweden, there were tunnel fans from Germany, tunnel siding from Italy, concrete from Spain. Dutchmen did some of the dredging; French alpinists helped string the cables.
Shortly after the opening ceremony, I joined the entourage crossing the bridge back to Copenhagen. But apart from bragging rights over riding the route on its first official day of operation, I didn't gain much from the experience; from the bus, one couldn't even see the towers. I decided to return to the bridge the next day, after all the royal personages had gone back to their respective palaces. And, seeking to enjoy the latest feat in European mass transit, I decided to cross it by train.
Expecting mobs of curiosity seekers, I got to Copenhagen's beautiful brick train station early that Sunday morning via the Stroget -- the lively pedestrian mall that runs through the old part of the city -- and the celebrated Tivoli Gardens. Once in the station, though, I encountered a vivid example of Danish nonchalance. It was as if, for Danes, it would be positively uncool to show too much enthusiasm for the new train connection; that was for their country cousins across the water -- repressed, boring, in search of novelty or at least a cold beer -- to do. (Even Mr. Rotne said he didn't expect to take his bridge very often. "I don't see any particular reason to go to Sweden," he told me.) The crowds in the station were sparse; the clerk sold me my ticket -- about $15 round trip -- with no fanfare or knowing smile. He did tell me, his voice full of regret, that I'd just missed the latest train; of course, this being Europe, there'd be another one in all of 19 minutes.
A few minutes shy of its scheduled departure, the train, a sleek streak of red, white and blue, pulled into the station. Its doors opened out, as if to welcome me inside. I took one of four facing seats, plush and blue, with clean and nicely cushioned white antimacassars on each. An elderly husband and wife, obviously thrilled by the prospect of reaching Malmo by train after 70 some years of ferries, sat across from me, waving at a younger woman, presumably their daughter, on the platform outside. When the train pulled out a bit late -- a few technical problems," the conductor explained in Danish -- she ran alongside for a bit, throwing kisses at she went.
The perfectly tuned train, free of grime and graffiti, was not even one of the 27 new ones ordered especially for the bridge, as I later learned to my amazement. Gliding, it headed east. "Welcome to the train that's going to Malmo," the voice, now in English, said over the public address system.
The train made several quick stops, including at the Copenhagen airport. Then, within a few moments, it went subterranean. It traversed the tunnel at a brisk clip, the only sound a quiet, high-pitched whisper. For a couple of minutes, nothing was visible but the green-and-white emergency lights flashing by. Then, gradually, the darkness tapered off. Water and boats appeared above the horizon, and then the moonscapes of Peberholm. Reflecting the environmental integrity of the project -- some $80 million was devoted to such concerns, and environmentalists seem content with the results -- nothing was planted there; the idea is that the wind and the birds will bring seeds, and whatever will grow, will grow. Soon the train climbed to the underbelly of the bridge. I saw snatches of blue on either side of me, framed by the trusses of the bridge. And then, with people standing on the shore watching what was still, after all, a novelty, the train entered Scania, the southernmost province in Sweden.
Scania, a part of Denmark until a bloody battle in 1658, still considers itself at least as much Danish as Swedish, and offers a concentrated dose of Scandinavia. There is wilderness and farmland and miles of beaches, for the sea is never more than an hour away; there are also hundreds of castles and at least 60 golf courses, said to be the highest concentration of them in northern Europe and evidence of the golfing craze that has hit Sweden in the last 25 years. One can go hiking and cycling and horseback riding, and book places not only in youth hostels but also in haylofts along the way. (A Swedish law known as allemansratten, or "all men's right," lets people hike even in privately owned areas.) Scania has festivals for eels (a favorite local delicacy) and herring and crayfish. Each year, the town of Kivik names an Apple Queen. Lund, better known, perhaps, for giving its name to Monsieur Rick's eternal flame in "Casablanca," is a university town dating back 800 years. I had time only for Malmo, which grew up around herring, withered for a while under the Swedes, sprouted factories in the 19th century and has flowered in its postindustrial incarnation.
Architecturally, Malmo is rich and intact like Copenhagen, unscarred by wars and filled with the overlapping styles of many centuries. And though it is much smaller than its sister city, it offers two of the greatest, but increasingly elusive, pleasures of travel: the feeling of really getting away, and of really discovering something new.
Malmo is surprisingly polyglot; many Holocaust survivors found new homes and rebuilt their lives here following World War II, and it continues to receive refugees warmly; 30 percent of its residents come from other countries. "Our neighbors in Scandinavia haven't been as open as we have," Charlotte Hago of the City of Malmo's press office told me. But the town of 255,000 people also remains true to its Swedish self. It is a place where one encounters few American corporate logos (only those stalwart advance scouts of American cultural hegemony, McDonald's and Burger King, thus far), and where one is blessedly unlikely to understand the conversation at the next table.
For a day I bicycled around Malmo with Ms. Hago. It is a gentle and beautiful place, filled with manicured parks and crisscrossed by roads whose every curb seems contoured for bicycle tires. We rode along the beach by the bay, with the Oresund Bridge visible in the distance, and to the Ribersborgs Kallbadhus, where men and women have taken saunas and dipped into the Baltic, icy or otherwise, for 100 years. We went to the 16th-century Malmohus Castle, now home to several museums. We had tea in the botanical gardens. And then we biked into the Old City, with its series of lovely interlocking piazzas. That evening, we sat with thousands of others in one of them, drinking Carlsberg beer and watching the finals of the European Cup soccer championship on a giant television screen. I felt I'd walked into a local festival, one to which tourists rarely find the way; and when France forced the game against Italy into overtime with only seconds left to play, I was pleased -- not so much because I wanted one team or the other to win, but because I simply was not ready for this magic moment to end.
Taking the new train back to Copenhagen, looking out at the Whistler bluish-grays on one side and the salmon-colored sunset on the other, I was struck by one of the paradoxes of progress. The Oresund Fixed Link will rescue Malmo from its isolation, making it more accessible to people like me. But it will just as surely deprive it, and quickly, of its provincial charms.
