HEADLINE: THE ANNOTATED LIST: ART;
A Gathering of New Isms, Old Masters and Noodles

BYLINE: By HOLLAND COTTER

 BODY:

A * indicates an event of special note.
 
September
 
* "SOL LEWITT: A RETROSPECTIVE"
Mr. LeWitt, a linchpin figure between Minimalism and Conceptualism, is celebrated in a retrospective that ranges from early, spare text pieces to modular sculptures to the colorful wall drawings he has been masterminding in recent years. The show is at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago, through Oct. 22. It travels to the Whitney Museum of American Art. Dec. 7-Feb. 25. Mr. LeWitt's work from the 1970's is on view in a small show titled "Incomplete Open Cubes" at the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford. Jan. 27-April 29. 

"TOM FRIEDMAN"
From mundane materials -- ballpoint pens, chewing gum, aspirins -- this young artist makes labor-intensive art of immense wit and ingenuity. A one-decade survey, organized by the Southeastern Center for Contemporary Art (Secca) in Winston-Salem, N.C., is on view at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago through Oct 1, then moves on to the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco (Nov. 4-Jan. 28); Aspen Art Museum. Colorado (Feb. 16-April 15); Secca (July 14-Sept. 24); and the New Museum of Contemporary Art, N.Y. (Oct. 11-Jan. 17, 2002)
 
"PARADISE NOW"
The new season's first entry in the Big Science sweepstakes. Genetic engineering is the theme tackled by the curators Carole Kismaric and Marvin Heiferman, with the artists Julian LaVerdiere, Inigo Manglano-Ovalle, Alexis Rockman, Mark Dion and others. Exit Art. Through Oct. 28. (212-966-7745) www.exitart.org.
 
"THE NEW FRONTIER: ART AND TELEVISION, 1960-1965"
Organized by the art historian John Alan Farmer, the show considers the influence of the Tube on the visual arts at a formative moment in American culture. Among the members of the TV generation to be included: Wallace Berman, Bruce Conner, Yoko Ono, Nam June Paik and Andy Warhol. Austin Museum of Art. Through Nov. 26. (512-495-9224) www.amoa.org.
 
"JEREMY BLAKE"
This artist's use of dissolving photo projections to create the equivalent of geometric abstract paintings has been much admired of late. Four of his video projections, along with large-scale photographs, are on view at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts, Philadelphia. Through Nov. 5.
 
"A BRUSH WITH NATURE: THE GERE COLLECTION OF LANDSCAPE OIL SKETCHES"
Arriving from the National Gallery, London, is a selection of modest-size 18th- and 19th-century landscape oil sketches, dashed off outdoors in an attempt to capture effects of light and atmosphere for reference in the studio. The Frick Collection. Tuesday through Nov. 12.
 
"JORGE PARDO: PROJECT"
Mr. Pardo's art-and-function project entails redesigning the lobby of the Dia Center's building in Chelsea, staging an exhibition in a reconfigured gallery and creating a new bookstore on the premises. Dia Center for the Arts. Wednesday through June 17.
 
"THE CHINESE PAINTER AS POET"
presents an array of fans, hanging scrolls, wood-block prints and jade carvings, from the Song Dynasty to the 20th century, to trace the integration of the written word -- often poetry -- with the image in Chinese art. China Institute. Thursday through Dec. 10. (212-744-8181) www.chinainstitute.org.
 
* "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION"
The Chinese consider calligraphy their supreme cultural achievement, which is saying a lot. This show, made up of selections from some extraordinary American collections, is the largest survey of its kind ever mounted in the West. Metropolitan Museum of Art. Friday through Jan. 7.
 
"EAST OF THE RIVER: CHICANO ART COLLECTORS ANONYMOUS"
A show drawn from work owned by a group of private collectors who support and preserve the community-based work of Chicano artists in Los Angeles. Santa Monica Museum of Art. Friday through Nov. 18. (310-586-6488) www.netvip.com/smmoa.
 
"PIERRE AND GILLES"
Using make-up, costumes and lighting, this collaborative team creates fantasy photographs that are further glamorized through hand-painting. The end product: transcendental kitsch. New Museum of Contemporary Art. Friday through Jan. 21. A related article is on Page 91.
 
"UDOMSAK KRISANAMIS"
This young Thai artist uses materials like noodles and newspapers to create abstract works with relief surfaces and cosmological imagery. Wexner Center for the Arts, Columbus, Ohio. Saturday through December. (614-292-0330)www.wexarts.org.
 
"RONI HORN: STILL WATER (THE RIVER THAMES, FOR EXAMPLE), 1999"
An installation of 15 photographs of the surface of the Thames, each annotated by a text. The Whitney Museum of American Art. Saturday through Jan. 14.
 
"JOHN WESLEY: PAINTINGS 1961-2000"
A first United States retrospective for a maverick artist, born in Los Angeles in 1928, who paints animals, show girls and athletes in a distinctive cartoonlike style influenced by Matisse, Art Nouveau and Surrealism. Alanna Heiss does the curatorial honors. P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, Long Island City, Queens. Next Sunday through Jan. 15. (718-784-2084) www.ps1.org.
 
"FOUNTAINS OF LIGHT: ISLAMIC METALWORK FROM THE NUHAD ES-SAID COLLECTION"
More than two dozen inlaid precious-metal objects from present day Iran, Syria, Afghanistan and Turkey. Dating from the 10th to the 19th century, they're on long-term loan to the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in Washington. Opens next Sunday.
 
"ART AND THE EMPIRE CITY: NEW YORK 1825-1861"
Between the year the Erie Canal was built and the beginning of the Civil War, New York turned into a commercial and cultural center and the largest city in the Western Hemisphere. This selection of 300 objects -- paintings, photography, furniture, silver -- documents the polishing of the Big Apple. Metropolitan Museum. Sept. 19-Jan. 7.
 
"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE: ALEXANDRA EXTER, NATALIA GONCHAROVA, LIUBOV POPOVA, OLGA ROZANOVA, VARVARA STEPANOVA AND NADEZHDA UDALTSOVA"
Art by six Russian women who, in the first quarter of the 20th century, made significant contributions to the development of European modernism. Guggenheim Museum. Sept. 20-Jan. 7.
 
"FOCUS: STAN DOUGLAS"
Organized by Okwui Enwezor, this exhibition by a widely exhibited Canadian artist will include 25 large-format color photographs of the socially and economically battered city of Detroit and a documentary film with a hip-hop score. Art Institute of Chicago. Sept. 20-Dec. 19. (312-443-3600) www.artic.edu. A show of Mr. Douglas's photographs and videos will be at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. Dec. 10-April 1.
 
"CY TWOMBLY: THE SCULPTURE"
includes 65 pieces in plaster, stone and bronze from 1946-98 by an artist best known for his abstract paintings. The show, which had its debut at the Kunstmuseum Basel, appears at the Menil Collection, Houston. Sept. 20-Jan. 7. (713-525-9400) www.menil.org. Traveling to the National Gallery of Art, Washington. May 6-July 29.
 
"BRIDGET RILEY: RECONNAISSANCE"
This British artist's optically mesmerizing paintings from the 1960's have long enjoyed mythic status, but are more often heard about than seen in New York. The exhibition will offer both older pieces and a new wall drawing. Dia Center for the Arts. Sept. 21-June 17.
 
"HIP-HOP NATION: ROOTS, RHYMES AND RAGE"
mixes video, music, art and fashion to examine an electrifying pop-cultural phenomenon, now two decades old, which has moved from the urban underground to television advertising. Brooklyn Museum of Art. Sept. 22-Dec. 31
 
"REMBRANDT CREATES REMBRANDT: ART AND AMBITION IN LEIDEN 1629-1631"
Rembrandt was a shrewd combination of soulfulness and showmanship. This small show focuses on his formative years and centers around an early self-portrait in the museum's collection. Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, Boston. Sept. 23-Jan. 7. (617-566-1401)www.
boston.com/gardner.
 
* "ULTRABAROQUE: ASPECTS OF POST-LATIN AMERICAN ART"
This traveling exhibition brings together 16 young artists from Latin America who examine the notion of a baroque sensibility long associated with Latin American art itself, but place this aesthetic in a context of international styles and loosened-up notions of cultural identity. The show opens at the Museum of Contemporary Art San Diego at La Jolla. Sept. 23-Jan. 24. (858-454-3541) www.mcasandiego.org. Traveling to the Modern Art Museum, Fort Worth (Feb. 4-May 6); San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (Aug. 18-Jan. 2, 2002); Art Museum of Ontario, Toronto (Jan. 30-April 28, 2002); Miami Art Museum (June 20-Aug. 24, 2002); and the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis (Oct. 13, 2002-Jan. 5, 2003).
 
"LOUISE DAHL-WOLFE: THE AMERICA IMAGE"
A survey of more than 130 photographs, with clips and memorabilia, by a leading American fashion photographer, active from the 1930's to the 1960's and associated primarily with Harper's Bazaar. Center for Creative Photography, Tucson. Sept. 23-Nov. 26. (520-621-7968) www.creativephotography.org.
 
"WAYNE THIEBAUD: A PAINTINGS RETROSPECTIVE"
An 80th-birthday homage to a painterly California Pop artist who seems to be the latest inductee into the American Master Hall of Fame. Organized by the Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco, it will be at the Modern Art Museum Fort Worth Sept. 24-Jan. 14. (817-738-9215) www.mamfw.org. Traveling to the Phillips Collection, Washington (Feb. 10-April 29) and the Whitney Museum (June 28-Sept. 23). A show of the artist's prints will be at the Corcoran Gallery of Art. Feb. 3-April 22.
 
"MOROCCO: JEWS AND ART IN A MUSLIM LAND"
Jewish culture, an important presence in North Africa, will be viewed through more than 180 objects, including gold and silver ceremonial objects, jewelry, textiles and Orientalist paintings of Eugene Delacroix. Jewish Museum. Sept. 24-Feb. 11.
 
"THE FILM ART OF ISAAC JULIEN"
Four multiscreen video installations, with photographs, make up a first solo museum show for an important black British independent filmmaker, best known for his sexy, dreamlike documentary film about the poet Langston Hughes, "Looking for Langston" (1989). Center for Curatorial Studies at Bard College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. Sept. 24-Dec. 15. (845-758-7598) www.bard.edu.
 
"IN THE PRESENCE OF SPIRITS: SELECTIONS FROM THE NATIONAL MUSEUM OF ETHNOLOGY, LISBON"
The show will include combs, carved pipes, stone funerary figures and monumental masks from Angola, Guinea and Ivory Coast, some making their first appearance in the United States. The show opens at the Museum for African Art. Sept. 27-Dec 31. (212-966-1313) www.africanart.org. Traveling to Flint Institute of Arts, Michigan (Feb. 1-April 29); National Museum of African Art, Smithsonian Institution, Washington, (June 10-Sept. 14); and the Birmingham Museum of Art, Alabama (Oct. 25, 2001-Jan. 5, 2002).
 
"RUSKIN'S ITALY, RUSKIN'S ENGLAND"
The Victorian monument named John Ruskin died 100 years ago, and this selection of drawings, watercolors, manuscripts, letters and artifacts, all from the Morgan Library's premier Ruskin holdings, offers a chance to pay tribute to his achievements and to ponder his elusive, unstable personality. Morgan Library. Sept. 28-Jan. 7.
 
* "MOMA2000: OPEN ENDS"
The final lap of the Museum of Modern Art's millennial marathon of self-examination and, one hopes, self-renewal, will arrive in three sections with staggered opening dates. Together they will embrace work in the museum's collection from 1960 through the present, from Jasper Johns to Pipilotti Rist. Part I, Sept. 28-Jan. 2; Part II, Oct. 19-Jan. 30; Part III, Nov. 5-Jan. 30.
 
October
 
"A SPIRITUAL JOURNEY: THE ART OF EDDIE LEE KENDRICK"
A survey of paintings by an American self-taught artist who took his themes from the Bible, gospel hymns and dreams. His work was first noticed in 1977 when a teacher in a Little Rock, Ark., public elementary school, where Kendrick was a janitor,saw some of his paintings in the custodian's office. Fenimore Art Museum, Cooperstown, N.Y. Oct. 1-Dec. 31. (607-547-1400) www.fenimoreartmuseum.org.
 
"THE YEAR ONE: ART OF THE ANCIENT WORLD EAST AND WEST"
The Met gets into the millennium swing with a culling of 150 works from its collection that date back approximately 2,000 years. Roman portraits, Celtic metalwork, Indian Buddhas and Egyptian sculptures spell "multiculturalism" in the Ancient World. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 3-Jan. 14.
 
"LOVE AND LOSS: AMERICAN PORTRAIT AND MOURNING MINIATURES"
Often painted in watercolor on thin disks of ivory and enclosed in lockets, these portraits were painted on commission to commemorate births, marriages and deaths by artists famous (John Singleton Copley, Benjamin West) and unknown. The show examines the connections between the miniature and the history of private life in America. Yale University Art Gallery. Oct. 30-Dec. 30. (203-432-0600) www.yale.edu/artgallery.
 
* "EDWARD STEICHEN"
A chronological survey, the first in 40 years, of this influential American photographer will include his iconic shots of Manhattan and of luminaries like Greta Garbo and J. P. Morgan, along with examples of his paintings and textile designs. Whitney Museum. Oct. 5-Feb. 4.
 
"LEE KRASNER"
This retrospective brings Krasner home to the city where she lived and worked. Famously the wife of Jackson Pollock, she was an artist with a mind, a life and a style of her own. Brooklyn Museum. Oct. 6-Jan. 7. A related article is on Page 91.
 
"SPANISH IMPRESSIONISM AND POST-IMPRESSIONISM: A NEW SELECTION"
The Hispanic Society of America on Manhattan's upper Upper West Side is a gold mine of modern Spanish painting, a tradition that includes such virtuosi as Sorolla and Fortuny. Seldom seen work by both will be brought to light and, as a bonus, there are fabulous Sorolla murals of Spanish village life on permanent view. Hispanic Society of America. Oct. 6-Dec. 22. (212-926-2234) www.hispanicsociety.org.
 
"RADCLIFFE BAILEY: THE MAGIC CITY"
This Atlanta-based artist combines expressionist painting, photography and sculpture in dense, poetic images of African-American history. Birmingham Museum of Art, Alabama. Oct. 8-Dec. 31. (205-254-2565) www.artsBMA.org.
 
* "ART NOUVEAU, 1890-1914"
had its debut at the Victoria and Albert in London and it's a very V & A affair: a vast assemblage of ceramics, jewelry, glass, textiles and furniture, along with paintings and sculptures, all to document the slinky fin-de-siecle Euro-American design movement. The National Gallery is adding a slew of material for its presentation, which is on view from Oct. 8-Jan. 28. The show will move on to the Tokyo Metropolitan Art Museum April 21-July 8.
 
* "ANTIOCH: THE LOST ANCIENT CITY"
This archaeological show brings to light one of the most important cultural centers of the ancient world through frescoes, mosaics, metalwork, glassware and a re-creation of a Roman dining room. Worcester Art Museum in Massachusetts, which organized it. Oct. 8-Feb. 4. (508-799-4406) www.worcesterart.org. Traveling to the Cleveland Museum of Art (March. 19-June 3) and the Baltimore Museum of Art (Aug. 30-Dec. 30).
 
"WHITFIELD LOVELL: WHISPERS FROM THE WALLS"
This audio-visual installation in the form of a one-room cabin is about the uprooting of an African-American community in the 1920's. The Studio Museum in Harlem. Oct. 11-Dec. 31. (212-864-4500)
www.studiomuseuminharlem.org.
 
"ARCHITECT OF DREAMS: THE THEATRICAL VISION OF JOSEPH URBAN"
The German-born Urban was best known for his architecture -- the New School for Social Research, for example -- but also designed stage sets for the Metropolitan Opera and the Ziegfeld Follies. Watercolor studies and stage models of his theater work will be at the Wallach Art Gallery at Columbia University, which has a strong track record with archival exhibition like this. Oct. 11-Dec. 16. (212-854-7288) www.columbia.edu/cu/wallach.
 
"POWER AND DESIRE: SOUTH ASIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE SAN DIEGO MUSEUM OF ART, EDWIN BINNEY 3RD COLLECTION"
Painting in India has a long history that survives, in part, in pictures known as miniatures. Whether they come from the court workshops of Rajput princes or from the grand Mughal ateliers in Delhi, they are amazing, and the Binney collection has a full range of styles. Asia Society. Oct. 12-Jan. 7. (212-288-6400) www.asiasociety.org.
 
"LEONARDO DREW"
A large-scale abstract installation and drawings by a young artist who evokes African-American rural and urban experience in monumental, material-rich sculpture. TheBronx Museum of the Arts. Oct. 5-Mar. 4.
 
* "THE GOLDEN DEER OF EURASIA: SCYTHIAN AND SARMATIAN TREASURES FROM THE RUSSIAN STEPPES"
You'll probably be able to see this show glowing on the horizon, what with its two-foot-high sculptures of deer and other gold items brought up from digs in southern Russia. Metropolitan Museum. Oct. 12-Feb. 4. And there's more precious metal in the "Gold of the Nomads: Scythian Treasures from Ancient Ukraine," which lands at the Brooklyn Museum at the same time. Oct. 13-Jan. 21.
 
* "UTOPIA: THE SEARCH FOR THE IDEAL SOCIETY"
This collaboration between the New York Public Library and the Bibliotheque National in Paris is about concepts of the ideal society in Western culture from classical antiquity to the present. Voltaire's manuscript of "Candide" will be here, along with some Shaker boxes, photographs of a Florida town named Disney's Celebration and a copy of the Declaration of Independence in Thomas Jefferson's hand. New York Public Library. Oct. 14-Jan. 27. (212-869-8089) www.nypl.org.
 
"PAINTING THE TOWN: CITYSCAPES OF NEW YORK"
A portrait of New York from 1809 to 1997, organized by a museum that specializes in the subject. Museum of the City of New York. Oct. 14-Dec. 31. (212-534-1672) www.mcny.org.
 
"YES YOKO ONO"
Ms. Ono was one of the early participants in the international Fluxus movement, and this first major United States retrospective will survey her career from the 1960's to the present with films, videos, artist's books, installations and instructional pieces. Organized by Alexandra Munroe and Jon Hendricks for the Japan Society Gallery. Oct. 18-Jan 14. (212-832-1155) www.jpnsoc.org. Traveling to the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis (March 10-June 17); Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston (July 13-Sept. 16); List Visual Arts Center at M.I.T., Cambridge, Mass. (Oct. 18, 2001-Jan. 6, 2002); Art Gallery of Ontario, Toronto (Feb. 22-May 20, 2002); San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (June 22-Sept. 8, 2002) and to Asia.
 
"GIORGIO ARMANI"
Did the fashion mogul sort of, like, rent the Guggenheim for this ramp-filling survey, or what? With the director-designer Robert Wilson in charge of the installation, Style is the name of the game. Guggenheim Museum. Oct. 20-Jan. 17. Traveling to the Guggenheim Bilbao Mar. 13-Aug. 26.
 
"THE KOREAN WAR IN AMERICAN ART AND CULTURE"
Scans a historical episode through period artifacts as well as work by contemporary Korean-American artists like Michael Joo, Yong Soon Min and Ik-Joong Kang. Organized by Simon Taylor for the Guild Hall Museum, East Hampton, N.Y. Oct. 21-Jan. 7. (631-324-0806) www.guildhall.org.
 
"GLENN LIGON"
Mr. Ligon, an artist whose text-based explorations of black life in America were an important part of art in the 1990's, has created new large-scale work for this show at the Walker Art Center, Minneapolis. Oct. 22-March 11.
 
* "MADE IN CALIFORNIA: IMAGE AND IDENTITY, 1900-2000"
This broad-spectrum thematic take on a century of art in California is the largest exhibition ever done by a museum noted for its compendious and unorthodox projects, and the results could be absorbing. Work by artists, well known and unknown, will share space with posters, books, advertisements and other evidence of the kind of pop culture California practically invented. Los Angeles County Museum of Art. Oct. 22-Feb. 25.
 
"NARRATIVES OF AFRICAN AMERICAN ART AND IDENTITY: THE DAVID C. DRISKELL COLLECTION"
The artist and historian David C. Driskell has been collecting since the early 1950's, and a representative selection of his holdings is in this traveling show at the Newark Museum. Oct. 25-Feb. 25. A concurrent show of work by Mr. Driskell is being presented by Aljira, A Center for Contemporary Art at the Paul Robeson Gallery of Rutgers University, Newark. Oct. 25-Dec. 13. (973-643-6877).
 
"TAINO"
The inauguration of a new permanent gallery dedicated to the art of the Taino, a culture that flourished in the Caribbean islands from 1200 to 1500, represents an important step for El Museo del Barrio, which offered a scholarly exhibition of this still under-studied material in 1997. The new gallery opens on Oct. 26. On the same day, a show of Latin American photography from the collections of the Lehigh University in Pennsylvania also goes on view at the museum. Museo del Barrio. (212-831-7272) www.elmuseo.org.
 
"WOLFGANG LAIB"
A midcareer retrospective for a sculptor whose spare, meditative work, inspired by Minimalism and non-Western cultures, is made of organic ingredients like pollen, rice and beeswax. Hirshhorn Museum. Oct. 26-Jan 22. Traveling to the Henry Art Gallery, Seattle (Feb. 13-May 6); Dallas Museum of Art (May 29-Sept. 2); Scottsdale Museum of Contemporary Art, Arizona (Oct. 5-Dec. 30); Museum of Contemporary Art, San Diego (Jan. 25-April 21, 2002); Haus der Kunst, Munich (Oct. 8, 2002-Jan. 5, 2003). An installation made of pollen will be at the Berkeley Art Museum in California Oct. 14-Dec. 17.
 
"BETWEEN THE THUNDER AND THE RAIN: CHINESE PAINTINGS FROM THE OPIUM WAR THROUGH THE CULTURAL REVOLUTION, 1840-1979"
Drawn from a single California private collection, this show highlights work by a wide range of artists during a turbulent period that saw the end of dynastic rule, Japanese occupation and the Cultural Revolution. Asian Art Museum of San Francisco. Oct. 25-Jan 14. (415-379-8800) www.asianart.org.
 
"NEW WORK: EDUOARD DUVAL CARRIE"
This Haitian-born artist evokes Caribbean religious themes in a site-specific installation at the Miami Art Museum. Oct. 26-Jan. 14.
 
"ADRIAN PIPER: A RETROSPECTIVE, 1965-2000"
A hard-hitting gathering of text-based photography, installations and early paintings by an American conceptualist who, since the early 1970's, has been one of the most incisive and articulate commentators on the politics of race. Organized by Maurice Berger for the Fine Arts Gallery, University of Maryland, where it opened, it will be at the New Museum of Contemporary Art. Oct. 26-Jan. 21. Traveling to the Weatherspoon Art Gallery, University of North Carolina, Greenboro (Feb. 11-April 15) and the Contemporary Arts Center, Cincinnati (June 23-Aug. 19). A separate survey of Ms. Piper's video work, "MEDI(t)ATIONS," organized by Dara Meyers-Kingsley, will also be at the New Museum and is on view at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles through Nov. 5.
 
"HENRI MICHAUX"
A survey of calligraphic works on paper by the Belgian poet and critic will be at the Drawing Center in SoHo. Oct. 28-Dec. 20.
 
"VIK MUNIZ"
The first museum retrospective of the Brazilian-born artist known for his photographic images made with sugar, yarn and chocolate syrup will inaugurate the new Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y. The show then tours to the Contemporary Art Center, New Orleans, and elsewhere. Also at the Tang: "S.O.S: The Sound of Art," an exhibition of contemporary work composed of or incorporating audio elements, including work by a master of the medium, Stephen Vitiello. Oct. 28-Jan. 31. (518-580-8080) www.skidmore.edu/tang.
 
"PAUL MCCARTHY"
This first museum retrospective for an influential California artist will include installations, performance videos and drawings, many of them of the hilariously in-your-face, "parental guidance advised" variety. Mr. McCarthy is big, bad and major. Museum of Contemporary Art, Los Angeles. Oct. 26-Jan 21. Traveling to the New Museum of Contemporary Art Feb. 15-May 13.
 
November
 
"INTERACTIVE DESIGN LAB,"
organized by the artist and writer Ronald Jones, is a sampling of interdisciplinary artists involved in exploring new technologies. Artists Space. Nov. 9-Jan. 31. (212-226-3970) www.artistsspace.org.
 
"PAINTING ON LIGHT: DRAWING ON STAINED GLASS IN THE AGE OF DURER AND HOLBEIN"
This show, which is on view at the J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles, through Sept. 24, brings together more than 50 stained-glass panels from the Gothic and early Renaissance periods, along with 80 drawings of window designs, many of them by the leading artists of the day. St. Louis Art Museum. Nov. 4-Jan. 7.
 
"TAOISM AND THE ARTS OF CHINA"
This ambitious exhibition will explore the pervasive relationship between the indigenous philosophy-religion known as Taoism and Chinese art and culture, with examples of sculpture, painting, calligraphy, textiles and books. Art Institute of Chicago. Nov. 4-Jan 7. (312-443-3600) www.artic.edu. Traveling to the Asian Art Museum of San Francisco (Feb. 21-May 13).
 
"CHORUS OF LIGHT: PHOTOGRAPHS FROM THE SIR ELTON JOHN COLLECTION"
The British pop veteran has amassed a considerable collection of work by blue-chip figures like Berenice Abbott, Tina Modotti and Edward Weston. "I never get fed up looking at the images," says Sir Elton. Nearly 400 pieces will be on view at the High Museum of Art, Atlanta, with "celebrity portraits" in a separate show in the museum's downtown gallery. Nov. 4-Jan. 28.
 
"MIRIAM SCHAPIRO: A RETROSPECTIVE OF PAINTINGS, 1954-1997"
covers the career of an artist who was a central figure in the early feminist art of the 1970's and in the Pattern and Decoration movement. Minnesota Museum of American Art, Minneapolis. Nov. 11-Jan. 28. (651-292-4355) www.mtn.org/mmaa.
 
ZIMMERLI MUSEUM
After being under renovation for more than a year, the Jane Voorhees Zimmerli Art Museum at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J., opens with seven exhibitions highlighting the museum's holdings in Russian 20th-century art and material related to the Japonism movement in America. Nov. 12, various closing dates. (732-932-7237) www-rci.rutgers.edu/zamuseum/.
 
"BODY POLITICS: THE FEMALE IMAGE IN LUBA ART AND THE SCULPTURE OF ALISON SAAR"
This show includes sculptures from the Luba kingdom of central Africa along with work by the contemporary African-American artist Alison Saar. U.C.L.A. Fowler Museum of Cultural History, Los Angeles. Nov. 12-May 13.
 
"WORLDS REVEALED: THE DAWN OF JAPANESE AND AMERICAN EXCHANGE"
The Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass., is a treasure chest of art and artifacts brought to New England by merchant ships and whalers two centuries ago. This exhibition documents early cultural interactions between the United States and what was once called the Far East. Nov. 17, continuing. Peabody Essex Museum. (800-745-4054) www.pem.org.
 
"ANDY WARHOL: SOCIAL OBSERVER"
Organized by Jonathan Binstock for the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts (where it is on view through Sept. 21), this show examines the Pop-meister's unblinking view of the social issues of the postwar years, from racial violence to the cult of celebrity. His political views veered between principled concern and opportunism (portrait commissions from the high and mighty were a career priority), but nothing escaped his attention. Corcoran Gallery. Nov. 18-Feb. 19.
 
December
 
"LISA YUSKAVAGE"
Ms. Yuskavage's paintings of extravagantly nubile women have attracted a lot of attention in the last few years. Some feminists find them retrograde; others say that they're taking control over what was once the exclusive terrain of "the male gaze." Institute of Contemporary Art, Philadelphia. Dec. 2-Feb. 4. (215-898-7108) www.upenn.edu/ica.
 
* "INDIA THROUGH THE LENS: PHOTOGRAPHY 1840-1911"
With formal portraits of dressed-to-the-nines maharajas, scenes of British colonial life joining Felice Beato's documentation of the aftermath of the Indian Mutiny of 1857, this is bound to be a mesmerizing show. Arthur M. Sackler Gallery. Dec. 3-Mar. 25.
 
"CHARLOTTE SALOMON: LIFE? OR THEATER?"
Salomon died at Auschwitz at age 26 and left behind hundreds of semi-autobiographical paintings on paper that document her haunted life. The show originated in London, is at the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston, through Oct. 29 and travels to the Jewish Museum Dec. 10-Mar. 25.
 
"THE DRAFTSMAN'S ART: MASTER DRAWINGS FROM THE NATIONAL GALLERY OF SCOTLAND"
Leonardo, Raphael, Rubens, Blake, Ingres, Seurat, with a few guys you've never heard of. Enough said. Frick Collection. Dec. 12-Feb. 25.
 
January
 
"ANDY WARHOL: PHOTOGRAPHY"
Warhol, with his infinite capacity for absorbing data, almost always packed a tape recorder or a camera, and sometimes both. This show covers the range of his photographic work. International Center of Photography, New York. Jan. 11-Mar. 18.
 
"INSIDE SPACE: EXPERIMENTS IN REDEFINING ROOMS"
The first show organized by the M.I.T. List Visual Art Center's new curator, Bill Arning, will see an international group of young artists -- among them Monica Bonvicini, Teresita Fernandez, Juan Maidigan and the team of Elmgreen and Dragset -- shaking up interior architecture. M.I.T. List Visual Arts Center, Cambridge, Mass. Jan. 16-April 8.
 
'JEAN POYET: ARTIST TO THE COURT OF RENAISSANCE FRANCE"
The illuminator Jean Poyet (active circa 1483-1503) served in the courts of three French kings. His Prayer Book of Anne de Bretagne is a gem of the Morgan Library's collection. This compare-and-contrast look at Poyet in the context of his contemporaries will be at the Morgan Library. Jan 25-May 6.
 
"GAUGUIN'S 'NIRVANA': PAINTERS AT LE POULDU, 1889-90"
Gauguin spent a brief time in the fishing village of Le Pouldu in Brittany with his disciple, patron and rival, the Dutch artist Jacob Isaac Meyer de Haan, who painted alongside him and paid the bills. Wadsworth Atheneum. Jan. 26-April 29.
 
* "ALFRED STIEGLITZ AND MODERN ART IN AMERICA"
A look at Stieglitz's formative role in advancing art in America, as photographer, publisher and gallery director. Works that he showed at his galleries will be reassembled; his 1914 exhibition of African art will be partially reconstructed. There will also be mini-surveys of American artists he championed, among them Charles Demuth, Arthur Dove, Marsden Hartley, Georgia O'Keeffe and Edward Steichen. National Gallery of Art. Jan. 28-April 22.
 
"ABRAHAM BLOEMAERT (1566-1651) AND HIS TIME"
Bloemaert was a skilled Dutch Mannerist painter of landscapes and religious scenes and apparently an excellent teacher with many talented pupils in Utrecht. This small show centers on a single painting by him in the museum's collection. Museum of Fine Arts, St. Petersburg, Fla. Jan. 28-April 8. (727-896-2667) www.fine.arts.org.
 
"JANINE ANTONI"
Ms. Antoni was the winner of the 1999 Larry Aldrich Foundation award, and work created during her recent residency at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield, Conn., appears there from Jan. 21-May 20. (203-438-4519) www.aldrichart.org.
 
"EDOUARD MANET: THE STILL-LIFE PAINTINGS"
Manet's late still lifes of flowers in tumblers are among his most purely beautiful pictures. They will be joined in this show, which originated at the Musee d'Orsay in Paris, by earlier paintings and prints. Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore. Jan. 28-April 22. (410-547-9000) www.thewalters.org.
 
"MODERN CHINESE PAINTING, 1840-1980: SELECTIONS FROM THE ROBERT H. ELLSWORTH COLLECTION IN THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART"
Organized by Wen C. Fong, this is a selection from nearly 500 works in the Ellsworth collection, all created during a period of dramatic political change as China entered the modern world. Metropolitan Museum. Jan. 30-Aug. 19.
 
February
 
"VAN GOGH AND PAINTERS OF THE PETIT BOULEVARD"
looks at the painter's relationship to artists of the Parisian avant-garde, among them Gauguin, Pissarro, Seurat and Toulouse-Lautrec. St. Louis Art Museum. Feb. 17-May 31.
 
"DISTANT SHORES: THE ODYSSEY OF ROCKWELL KENT"
A survey of landscape paintings by an American artist and illustrator whose commitment to populist politics was unswerving but whose conservative art fell into disfavor after World War II. Organized by the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, Mass., the show appears at the Terra Museum of American Art, Chicago. Feb. 24-May 20. (312-664-3939) www.terramuseum.org.
 
"ROSMARIE TROCKEL: DRAWINGS"
A show of drawings by this artist caused a stir at the Museum of Modern Art in 1980, and there is reason to have high hopes for this new exhibition, which will be on view at the Pompidou Center in Paris before coming to the Drawing Center in SoHo. Feb. 24-April 7.
 
"TREASURY OF THE BASEL CATHEDRAL"
More than 70 liturgical items from the Basel Cathedral's treasury, which was dispersed in the 19th century, are reunited. One of the original storage cupboards is on display, too. Metropolitan Museum. Feb. 27-May 27.
 
"WILLIAM KENTRIDGE"
The animated films -- narratives of political and personal turmoil -- by this South African artist have been a staple of international art festivals. Ten are included here, along with related drawings and prints. The show has its debut at the Hirshhorn Museum, Washington. Feb. 28-May 6. Traveling to the New Museum (June 7-Sept. 16); Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago (Oct. 20-Jan. 20, 2002); the Contemporary Arts Museum, Houston, (Feb.-May 2002); Los Angeles County Museum of Art (June-Sept. 2002).
 
March
 
"EGYPTIAN ART FROM THE BRITISH MUSEUM"
The dynastic blowouts in New York and Boston last season left you hungry? There's more of the same in this show drawn from a thoroughbred collection. Organized by the American Federation of Arts, it opens at the Toledo Museum of Art. Mar. 2-May 27. (800-644-6862) www.toledomuseum.org. Traveling to Wonders, Memphis International Cultural Series (July 2-Oct. 21); Brooklyn Museum of Art (Dec. 1, 2001-Feb. 24, 2002); Nelson-Atkins Museum of Art, Kansas City (April 12-July 7, 2002); Minneapolis Institute of Art (Dec. 20, 2002-Mar. 16, 2003); Field Museum, Chicago (April 26-Aug. 3, 2003); Walters Art Gallery, Baltimore (Sept. 5, 2003-Jan. 7, 2004).
 
"ANDREAS GURSKY"
The curator Peter Galassi is in charge of this show made up of more than three dozen of the German-born artist's panoramic photographs, which turn modern life into a nightmare of material plenitude. Museum of Modern Art. Mar. 4-May 15.
 
"INTIMATE WORLDS: MASTERPIECES OF INDIAN PAINTING FROM THE ALVIN O. BELLAK COLLECTION"
A superb collection of miniatures that has been promised to the Philadelphia Museum and is on view in its entirety for the first time under the curatorial hand of Darielle Mason. Philadelphia Museum of Art. March 4-April 29. (215-684-8100) www.philamuseum.org.
 
"AUGUST SANDER: GERMAN PORTRAITS, 1918-1933"
Sander's photographs scrutinized the social soul of a country and an era. The faces of peasants, artists and industrialists fill this survey of pictures made during the post-World War I Weimar Republic up to the eve of Hitler's Third Reich. J. Paul Getty Museum, Los Angeles. Mar. 6-June 24.
 
"VERMEER AND THE DELFT SCHOOL"
Organized by the Metropolitan Museum and the National Gallery, London, this exhibition perks up the standard image of Delft as a town of hushed Vermeerian interiors by adding busy historical paintings, princely portraits and attention-grabbing decorative arts items. Metropolitan Museum. Mar. 8-May 27.
 
"GRANDMA MOSES IN THE 21ST CENTURY"
begins with painting from the 1940's by the self-taught upstate New York artist Anna Mary Robertson "Grandma" Moses and ends with her last picture, in 1961. Her work was overexposed in the past, but she's really good. National Museum of Women in the Arts, Washington. Mar. 15-June 10. (202-783-5000) www.nmwa.org. Traveling to the San Diego Museum of Art (June 30-Aug. 26); Orlando Museum of Art (Sept. 15-Nov. 11); Brooklyn Museum of Art (Dec. 1-Jan. 27, 2002); Gilcrease Museum of American History and Art, Tulsa (Feb. 23-April 20, 2002); Columbus Museum of Art, Ohio (May 11-July 28, 2002); Portland Art Museum, Oregon (Aug. 17-Dec. 1, 2002).
 
* "WILLIAM BLAKE, 1757-1827"
More than 200 works, including one-of-a-kind hand-printed and painted books, by this British poet, political revolutionary and mystic, who saw angels sitting in trees, are in a show organized by the Tate Gallery. Metropolitan Museum. Mar. 27-June 24.
 
"THE PLEDGE OF FRIENDSHIP: AMERICAN PHOTOGRAPHY AND MALE AFFECTION, 1840-1918"
Organized by the art historian David Deitcher, an examination of images of male intimacy as seen in daguerreotypes, tintypes and paper photographs from the 19th and early 20th centuries. Also on view in what sounds like a dynamite lineup: the first museum survey devoted to Kiki Smith's photographs, and a show titled "Behind Closed Doors: The Art of Hans Bellmer." International Center for Photography Midtown. Mar. 29-June 10.
 
April
 
"RALPH FASANELLA'S AMERICA"
A retrospective of paintings by the wonderful second generation Italian-American artist who depicted minutely detailed scenes of labor history, American politics and his own urban working-class life. Fenimore Art Museum, Cooperstown, N.Y. April 1-Dec. 31.
 
"AZTLAN TODAY: THE CHICANO POSTNATION"
Aztlan is the legendary territory, covering parts of both Mesoamerica and the American Southwest, claimed as homeland by the ancient Aztecs and by Mexican-Americans or Chicanos today. This show includes photography and video by a dozen Chicano artists, including Laura Aguilar, Daniel Joseph Martinez and Kathy Vargas. Bronx Museum of the Arts. April 5-Sept. 9. Another show, "The Road to Aztlan: Art from a Mythic Homeland," is a historical investigation of the cultural makeup, ancient and modern, of the region. Los Angeles County Museum of Art. May 13-Aug. 26.
 
"SANTOS: SCULPTURE BETWEEN HEAVEN AND EARTH"
An exhibition of small carved wooden polychrome religious figures from the collection of El Museo del Barrio in Manhattan. Newark Museum. April 18-July 29.
 
"MARLENE DUMAS WITH LAYLAH ALI"
Two artists whose very different figurative styles deal indirectly with implied narratives of repression and violence. Institute of Contemporary Art, Boston. April 18-July 1. (617-266-5152) www.icpboston.org. Work by Ms. Ali is also on view at the Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco. Feb. 10-May 6.
 
"MONDRIAN: THE TRANSATLANTIC PAINTINGS"
is a gathering of 15 paintings that the Dutch artist began in Europe and completed in America after he fled Europe during World War II. Organized in part by Harvard's Straus Center for Conservation, the show offers detailed technical evidence of the revisions the artist made to the original paintings -- a jazz fanatic, he wanted to add what he called "more boogie-woogie" -- as well as insights into his technical process. Busch-Reisinger Museum at Harvard University, Cambridge, Mass. April 28-July 22. (617-495-9400) www.artmuseums.harvard.edu.
 
"L'ESPRIT NOUVEAU: PURISM IN PARIS, 1918-1925"
The classical geometric simplicity and machine aesthetic promoted by the likes of Le Corbusier and Fernand Leger are the focus of this exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. April 29-Aug. 5.
 
"SPIRIT WORLD: MEDIUMISTIC AND VISIONARY MESSAGES"
is an international show of work by self-taught artists who generated images while in a state of trance, or who chose to experiment with mystic or metaphysical issues. Museum of American Folk Art. April-Sept. (212-977-7170) www.folkartmuseum.org.
 
May
 
"JACQUELINE KENNEDY: THE WHITE HOUSE YEARS"
The Inaugural pillbox hat and the red dress she wore for her televised White House tour are among the 80 items associated with America's style-setting First Lady put together for this show by the Costume Institute at the Metropolitan Museum. May 1-July 15.
 
* "OVER THE LINE: THE ART AND LIFE OF JACOB LAWRENCE"
This retrospective of around 90 paintings by the esteemed artist who died this June coincides with the publication of a catalogue raisonne of his work. The show is organized by the Phillips Collection, Washington. May 26-Aug. 19. (202-387-2151) www.phillipscollection.
org. Traveling to the Whitney Museum (Nov. 8, 2001-Feb. 3, 2002); Detroit Institute of Arts (Feb. 23-May 19, 2002); Los Angeles County Museum (June 16-Sept. 8, 2002); Museum of Fine Arts, Houston (Oct. 6-Jan. 5, 2003). June
 
"YVES TANGUY"
A centennial birthday retrospective for the French Surrealist artist who painted bad-dream moonscapes running off to the horizon. Menil Collection, Houston. June 1-Sept. 16. (713-525-9400) www.menil.org.
 
"SNOWDON"
According to the director of the National Portrait Gallery in London, Lord Snowdon, ex-husband of Her Royal Highness Princess Margaret, "has known everyone worth knowing." Here are his pictures of fabulous people -- kings and queens and actors and models -- to prove it. Yale Center for British Art. June 15-Aug. 19. (203-432-2800) www.yale.edu/ycba.
 
"MARISOL"
A selective survey of some two dozen of this artist's large-scale Pop-inflected figurative sculptures made from carving, constructing, drawing and painting. Organized by Judy Collischan for the Neuberger Museum of Art, Purchase, N.Y. June 17-Sept. 2. (914-251-6100) www.neuberger.org.
 
"MIES IN BERLIN"
includes 30 designs by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe done between 1905 and 1938, the year he emigrated to the United States. Museum of Modern Art. June 21-Sept. 11, 2001).
 
"WORSHIPPING THE ANCESTORS: RITUAL AND COMMEMORATIVE PORTRAITS IN LATE IMPERIAL CHINA"
In China, ancestors were powerful beings and their portraits were venerated. Three dozen near-life-size examples from the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911) will cast their imperturbable glances around the Arthur M. Sackler Gallery in Washington. June 17-Sept. 9.
 
"MICHELANGELO DRAWINGS AND OTHER TREASURES FROM THE CASA BUONARROTI, FLORENCE"
will have about two dozen pieces by the man himself, including studies for the Sistine Chapel. High Museum of Art, Atlanta. June 23-Sept. 2.
 
"H. C. WESTERMANN"
The first career survey for Westermann (1922-1982) since the Whitney's in 1979 includes his kooky, often aggressively pessimistic sculptures and drawings. It begins at the Museum of Contemporary Art, Chicago. June 30-Sept. 23. Traveling to the Hirshhorn in Washington (Feb. 14-May 2, 2002); the Menil Collection, Houston (Oct. 4, 2002-Jan. 5, 2003). A show of the artist's prints will be at the Smart Museum, University of Chicago. June 28-Sept. 9.

PUB-DATE: September 10, 2000

SECTION: Section 2; Page 100; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 990 words

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE;
Design That Coaxes Buildings Out of Themselves

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

 BODY:
THE term "contextual" having become debased by those who fundamentally despise the whole idea of architecture, the time has come to speak of "relational" design -- buildings that interact with their surroundings in full dimension instead of dumbly mimicking the scale and form of their next-door neighbors. We should think of architecture as a supremely interactive art -- a participatory medium that transforms configurations of scale, dimension, shape, proximity, space, time, energy, cultural meaning, economic value and land use.
In the coming months, there will be many opportunities to enrich the vocabulary for talking about architecture in relational terms. Perhaps the most spirited of these projects is the continuing development of SPARCity -- Eric Owen Moss's name for the discontinuous loop of urban development he has been designing for Culver City, Calif.. (The project is named for the air rights over the former tracks of a Southern Pacific freight line). 
 Since the mid-1980's, Moss, supported by two enlightened clients, Frederick and Laurie Smith, has been converting abandoned factory buildings for use by firms specializing in graphic design, advertising, film production and other post-industrial businesses. This month, SPARCity reaches critical mass with the completion of the Stealth Building, as it has become known, the ground-hugging centerpiece of a newly redeveloped Culver City block. The building vaguely recalls the bomber's tapered horizontal profile.This is the authentic New Urbanism -- the productive future of the tattered industrial center.
The Tang Teaching Museum and Art Gallery at Skidmore College in Saratoga Springs, N.Y., is the first project in the Northeast by Antoine Predock, the architectural shaman of the American Southwest. Designed to foster crossdisciplinary experiments in the arts, the Tang is finished in stone, metal and concrete, and is surrounded by a circle of white pines. Two giant staircases converge to form a symbolic crossroads of culture and nature. Not since the glory days of the Beaux Arts have we seen such an extravagant representation of the ascent to Parnassus.
Since no relationship matters more than the unstable links between older urban centers and the suburbs encircling them, the most important event this season will be the presidential campaign. Between now and November, we will find out whether either candidate has anything substantial to say on urban policy. The past eight years have seen declining crime rates and increased participation from the private sector in urban life. But the Clinton administration wasted the opportunity to invest in housing, transportation and public space, or to revitalize the urban core as an economic engine.
Nowhere have the shortcomings of urban policy been clearer than in Baltimore, a city that has been at the forefront of innovation for three decades. Despite urban homesteading, the Harborside festival marketplace, the Camden Yards ball park and other initiatives undertaken by the public and private spheres, Baltimore continues to epitomize the city as a permanent invalid of modern life. The Student Arts Center, designed by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien for Johns Hopkins University, adds a new layer to the city's cultural mix. Intended to bring art into an environment dedicated to science, the three-winged building creates a new campus landscape with courtyards, paths, and views.
Things are really cooking this year for Zaha Hadid. Her most ambitious built work to date will open in December. A tramway station and car park in the French city of Strasbourg, the project is an infrastructural intervention designed to reduce car traffic in the central district. Like Peter Eisenman's design for the Staten Island ferry terminal, Hadid's forms are derived from the motion patterns of different transportation modes. And what, by the way, is the status of Eisenman's fine plan?
Not one of these forthcoming projects is "appropriate." Isn't that great? Like "contextual," the word "appropriate" has ceased to be constructive. Buildings can be good, bad, mediocre or pointless. But "appropriateness" is a useless gauge of architectural value. Rather, it has become equivalent to the notion of progress in the postwar decades. It represents the evasion of responsibility for personal preference. "Don't hold me accountable. History made me do it. Peer pressure made me do it." Mediocrity loves company.
Our understanding of older buildings will also benefit from the relational approach. David Leatherbarrow's "Uncommon Ground," a book due in October from MIT Press, revisits the work of Richard Neutra and other mid-20th century modernists to show that so-called International Style architects were often acutely sensitive to the local particulars of their building sites. By emphasizing the section (the cutaway view) over the plan and elevation, Leatherbarrow demonstrates how modern construction methods introduced a new connection between the interior and the exterior of buildings.
PHILIPPE STARCK specializes in the surreal dimension of the inside-outside equation. The hotels Starck has designed for Ian Schrager typically contrast a minimally remodeled exterior with rooms that retain a sense of unfamiliarity despite Starck's repeated use of signature motifs. The 1,000-room Hudson, Schrager's latest oasis of style at (356 West 58th St.), features a year-round private garden -- a Gramercy Park for sophisticated transients -- furnished with overscaled, Alice in Wonderlandish horticultural tools. Guest rooms will feature bedside lamps with shades painted by Francesco Clemente.
Also due this fall: the final design for Schrager's Astor hotel, in the East Village. A collaboration between Rem Koolhaas and the Swiss team Herzog and de Meuron, this will be Schrager's first ground-up building. It also signifies the idea of collaboration as architecture's new wave.

HEADLINE: Where Buttons Are Only the Beginning

BYLINE: By DICK AHLES

 BODY:
IN 1896, the Republican boss Mark Hanna distributed phony half dollars bearing the likeness of the Democratic presidential candidate William Jennings Bryan and the legend "In God We Trust . . . for the other forty seven cents." It was the Republicans' way of warning what would happen to the economy should free silver champion Bryan defeat William McKinley in the coming election.
The bogus coin is among scores of political artifacts being assembled by the Museum of American Political Life at the University of Hartford -- which describes itself as the nation's only museum devoted exclusively to presidential campaign memorabilia -- for a special election-year exhibition recalling six significant presidential elections. 
 Items from the elections of 1800 (Thomas Jefferson vs. John Adams), 1828 (Andrew Jackson vs. John Quincy Adams), 1860 (Abraham Lincoln vs. Stephen Douglas, John Bell and John Breckenridge), 1896 (McKinley vs. Bryan), 1932 (Franklin Delano Roosevelt vs. Herbert Hoover) and 1980 (Ronald Reagan vs. Jimmy Carter) will be showcased from today through the end of the year. The items come from a collection of 60,000 (only the Smithsonian Institution has a larger collection).
The museum' director, Zina Davis, said the 1800 election was selected for the exhibition because it was the first in which the presidency passed from one party, the Federalists, to another, the Democratic Republicans. By 1828, suffrage had been given nearly all white males the right to vote in elections previously reserved for white male property owners. These new voters turned out to help Andrew Jackson defeat President John Quincy Adams.
In 1860, the issue was, of course, the future of the Union as the election of Lincoln led to the secession of the Southern states and war. The McKinley-Bryan race in 1896 was the first in which big money played a major role. Big business, frightened at the prospect of electing the populist Bryan, gave more than $7 million to McKinley while Bryan was able to raise only $300,000.
Twentieth-century elections gave the nation two of its most charismatic presidents, Franklin Delano Roosevelt, who led the nation through the Depression and World War II as the only four-term president, and Ronald Reagan, whose 1980 election was chosen because it ushered in a new conservative era.
The jewel of a museum is a perfect election-year destination. The first thing a visitor sees is a life-sized, torch-light parade of 17 uniformed Lincoln supporters known as the Hartford "Wide Awakes."
Their parade route begins at the museum's entrance and winds down a spiral staircase to the 7,000-square-foot exhibition area, where a 10-minute film on the history of political campaigns. Included in the permanent exhibition is a 70-foot time line containing nearly a thousand banners, buttons, photographs, medallions, snuff boxes, fans, bandanas, match covers and other knicknacks from every election since George Washington's. Only a relatively small fraction of the collection can be exhibited at any given time.
The nucleus of the collection was given to the university by J. Doyle DeWitt, who was president and chairman of the Travelers Insurance Company in the 1950's and 60's. Mr. DeWitt sent Travelers employees to national conventions and had insurance agents across the country on the lookout for additions to his collection. He was one of a group of Hartford citizens who founded the University of Hartford in 1959, the same year he began giving the university items from his collection. What remained went to the university on Mr. DeWitt's death in 1972, but no provision was made for housing the collection and it remained in storage for nearly two decades.
It's rather appropriate that funds for the political museum finally came from a pork barrel, which "Safire's Political Dictionary" defines as "the state or national treasury into which politicians and government officials dip for 'pork' or funds for local projects."
The politician doing the dipping on behalf of the museum was Senator Lowell P. Weicker Jr. In 1985 he offered an amendment to a National Library Expansion Act that provided $6.5 million for the university to build a home for the DeWitt collection and the items added to it since 1972. President Reagan put the appropriation on a list of amendments to be eliminated but Mr. Weicker, as was his custom, ignored the President's recommendation and pushed the bill through.
The museum became part of a $20 million student center and opened in 1989.
The Museum of American Political Life at the University of Hartford (200 Bloomfield Avenue, West Hartford; 860-768-4090) is open Tuesday to Friday from 11 a.m. to 4 p.m., Saturday and Sunday from noon to 4. It is closed Mondays and university holidays. Admission is free but contributions are appreciated.

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Rockville Centre;
A Community Not Easily Pigeonholed

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER

 BODY:
NOT quite fitting the Long Island profile of a village, a town or a city, Rockville Centre combines elements of all three in a self-contained setting on the South Shore of Nassau County where expensive to moderately priced single family homes combine with a large number of cooperative apartments.
It is as if the rare appellation "centre" was coined precisely to define this place, officially an incorporated village since 1893 but with certain unique aspects that set it apart from other areas in affluent Nassau. 
 Foremost among these is a municipally owned electric company with rates low enough to have spared Rockville Centre from Long Island's years of agony over rates the former Long Island Lighting Company charged. Average bills are roughly half of what others pay, the village said. The Long Island Power Authority charges almost $71 for 500 kilowatts of electricity; a village resident would pay a bit less than $38.
There are also city-style services, including a police department; a municipal water utility, whose presence is proclaimed by a huge water tower on Maple Avenue built in a style that might be called mid-20th-century futuresque; and a public housing authority that tends to seniors and low-income residents.
The Rockville Centre housing market runs the gamut from subsidized apartments to gemlike residential areas with towering trees and Tudor, colonial and Victorian-style houses selling for well above $500,000, a range unusual in Nassau County, where in many communities housing and economic status are confined to a far narrower band. With an African-American community of long standing, the village also has a racial mix atypical for Nassau.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre is spiritual headquarters for Long Island's more than one million Catholics, and St. Agnes Cathedral on Quealy Place is where new diocesan priests are ordained.
People familiar with Rockville Centre say there is a pronounced tendency of residents to stay on and on, upgrading from starter to larger houses and then eventually snugging into one of the many cooperative apartment complexes. Nearly a quarter of village residents are seniors, a high percentage for a Long Island community, and the village has two senior-citizen centers and an array of senior services.
Mayor Eugene J. Murray, a lifelong resident, who recently turned 75, said many houses he knew as a boy still stand, and shine. "I have seen many changes, but I have also seen that residential homes have been preserved, and we are striving to keep it that way," he said.
The village is currently adding parking near the Long Island Rail Road station and refurbishing downtown areas. A newly installed free-standing "millennium" clock in a new pedestrian plaza near the station looks back, in its boxy, nondigital style, to the 20th century rather than ahead to the 21st, befitting the architectural mood of the village.
Cathleen Quinn Nolan, a lawyer who has lived in the village since she was 11 years old, said she liked the small-town cheerfulness exemplified by meter maids who apologized about giving tickets. "You say, 'Rats,' and they always say they're sorry," she said.
But parking is a problem, particularly in downtown commercial areas along Sunrise Highway and Merrick Road and at the railroad station, where frequent trains provide swift service to Manhattan on tracks that are thoughtfully elevated -- no loud whistles at grade crossings here.
THE good rail link to the city and a local public school system that sets high standards for students attract buyers in a housing market that has cooled slightly since last spring, but still sizzles.
"At least buyers are not entering into bidding wars as much," said Elizabeth Souto-Wallace, a broker and an owner of Century 21 Sherlock Homes in Rockville Centre. "You don't have that frenzy, but it's still a very strong seller's market."
Real estate professionals insist a house in Rockville Centre is money in the bank, with high interest. "I have never seen anybody lose money on a house, not ever" said Pat Cantwell, the office manager at the Rockville Realty Corporation.
Most of the village's 6,000 single-family houses were built between 1900 and 1950, giving residential areas a long-settled and comfortable look. They range in price from the mid-$700,000's in the Canterbury enclave, where spectacular Tudors may be found, to the more affordable Greystone area nearer downtown, where prices are in the $300,000's.
In general, higher-priced areas are in the northern part of the village, and less-expensive areas are to the south. Most lots are from a third to half an acre in size, and garages are frequently detached.
Co-ops, which account for the bulk of other housing, offer two-bedroom units in the $150,000 to $175,000 range. Ms. Souto-Wallace said co-op studios selling for less than $60,000 may also be found.
At the 84-unit Park Lane, one of two condominium complexes, two-bedroom units are about $300,000, up $50,000 from five years ago. Two-bedroom rentals are about $1,600 in rental buildings, or about $1,300 in two-family homes. Rockville Centre was built out years ago, and there is little new construction.
Halandia Court, a 165-unit privately owned subsidized apartment complex, is for the disabled and people 62 and older, regardless of whether they ever lived in the village. Rents are 30 percent of income for singles earning up to $26,800 annually and for couples earning $30,600 or less. The complex has a five-year waiting list.
The village housing authority manages rent-subsidized complexes, including the 164-unit Mill Court, for low-income families, and 50 units for people 62 and older on Merrick Road. The village helps place seniors in subsidized units.
Mercy Medical Center, a major employer, is at the village's northern boundary. Molloy College, established in 1955 by the Dominican Sisters, is next door and offers B.A., B.S. and Master of Science degrees. It has extensive noncredit adult education courses.
The village has seven parks with playing fields and playgrounds and six others, including a village green, for sitting or walking. They cover 140 acres. Ocean beaches are about 15 minutes away.
Just west of the village, Hempstead Lake State Park offers sweeping fields, picnic areas, soccer fields, a lake and three ponds.
Village businesses include an array of stores and specialty shops, including Spymaster, which invites customers to "ask about our new nanny cam." There are 10 banks, several investment firms, two seven-screen movie theaters and nine professional office buildings.
There are also a growing number of restaurants and take-out places, including the First Tortilla Grill on Maple Avenue, a Tex-Mex eat-in or take-out place where a tasty quesadilla with Monterey Jack cheese is only $2.19.
The village Department of Parks and Recreation has a book full of programs for all ages. A 10-session parent-toddler workshop allows 24- to 36-month-old children to go to school with their parents or caregivers. Fees begin at $90 for residents and $97.50 for nonresidents. A troupe for people 60 and older, the Center Stage Players, enlists local talent for performances at the village's Leonard Sandel Senior Center. The Guild for the Arts, another village group, sponsors concerts and musical performances throughout the year.
The nearly 3,500-student Rockville Centre Union Free School District includes five elementary schools for grades K-5, a middle school for grades 6-8 and South Side High School. More than 80 percent of the 241 graduates in the class of 2000 earned Regents diplomas. The percentage is among the highest for any school district on Long Island. More than 90 percent of graduates have gone on to higher education.
THE high school offers a special International Baccalaureate Program for academic achievers. The stringent two-year curriculum requires mastery in six academic groups: English, foreign language, social studies, experimental sciences, mathematics and arts. Successful students earn an I.B. Diploma. Some 69 students earned the degree last year.
In March, Newsweek magazine rated the high school the 23rd best in the country based on the number of students in advanced placement and I.B. programs.
A before- and after-school program is opened to students in kindergarten through fifth grade. The morning program, which begins at 7 a.m at the child's home school and includes breakfast, costs $100 monthly for five days a week. The afternoon program, from 3:30 to 6:30 p.m., costs $190 monthly for five days.
St. Agnes Cathedral School, a Roman Catholic school for pre-K through grade 8, has about 900 students. A small portion of Rockville Centre is in the Oceanside School District.
By Long Island standards, Rockville Centre developed early. The village and surrounding areas were inhabited by the Reckouackie Indians before Dutch and English settlers came in the 17th century, and the area became known as the Rockaways.
When the first post office opened in 1849 in what is now the village, postal officials chose the name Rockville Centre from among several suggestions, setting in place the "r" before "e" spelling that has confounded spellers ever since. The "Rock" honored Mordecai "Rock" Smith, a prominent Methodist minister.
Long Island Rail Road service began in 1867, and five years later a school district was established in the village. South Side High School opened in 1892, the first public high school on Long Island's South Shore. The building that housed it has been the village hall since the 1920's, a decade of early housing growth.

The celebration on Long Island has highlighted growing diversity as recently arrived Hispanics and Catholics from Korea, Vietnam and Poland have swelled parish ranks. The trend is also noted in Rockville Centre, where the Hispanic population has risen in recent years.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 9-10-00: The Ethicist;
Perk Up

BYLINE: By Randy Cohen

 BODY:
Two of us at work travel to the same city to check on our project. One stays at an expensive upscale hotel and receives hotel credits. The other chooses to stay at a much cheaper hotel, closer to the job and equally nice, but without that bonus. Is the first person taking advantage of the corporation? -- B. K., St. Paul
If your bonus-loving colleague adheres to the company's rules on travel and is honest with the boss, he's doing nothing underhanded. While it is a fine thing to minimize expenses to your employer, you are not obliged to squeeze dimes by pitching tents beside the Interstates. In fact, choosing more austere quarters could be false economy. Your boss may prefer you pampered and pleased; that can make for a more productive worker. If hotel credits contribute to your coworker's contentment, there's no harm in that. 
 To forestall the resentment a frugal traveler may feel for a sybaritic colleague, you might suggest that your boss offer each employee a standard travel allowance and a choice: squander it on high living or choose modest accommodations and pocket the savings. Or the boss might have one travel agent make the arrangements for all employees, booking everyone into similar accommodations. Or he could issue everyone a folding tent and a road map and enjoy the team spirit engendered by common suffering.
I'm a university professor, and I often get unsolicited copies of textbooks from publishers hoping that I'll adopt them for my course. They clutter up my shelves until book buyers come through, offering cash for old texts. Is it wrong for me to sell them and pocket the money? Should I donate them instead? -- Anonymous, Evanston, Ill.
The publishers sent the books hoping you'd find them worthy of inclusion in your class. They were not a bribe. They're yours to do with what you will. Not every perk is a transgression. (At a TV show where I worked, we received many T-shirts emblazoned with the names of Kevin Costner movies; I saw using them to clean up after the cat as a legitimate form of film criticism.) Unless university policy prohibits your selling these books, go to it.
If you still feel uneasy, note that some magazines give unsolicited books to the public library; others offer them to their unpaid interns. Consider following their examples or donating your book money to a student-aid organization.
I work in an office suite shared by different companies. The occupants of the offices across from mine spend their day with the door open, on the speakerphone, screaming about their firm's key strategic and tactical decisions. I could easily record everything they say. Would it be legally and morally wrong to do so and sell the tapes to their competitors? -- Anonymous, New York
Ethically, your plan is pretty shabby. If you're vexed by their screaming, why not ask your neighbors to keep it down? Their inconsiderate behavior does not justify your industrial espionage.
I write the Ethicist, not the Legalist -- I am not qualified to rule on the legality of your contemplated scheme. I can caution you that the laws on taping vary from state to state, as Linda Tripp discovered to her dismay.
I recently started a temp gig at a church, and they've intimated that they would like to hire me. I'm concerned that they'll ask me what my faith is -- agnostic on good days. I think they may have gotten the wrong idea because they saw me reading the Bible in the chapel. Is it wrong to work for a church and not believe in God? -- J. H., Toronto
If your work is technical in nature -- bookkeeping, say, or plumbing, or even organ maintenance -- your own theological opinions are beside the point. This is not hypocrisy; it's tolerance. I doubt that the minister would object to his car being repaired by a Hindu, Muslim, Jew or atheist. Unless you have strong personal objections to that church's teachings, there is no reason you shouldn't work there.
If, however, you're actually conducting services or otherwise participating in the church's spiritual life, all concerned would probably feel much better if your personal beliefs were in accord with the congregation's. And if you refrained from playing "In-A-Gadda-Da-Vida" on the organ.
A friend purchased what he thought was a stolen fine watch, at a discount. I can see from the way it has worn that it is not authentic. Should I tell him? I don't want to shatter his love for it or insult him. But I also don't want him to remain misled or make this mistake again. -- M. R., New York
If I understand correctly, what was thought merely to be a case of receiving stolen goods turned out instead to be a swindle involving counterfeit products, and it's unclear to you if continued deception on your part is the honorable way to treat a friend and his bauble? I'm just relieved that no one got killed. And now I've got to go lie down a put a cold compress on my forehead.

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
In Neptune, a Tech Park Plan for Route 66

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE

DATELINE: NEPTUNE TOWNSHIP

 BODY:
THE 167 hilly acres dotted with wetlands and thick woods along Route 66 in the north-central portion of this Monmouth County township have long defied development. But now, a group of New Jersey investors has advanced a plan to turn most of the property into a four-million-square-foot technology and office park.
Last month, Garden State Hi-Tech Park L.L.C., a Neptune development company, was granted general site plan approval from the Neptune Township Planning Board to develop the commercially zoned property. The $400 million project, to be called Garden State Hi-Tech Park, will consist of 18 two- to six-story buildings and a 12-story, 200-room hotel and conference center, the developers said. The park, which will be built in phases over 10 to 20 years, depending on market demand, will also have underground parking for up to 12,000 cars as well as a helipad, the developers said. 
 About 70 acres of the site, most of them containing wetlands, will remain undeveloped. Under state law, wetlands are protected from development.
Construction of the project's first phase, with 150,000 to 450,000 square feet of office space, is expected to start by next spring, said Kenneth E. Himsel, director of development for the group. The first phase must still receive final approval from the township, and developers say that construction will not begin until a tenant leases a percentage of the space.
Financing for the initial phase is to be provided by banks and the partners, who have developed residential and commercial projects in New Jersey, Connecticut and New York. The partners have invested $2 million in the Neptune project, Mr. Himsel said.
"We looked beyond the wetlands and saw that it had great potential, given its location," he said. In addition to being on Route 66, the site is bisected by Route 18 and is close to Exits 100 and 102 of the Garden State Parkway and to Interstate 92, making access convenient. The site's development, Mr. Himsel added, also comes at a time when large buildings are needed for the high-technology businesses that are moving expanding in Monmouth County.
Though the county has been known more for its seaside resorts than for its technology industry, it is home to operations of AT&T and Lucent Technologies. In addition, it has a variety of housing and a labor pool balanced with skilled and unskilled workers, said Joseph J. Sarno, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield, the real estate services firm, which is the project's leasing agent.
Indeed, many commercial brokers are using the phrase "Silicon Parkway" for the area in Monmouth County stretching from Exits 102 to 120 of the Garden State Parkway, describing it as New Jersey's emerging version of the technology-rich Silicon Valley in California, Route 128 in Boston and Research Triangle Park in North Carolina.
The Neptune Township technology park, Mr. Sarno added, is being marketed as a place "where larger companies can establish a presence and smaller ones have the flexibility to grow." Prospective tenants include telecommunications and biotechnology firms.
Moreover, he said, his company has been working with six tenants who together are looking for up to 1.25 million square feet of space in the county. In its midyear office market survey, his company reported that the vacancy rate in the county was 5.4 percent, down from 6.5 percent in mid-1999.
The project is moving forward after two years of discussions with Neptune Township officials, who wanted "to take advantage of the strong economy and the southward migration of businesses" by promoting Neptune as a place to do business, said Mayor Kevin B. McMillan. Commercial development, local officials said, would help balance the economic base of their eight-square-mile township of 30,000 people and help keep property taxes stable.
The initial phase of the high-tech park is estimated to generate $726,000 in annual tax revenue for the township and, when complete, a yearly total of nearly $8 million. Over the years, it is also expected to produce at least 5,000 permanent jobs.
Mayor McMillan stressed, however, that the township wanted development that would "improve the overall health of the community" and benefit residents, not overburden municipal services.
STILL, when the township's seven-member Planning Board unanimously voted to approve the project last month, some residents, particularly those who live near the site, expressed concerns about increased traffic and noise. They said they were also worried that a few buildings would be too close to some homes and that so large a project would detract from the area's semirural character.
Michael J. Bascom, the township's economic development director, said the developers would be required to make the necessary road and other improvements to accommodate their project. Mr. Bascom, who is also the township's chief financial officer, added that over the last two years, Neptune has updated its master plan to reflect its direction of growth and created the nonprofit, semiautonomous Neptune Township Economic Development Corporation to attract businesses.
"We were missing out on the economic boom," said Kurt Cavano, president of the economic development group. "We have available land and people looking for jobs."
The results so far include efforts to boost particular neighborhoods in the township, like Ocean Grove, its historic beachfront section. But much of the new development has taken place along Route 66, where most of the township's available commercially zoned land exists, Mr. Bascom said.
During the mid-80's building boom, before the recession of the early 90's, the corridor, touted as the Golden Mile, attracted office structures with a total of about 700,000 square feet. But in the last year, it has drawn commercial developments like a 135,000-square-foot Home Depot store, which is part of a larger project that is expected to add up to 315,000 square feet of retail space. Two other projects planned or nearing completion are expected to add 350,000 square feet of retail space.
The high-tech park, Mr. Bascom said, will serve as the easternmost anchor to the Route 66 corridor, which extends west to Exit 100 of the Garden State Parkway.
The township formerly owned about 70 acres of the park's site. Decades ago, the newspaper that owned the property divided it into small lots that were given to subscribers as part of a promotion. Over time, lot owners who could not develop their sites because the sites were too small stopped paying taxes, and by the early 1980's, the owners lost their land to the township through foreclosure. Others deeded their sites to the township, Mr. Bascom said, noting that the property has been zoned for commercial use for 17 years.
In 1995, the township tried to sell its 70 acres at a public auction. But Mr. Bascom said the property's topography and environmental concerns frustrated developers, who thought the site was too expensive to build on. But he said the township always believed that the site was ripe for development because of its location and because it was connected to public water and sewer services.
In 1998, the township sold its 70 acres for $500,000 to a developer for a retail project that never moved ahead. That year, Garden State bought it for $750,000. Mr. Himsel said buying up the remaining 97 acres of vacant land from various owners provided enough buildable land to accommodate the project as well as add access to the site.
The buildings, to be designed by a Neptune architect, James J. Monteforte, are to have a minimum floor area of 50,000 square feet and follow the natural contours of the land, which rises in elevation from 60 to 150 feet. The developers also intend to offer tenants dual power sources and access to fiber-optic lines. And the grounds will feature man-made waterfalls and ponds, the latter doubling as retention basins for storm water runoff, Mr. Himsel said.
The offices will be laid out with few indoor columns and 9- to 10-foot-high ceilings to accommodate raised floors so that high-tech tenants can install the wires needed for their businesses, added Mr. Sarno, the broker. He said average rents were expected to be $20 a square foot. In Cushman & Wakefield's midyear market survey, the average rent for office space in Monmouth County was listed as $21.69 a square foot.
Mr. Himsel, talking about the county, added, "This is not a case of 'Build it and the tenants will come,' because the tenants are already here."
