HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE VOTERS;
PRESIDENTIAL RACE IS BEING RUN HARD IN KEYSTONE STATE

SERIES: BATTLEGROUNDS: Pennsylvania

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: SCRANTON, Pa., Sept. 8

 BODY:
"Battleground Scranton," said a banner headline in The Tribune here on Tuesday.
"It's beginning to seem as though they're running for president of Pennsylvania," commented The Pittsburgh Post-Gazette on Thursday. 
 Little wonder. This week alone, Vice President Al Gore campaigned in Philadelphia on Sunday, Pittsburgh on Monday and the Scranton area on Thursday. Gov. George W. Bush of Texas was in Allentown and Scranton on Tuesday, Scranton on Wednesday and Pittsburgh on Friday. Lest anyone's attention wander, Dick Cheney, Mr. Bush's running mate, hit the Philadelphia suburbs.
By early this week, the Democrats and the Republicans had each spent more than $5 million in Pennsylvania, in soft money and hard, on television advertising. By late this week, Mr. Bush had been to the state 14 times and Mr. Gore had made no fewer than 17 campaign visits. On the most recent one he pleased local chauvinists by commenting, "I believe that this state is literally 'the Keystone state,' and I'm going to continue to spend an enormous amount of time here."
Hyperbole aside, Pennsylvania is one of the handful of states -- 6, 8, maybe 10, depending on who's counting -- where the presidential race of 2000 will be decided. Even after decades of population decline, it still casts 23 electoral votes, more than any other closely contested state. So when public and private polls suggested the start of a slide toward Mr. Gore, Mr. Bush stormed in to try to halt the slide, and the vice president arrived to try to keep the momentum going.
"No question about it," Gov. Tom Ridge, a Bush confidant, said in an interview. "Gore got a huge bump out of his party's convention. It was very surprising, an enigma to me. But I'll tell you, we're not in such bad shape. Even or a few points behind, running against the vice president when times are good, a strong economy and no war -- sign me up, I'll take a shot."
Mr. Ridge said he thought Mr. Bush needed to "maximize voters' chances to see him personally, because he's the more likable of the two candidates, close up." Mr. Bush seems to be moving in that direction, with his staff's promises on Thursday to hold town meetings like the ones he held in the primaries.
What Mr. Ridge did not say, but virtually every other politician in the state has been saying for weeks, is that Mr. Bush has been handicapped by his vice-presidential choice. Had he chosen Mr. Ridge, the pros here say, he would have won the state with ease and gained in other states that are witnessing hand-to-hand political combat this fall, like Michigan.
But instead of making that choice, said Prof. Joseph DiSarro, chairman of the political science department at Washington and Jefferson College, "he chose Dick Cheney, who has been a dud."
"No excitement at all," Professor DiSarro added. "Two white Anglo-Saxon Protestant males, which doesn't put much of a fresh face on the Republican Party. Whereas the Democrats chose Lieberman, who's perfect for Pennsylvania -- a very personable but unconventional and socially conservative Democrat."
This is a somewhat unconventional state, politically speaking. It has relatively few registered independents. It has almost half a million more registered Democrats than registered Republicans, but the Democrats are an unorthodox breed -- more conservative than most in their party and much less supportive of ideas like abortion rights and gun control. Bill Clinton carried the state easily in 1992 and 1996, but Republicans control the governorship, three of the four other statewide offices and both Senate seats.
Paradoxically, given the paucity of officially independent voters, party-lining does not play well here. A candidate is "better off here to be viewed as an independent," Mr. Ridge said, "because up-and-down anything -- liberal, conservative -- is not good."
Pennsylvania's population of 12 million is older than that of most states; many young people leave, and few come from elsewhere. Only 13 Congressional districts have older populations than Representative Paul E. Kanjorski's district, centered on Wilkes-Barre, a weary anthracite coal town southwest of here, and all 13 are in the retirement havens of Florida and Arizona.
In Scranton and Wilkes-Barre, hardscrabble places with scores of vacant and boarded-up buildings downtown, people count on Washington for help. For decades, they got it from their men in Washington, Representatives Daniel J. Flood and Joseph M. McDade, but both left office under clouds of scandal. Some local people still say of them, "If they stole, at least they stole for us."
So issues like Social Security, Medicare and especially prescription drugs, important everywhere this fall, are critical in this region and this state. Both candidates have shown commercials about health care in Pennsylvania, and next month a group from Scranton and elsewhere in the state is taking a bus trip to Canada to buy drugs, because they are cheaper there.
Mr. Kanjorski, a Democrat, recently held eight town meetings on health issues and drew the largest crowds of his career -- more than 500 people in some cases, many of them recently left in the lurch when two of the area's major managed care plans, run by Blue Cross and Geisinger, were closed.
Under pressure for weeks to state a detailed position on prescription drugs, Mr. Bush did so on his visits to Allentown and Scranton, proposing a plan that would rely much more heavily than Mr. Gore's on the states and on the big health care providers. Mr. Ridge had been among those pressing him in private conversations, and he enthusiastically supported the new Bush plan. Pennsylvania already has the largest state prescription drug program, paid for by state lottery money; it will cost $290 million this year.
Mindful of the need to attract uncommitted voters, who here as elsewhere tend to be turned off by excessive partisanship, Mr. Bush repeatedly promised a bipartisan approach to the health care problem and mentioned Democratic senators with whom he said he could work well, like John B. Breaux of Louisiana.
"We are in a very critical week," said Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School of Communication at the University of Pennsylvania, which studies news coverage. "The question is, will Bush get the traction he needs on this issue? The proposals are complicated, but what emerges from the media is pretty simple: Both have plans now; Gore would spend more money."
One of those who lost coverage, Jacob Nykaza of Jermyn, near Scranton, told The Tribune: "We have to decide who has the better program. Either one should be better than nothing." His medications cost $35 a week.
Mr. Bush did something else here that could have a considerable impact among the large numbers of Roman Catholic voters in Scranton and Wilkes-Barre, most of whom strongly oppose abortion, as does Mr. Bush. There are no abortion clinics in Lackawanna County (Scranton) or Luzerne County (Wilkes-Barre). Although he said nothing publicly about abortion, Mr. Bush paid a well-publicized 40-minute call on Bishop James C. Timlin of Scranton.
The bishop, an outspoken opponent of abortion, said afterward that the visit had nothing to do with politics. But it certainly sent a message, especially since he had forbidden a planned appearance this year by Mr. Gore, an abortion rights supporter, at the Catholic Mercy Hospital here.
"This means the church has given its tacit approval to Bush," said Steve Corbett, a columnist for The News-Leader in Wilkes-Barre. "That's how people will interpret it. You're in the heart of anti-abortion country."
This area is not nearly as populous, of course, as Philadelphia or Pittsburgh. But it is closely balanced in partisan terms. Representative Donald L. Sherwood, whose district is centered on Scranton, won by only 515 votes in 1996, defeating Patrick Casey, a son of former Gov. Robert Casey and a brother of the state auditor, Robert Casey Jr. Mr. Casey, a Democrat, is running again, which should guarantee a big turnout and a close presidential contest in a district that President Clinton won in 1996 but lost to President George Bush in 1992.
"This election is about two things," said Prof. G. Terry Madonna of Millersville University. "Can Gore hold onto the socially conservative working-class Catholics in the hard-coal country in the northeast and the soft-coal country in the southwest, the ones you call Reagan Democrats and we call Casey Democrats? And can Bush hold onto the weakly leaning Republicans, fiscally conservative but not antigovernment, in the suburban counties around Philadelphia, especially the well-educated women?"
A poll taken for KDKA-TV in Pittsburgh on Sept. 5 and 6 and released on Thursday put Mr. Gore at 53 percent and Mr. Bush at 42 percent, with 4 percent opting for other candidates and 1 percent undecided. The survey questioned 800 likely voters, pushing them to state a preference even if they were unsure; the margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3.5 percentage points.
Professor Madonna, a pollster himself, said he thought Mr. Gore's lead was more like four to six percentage points. He said that because he did not believe the race had settled yet, he had delayed a new poll until later this month.
All the polls show big gender gaps. A poll taken for another western Pennsylvania television station, WPXI, indicates that Mr. Gore's entire margin comes from women. And they all show Mr. Bush fading in the pivotal suburban counties that surround Philadelphia -- Bucks, Montgomery, Delaware and Chester.
Neil Oxman, a Democratic campaign consultant in Philadelphia, said the Republican National Convention, held there, was the catalyst. Polls Mr. Oxman has taken for local and regional candidates, he said, show that Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore have consolidated 92 to 93 percent of their bases, which yields Mr. Gore a significant advantage, given the big Democratic registration edge.
Mr. Bush was doing nicely, he said, "and then bam! this yawning gender gap opens up, and you suddenly have Gore running strongly in the Main Line, especially among the moderate and upscale women there."
With that constituency, abortion is hurting Mr. Bush, Ms. Jamieson of the Annenberg School said. Although he mentioned the subject only briefly in his acceptance speech, she said, his position, the platform position and that of Mr. Cheney were all discussed at length in the local news media during the convention.
"Voters here know just where he stands," she said.
 
Battlegrounds
This is the first article in a series about four swing states that are likely to be critical to the outcome of the presidential race. Later articles will look at Ohio, Wisconsin and Michigan.

HEADLINE: FOOTLIGHTS

BYLINE: By ROBERTA HERSHENSON

 BODY:

All the City, and a Stage
Fleetwood Stage and the city of New Rochelle are a happy mix, according to the company's founder and producing director, Lewis Arlt. "The move here was hugely successful," said Mr. Arlt, who will star in the group's production of Ira Levin's "Deathtrap," starting Sept. 21. "We're part of the spirit of the redevelopment of the city." 
 The theater company, which is beginning its eighth season, moved to the craggy grounds of Wildcliff, overlooking Long Island Sound, four years ago. The city, which owns the theater building and rents it to Fleetwood for a nominal fee, helps both officially and "as a group of individuals," Mr. Arlt said. That means the driveway gets plowed, and familiar faces lend panache to fund-raising events.
Fleetwood has also been a boon to Mr. Arlt's many faceted career. He has both acted and directed with the company, most recently appearing in "The Importance of Being Earnest," and directing "The Comedy of Errors." In "Deathtrap," a 1978 comedy-thriller directed by Nelson Sheeley, he will appear as a playwright prepared to kill for success. Mr. Arlt also played the role last winter at the Paper Mill Playhouse in New Jersey.
"It's a dream come true," he said of the chance to juggle jobs at Fleetwood. The actor-director's open secret is that he is also a writer, having provided 15 years of dialogue for soap operas like "Ryan's Hope," "General Hospital" and "Another World."
So what does he like to do best? "Acting is easier than directing and writing," he said. "Writing is a grind, all that pressure and responsibility. And the problem with directing for theater is that you can't make a living at it."
Fleetwood Stage is "hovering near the black," he said, and hopes to sell out its 105-seat theater with four main stage productions this season. Ticket information: (914) 654-8533.
 
Orchestra's Fund-Raising Awards
At 75, the Westchester Symphony Orchestra is by far the county's oldest orchestra. It has also changed more dramatically than other county orchestras, beginning as an avocational group and gradually climbing toward full professionalism (as measured by the level of both the playing and the pay scale).
"The musicians have consistently been getting raises and benefits," said Anthony Aibel, the group's 31-year-old conductor and music director. "I think within the next two or three years, we'll be up to union scale."
The orchestra has begun a new fund-raising strategy with its Bravissimo Awards, which are planned as yearly presentations to respected county residents in the arts, education and government. Awards call for a celebration, and the first such event -- to honor George S. Latimer, chairman of the County Board of Legislators, and Robert Merrill, the baritone -- will be a dinner party with cocktails on Sept. 24 from 5 to 8 p.m. at the Mamaroneck Beach and Yacht Club. Tickets range from $150 to $1,000, and proceeds will benefit the orchestra's children's and community outreach programs. Information: (914) 631-4313.
 
A Regional Theater From Purchase
Each year students in the drama division of Purchase College stage a series of plays that go largely unseen by the larger community.
Yet a senior in the 25-year-old film and theater division is just a short step away from the professional stage, and a relatively large number of recent Purchase graduates have gone on to major careers: Wesley Snipes, Stanley Tucci, Sherry Stringfield, Edie Falco and Parker Posey, to name a few.
Besides the freshness of the youthful casts, the plays -- which are often professionally directed -- benefit from the versatile theaters of the college's Performing Arts Center, which provide a malleable "black box" as well as the traditional proscenium stage.
This school year the division will offer seven plays to the public in a subscription series on Friday nights, which also includes several unannounced events. Subscribers at the $150 level are also entitled to break bread with famous alumni at three opening night dinners. (Subscribers at the $75 level just get to see the plays.) "The goal here is to create a regional theater," said Walter H. Liebman, a former trustee of the Purchase College Foundation, who came up with the idea for the series.
Mr. Liebman said the quality of the acting would be high, considering the rigorous screening of program applicants and the weeding-out process during four years of study. "It is a very good regional theater," he said. "There's nothing between here and New Haven that compares to it."
 ROBERTA HERSHENSON

He played a supporting role; the lead character was played by Jonathan Hadary.

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 50; Column 5; Sophisticated Traveler Magazine

HEADLINE: Death Valley: Present At The Creation

BYLINE: By Barbara Lazear Ascher; Barbara Lazear Ascher is the author of "Dancing in the Dark: Romance, Yearning and the Search for the Sublime" (HarperCollins).

 BODY:
Death Valley was Creation's trial run. The ideas were good. The raw materials were in place, though not necessarily in what we've come to regard as the "right" place.
Let there be iron oxides and copper and magnesium and mica to form alluvial fans and washes and canyons and mud hills. Let there be two great lights; the greater to scorch by day and the lesser to rule the night and inspire Ansel Adams. 
 Let there be winged fowl that may fly above the earth: road runners, ravens, hummingbirds. And creeping things and beasts of the earth: tarantulas, lizards, rattlesnakes and tortoises; bobcats, ringtails and mountain lions; foxes to feed on kangaroo rats, bighorn sheep to feed upon the herb-yielding seed.
Visiting geologists studying this 3.3-million-acre national park, some 120 miles northwest of Las Vegas and 285 miles northeast of Los Angeles, speak in billions. "Well, one billion years ago" -- this rock did that to that rock. To them it was just yesterday.
When you're here, it begins to feel that way. You're back at the beginning. Voluptuous alluvial fans, dips and rises of gravel dumped by flash floods over the last few million years resemble so many attempts to get form just right. You can practically hear Creation's thoughtful "Hmmmmm." It's that silent here.
Alex Cabana, the front desk manager at the Furnace Creek Inn, a 66-room resort opened in 1927 by the Pacific Coast Borax Company, claims, "It's the sound of your own heartbeat."
I check into this mission-style, adobe brick inn for a few days, to use it as a base as I hike into the desert to try to make sense out of a landscape that eludes casual categorization.
People have come to the desert for centuries for just this reason, to shed habits of thinking. To let their thoughts unfold to the very end. Mystics, prophets and seers, 60's acid droppers, New Millennium fast-lane dropouts. The extreme conditions (temperatures that plummet 40 degrees between a 113-degree morning to a chilly night) and the untouched-by-man vastness -- 95 percent of the park is wilderness -- of white sand dunes 50 feet high, golden cliffs, purple hills all serve to put us in our place.
At this moment, all I have in mind is relief for travel-weary joints. The pool, says Alex. The pool's water, fed by an underground spring, is a constant 85 degrees. "No chemicals. No chlorine."
There are 600 known springs in Death Valley, and the original settlers found them by following animal tracks. The spring feeding the Furnace Creek Inn's pool is so mineral rich that I float and bob on the surface.
But not for long. The sun is unyielding. I head for the shade of my cool, spare, whitewashed room, lie down on the bed and expect to evaporate.
I try to close my eyes against the view, a vast sweep of desert and distant, snowcapped Panamint mountains. A nap is imperative because in two hours the Inn's manager, Toni Jepson, and I are going to the opera. No long skirt required. No pashmina. No jewels. Actually, not much of an audience, because some of it's painted on the walls.
In 1967, 43-year-old Marta Becket, a dancer on a trip home to Manhattan from Hollywood, was waylaid by a flat tire in Death Valley Junction. It was then, she claims, while exploring the ghost town -- once owned by the Pacific Coast Borax Company -- where she sought shade, that she saw her dreams take shape.
Deserts do that. Chimeras. Mirages. Thoughts that begin to form patterns rather than bouncing back at you. Tricks of light that make the veil between form and illusion thin to the point of disappearing. So why not? Why not claim the borax company's music hall, built in 1907 and deserted 40 years later, when the borax mining boom came to an end.
Over the next few years, Marta restored and repaired structures, and then, just in case nobody ever came, she painted an audience on the walls. What does it matter that it's a 16th-century Spanish audience, complete with monks, nuns, ladies of the night and nobility? In Death Valley, time stretches with the horizon.
And so does credibility. After all, this is the place where a Chicago millionaire, Albert Johnson, built a Spanish-style mansion in 1915, and did not protest when his friend Walter Scott claimed to the world that it was his. A charismatic pretender, Scotty persuaded investors that he owned several lucrative gold mines in Death Valley. The mines were a fantasy, the mansion a fantasy given form, complete with towers, turrets and 14 fireplaces, forever to be known as "Scotty's Castle."
So, no one thought much about a dancer performing for a painted audience. But tonight is looking busier than those early days, in the living, breathing sense of busy, including a group of teenagers on a school trip from the Fresno Valley. Tonight, 76-year-old Marta will perform her original work "The Doll Maker," in one act, three scenes, "with incidental music by Johann Strauss."
Toni and I drop our $10 admission charge into a gold-painted coffee can held by Marta's boyfriend of 17 years, Tom Willett. A man in his 70's, he sports 60's-style hair and clothes and affects a certain 60's defiant insouciance. I ask if tonight looks like a full house. "Yup, 120, that's a full house." We take our seats (1940's movie theater seats) next to a group I recognize from the Inn. Chances are that the others are campers, unless the curious have driven from the nearest civilization, the town of Pahrump, some 60 miles away.
The lights, bare bulbs shielded by five-pound coffee cans, dim. The pink curtain, painted by Marta, parts and there she stands. Dressed as a doll and on point. Irony is washed out in the desert. There's not enough energy for the extras. This is not a play on itself. This is the play. And the performer takes it seriously as she delivers her aria in a high, frail voice punctuated by the braying burros she keeps in a corral out back.
An hour later, at the show's conclusion, I go to the front desk where one can rent a room for the night. "Honey, did ya like the show?" the clerk wants to know. I assure her that I did and ask if I might see a room. "Sweetheart, just walk along out there and somebody'll let you into their room."
Sure enough. A man and a woman standing on the threshold of an open door, invite me to have a look. "If you can believe it," says the husband of the pair.
The double bed's mattress folds in the middle like a wing. The bathroom tiles are few and far between. But Marta has painted a pre-Raphaelite scene of exuberant romance above the missing headboard. "She's a good painter," I offer. Wife: "It's a nice room. Very comfortable. I've seen worse." Husband: "Well, I haven't." Wife: "Better than our tent." Husband: "Well, then you sleep here. I'm goin' to the tent."
I ease my way through the growing tension and into the wide expanse of night air. Christmas tree lights in red, yellow and green illuminate the few mesquite bushes around the property. Sirius and Procyon overhead outshine them. And though there is no moon tonight, the stretches of white sand reflect all available light, as though the source is within them. The landscape undulates like a sea.
If you find yourself in Death Valley and prefer to sleep without burros for neighbors, you have a choice of three National Park Service concessions. Furnace Creek Inn is the most luxurious. Family-oriented Furnace Creek Ranch is more casual (so casual that coyote pups fetch your ball should you care for a game of golf on the world's lowest course, 214 feet below sea level). And Stovepipe Wells, which is rudimentary to the point of high camp.
I dine at Stovepipe Wells the following evening and am swept back to the 50's and the first road trip my family took cross-country. It was a 50's family thing: load the kids and a drooling dog into a Studebaker sedan and go see "this great land of ours." Those same families seem to have been frozen in time because here we all are, on Naugahyde seats in a large paneled dining room, dining at 5:30 on Jell-O-and-marshmallow salad.
My pre-moonlight horseback ride feast. The National Park Service and Furnace Creek Ranch run a horse program led by Robin and Mark Berry, who have the horses saddled and standing in perfect formation as five of us gather in the corral.
"Butt in the saddle, back straight, head high," Robin advises. She has the no-nonsense self-confidence of one who has grown up with horses and knows what makes them tick.
"And don't let them stop to eat mesquite," Mark adds. "If you do, you'll be out there all night."
Mark cuts such a striking figure, a horse whisperer with a black eye patch, that I wonder if he's in disguise to make the unsuspecting Easterner swoon. His assistant, James, is also one of those Cowboys-Are-My-Weakness kinds of cowboy. He wears a lavender bandanna around his neck. It matches his eyes. A long, brown ponytail hangs out the back of his Stetson.
He helps me mount my horse and holds my knee while adjusting the stirrups. Oh, my. "How's that?" he asks, easing my foot into the stirrup. I want to say, "Hmm, not quite right." Liar.
We head out after James, who, mounted, makes a large, Westward-Ho gesture. We pull bandannas over our noses as the horses kick up the dust. You can see this from miles away. It looks like a whirlwind when, from a distance, you spot the spirals of heat and sand kicked up by a herd of wild horses or riders such as ourselves.
We ride beneath a navy blue sky as darkness moves across the land and begins to blur the outlines of mesquite and sage. Then Mars pops out like a celestial jack-in-the-box. Then Jupiter and Saturn. The Big Dipper dips down, and soon the Funeral Mountain peaks take on a glow like the nimbus in Northern Renaissance paintings. Then, pop! There it is! The goose has laid the golden egg. Upside down. In slow motion.
"Wow! The moon!" the kid behind me shrieks. "Yowks!" I hear myself echo. We're the first people on earth seeing the first moon for the first time.
A kinship with those ancients is strongly felt in a landscape that looks much as it did when they inhabited it. "You know, there are petroglyphs here that show a man on a horse," whispers Dave Woodruff, my waiter at breakfast the next morning.
Dave moved here to experience the timelessness. It's a passion that makes people come and stay. A passion for silence, for vistas that change with every slight slant of light. Because you are afloat in a sandy wash of time, you feel weightless. You can travel a billion years in a minute. As though to accentuate that point, the moonlight ride featured falling stars. Stars too tired to stay up after billions of years. Stars that had died long before we saw them fall.
Dave also whispers that if I'm willing to walk for six hours, I'll come to a rock where the forty-niners engraved their names before moving on or giving up the ghost. Top secret. "You'll recognize the names." Just about everybody here lives with the ghosts of these forty-niners who came through looking for a shortcut to the California gold fields. It feels like yesterday to today's inhabitants. They're well versed in William Lewis Manley's 250-mile trek over mountain and desert in search of the stranded members of the Bennet party. They speak of Julia, a baby who died soon after birth to a mother who had suffered dehydration and starvation as the group frantically circled the desert, seeking a way out. They speak of these people as though I could pick up the phone and request an interview if I had any further questions.
Dave draws me a map on his order pad. "You go exactly 8.1 miles down this road that's closed. You got four-wheel drive and high clearance?" I tell him I had rented a Volvo C70, not realizing I was going to be needing a Humvee. "That's fine. They test-drove that car here. You know, above sea level, below sea level, over boulders. You'll be fine. Go slow. Take plenty of water. At 8.1 miles get out and walk this way."
His map becomes topographical. Plateaus, valleys, canyons. If I follow his lines, I'll come to the petroglyphs.
I pack a backpack with a compass and a whistle (sound travels for miles, so there's always the chance that if I get lost out there, someone 20 miles away, the distance I'm traveling from the nearest ear, might hear me). Half a gallon of water, the amount recommended if you're heading into the desert, a wide-brimmed hat against the sun and hiking boots against any surprises.
I spend the day in fruitless search. And yet, I'm discovering that out here, the plans you make have little to do with the vistas you'll see.
There is no predicting in Death Valley. You think that there's nothing but sand before you, then you gain slight elevation and you're gazing out over a mesquite-green valley leading to snowcapped mountains. This is the view that stops me in my tracks, makes me lower my pack to the ground and myself to a flat rock. I begin to understand why the Old Testament Prophets headed to the desert. It's a place of visions. The now-you-see-it, now-you-don't of miracle.
When I return to the Inn, a message from Mark Berry invites me to sign on as a volunteer with the Park Service, and accompany him into a desolate canyon to pick up Nathan Niemi, a geologist who's been camping there while mapping uncharted territory. We'll drive the horses an hour into the desert, then ride them for three hours each way.
We meet at 6 a.m. and head off with two pack mules and an extra horse for Nathan. It's spring and the poppy-yellow globemallow pushes through any available space between rocks. Vibrant pink blossoms adorn spiny beaver-tail cactus. Finches sing sweetly in the sagebrush and blue-gray gnatcatchers weave a demitasse-shaped nest between branches of an indigo bush.
After half an hour of climbing, we look behind and observe that the truck and trailer have taken on the diminutive, toylike quality of objects seen from an airplane. The canyon pulls us forward like an updraft.
Mark lets me take the lead. "See if you can find the way." I begin to feel cocky until he warns, "Don't get so close to that lip" of the three-foot-wide ledge I'm crossing. I look over the side. Oh, yes. Three hundred feet straight down in either direction. I straighten my back into a posture that I hope bespeaks great courage. I do want to be invited back.
After an hour in the lead, I spot the waving gesture of a man clearly eager to see us. A week alone with rocks and snakes and black widows and a moon so bright that he couldn't sleep fuel his enthusiasm. Mark is still out of sight; Nathan sees me alone and looks puzzled.
"I saw your flares," I announce, "and I have come to rescue you."
Take a woman out of Manhattan. Put her in the desert with no company but a horse and a cowboy, and she's bound to put on airs.
 
OASES
The entrance fee for DEATH VALLEY NATIONAL PARK, $10 for noncommercial vehicles, is payable at ranger stations at Furnace Creek, Stovepipe Wells, Grapevine or Beatty. Unless otherwise noted, all accommodations and attractions are open all year.
The FURNACE CREEK VISITOR CENTER (telephone: 760-786-2331), open daily from 8 to 6, houses exhibitions on the area's natural, cultural and economic history, as well as a bookstore operated by the Death Valley Natural History Association.
FURNACE CREEK INN (760-786-2345; fax: 760-786-2423) has 66 air-conditioned rooms; a double is $260 to $290, depending on season. Amenities include a spring-fed swimming pool and tennis courts. The dining room offers a Continental menu with California accents; dinner for two is about $60, and a bottle of wine costs an average of $30 to $50.
FURNACE CREEK RANCH (760-786-2345; fax: 760-786-2514) has 224 rooms; a double costs $124 or $129, depending on season. In addition to a spring-fed pool and tennis courts, there are an 18-hole golf course and stables for riders. Dining options include the WRANGLER STEAKHOUSE, where dinner for two is about $50; add $30 to $50 for wine.
STOVEPIPE WELLS VILLAGE (760-786-2387; fax: 760-786-2389) has 83 rooms, all of which cost $84 (although not all have telephones and television sets). There is a pool and a restaurant that serves American comfort food of the meatloaf and mashed potatoes variety; about $40 for two, with wine adding an average of $25 a bottle.
Marta Becket's AMARGOSA OPERA HOUSE (760-852-4441; fax: 760-852-4138) is in Death Valley Junction, at the intersection of Routes 127 and 190. Performances are scheduled on Monday and Saturday in November, February, March and April, and on Saturday only in October, December and January through the middle of May. Tickets are $10, and reservations are recommended. The hotel has 12 rooms, each with bath or shower and all with air-conditioning; rates for a double are $55, October to mid-May; $45 the rest of the year.
SCOTTY'S CASTLE (760-786-2392) is open daily for tours conducted by the National Park Service. The tours, which cost $8, last for 50 minutes to an hour; the earliest is at 9 a.m., the last at 5 p.m.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 28; Column 3; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Sins of the Marketplace

BYLINE: By John T. Noonan Jr.; John T. Noonan Jr.'s most recent book is "The Lustre of Our Country: The American Experience of Religious Freedom."

 BODY:

 Who Are We?
 Critical Reflections and Hopeful Possibilities.
 By Jean Bethke Elshtain.
 178 pp. Grand Rapids, Mich.:
 William+B.+Eerdmans Publishing Company. $20. 
 Dietrich Bonhoeffer and John Paul II are her "primary interlocutors." Pride and Sloth are the categories in which she arranges the flaws of contemporary culture. She speaks from a Lutheran tradition now effecting a rapprochement with the older church from which it has been divided. For this Christian moralist, sin distorts individual and communal lives, hope is a necessary virtue, and God is not an icon or a mirage but a presence.
Jean Bethke Elshtain is the Rockefeller professor of social and political ethics at the University of Chicago. Unsurprisingly -- to use one of her favored adverbs -- she has found her academic home not in the departments of sociology or political science but in the school of divinity. At Chicago, where the methodologies of economics have threatened to swallow other approaches to life, theologians are still hospitable to human concerns not expressible in cash.
Commodification! It appears, as Elshtain observes in "Who Are We?," to be a visible destroyer of values that should not be for sale or measured in monetary terms. She cites the advertisements that have run in college newspapers throughout the country offering $25,000, $50,000, (and now) $100,000 for the ova of young women with high admission scores, athletic ability and, in some instances, blue eyes and blond hair. Stanford, to take a campus I know, has not forbidden such advertising; after all, a woman could pay much of her college tuition in this way. What is bought and sold, however, is closely linked with personal identity, with motherhood, with interpersonal love. Unsurprisingly in this culture, a television show gains millions of viewers and is reported on the front page of The New York Times when the show presents 50 women wanting to marry a man of whom they know nothing except that his assets presumably exceeded $1,999,999. To extend Elshtain's argument, what Sloth to seek a lifelong partnership this way.
In plenty of cultures, to be sure, and in many times and places, men and women have married for money or used money to win a partner in procreation. The critic of our commodifying culture is not identifying an unknown vice but a new openness, a new thoroughgoingness, a new hardness in bartering what should not be sold. The old moralists denounced the sin of simony as the attempt to buy or sell the Holy Spirit; they extended the sin to the sale of justice, another value they thought could not be commodified. No one -- not even the most ruthless of economists -- has suggested that we auction justice. Is it any better that we auction human ova or human love?
As we move into a world of new technologies, the cloning of human beings has become a possibility. Warning voices have been raised; Elshtain endorses the arguments of the bioethicist Leon Kass against even embarking on this course. Certainly the strongest argument is that in the present culture, clones would be commodified. A competitive market in the production and sale of clones -- varieties designed and sold for a variety of purposes -- poses a future in which slavery would return in subtler guise.
Feminists have protested the obscene television display of the women willing to marry for $2 million. Left and liberal critics have lamented the push of the market into every sphere from education to prisons. Wittily critiquing commodification, Elshtain will receive a sympathetic hearing. On other aspects of the dominant culture, like abortion and assisted suicide, she will encounter resistance. Believers are divided as to the moral acceptability of such practices. Elshtain, however, argues that the acceptance of these forms of human-inflicted death relates to a sense of human autonomy that accords no rights to God. Here's where Pride takes its lumps. Outside traditional religions, the very notions that a human being has been created by God, has a destiny beyond this life that is directed to God and has responsibilities to God are atrophied, neglected, unknown or disbelieved. Belief in the theistic propositions does no more than open the mind to the possibility of limits to human freedom. Without them, the views thoughtfully espoused by Elshtain will not make sense to many. On other subjects, notably contraception and celibacy, where believers are even more divided among themselves, Elshtain is prudently silent.
Many believers and unbelievers come together again on capital punishment -- believers because they have come to see it as another human invasion of the Creator's power, unbelievers because they see it as an irredeemable extinction of life. So limited in practice as to be of little more than symbolic significance (except for those executed), the death penalty is another feature of our culture scrutinized with critical concern by Elshtain.
I find it difficult to say that one culture, globally considered, is worse than another. We don't have the tools to make the measurement. Until well into the 19th century, human slavery was legally and morally accepted in substantial parts of the world. Up until the middle of this century, racism was legally and morally accepted in this country and in many parts of the world. Discrimination determined by gender is only now being dismantled. Every culture to the moralist is distinguished not only by Pride and Sloth but by the five other deadly sins, Anger, Avarice, Envy, Gluttony and Lust; and the deadly sins don't exhaust the possibilities of going wrong. What distinguishes a culture is the particular forms the vices take.
Sounding at the end the note of hope, Elshtain finds it running like a submerged stream in some modern films, including "Titanic," and some modern literature, like the poetry and prose of Czeslaw Milosz, a survivor of Nazi occupation and Communist domination. In his celebration of human living, Elshtain, a devoted grandmother, sees "the fragility and miracle of the quotidian." The title of the book asks a question, to which the book implicitly responds. We are those who make this culture of atheism and faith, cash bottom lines and virtues beyond price, cynicism and aspiration.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 991 words

HEADLINE: New Economy;
When the Internet businesses shake, the next domino is the companies that provide them with consulting services.

BYLINE: By Susan Stellin 

 BODY:
IN the current climate for technology stocks, it is not surprising that the troubles plaguing other sectors of the industry have now fallen on the consulting companies that help businesses build and manage their Internet operations. What is remarkable, though, is how quickly the pall has descended.
Over the last two weeks, several leading Internet consulting companies have announced negative news, starting a downturn in much of the sector. Viant and iXL Enterprises, which had previously been profitable, both announced they would post a loss for the third quarter, with revenue falling short of the record results each had in the second quarter. 
 Meanwhile, Organic announced smaller-than-anticipated revenue growth and iXL Enterprises said it would lay off several hundred employees.
This reversal in a sector previously characterized by double-digit revenue growth each quarter sent share prices tumbling, with the sector down overall 15 percent since Aug. 29. Although the spill can primarily be attributed to the misfortunes of the consulting companies' dot-com clients, the pace of the change also says that an industry that operates on the vaunted 24/7 pace can also implode at Internet speed.
To be sure, the backlash in the services sector was foreshadowed in late June, when Banc of America Securities downgraded the consulting firm Scient from "buy" to a "market performer" after two of Scient's clients filed for bankruptcy. The drop showed that Scient, based in San Francisco, and its competitors were vulnerable to the shifting fortunes of their dot-com clients. Scient's stock has fallen to $27, down from a 52-week high of $133.75 in March.
But the sector's real trouble became evident late last month when the bad news really began piling up. On Aug. 31, Viant, a previously profitable Internet consulting company in Boston, announced that it would post a loss for the third quarter and that revenue would be as much as 15 percent below its second-quarter sales of $38.5 million.
A day later, Atlanta-based iXL Enterprises issued a similar warning, predicting a loss in the third quarter and revenue as much as 20 percent below the $119.2 million revenue of the second quarter.
IXL has since announced a management overhaul and plans to lay off 350 employees.
And then San Francisco-based Organic Inc. announced last Wednesday that because of smaller-than-expected anticipated revenue growth, the company would not reach its goal of profitability in the third quarter -- although Organic does expect to increase revenue 5 percent over its $37.2 million in the second quarter.
The market's reaction to these announcements was unforgiving. Viant's stock closed on Friday at $7.53, down from a 52-week high of $63.56. iXL closed at $6.44, down from a high of $58.75, and Organic dropped to $4.53, from its 52-week high of $60.
Mark Wolfenberger, senior information technology services analyst at Credit Suisse First Boston, said analysts had downgraded the stocks of about a third of the Internet consulting companies they cover, anticipating a period of retrenchment and ultimately, consolidation. Among the companies that have been downgraded by Credit Suisse are Viant, Rare Medium, Modem Media, Cambridge Technology Partners and iGate.
"The opinion on the group in the past five days has gone from optimistically positive to downright negative," Mr. Wolfenberger said in an interview last Thursday.
The main reason for the gloomy outlook is a shift in the demand for the services these companies provide. While the consulting companies feasted on business from cash-rich start-ups and the brick-and-mortar companies that tried to keep pace, the dot-com shakeout has meant even old-economy companies feel less urgency to develop their Internet strategies.
"I think that the consulting companies got the sense that life was going to continue in the passing lane, traveling at 85 miles an hour," Mr. Wolfenberger said. "We've moved from 85 miles an hour back into the right-hand lane at 60 miles per hour."
Mr. Wolfenberger underscored that there was still plenty of demand for Internet consulting services. Forrester Research, for example, estimates the United States market for e-commerce services will reach $64.8 billion by 2003, up from an estimated $19.6 billion this year.
But as consulting firms shift their focus from working primarily with start-ups to serving more traditional clients, they need to be able to handle projects far more complex than merely getting first-time Web sites up and running. The tougher tasks include integrating a company's Web site with its existing systems, like inventory management software or customer databases. Such projects tend to require more complicated technology, as well as longer sales cycles.
Stephen Mucchetti, president and chief operating officer of Scient, which had 60 active clients as of last quarter, said that although the company was still working with venture-backed start-ups, it was increasingly focusing on traditional corporations, including AT&T, Chase Manhattan and the cosmetics retailer Sephora.
"The Internet-driven side of this is gone now," he said. "The next phase is this integrated virtual and physical business."
In that respect, Internet services firms like Scient and Viant may be more vulnerable to competition from seasoned information-technology consultants like I.B.M. Services, Deloitte Consulting and KPMG Consulting, which already have relationships with many of the world's biggest companies and have been ramping up their Internet services to compete with the newer players.
Bob Gett, the chief executive of Viant, said that even though his company had been expecting a shift in the market, it came so suddenly that Viant had not had time to react to the changing nature of the demand.
"I think what caught everybody by surprise is the rate at which it happened," he said. "Welcome to the new economy."

HEADLINE: 2000 SYDNEY GAMES;
Running for Her Country, Her People, Herself

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER CLAREY

DATELINE: SYDNEY, Australia

 BODY:
The biggest Olympic stadium in history rises up all around you at Homebush Bay: 110,000 seats amid gentle sea breezes that can become gusts in the time it takes for a sprinter to lean forward and plant his splayed fingers and great expectations behind a thin white line.
Cathy Freeman, one of Australia's most prominent athletes and its most prominent Aborigine, already knows the place well. She came here shortly after the stadium was finished in February 1999 with Nick Bideau, who was formerly her manager, boyfriend and mentor. Bideau had already researched on which part of the new track the women's 400-meter race would begin at the Summer Olympics. 
 "One lap as fast as you can," Bideau remembers saying, before setting her loose on a first training run at Homebush Bay. "Right now there is nobody here, and when you come back there will be hundreds of cameras, tens of thousands of people but it won't change what you've got to do, and that's start here and finish here."
Off Freeman went in the silence, her long legs gobbling up meters of track and her heels nearly touching her buttocks at the end of each enormous and beautifully balanced stride. She has been running fast enough to win medals and generate headlines since she was 11 and newspaper reporters in her hometown of Mackay dubbed her "wonder girl." A year before that, her stepfather Bruce Barber, a white railway guard with no track and field experience, sat on a log and watched her train and decided that she looked like a future Olympian.
"That was the first time I ever heard anybody say to me that I could do it," Freeman said.
She has now done it twice: first in 1992, when she failed to advance past the second round of the 400, and again in 1996, when she advanced past everyone except her much taller French measuring stick, Marie-Jose Perec, and ended up with the silver medal in Atlanta.
But on the evening of Sept. 25, the date of the 400 final in Sydney, she will be -- barring injury -- the favorite: both on paper and in the hearts and minds of the Australian fans whose interest in and connection with Freeman made this the first session of track and field to sell out. Freeman has not lost a 400 in more than two years. She has won the last two world championships in the event, and she recorded the fastest time since 1998 last month in Monaco: 49.48 seconds.
If she holds firm -- despite the pressure, despite the specter of the diminished but potentially still-dangerous Perec, and despite some painful recent distractions -- Freeman will become the first Aboriginal athlete to win an individual Olympic gold medal. And if she wins, she plans to reprise the victory celebration that helped make her reputation here by carrying both the Australian flag and the Aboriginal flag: just as she did after striking gold at the Commonwealth Games in 1994 and at the world championships in 1997.
"It's going to be a special time," she said recently, a touch of weariness in her voice. "A once-in-a-lifetime experience, but you know what? It's just running. That's my coping strategy."
 
A Romance Ends, a Business Thrives
Freeman, 27, has had much to cope with recently: first and foremost her acrimonious and litigious professional split in May with Bideau, the former Melbourne sports journalist and track and field specialist who wrote about Freeman's early exploits and began dating her in 1990 when he was 30 and she was 17.
It was Bideau who persuaded Freeman to move far south to Melbourne from Brisbane, the capital of the Australian state of Queensland in northeastern Australia.
It was Bideau, who in Pygmalionesque fashion, took control of her training, diet and career and helped her develop from a raw talent into a champion.
Even after their romance ended in November 1996, he remained her manager for the next three and a half years. Both developed new relationships. Bideau became romantically involved with Sonia O'Sullivan, the Irish middle-distance runner and former world 5,000-meter champion. Their daughter, Ciara, was born in July last year.
Two months later, Freeman married the American Sandy Bodecker, an executive with Nike, which happens to be her biggest sponsor. The wedding was less than a month after the world championships in Seville, Spain, where Freeman defended her 400 title and where Bodecker and Bideau argued publicly -- not for the first time -- about Freeman's pre-Olympic plans.
According to an authorized 1999 biography of Freeman, "A Journey Just Begun," Freeman had to intervene to put an end to that dispute. But while outsiders shook their heads in wonder at the continued intermingling of fractured relationships and shining goals, Freeman and Bideau continued working together under the umbrella of the Melbourne International Track Club, which Bideau and his business partner Peter Jess formed in the wake of Freeman's success.
"We're trying to do a job that we know is bigger than both of us," Bideau said in February when asked how they managed to keep working together. "What we're trying to achieve has a much more far-reaching effect than anything we can possibly do in our lives. If we can do that working together, and I can help her win it, that will affect so many people and will be remembered."
That same day in Melbourne, Freeman said, "It was important for me to have Nick stay part of my sports group because he is so passionate. He's passionate about track and field and very good at understanding the sport and athletes and their needs."
But her words and actions were diverging. Later that month, Freeman reportedly offered Bideau a lump-sum settlement as part of a separation offer, one Bideau reportedly refused as far too low. In May, Freeman announced that she was severing ties with Bideau and the Melbourne track club, although she did retain the coach Peter Fortune, who had begun working with her at Bideau's suggestion in 1991.
In June, Bideau and Jess retaliated by issuing a writ in the Victorian Supreme Court in Australia citing breach of contract and seeking damages on behalf of the Melbourne International Track Club and an injunction against anyone else managing Freeman. After a preliminary hearing, the two parties decided to postpone further action until after the Olympics in an attempt not to further disturb Freeman's preparations for the Games.
Neither Freeman nor Bideau responded to interview requests last month to discuss the developments, but Freeman did say: "I thought it was time to take a bit of control. I wanted to be in a position where I could do things for myself. From the time I was young, things were done for me, and I just let people do it for me. I didn't know anything different."
According to Fortune, the coach who is the link between a successful past and an uncertain future: "The things that have happened surprised me, but not totally. There are personal issues, but I've just been impressed with the way she's picked it up and run with it. Things are certainly different now. She's much more self-determining. I think her motivation and focus have never been better.
"She's working on a similar program to what she has done in the past, but the difference this year is that she's taking much more of a role in it herself, not so much in devising the program but in executing it and training at a high level. She's doing it without being in any way pushed, which maybe in the past was not the case."
But then, if Freeman cannot generate self-motivation with her own nation preparing to play host to the Games for the first time in 44 years, when will she ever be a self-starter?
"Everybody's getting nervous; I'm getting nervous; I have to control my emotions," she said shortly before leaving her training base in Britain and returning to Australia after spending three months abroad, including a five-week stop at U.C.L.A. with the American coach John Smith and his group of feisty and talented sprinters.
 
A Runner, an Australian, an Aborigine
Freeman left Australia to avoid the crush of pre-Olympic attention and to find the best competition available. Australians have been watching her closely since she was 16, when, with only one year of serious training behind her, she ran a leg in the gold-medal-winning 4 x 100 relay at the 1990 Commonwealth Games. By 1997, a street had been named for her in Mackay and she had become, according to some national polls, the most admired woman in the country.
But this month, the whole world will be watching her closely, and outsiders will be intrigued for much the same reason Australians were first intrigued: because of her "Aboriginality." Indigenous Australians, who represent approximately 1 percent of Australia's population of 19 million, remain a distinctly underprivileged minority here, with markedly shorter life spans and markedly higher rates of child mortality, unemployment, alcoholism and criminality.
The tattoo on Freeman's right shoulder might read "Acosda I'm free," but her family has not escaped unscathed.
Her father, Norman, was an accomplished rugby league player in North Queensland who later learned that he had diabetes, developed a drinking problem and separated from Freeman's mother in 1978 when Freeman was 5. He died at 53. Freeman's older sister Anne-Marie was born with cerebral palsy, spent most of her life in an institution and died of an acute asthma attack at 24.
Freeman's maternal grandmother, Alice Mero, was one of thousands of Aboriginal children taken from their parents by Australian authorities in the first 60 years of the 20th century and handed over to foster parents or missions in an attempt to increase their chances of assimilating into mainstream Australian society. Aboriginal leaders have been pressing the current government for an apology for the treatment of what is now known in Australia as "the stolen generation."
But the conservative government has refused, limiting itself to an expression of regret and sparking outrage in some segments of the Aboriginal community. Though seldom hesitant to discuss the plight of fellow Aborigines, Freeman has customarily been measured in her criticism, and she made it clear this year that she had no intention of heeding increasingly faint calls for an Olympic boycott or of using her celebrity as a political lever.
She has indicated that she is interested in a career in politics when her athletic career finishes.
"The time will come when I can be more instrumental in politics and national affairs, but not now," she said. "I think I'm playing a big part just doing what I'm doing on the track."
 
This Time, Peaking on Her Own
Freeman has never been a rock-steady performer, her weight and desire fluctuating with her moods. But she has made a habit of peaking for major events. She ran the fastest time of her career and sixth-fastest in history -- 48.63 seconds -- in the last Olympic final. The difference in Sydney is that Bideau will no longer be there to help her peak; no longer there to harken back to the hard work gone by with the words, "One lap as fast as you can."
This time, it will be up to Freeman, and if she can do it amid the din, she knows she will feel a great deal more emotion than she felt after defending her world title last year and slumping wearily to the track without bothering with a victory lap as if already feeling the weight of a nation's Olympic expectations.
"I was already thinking about Sydney," she said. "A world title gold medal is not my dream. An Olympic gold medal is."

HEADLINE: Daily News Opens a New Front in the Tabloid War;
Free Paper Raises Stakes in Battle With Post

BYLINE: By FELICITY BARRINGER with JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Despite its Texas-size sense of its own primacy in almost everything, New York City in recent years has not been the site of the country's bloodiest newspaper war. That title went to Denver, where rival papers tried to starve each other into submission by offering themselves for a penny a day.
Penny, schmenny. Tomorrow, New York gets a new afternoon newspaper for nothing, courtesy of The Daily News. (The News itself still costs 50 cents.) After The News announced its plans for the free Daily News Express, The New York Post quickly cut its newsstand price to 25 cents from 50 cents within the city limits. If red ink trickled through the streets of Denver, it threatens to course through the streets of Manhattan. 
 What does it mean? Everyone in the business has his own take. But most agree that the sudden escalation of New York's long-running tabloid war makes the perennially uncertain newspaper landscape even more uncertain. A new weapon, the free daily afternoon newspaper, hurts The Post. The Post, however, has shown that it knows how to undercut The News. Four years ago, it introduced a cut-rate Sunday newspaper, forcing The News to cut its newsstand price; even so, in less than a year, circulation of The News's most valuable edition dropped more than 100,000 copies.
Leonard N. Stern, who, as the owner of The Village Voice, turned the paid alternative weekly into a free newspaper and then sold it at a significant profit, sees the latest developments in stark terms. "The Daily News is the dominant tabloid of the city, and it is now under challenge for its life," he said. Mr. Stern, chairman of the privately held Hartz Group, added: "This is it. I believe the battle has been joined. When it's over, things are not going to look the way they do today."
Mr. Stern's views are stark, but he is not alone. Even more moderate observers do not disagree about the intensity of the current battle, or the willingness of the combatants to incur short- or medium-term losses in pursuit of long-term dominance. John Morton, a newspaper industry analyst, observed, "When you have two papers, neither of which is making money, going at it in this fashion, what it promises to do is increase the losses for both of them." He added that Rupert Murdoch, chairman of The Post's parent, the News Corporation, and Mortimer B. Zuckerman, co-owner of The News, have each demonstrated a determination to keep control of a New York newspaper. "It's not about money," he said. "It's about image and being the publisher of a major newspaper in the world's most important city."
So The News and The Post are willingly incurring extra economic pain at a time when there is already pain enough: the price of newsprint, the biggest nonlabor cost for any newspaper, is rising steeply in a market tighter than at any time in the last four years.
For The News, there is also the question of fighting a two-front war: Newsday, the Long Island newspaper, is beginning a circulation comeback in Queens after years of decline; its editor, Anthony Marro, said he planned to send in 15 people next year to strengthen a Queens-based editorial staff that now numbers about 45. (Newsday is now owned by the Tribune Company, the former owner of The Daily News.)
Indeed, to hear News executives tell it, you would not know that there was anything but fun and profit ahead. Their blithe willingness to flout received wisdom (newspapers that cost nothing are worth nothing to advertisers) has provoked guarded enthusiasm from both media analysts and advertisers. About 75,000 copies of Express will be distributed at 85 commuter hubs: bridges, tunnels, bus terminals and subway and train stations. It can carry news that breaks as late as noon, executives say.
Robert J. Broadwater, managing director of the media-centric investment bank Veronis, Suhler & Associates, is impressed. "I don't know if it will work for The News or anybody, but it's intriguing as all get-out," he said. "In the current market for news and information and entertainment, it's increasingly difficult to get and hold a paying subscriber or reader. Circulation is the biggest challenge."
Esther Eaton, advertising director at Seaman Furniture, one of The News's major advertisers, called Express "a great vehicle," adding, "There's difference between a penny-saver type vehicle and a real newspaper."
Les Goodstein, chief operating officer of The News, said executives at The News conceived the idea when they heard that Metro, a Swedish-owned free newspaper, would be distributed to Philadelphia commuters in cooperation with the city's transit authority. "We are taking the concept and refining it to fit the needs of the New York area," he said. And maybe trying to discourage the executives of Metro's parent company, the Modern Times Group, from thinking about a move to New York. Earlier this year, Modern Times executives discussed a possible collaboration with The Post, but those talks were not productive, according to an executive involved in the talks.
Express, as designed, will split its 40 pages roughly equally between advertising and editorial material: pictures, listings and short, 300-word articles, emphasizing topics like business, entertainment and sports. In Europe, such free dailies began to win audiences more than two decades ago. But almost all were morning publications -- and New Yorkers can choose from The Post, The News, The New York Times and Newsday in the morning.
"The gaping hole," Mr. Goodstein said, "was in the afternoon."
The high-profile introduction is generating guarded excitement among advertisers, who have been less than enthusiastic about reader erosion. The News -- which a decade ago had a circulation of more than a million -- is struggling to keep its circulation figure above 700,000 for the six-month period ending Sept. 30.
In fact, erosion of New York City circulation has affected not just The News but The New York Times as well. The Post has bucked this trend the last few years but has lost some of its core Manhattan readership. Others who remain loyal to The Post have known it since it was an afternoon newspaper itself -- and save it for the train or bus ride home. Tomorrow, these readers of The Post will be offered a free copy of Express by a novel crew of hawkers, including an actress, an opera singer and a handful of leggy cheerleaders.
If The News wants to grab The Post's readers, it would not mind slicing into Newsday's advertising revenue. Last year, Newsday's Queens circulation increased after three years of losses, while the Queens circulation of The News dipped. Retailers like Seaman Furniture, which advertise in both, have limited budgets. Eventually, Ms. Eaton said, new expenditures for ads in Express would require her to cut spending elsewhere. Perhaps at Newsday. Or, perhaps, at The News.
Cannibalization of readers and advertising dollars, is a consideration for executives of The News. But Mr. Goodstein said he was not worried. Express, he said, posed little threat to The News. "If we compare them, the morning paper is the novel, the evening paper is the Cliffs Notes." Edward Kosner, editor in chief of The Daily News, said Express has a staff of 20, about half carved out of The News staff and many of the rest hired, for the moment, on a contingency basis.
"The New York market is going to stay competitive," Mr. Goodstein said. "The way we're positioning our product is as an all-day news product." Much of its breaking business news will come from the San Francisco-based Web site CBSMarketwatch.com.
But can The Daily News's daily circulation (730,542 for the six months ended March 31) withstand the possible hammer effect of The Post's price cut? With a circulation measured at 436,544 for the period ended March 31, The Post looses less from such an action than The News does if it follows suit.
Mr. Murdoch, for his part, is legendary for using blunt instruments like price cuts to good effect in one market after another. In London, a 1993 price cut at The Times of London brought in close to 400,000 new readers, more than half of whom stayed even when the price went back up. Its rival, The Daily Telegraph, was forced to cut its own prices in response.
In Britain, cuts in the cover price are a more dire move, since 35 percent to 50 percent of most British newspapers' revenue come from readers. By contrast, most American newspapers gain close to 80 percent of their revenue from advertisers. Still, analysts believe The Post already loses at least $10 million annually; the new price cut should add millions more to the loss column.
As Mr. Stern sees it, Mr. Murdoch's willingness to sustain that kind of drain makes him a fearsome competitor. "I've been in many businesses, including publishing. I can tell you categorically: I don't want to be in any business where I have to compete with Rupert Murdoch."
Ken Chandler, publisher of The Post, alluded to the News Corporation's willingness to endure economic pain when he said, "I remind people that we have a history of being patient and taking a long-term view with newspapers." He added, "Basically, we just see this price change as a chance to introduce new readers to the paper and reintroduce old readers who may not have looked at us recently," pointing out that the paper has increased its daily circulation by 50,000 in the last five years.
Keeping that upward momentum is important, particularly when $200 million worth of new presses are nearing completion. Some observers suggest it may also be important for The Post to impress federal regulators with its willingness to publish at great cost to itself -- so they will not overrule the News Corporation's recently announced plans to buy a second television station in New York as an unacceptable concentration of media power.
For his part, Mr. Chandler is willing to do some genteel trash-talking about his rivals at The News. "Our hawkers will go toe to toe with theirs," he said. "And we have got a few things that we're keeping close to our chest that will make life more interesting." He does not rule out the possibility that his morning paper will publish a few evening special editions of its own. Major events at the Summer Olympics in Sydney are scheduled for the early-morning hours, East Coast time -- perfect timing for a noon deadline.
Indeed, it is no accident that Express is starting just as the Summer Olympics are about to begin and the pre-Christmas advertising begins to roll in. But then what? Ms. Eaton of Seaman said she was originally asked to commit to 16 weeks of advertising (she committed to 8). Mr. Goodstein said Express's viability -- meaning its appeal to advertisers -- would be continually monitored; it is clear that it could be abandoned quickly if its usefulness seemed doubtful.
Meanwhile, executives at The Post will be monitoring their own circulation; Mr. Chandler does not rule out further price cuts, ignoring Mr. Goodstein's provocative description of The Post's move as a "desperation" strategy.
"Obviously this is a very, very competitive environment," Mr. Chandler said. "We are wholly focused on The Post and we see The Post as a long-term investment."

THE DAILY NEWS
OCT. '90 -- Nine of 10 News unions go on strike for five months.
MARCH '91 -- The Tribune Company sells The News to Robert Maxwell for $60 million.

JAN. '93 -- Mortimer B. Zuckerman and Fred Drasner take over The News.
MARCH '00 -- Edward Kosner is named editor in chief of The News.
SEPT. '00 -- The News introduces Express, a free paper.
 
NEW YORK POST
AUG. '91 -- The Post's owner, Peter S. Kalikow, files for personal bankruptcy.
MARCH '93 -- Abraham Hirshfield, a real estate developer, takes over The Post.
OCT. '93 -- Rupert Murdoch, who owned The Post from 1976 to 1988, buys back the bankrupt paper.
APRIL '96 -- The Post brings back its Sunday edition and charges only 50 cents.
FEB. '00 -- Xana Antunes is named editor in chief of The Post.

HEADLINE: Robert E. Dewar, 77, Who Led Kmart in 70's Expansion, Dies

BYLINE: By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
Robert E. Dewar, the former chairman and chief executive of the Kmart Corporation, who led the company's huge expansion of retail stores nationwide, died at his home on Thursday. He was 77 and lived in Bloomfield Hills, Mich.
The cause of death was complications from colon cancer, said Mr. Dewar's son, Robert Jr. 
 After Mr. Dewar spent three years as a pilot in the United States Naval Air Corps, he attended law school at Wayne State University in Detroit. He received his degree in 1948. For six months after his graduation, he practiced at a Michigan firm, but his interest quickly turned toward corporate law.
In 1949, he joined the legal department of the S.S. Kresge Company, which operated a group of variety stores -- those "five-and-dime" stores that operated usually in downtown areas or old city neighborhoods. He continued as a company lawyer until 1960, when he was promoted to assistant to the president.
For the next two years, Mr. Dewar studied finance in evening classes at the University of Michigan Graduate School of Business Administration.
By 1963, Mr. Dewar's classes apparently paid off -- he was promoted to assistant vice president of finance. He worked in a variety of finance positions until he was named president in 1970. Two years later, he was promoted to chairman and chief executive.
By that time, Kresge was in the middle of a transformation. During the 1960's, the company began moving away from the variety store strategy toward diversifying into low-margin, one-stop discount centers, known as Kmarts.
With Mr. Dewar at the helm, Kresge earned a reputation as a company in a hurry. With inflation and competition heating up, the company set lofty sales goals and began an aggressive campaign to open additional discount centers around the country. In 1977, Kresge renamed itself after its flagship business, becoming the Kmart Corporation.
By 1979, when Mr. Dewar became chairman of the company's executive and finance committees and relinquished his other titles, Kmart had won a reputation as one of the country's largest and fastest-growing retail operations. Mr. Dewar continued with the company in that position until his retirement in 1988.
In the years since leaving Kmart, Mr. Dewar focused his attention on his two other passions: opera and the city of Detroit. He was named chairman of the Michigan Opera Theater, where he worked to raise more than $18 million. That money was used to transform the former Grand Circus Theatre into a new opera house for Michigan.
"He went from auto company to auto company, from person to person, to raise that money," Robert Dewar Jr. said.
During his retirement, Mr. Dewar also served on the board of several nonprofit organizations in the state, and was chairman of a local United Way organization.
In addition to his son Robert Jr., Mr. Dewar is survived by his wife, Helen, and his two other adult children, Jane and John.

HEADLINE: OPEC Agrees to Increase Oil Production by 3 Percent

BYLINE: By NEELA BANERJEE 

DATELINE: VIENNA, Sept. 10

 BODY:
Faced with growing international pressure to drive down stubbornly high oil prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries decided today to increase its crude production by 800,000 barrels a day, spokesmen for the group and delegates said.
An official statement on the production increase will be issued Monday afternoon, the spokesmen said. The OPEC meeting was cut short because the city of Vienna had planned a celebration for the delegates this evening to mark the cartel's 40th anniversary. 
 The members were scheduled to meet again on Monday morning to confirm the increase and to discuss other issues in preparation for a meeting of OPEC heads of state in Caracas, Venezuela later this month.
Just days before this OPEC session, the price of crude oil reached its highest levels since the Persian Gulf war, before receding somewhat on Friday. OPEC members said they hoped that the 3 percent increase from its current daily production of 25.4 million barrels will gradually push oil prices below $30 a barrel -- it has been above $33 -- with most nations asserting that a favorable price would be between $22 and $28 a barrel.
Most of OPEC realizes that oil that costs more than $30 a barrel threatens to stunt worldwide economic growth, which, in turn, would cut into revenues member nations earn. But many oil industry experts in Vienna said that although the decision to increase its output signals OPEC's willingness to rein in prices, the increase is probably not enough to result in a significant fall in the cost of crude oil. They said it probably would bring prices down to about $30 a barrel.
"It's an important first step in dissipating the upward pressure on crude oil prices," said Michael Rothman, director of energy research for Merrill Lynch. "But we have to see if inventories in the U.S. increase down the line."
Indeed, crude oil prices in the United States have been driven up largely because of concern over the low supplies of crude oil and heating fuel compared with the levels in previous years. Most experts say the low inventories stem from high demand for gasoline and diesel during the summer and OPEC's increasingly constrained supply.
The cartel has raised production by nearly 3 million barrels since the beginning of the year, but the growing supply of oil has been quickly absorbed by the booming international economy, although demand has slackened slightly in the last few months as a result of high fuel prices.
Prices remain very high in Europe, as well as in the United States, and there has been a wave of protests across the continent. While truckers and others who had imposed blockades across France gradually lifted them this weekend, protesters tied up traffic in the center of Brussels today to protest high fuel costs.
This latest production increase by OPEC, which would probably go into effect Oct. 1, appears to be as much as the group could eke out. Most OPEC nations and countries allied with them like Mexico and Norway are already producing crude at maximum capacity. Only Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates are believed to have spare capacity to devote to increased production.
Most OPEC countries stand to lose money from the production increase, because they cannot produce the extra volumes needed to compensate for a decline in prices. But OPEC delegates conceded that they were under substantial pressure from the West to act, despite the conviction among many that a powerful demand in Europe, Asia and the United States is what is responsible for pushing up the prices.
"OPEC is not the cause of these high consumer prices," said Abdulla Salatt, the OPEC governor from Qatar. "We know that prices really can't be affected very much" by the OPEC decision.
A major factor in determining the impact of the decision on world crude oil supplies, which is a rough estimate, at best, is how much so-called new oil will be produced now. Since OPEC's last meeting in late June, cartel members have been producing above their official quotas, by anywhere from 650,000 barrels to 750,000 barrels a day -- the bulk of it seeping quietly out of Saudi Arabia, according to industry experts.
The increase today takes into account such "cheating," so it remains unclear how much additional oil actually will flow. During the coming months, more overproduction may occur, but volumes will probably be small, given the greatly limited extra capacity among OPEC members.
Obviously, not all the oil from the OPEC increase will be destined for the United States, and the first shipments of any new oil will probably arrive in early November, a month after the decision goes into effect. In the meantime, if supplies of crude oil and heating fuel in the United States remain low, the chances grow for price spikes and possible shortages of heating oil in the winter.
With such a scenario looming in an election year, the Clinton administration and the Department of Energy are considering releasing oil from the country's Strategic Petroleum Reserve to replenish commercial crude and heating oil reserves, industry experts said.
The estimated 570-million-barrel reserve was created in the mid-1970's, during the height of the Arab oil embargo, to shield the United States from another global energy crisis. While current oil prices and low heating oil supplies may not constitute a crisis, the administration has staked its credibility on a yearlong campaign to reduce oil prices.
The energy department is already in the process of creating a two-million-barrel heating oil reserve for the northeastern part of the United States, where most of the country's heating oil is consumed. The new idea of tapping the Strategic Petroleum Reserve would apparently entail giving oil from the reserves to refineries this autumn, with the refineries required to return it to the reserve at a later date.
