HEADLINE: Avoid the Lines. Vote Now!

BYLINE: By Gary Krist; Gary Krist is the author, most recently, of "Chaos Theory," a novel.

 BODY:
Dear Voter:
In order that our presidential candidates can better tailor their policy initiatives to the needs, priorities and blatant self-interest of you, the average hard-working American family, the bipartisan Commission for Responsive Electioneering has assembled the following questionnaire. 
 Candidates from the two major parties were asked to submit one question in each of five different policy areas. Please answer all questions in full and return the questionnaire to: C.R.E., Dept. of Public Pandering, 5001 K Street NW, Washington.
 
The Tax Cut
GORE: If we Americans are to stay the course in this greatest economic expansion in our history, we must be especially vigilant about the effects of any federal tax cut on inflation and consumer spending. To help us protect our robust economy from the dangers of overheating, please list below all probable areas of increased spending for you and your household under the following scenarios: (A) a 1.5% tax cut; (B) a 2.73% tax cut partially offset by a $257 decrease in the Dependent Exemption Allowance; (C) a 1.357% increase in the Earned Income Tax Credit, combined with a 2.541% increase in the Child Care Credit and abolition of the Alternative Minimum Tax as calculated on Form 6251, line 11, of your 1999 Federal Income Tax Return.
 BUSH: How much of your own money do you want back?
(A) $1,000
(B) $10,000
(C) As much as you can give me.
 
Technology and the Internet
 GORE: Like any proud father, I take a great interest in the health and welfare of my baby, the Internet. (Just kidding. See? I can poke fun at myself like any other regular guy!) But seriously, the Internet is poised to change the way we live in fundamental ways. In order to ensure that it realizes its massive potential to better the lives of each and every American, we need to know just how and for what purposes you use the Internet. Please print out and attach the contents of the history folder of your preferred Web browser. Also append information about ISP, modem connection (56K, DSL, ISDN or cable), computer chip megahertz rating, and hard disk size. If necessary, seek out the minor children in your household for assistance.
BUSH: Internet, Schminternet. Has anyone ever gotten onto that America Online thing between 4 and 6 in the afternoon? Or do you -- like the Rodriguez family of Beloit, Michigan, or the Chen family of Seattle, or the Baileys of Manchester, Vermont -- spend hours listening to busy signals, just waiting to hear the little man say "You've got mail"? We can fix that.
 
Education
GORE: Priority One -- Don't you think we owe it to our children to give them the best possible education money can provide?
 BUSH: Priority One -- Don't you think we owe it to our children to give them the best possible education teachers can provide?
 
Health Care
GORE: Health care, as we all know, is an extremely complex issue -- one that could fill hours and hours and hours of adult, intelligent debate, preferably in front of a national audience on all major networks, ahem, ahem. However, in the interest of brevity, just attach complete medical records, drug prescription information and insurance policies for you and every member of your household. We'll take it from there.
BUSH: You wanted details, we gave you details. Like 300 pages worth of details on Medicare alone! Lots of numbers, statistics, cost analyses-type things in there -- hey, we can play that game as well as they can. But the real question is this: Is anyone out there actually gonna read the darn thing?
 
Social Security
GORE: As the Baby Boom Generation moves toward retirement, it becomes increasingly important that we ensure the long-term fiscal health of the Social Security system. You can help us plan for your future by estimating your automatic payroll deductions and/or self-employment tax contributions to the system over the next 10-, 20- and 30-year time periods, assuming normal income growth of 3.5 percent per year. (Dot-com entrepreneurs: attach separate schedule for vesting stock options and obscene capital gains.)
Please include information about your probable retirement age and any health problems, self-destructive behaviors or other factors that may impact your life expectancy and therefore affect the amount of time you will likely be claiming benefits.
BUSH: Let me speak plainly here to finish up. So here goes: Who would you rather trust with your hard-earned retirement nest egg -- Wall Street or Uncle Sam? Answer yes or no.

HEADLINE: In Aisle 3, Meet-and-Greet With Belgian Royals

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
It was just another ho-hum supermarket promotion until the royals arrived in the cheese aisle.
Then, quite suddenly yesterday, the diminutive D'Agostino market in Chelsea became a fanatically overscrutinized beachhead of international trade. To the astonishment of grocery shoppers, dozens of reporters and diplomats invaded the modest store to attend the visit of the fairytale couple that has dominated all those magazine covers and glossy photo spreads in Europe. 
 At 2:38 p.m., the handsome Crown Prince Philippe of Belgium and his dazzling bride, Princess Mathilde, arrived in a nine-car motorcade that included five black Mercedeses and a police escort. For the couple, whose Brussels nuptials were celebrated in December as the last royal wedding of the millennium, it was Day 2 of a whirlwind five-day visit.
No, they hadn't decided to try a little shopping-cart schlepping to enliven their giddy but overscheduled round of exclusive galas. Instead, their mission was to showcase Belgian products and industries while capitalizing on the growing visibility of things Belgian in New York City of late.
"Who ever thought the Prince and Princess of Belgium would come to Chelsea and take a grape with us," said Zell Schwartzman, who lives a block from the store and was taking in the spectacle from the relative safety of the salad bar. She allowed that she was far from a Belgian novice "because of my next door neighbor," Alphonsine Conolly, a Belgian who has lived in the United States for 41 years.
"I wanted a picture of my prince," Ms. Conolly said, clutching her camera.
And she began snapping as the royals made their way around the cozy 6,500-square-foot D'Agostino, on 23rd Street near Eighth Avenue, kicking off a celebration of Belgian products at the food chain's 24 stores, and incidentally furthering their mission to win the hearts, minds, media and market share of New Yorkers.
But one grim reality did intrude: the news that a cousin of Prince Philippe, Prince Guillaume of Luxembourg, had been severely injured in a car crash yesterday. "It is a great shock; he is in a coma," Prince Philippe said in an interview. "If it becomes more grave, we may return."
In the interim, the 40-year-old prince belied his reputation for reticence by chatting up folks at displays of Belgian chocolate, Belgian marmalade and Belgian beer.
The royals had been welcomed on Saturday at Kennedy International Airport by reporters and news crews (40 had accompanied them from Brussels on a military jet, where the couple broke all precedent by chatting at length with them).
At a reception Saturday night for 350 of the metropolitan region's 8,000 Belgians at Markt, the glam Belgian bistro in the meatpacking district, the royals stepped through intermittent showers to face the multitude. "This rain is very Belgian," said Danielle Kurz, the Belgian-born owner of the Belgian gallery Artwall + B, in Rutherford, N.J. "But there, the rain would be colder."
The royal couple navigated the crowds confidently and chatted easily with Belgian subjects as well as American admirers, some of whom seemed positively royal-struck. There were actually flustered curtsies and a few "Your Majesties" and a "Highness" or two. But in fact, according to Belgian consulate officials, the prince and princess -- as Belgium's future, not present, monarchs -- are to be addressed as "monseigneur" and "madame."
The prince sipped a glass of Stella Artois beer during the meet-and-greet at Markt, while 27-year-old Princess Mathilde worked the room to unrestrained admiration. Although some have likened Princess Mathilde to the model Claudia Schiffer or Diana, Princess of Wales, "I don't see that," said Jerry Lucadamo, a Westchester teacher who had been invited to the reception with his Belgian wife. He explained: "I think she's so Grace Kelly."
In an interview yesterday in a Belgian restaurant, Le Pain Quotidien, the prince expressed his satisfaction that in the three years since his last New York visit "the economic boom is now visible everywhere."
And Belgium wants to contribute to it. To honor the royal visit, one luxury Brussels fabric maker, Scabal, is exporting a new woolen product it calls "diamond chip." At $1,000 a yard, it is blended with microscopic pieces of diamond from Antwerp. "The diamonds are wrapped around the threads," said Scabal's American agent, Neal Boyarsky. "You see, that is why the fabric doesn't cut people's skin."

HEADLINE: Experts Fear a Brutal Season For Heating in the Northeast

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON 

 BODY:
It was perhaps only natural, as chilly, fall-like air flowed into the New York region last week -- capping a much cooler than normal summer -- to let out a sigh of relief. Electricity experts had predicted power failures and brownouts, but neither happened. Bills went up, but not as much as they could have, because air-conditioners were not running round the clock.
But don't gloat just yet. Energy experts and meteorologists say that the Northeast, for reasons as varied as the patterns of Canadian arctic air flow and decisions made by oil refiners in the Midwest and oil buyers in Germany, is now facing what could be a particularly brutal heating season. 
 Much of the problem, they say, is broad and national: a shortage of natural gas, the most common heating fuel nationwide, sent wholesale prices last week to a level that market researchers say has never been reached in early September, nearly double what it was a year ago.
Regional forces, however, especially a steep drop in Northeast heating-oil inventories and what some forecasters predict will be a sharply colder autumn in the Northeast, are likely to compound the effect of those high prices.
Although no utility or regulatory body is predicting an actual shortage of fuel oil or natural gas for the region, the public anxiety over the price and availability of a commodity that most people consider a necessity is almost certain to keep the energy issue on the front burner. The economic tumult of a deregulated electricity market in New York State, the key energy issue of this summer, will be heightened in winter by the strategies of petrochemical traders around the world.
"It's a bit of Murphy's Law -- a lot of little things have gone wrong," said Sarah Emerson, the managing director of Energy Security Analysis Inc., a research and consulting firm in Wakefield, Mass.
Last month, for example, the price of No. 2 heating oil -- used primarily in homes -- arriving in New York Harbor reached its highest level in nearly 10 years: more than $36 a barrel, up 59 percent from August 1999. At the same time, the regional oil inventory, called days of supply, reached its lowest level since 1996, and inventories in August were 47 percent below the level of a year ago. The monthly average wholesale price of natural gas on the New York market was also up about 59 percent from August 1999.
KeySpan Energy, the region's largest provider of natural gas, warned its customers in July, even before the latest price surge, that this winter's bills would be 12 percent to 15 percent higher than last winter's. And one of the first long-range weather forecasts for the region, issued late last month, said that temperatures in the New York region this fall would be much cooler than last year.
The emerging winter's tale of energy in New York City is also vastly more complicated than this summer's. In June, July and August, the key questions were how hot the weather would get and whether the electricity supply would be able to handle the demand. The new terrain is as unpredictable as the next northeaster. Energy experts said the heating-oil inventory problem, for instance, could resolve itself suddenly with a vast increase in supplies in midwinter, as sellers from around the world rush to capitalize on high prices. Or the problem could be compounded as sellers try to play the market, holding back oil and choking off supply even more as they wait for higher prices to come.
The reach of the global economy also explains why reserves have fallen so low already. Because the price of gasoline was high in the Midwest this summer, refinery owners found that making plain old heating oil just did not pay. At the same time, Germany went on a buying binge to bolster its oil reserves, taking much of the European supply. A fire at a Kuwaiti oil field cut back the trans-Atlantic oil flow even more. A commodities-trading phenomenon that sounds like a new dance craze, contango, in which traders bet that prices will drop in the future, gave oil distributors little incentive to stockpile oil. With the heating season only weeks away, inventories in the mid-Atlantic states were nearly 40 percent below the 1990's average for this time of year.
But however it happened, low inventories in the Northeast have become a factor in the price of energy.
"When you have very low inventories, there are ripple effects," said Kevin Lindemer, a senior director at Cambridge Energy Research Associates, a research and consulting firm in Cambridge, Mass. "Unexpected things can cause price fluctuations."
During one winter in the early 1990's, for example, high winds kept oil barges from docking in New York for weeks. But that was not a problem then because reserves were twice as high as they are now. In other winters, iced-over rivers or snow-clogged streets hampered oil deliveries, but the problem did not make the front page because supplies were ample. This year, Mr. Lindemer said, bad weather that affects deliveries could be as much of a factor as bad weather that makes people use more fuel.
Another important factor in the energy price picture is that the mix of fuels in the region has changed. Demand for natural gas in the Northeast has soared in recent years and is expected to climb further, altering the chemistry of a region that long had a national distinction for its dependence on heating oil. All the new electricity-generating plants in the region, for example, burn natural gas, and the ones being proposed will also burn natural gas. And customers of KeySpan have been requesting conversions from oil to gas in record numbers this year, the company says. All those extra buyers of natural gas could push prices up if national supplies remain tight.
New York State and the federal government have both taken steps to smooth out potential bumps. The Clinton administration said late last month that it had reached agreements to bring two million barrels, or 84 million gallons, of heating oil into New Jersey and Connecticut to bolster reserves. And although most energy analysts said the added oil would dampen price increases, others said the new supply could make some suppliers complacent about building up their own inventories.
The New York State Public Service Commission, which regulates energy delivery companies, issued rules last month requiring some big energy customers, especially industrial users that can switch from one fuel to another, to increase their oil reserves now so that sudden surges in demand caused by switching will not unbalance the markets. A spokesman for KeySpan said the company was training two dozen inspectors to make sure that customers comply with the rules.
The weather, of course, is the biggest variable of all. Energycast, an online energy and weather-forecasting service, said late last month that the daily average temperature for November in New York would be 39.6 degrees, 4.4 degrees colder than last year's daily average for November. On the other hand, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, which also issues long-range forecasts, has said the fall and early winter forecast in the Northeast is too uncertain to call.
Behind all these variables is a certain mystery. The oil inventories that are reported to government agencies and energy consultants are based on huge wholesale stockpiles, not on the more precise numbers from local companies, which do not have to tell anyone what they have. If a supplier admitted to sitting on a lot of oil, market analysts say, his customers could reasonably ask why their bills were so high. So the suppliers speak in a kind of code.
"They say, 'I'm wet,' which means, 'I have product,' or, 'I'm dry,' which means they don't have any," said Tom Collins, a spokesman for the New York State Energy Research and Development Authority. "That's all you have to work with."

HEADLINE: Clash Time in the Senate Race

 BODY:
New York's Senate race had settled recently into a tediously safe campaign between two cautious candidates. All that changed over the weekend with the politically motivated White House decision to release a 1998 photograph of Representative Rick Lazio shaking hands with Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader. As a result, Mr. Lazio and Hillary Rodham Clinton will likely use their debate in Buffalo on Wednesday to continue their highly charged battle for the Jewish vote and to defend the tactics being used in that competition.
Indeed, New York voters will have to judge substance as well as tactics. On substance, they should be clear that both sides are trying to sell pejorative explanations of acceptable diplomatic behavior. President Clinton was right to shake the hand of President Fidel Castro of Cuba when they met at the United Nations last week. Mrs. Clinton made the correct protocol judgment not to have a public confrontation with Suha Arafat during a trip to Israel last year. Finally, Mr. Lazio and the other Congressmen who joined Mr. Clinton in a meeting with Mr. Arafat made the appropriate judgment in shaking Mr. Arafat's hand. 
 What New York voters should look for Wednesday is the level of maturity with which Mr. Lazio and Mrs. Clinton discuss the whole range of issues and the level of skill with which they address this skirmish. After weeks of long-range exchanges, the public will at last get a chance to see them really tested. Mr. Lazio will now have to show that he can explain the seeming hypocrisy of his position that some handshakes are worse than others. For her part, Mrs. Clinton needs to show that she does not need meddling from a White House well known for trickery to prop up her candidacy.
With polls showing a very tight race, the debate offers the advantage of broader exposure for Mr. Lazio. But with the exposure will come a more intense kind of testing. So far, Mr. Lazio's ability to respond under pressure has been an unknown factor. His supporters have counted on the deep animosities that many people feel toward Mrs. Clinton to keep his campaign moving. Those feelings among conservatives have helped boost state and national fund-raising for Mr. Lazio. But many people still want to vote for somebody they feel can do the job, not merely against someone who irritates them.
Like the two other debates scheduled before the election, this one presents difficulties for the first lady. Since she lacks a legislative record, she must convince voters by the force of personality and conviction. Her advisers want her to focus on issues like education, health care and the economy. Polls show that Mrs. Clinton has recently gained support among Jewish voters after months of tension. She won some applause for using her White House influence in the effort to keep Jonathan Pollard, an American convicted of spying for Israel, from being transferred to a rougher prison environment. Further attempts to meddle in this case would almost surely backfire, however, because of its serious national security implications.
Against this landscape, we can see key tasks for each candidate. Mr. Lazio has to show that he can function outside the cozy world of Long Island G.O.P. politics. Mrs. Clinton must prove that she can fight her corner without help from her husband or the White House press office. And the reality for both candidates as they face the cameras is that the winning votes are still in play.

HEADLINE: South Korean Says North Agrees U.S. Troops Should Stay

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

 BODY:
The most important outcome of his summit conference with North Korea in June, President Kim Dae Jung of South Korea says, was a common understanding that American troops must stay in South Korea to prevent a vacuum on the Korean peninsula that would be inviting to its neighbors.
"We are surrounded by big powers -- Russia, Japan and China -- so the United States must continue to stay for stability and peace in East Asia," he said. Mr. Kim said he was recounting almost the exact words of his counterpart, Kim Jong Il, in North Korea during their meetings in Pyongyang. 
 The Communist government in North Korea, whose hostility has been cited by the Clinton administration as a major reason for pursuing a missile defense system, wants normal relations with United States, Kim Dae Jung said.
"I believe that North Korea wants improved relations with the United States," Mr. Kim said on Saturday in an interview at his Manhattan hotel at the end of the gathering of world leaders at the United Nations. "That is their basic goal. If it is not their basic goal, there is no reason why they should change their position on American forces."
The mantra of Communist propaganda since the end of Korean War has been that American troops must leave South Korea. So the North Korean leader's support of their staying is a reversal of position -- albeit one that Pyongyang has not yet acknowledged in public.
After a peace treaty replaces the armistice now in place between the two Koreas, the presence of American troops in South Korea and on the Japanese island of Okinawa would operate "under the same logic" that governed the continuing presence of American troops in Europe as part of NATO after the collapse of the Soviet Union, the South Korean president suggested.
Mr. Kim, a human rights dissident who was put on death row by the South Korean military junta and then survived to become the democratically elected president, spoke eloquently of what he saw as the steady but long journey to bring the two Koreas together.
During his visit here, Mr. Kim, 75, was a sought-after figure: he met privately with President Clinton, he answered questions from Democratic and Republican experts who are advising the two presidential candidates on Asia and he delivered a speech at a Korea Society event.
Mr. Kim, dapper in a blue suit and pink tie, said he was encouraged that Republican and Democratic experts supported the continued presence of American troops on the peninsula.
Overall, he said it was impossible to predict the speed and substance of what would happen. "No one predicted unification in Germany so suddenly," he said in the interview. But for the moment, he said, the goal in Korea is not unification between the totalitarian regime in the North and the democratic government of the South. Even it that were to occur, he said, "it would create a lot of negative consequences."
By the end of his term in a little more than two years, he wants to see "peace, cooperation and exchanges" with North Korea, cemented by a peace treaty, he said. But to get even that far, he added, South Korea needs help from its allies.
"For things to progress smoothly, there must be improved relations between the United States and North Korea, between North Korea and the European Union and between North Korea and Japan," he said. "We cannot carry on this process on our own."
One important step toward better United States-North Korean relations, he said, would be looking seriously at the suggestion by Kim Jong Il that North Korea is willing to curb its missile program in exchange for financing that would allow it to launch satellites.
The North Koreans first broached the idea this summer to the Russian president, Vladimir V. Putin, who discussed it with President Clinton in July. Since then, American officials have held talks with Moscow on exactly what North Korea had in mind. Senior administration officials said last week that the idea appeared to be worth pursuing but that the United States needed to ensure that it did not involve the transfer of technological advances to the North Koreans.
Mr. Kim said he had spoken to President Clinton in their meeting this week about the possibility of a satellites-for-missiles deal. Mr. Kim said he believed that the North Korean suggestion would "serve as the basis" for the ongoing negotiations between North Korea and the United States on Pyongyang's missile program.
On the financing of the satellite launchings, Mr. Kim said it was not clear to him whether the North Koreans were seeking assistance from the United States or from multilateral sources.
But one aspect is clear, he said. Although the North's leader suggested three satellite launchings a year at the cost of $300 million each, "the experts on our side say that the rocket launches do not cost as much as the chairman says."
Once relations between the United States and North Korea improve, Mr. Kim said, there will be enough confidence for wealthy nations, multilateral institutions -- the International Monetary Fund, the Asia Development Bank -- and private investors to help develop the moribund North Korean economy.
The South Korean government does not have the resources to carry the burden of investment in the north, but will encourage the country's businesses to plunge ahead, he said.
Since the summit conference in June, officials from South and North Korea have started working on a basic economic framework to encourage investment in the North, he said. The steps include investment guarantees, avoidance of double taxation and dispute arbitration, he said.
Officials from the defense ministries on both sides are scheduled to meet to discuss measures to reduce tension. Those would include observations by each side of the other's military exercises and exchanges of information on each other's troop movements.
Talking of the peace treaty that he said he hoped he would sign with North Korea before leaving office in 2003, Mr. Kim said the United States and China, who were also combatants in the Korean War, would play "supporting roles" without being signers.
By the time he leaves office, he said, he wants to see North Korea as a "responsible member of the international community."
In economics, he hopes there will be "significant" cooperation between the United States and North Korea. The North, he suggested, could follow the model of China and North Vietnam, where "the economy is very successfully opened" but the political system remains intact.
Mr. Kim said the North Korean leader might visit Seoul as early as this fall, but more likely next spring. A close aide to Kim Jong Il arrived in Seoul today to discuss the visit, Agence France-Presse reported.
As the moves towards normal relations unfold, there are seemingly small bumps that require considerable effort to overcome.
One occurred at the start of the United Nations gathering, when the second most powerful leader in North Korea, Kim Yong Nam, angrily turned back home after being put through a body search at Frankfurt Airport by employees of an American airline.
The South Korean president was supposed to meet with the North Korean in New York as part of the reconciliation process. So he asked President Clinton for his help in calming the insulted North Koreans.
On Friday, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright announced that the North Koreans had accepted the apologies and that the North Korean foreign minister, Paek Nam Sun, would be coming to the United Nations this week. But he will arrive after President Kim leaves New York.

HEADLINE: Unfriendly Skies: What to Do?

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Crisis for Air Traffic System: More Passengers, More Delays" (front page, Sept. 5): 
 Our aviation industry is a cornerstone of the global economy. Yet for years the Federal Aviation Administration ignored its own warnings about the system's reaching gridlock by 2000.
The public and business world are now paying the price with record delays and cancellations, poor service, outdated technology and overburdened airports.
One of the worst chokepoints is O'Hare International Airport. Sixteen years ago, the F.A.A. directed the State of Illinois to begin planning a third regional airport. Those plans are complete but have been stymied by the Clinton administration, bowing to pleas from Mayor Richard M. Daley and the airlines that control O'Hare.
Now Transportation Secretary Rodney Slater and the F.A.A. say that it's time to study aviation problems. But given the agency's knowledge of the problems and inaction, the call rings hollow.
 
JESSE L. JACKSON JR.
Member of Congress, 2nd Dist., Ill.
Washington, Sept. 6, 2000

HEADLINE: Harlem U.S.A. Tries to Lure Stores Owned by Minorities

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Since it opened in February, the Harlem U.S.A. retail and entertainment complex on 125th Street and Frederick Douglass Boulevard has provided jobs for hundreds of local residents and has drawn crowds to national chain stores like Modell's Sporting Goods, Old Navy and HMV Record Stores.
But what Harlem U.S.A. does not yet have are independent stores with minority owners. This has been a sore point with some people in the neighborhood -- among them, the city councilman who represents Harlem, Bill Perkins. 
 Efforts are under way, however, to bring several black-owned businesses to the shopping complex, including Harlem's first large bookstore, said Drew Greenwald, the president of Grid Properties, the private company that developed the $66 million Harlem U.S.A. with the Harlem Commonwealth Council, a local nonprofit organization. Mr. Greenwald said he is negotiating leases with several retailers that want to expand into Harlem. They include Blackberry, a small chain of home-furnishings boutiques; Moshood, which operates a popular clothing store in Fort Greene, Brooklyn; and the bookstore, which is called Hue-Man Experience in Harlem. These stores would occupy a total of 8,500 square feet of adjoining space on the second floor, Mr. Greenwald said.
In June, Clara Villarosa, the founder of Hue-Man Experience, a bookstore in Denver that focuses on black and multicultural themes, received a $475,000 loan from the New York Empowerment Zone to help her get the new bookstore going. Ms. Villarosa sold the Denver store and now lives in Harlem.
The empowerment zone, a seven-member board that administers a huge government program to stimulate economic development in Upper Manhattan and the South Bronx, is expected to vote soon on loans of $325,000 and $300,000, respectively, to Blackberry and Moshood. The loans have been approved by the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone, which manages the program for Harlem, Washington Heights and Inwood. The vote was supposed to take place Friday, but the board meeting was postponed after some members complained that the financial information they were given was incomplete. No new meeting date was set.
Jim Capel, the chief of staff for United States Representative Charles B. Rangel, a member of the empowerment zone board, said that he expected the pending loans to be approved. "Oftentimes, emerging businesses have difficulty getting into these buildings because they can't afford the rent," he said. "The empowerment zone is doing everything it can to help them."
Blackberry, based in Arlington, Va., sells African art and candelabras, table runners and other items inspired by African themes, said Barry Blackman, who founded the store 10 years ago with Dorothy White and her daughter, Diane White. The store has boutiques at Macy's in Manhattan and Brooklyn and at Stern's in Brooklyn.
Mr. Blackman said that having a free-standing store at Harlem U.S.A., instead of being limited to a boutique inside a department store, would allow Blackberry to sell furniture along with the smaller items. "To be included in this type of mixture is really very interesting to us," he said, referring to the shopping complex. "The demographics are really great."
Moshood, named for its Nigerian proprietor, carries contemporary clothing made from traditional African prints. The six-year-old store attracts passers-by by featuring live mannequins in its windows and has helped to revitalize the Fulton Street shopping strip in Fort Greene. Moshood also has a store in Atlanta.
Mr. Greenwald said that he has always intended to mix in tenants like these with the national retailers. "We've been trying from Day 1 to identify minority-owned businesses that would fit in with the project," Mr. Greenwald said.
Councilman Perkins said many Harlem residents have mixed feelings about Harlem U.S.A. "Obviously, folks appreciate the convenience of being able to shop in their neighborhood, as opposed to having to travel downtown," Mr. Perkins said. But he said that many entrepreneurs who had stuck it out in Harlem when times were hard now felt they were being left out. "They feel that now that resources are available," he said, "they're not experiencing the good times."
He said the proposed stores, which would be newcomers to the neighborhood, were a "step in the right direction."
Outside the Modell's store at Harlem U.S.A., Ella Brown, an insurance company representative in her 40's who lives in Harlem, said she had nothing against national chains, "just as long as they give to the community, such as jobs."
She said she had only one priority when she went out to shop: "Getting what I want at a reasonable price."

HEADLINE: When Diplomats Flee to Dot-Coms

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Your Sept. 4 news article about the State Department's losing its attraction as a lifelong career was right on the mark. Perhaps this trend reflects the reality that in today's economy, career changes are expected and often welcomed. 
 However, it is understandable that topnotch officials are frustrated by a scattershot personnel assignment system, the eternal shuffling of ineffectual personnel, the placement of officers with little management expertise into managerial positions, a promotion system plagued by the worst excesses of grade inflation, an inability to deal informally with other government agencies and nongovernmental organizations, and the endless shuffling of papers to little effect.
As a former diplomat, I know that people join the State Department to perform fulfilling work in the service of their country, not to make their fortunes. But unless the department's hidebound management addresses its glaring problems, it will increasingly lose those who are best able to carry out our foreign policy.
 
GREGG MORROW
Tiverton, R.I., Sept. 5, 2000

HEADLINE: The Town That Prosperity Forgot;
Blighted, Broke and Crime-Ridden, Irvington Seems Helpless to Help Itself

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: IRVINGTON, N.J., Sept. 6

 BODY:
Like many of those who live in this fraying suburb of Newark, Margaret Jackson moved her family here two decades ago to escape the lawlessness, decay and despair then spreading through the city that nearly surrounds it. With its no-nonsense police force and racially mixed neighborhoods, Irvington beckoned middle-class Newark residents with the promise of safe, suburban-style living.
"What a beautiful, beautiful neighborhood this was," Mrs. Jackson, a secretary, recalled as she stood in front of her house on 21st Street, just over the border from Newark. "We had all kinds of people living here: whites, blacks, Puerto Ricans. I thought it was a solid investment." 
 As she spoke one recent evening, Mrs. Jackson took in a Dresdenesque landscape of fire-blackened homes, collapsing front porches and trash-filled lots. Mrs. Jackson's house, sandwiched between two crumbling ruins, is the only occupied building on her side of the block.
"If I could sell this place, I'd be gone in a heartbeat," she said. "But who's going to want to live here?"
These days, not many. Irvington, a township of 59,000 people, has lost a tenth of its population since 1980 and 15 percent of its housing stock. In an era of long-running prosperity, when even Newark can crow about revival, Irvington remains a stubborn pocket of dread and instability.
A shrinking tax base and years of fiscal mismanagement have left the township insolvent, and it has been declared a "distressed city" by the state, a status qualifying it for emergency aid. Property taxes are so high -- among the highest in the state -- that scores of homeowners are walking away from their investments. While crime continues to decline elsewhere, Irvington now has the state's second-highest violent crime rate per capita, behind the shore resort of Seaside Heights. Last year there were 15 homicides within Irvington's 2.8 square miles, up from 9 in 1998.
With a mixture of envy and disgust, Mrs. Jackson pointed out the new crop of town houses rising down the street in Newark while the stately homes on her block rotted or fell prey to fires inadvertently started by squatting drug addicts. "I can't even get the city to clean up this trash," she said, gesturing to a mound of clothing and bricks and a broken toilet bowl on the sidewalk. "It's deplorable and it's breaking my heart."
Many residents blame the mayor and Township Council members for Irvington's problems, saying that these officials are more interested in internecine warfare than in governing. Others point to the overwhelmed police force, which has been accused of ignoring the drug dealing and prostitution that flourishes in many neighborhoods. And some say that Irvington is simply suffering from the aging infrastructure, crime and public indifference that have ravaged so much of urban America.
With its mix of prewar apartment buildings and rows of tightly packed two-family houses, Irvington long ago lost its appeal to home buyers who craved spacious lawns and more privacy. "Irvington is typical of a class of old bedroom communities tied to the state's vanished manufacturing economy," said James W. Hughes, dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "Its housing stock has become outmoded and obsolete. It's not going to be an easy future."
Irvington may have been dealt a bad hand, but state officials partly blame the local government for making Irvington's problems worse. In the last year, federal authorities have begun two investigations: one examining the Police Department's exclusive contract with a local towing company and another into the Irvington Board of Education, which has been mired in a case involving bribery charges against Kenneth A. Gibson, an engineering consultant who is a former mayor of Newark.
"I wish I could say things are looking up, but things are getting worse," said David Lyons, a member of the Township Council who is frequently at odds with his colleagues.
In what the state calls a typically bungled opportunity, the township removed its parking meters and did not replace them until more than three years later, depriving municipal coffers of nearly $1 million. Last year, $22 million of the township's $73 million budget came from Trenton, which is monitoring its finances. The mayor of Irvington, Sara B. Bost, who was first elected in 1994, did not respond to numerous telephone messages left at her office.
Irvington began its most precipitous decline after 1996, when the state forced it to reassess its property values, leading to a 30 percent tax increase. The higher taxes have been driving many working-class homeowners into foreclosure. These days the tax collection rate is less than 86 percent, a situation that makes taxes even higher for those who do pay.
The township, which is a month late with its state-mandated financial statement, has been without a business administrator and a financial officer since last spring.
"We have some very deep and ongoing concerns for Irvington," said Ulrich H. Steinberg Jr., director of the State Division of Local Government Services. "They need to step up their management and provide direction for recovery. Until now, they haven't been able to do that."
Real estate brokers complain of taxes so high -- an average of $4,000 a year for a single-family house -- that many prospective buyers will not even look at Irvington, despite its affordable housing and proximity to New York City and major highways.
"The drug situation gets worse day by day, the taxes are ridiculous and the services are nonexistent," said Arthur Rosa, president of Rosa Realty, which has several offices in and around Newark. "I've never seen a town deteriorate so quickly."
Still, officials say there are reasons for optimism. On a recent tour of Springfield Avenue, the township's main commercial strip, Janet Nunez, coordinator of an urban enterprise program, pointed out new trash cans, hanging flower baskets and a string of refurbished facades.
"As soon as there's a vacancy here, the space gets snapped up," she said, adding that the township's industrial zone is drawing new businesses. In the last four years, she said, 360 full-time jobs have been created in Irvington. "Things are really looking up," she said. "Right now we need to overcome the negative press."
But well-swept sidewalks and hanging geraniums cannot offset the sight of the empty police booth that sits at the center of town. Although the enterprise program spent $16,000 building the booth last year, the Police Department cannot afford to station an officer in it.
The police chief, Steven Palamara, said response time by the police lagged because his force of 163 officers had a dozen fewer officers than it had three decades ago, when there were 8,000 annual service calls. Last year there were 80,000. The increasing workload, he said, leaves little time for old-fashioned patrolling. Low-priority calls, including those that involve drug dealing and prostitution, receive scant attention, Chief Palamara added. "It gets wild here at night," he said apologetically, explaining that the police are often kept busy responding to emergency calls.
Paradoxically, the improving fortunes of Newark, he said, have been bad for Irvington. With a much larger force, the Newark police have unintentionally pushed crime across the border, he said. "We're like a small town, except we have big-city problems and a small town's resources," Chief Palamara said. But help will arrive in December, he said, with the addition of 26 officers, their salaries paid with state money.
Record crime seems to be on everyone's mind. Last year, Mayor Bost's home in the East Ward was sprayed by gunfire. Although at first she said the attack was in retaliation for her get-tough stance on crime, investigators say it is now believed to be the result of random gunplay between rival drug dealers.
It is in the East Ward that Irvington's desperation is on full display. Uriel Burwell, 27, who grew up just across the border in Newark, said the changes in Irvington have been numbing. "Irvington was one of those towns you didn't want to get caught in after dark," he said. "The police would lock you up just for crossing the line."
Mr. Burwell, who runs Standing Together Against Neighborhood Decay, a group serving a neighborhood that straddles the Irvington-Newark border, said there were 500 abandoned buildings on the Irvington side, at least 150 of them in immediate need of demolition. "Every day," he said, "someone else walks away from their home."
His group is using government grants and low-interest loans to build 35 houses in Newark. Until things get better on the Irvington side, he said, he does not hold any hope for a revival there.
Across town, on a tree-lined, well-manicured block, Elouise McDaniel was driving down Nesbit Terrace in her West Ward neighborhood and pointing out what she called early signs of encroaching blight: a half-painted house, an overgrown front lawn, a "for sale" sign that had been up far too long.
"These people refuse to maintain their property," Mrs. McDaniel, a retired Newark schoolteacher, said with indignation. The landscape a few blocks east seemed to bear out her fears: Colonial-style houses sealed with plywood, uncollected trash, knots of young men loitering about and a collection of go-go bars. (Irvington, she said, has 13 of them.)
As she drove, Mrs. McDaniel shook her head and recalled a time not long ago when these streets resembled tidy Nesbit Terrace. She spends most days writing letters to elected officials, organizing community meetings and pestering neighbors to clean up their yards. Selling her brick-faced split-level home is out of the question: she knows it would fetch less than what she paid for it 25 years ago.
"I wish I could just pick up my house and move it someplace else," she said. "But I'm stuck. The only thing left to do is fight."

MANHATTAN: PARK SHOOTING REPORT INVESTIGATED -- Detectives are investigating a report by a man who said he was shot in the back while sitting on a bench in Central Park late Saturday night, the police said. The man, Troy Cupano, 33, of Somerset, N.J., arrived by cab at Mount Sinai Medical Center shortly before midnight Saturday. He had been shot once in the lower back with a small-caliber pistol, the police said. LAKE GEORGE: GASLIGHT VILLAGE GOES OUT -- One buyer paid $150 and ran away with the dish that ran away with the spoon. A Vermont couple paid $125,000 for a double-decker carousel made in Spain. In all, 430 pieces of nostalgia from the old Gaslight Village family amusement park here, including the dish lawn ornament and the carousel, sold for more than $1 million at an auction Saturday. Gaslight Village was opened in 1960 by Charles R. Wood in this lakeside resort 53 miles north of Albany. He closed it this year as part of a plan to build a civic center. (AP)
 
ALBANY: $750,000 FOR CONTAINER PORT -- Seeking to improve the local economy, Gov. George E. Pataki yesterday said the state would spend $750,000 to modify 2,000 feet of track this fall so barges from New York City can load shipping containers directly onto rail cars. Making Albany a barge-to-rail container port along the Hudson River would preserve 120 jobs and add 80 more by 2005, when the city could handle up to 24,000 containers annually, Mr. Pataki said. (AP)
 
ALBANY: FAMILY GROUP FAULTS AGENCY -- An advocacy group for poor families says the state is too quick to open and close investigations of child abuse. Two-thirds of the 145,500 abuse claims in 1998 were found to be unsubstantiated, while 40 percent of substantiated cases were closed the same day they were investigated, said the group, the State Communities Aid Association. The group called on the Child Protection Services division to develop a two-tiered response system, dispatching investigators to homes with potential for the most dangerous situations, and sending workers from social service agencies in other cases. Bill Van Slyke, a spokesman for the Office of Children and Family Services, which oversees Child Protection Services, said the agency was examining the group's findings. (AP)

Mr. Kennedy sold the 1977 Cessna Skylane in May 1999, two months before crashing a more advanced Piper Saratoga off Martha's Vineyard. HEADLINE: Documents Portray Tire Debacle As a Story of Lost Opportunities

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Sept. 10

 BODY:
More than four years before Firestone gave the Ford Motor Company or federal regulators any hint of a problem with its tires for sport utility vehicles, the company's engineers had been alerted by the State of Arizona that the tires' treads tended to separate in hot weather.
More than two years before Firestone recalled the tires, its financial staff was aware of mounting warranty claims. Almost a year ago, most of Ford's management was told about deadly failures of Firestone tires on Ford Explorers overseas. 
 Yet little of this information appears to have made it into the hands of safety experts for Firestone or Ford. At the same time, personal injury lawyers across the United States were sharing information about dozens of deaths involving Ford Explorers equipped with Firestone tires -- but kept the information from federal regulators.
The story of the Firestone tire debacle, blamed for as many as 150 deaths around the world, is one of missed hints and lost opportunities, according to personal interviews and a review of more than 100 company and government documents, including many documents not previously reported.
Firestone and Ford officials each said they looked at routine measurements of safety problems -- warranty claims in Firestone's case, consumer complaints to regulators in Ford's -- and concluded that they did not have a problem. Yet each company had other data that, if checked, might have shown years ago that people were dying.
The tire debacle is also a story of questions that remain unresolved: Why do the tires fail? Why are all of the deaths in sport utility vehicles, mostly Ford Explorers, when some of the tires were installed on pickup trucks? Did Ford put customers' comfort, and the marketability of the vehicle, ahead of safety by choosing tires that would give a softer ride but might be more prone to failure?
Above all, why did Ford or Firestone not recognize sooner that while tire failures and rollovers were serious problems by themselves, the combination of the two would prove especially lethal? With another hearing in Congress scheduled on Tuesday -- and millions of recalled tires still on the road -- the pressure to find answers remains intense.
Early on, Firestone had more information about the extent of the problem than Ford, the documents showed, because it was Firestone's warranty that covered the tires. The tire maker, owned by Japan's Bridgestone Corporation, received more than 1,500 legal claims, many dating to at least 1997, for property damage, injuries and even some deaths resulting from failures among the 6.5 million tires now being recalled. It also had an increased number of requests from consumers to replace tires under warranty.
Yet in response to numerous inquiries from Ford beginning late in 1998, Firestone repeatedly gave the same answer that it and other tire makers had been giving plaintiffs' lawyers for years: Some tires inevitably fail, and the usual culprit is abuse by customers who do not inflate the tires properly or overload the vehicles.
Firestone's engineers took an unusual approach when they went to Venezuela to test suspect tires, according to a memorandum dated Aug. 9, 1999, by the company's manager of market quality engineering, identified as B. V. Halverson. "During the travel between cities, we drove at speeds up to 95 m.p.h. for extended periods of time," the memorandum said, one of dozens of documents coming out of an investigation led by Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana. No tires failed during the test, though government investigators in Venezuela have since attributed at least 46 deaths to crashes involving Firestone tires on Ford Explorers.
Firestone engineers occasionally checked tires in the field. But when Arizona complained in July 1996 that tires on state vehicles were losing treads in hot weather, Firestone blamed poor tire maintenance.
 Yoichiro Kaizaki, president of Bridgestone, acknowledged on Monday at a news conference in Tokyo that Bridgestone had not paid proper attention to quality control of its Firestone tires. He said the company would would begin applying the quality-control criteria used for its Bridgestone tires to Firestone tires.
 There had been dual standards within the company regarding problems with the two brands, he said. "The responsibility for the problem lies with Tokyo," he said.
The company relied heavily on its warranty information, which showed that while replacements under warranty increased in 1999 over 1998, the frequency of replacements remained fairly low. Firestone has insisted that its safety staff did not look at information on damage claims. Yet its financial staff was calculating that information annually, and even pinpointed by 1998 an increase in claims associated with the models now being recalled -- and particularly with tires from the Decatur, Ill., plant identified as having made the tires with the most problems.
By comparing the records of sales meetings with a confidential government report on Firestone tire production by serial code, it can be calculated that less than four-tenths of a percent of the recalled tires were replaced under warranty in 1998 and 1999. By a comparison, 17 percent of the tires were replaced under warranty in 1978 before Firestone's last major recall, of model 500 car tires. The earlier recall involved a similar number of tires, but fewer than half the 88 deaths under review in the investigation in the United States.
What Firestone appears to have missed is that sport utility vehicles require more reliable tires than cars, because they are more likely to roll over when they lose a tire, documents showed. The rollover issue goes virtually unmentioned in the Firestone documents, yet now the company cites it frequently, even noting that rollovers are an especially deadly kind of crash.
Federal regulations do not suggest that Firestone should have paid closer attention to sport utility tires. Sport utility vehicles have been regulated as light trucks since the late 1960's and face more lenient rules than cars.
A vehicle's ability to withstand crashes from the front, side and rear are regulated, because these are the main causes of deaths in cars. But a vehicle's tendency to roll over is not regulated by the government, though rollovers accounted for 62 percent of deaths in sport utility vehicles.
Federal regulators are now reviewing the rules covering tires and, after 27 years of studying the rollover issue, announced plans last spring to start rating a vehicle's tendency to roll over. Automakers and their allies in Congress are trying to block the ratings.
Among the documents distributed and then uncovered by Mr. Tauzin's investigators, the one that stands out as perhaps the most serious missed opportunity at Ford is a two-paragraph memorandum dated Sept. 15, 1999. Written by Carlos Mazzorin, Ford's group vice president for purchasing, it was addressed to Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive and president; Wayne Booker, vice chairman for international operations; and six vice presidents responsible for sales, manufacturing, quality control, vehicle engineering, Asian operations and public relations.
The memorandum described a problem with some Explorers in Saudi Arabia, Oman, Qatar and Venezuela. The tread sometimes separated from the rest of the tire when the vehicle was driven for long periods at high speeds, Mr. Mazzorin wrote. This had caused 19 rollovers and some deaths in the Middle East, where Ford had just recalled the tires, and an unspecified number of deaths in Venezuela.
But Mr. Mazzorin concluded with a statement that would prove wrong: "No known instances have occurred in other markets."
Two executives not on the memorandum's distribution list might have told Mr. Mazzorin that he was wrong, had they received the note and then checked records.
One was John M. Rintamaki, Ford's general counsel; the company had already been included in several lawsuits against Firestone. But Ford paid little attention, because automakers routinely face thousands of lawsuits after crashes.
Also missing from the distribution list was Helen O. Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for safety and environmental issues. Ford's safety engineers, who worked for Ms. Petrauskas, were aware of the rollover issue in sport utility vehicles.
Ford engineers had also paid attention to tires. In designing the Explorer, the engineers had rejected high-pressure tires like those on the rival Chevrolet Blazer -- which might have been less likely to lose their treads -- because they made the Explorer more likely to roll over. For the tires they did select, they recommended inflation pressures lower than for most other sport utility tires.
The New York Times reported on Friday that a computer analysis of federal data on fatal crashes showed that Explorers had a higher proportion of fatal crashes from tire problems than other sport utilities.
But memorandums indicated that as problems with Firestone tires surfaced overseas, Ford engineers, as did the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, looked mainly at other data: consumer complaints to the government agency's toll-free hotline. That data, it turns out, had a flaw: lawyers and their clients had virtually stopped reporting serious incidents with tires.
Lawyers suing tire makers had suffered a setback in February 1995, when regulators closed an investigation into Michelin tires despite 62 consumer complaints.
The safety agency decided that the tires were not defective and accepted Michelin's argument that consumers had overloaded or underinflated the tires -- the same argument that Firestone has made in fighting lawsuits over its tires now recalled. A ruling by a federal agency that a product is not defective usually makes lawsuits against the manufacturer more difficult.
Even as lawsuits against Firestone accumulated in the late 1990's, regulators received very few complaints from the public. Until they opened a preliminary inquiry on March 6, after a report on a Houston television station prompted several dozen complaints, there were no fatal incidents in their files.
Yet a tally released today by SafetyForum.com, a firm that coordinates lawsuits against auto and tire makers, found that lawyers had already sued Firestone, and sometimes Ford as well, in cases involving 22 deaths and 69 serious injuries by the end of 1998.
Ralph Hoar, the owner of SafetyForum.com, said lawyers had a responsibility to their clients, not regulators, and could not take the risk that if they did file enough complaints to prompt an investigation, regulators would rule that the Firestone tires were free from defects.
"The manufacturers use that as a sledgehammer in litigation," Mr. Hoar said.
A combination of problems appears to have made the Firestone tire failures especially deadly. But a combination of mistakes by everyone involved allowed the deadliness to go undetected for years.

HEADLINE: Low-Price, Highly Ambitious Digital Chip

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
Suddenly, the future of digital photography seems to be becoming much clearer.
Only two weeks ago, Eastman Kodak announced a chip able to capture digital images with a resolution of 4,096 by 4,096 picture elements -- or pixels -- per square inch. That, by some measures, is about twice the resolution of 35-millimeter film. 
 Today, a company founded by one of Silicon Valley's pioneer chip designers, will announce an image-sensing chip capable of the same resolution as the Kodak chip, but made using a technique that could be much less expensive.
Executives of the company, Foveon, said they had given a prototype camera based on their chip to a photographer in Los Angeles, Greg Gorman, who had used it to make a portrait of a cowboy. In that image, no pixels, or dots, were visible to the eye, even with the photograph blown up to a size of 8 feet by 4 feet.
Already, digital cameras being sold on the consumer market for less than $1,000 are rivaling 35-millimeter film cameras. Digital images of the clarity achieved with Foveon chip could begin to challenge even the much more expensive 4-by-5 film cameras made by companies like Hasselblad that are used by professional photographers for portraiture, advertising and fashion.
"We're headed to flat-out replace the film camera," said Carver Mead, the founder of Foveon, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif. Mr. Mead, a pioneer of the chip industry, became a Silicon Valley legend in the 1970's by helping develop techniques that for the first time enabled chip engineers to create circuits containing tens of thousands of transistors.
Industry analysts say that the new technologies could affect much more than still cameras. High-resolution images, if produced in quantities that made the new generation of image-sensing chips cost only several dollars apiece, could become a staple of cellular telephones and other hand-held devices and might bring the cost of a consumer video camera below $100.
And the contest is not only between film and digital sensors, but between two kinds of chip-making techniques. Foveon's planned announcement, coming on the heels of Kodak's, suggests a sharpening battle between the two competing manufacturing technologies at the heart of a billion-dollar market for digital photographic sensors.
The Foveon chip is based on a low-cost semiconductor industry technology known as Complementary Metal-Oxide Semiconductor, or CMOS (pronounced SEE-moss). The Kodak chip's sensor is based on a more expensive manufacturing technology known as Charged Coupled Device, or C.C.D. imaging.
C.C.D.'s now dominate the digital-imaging industry, but compared with CMOS devices, they require production and assembly of several chips and related components to combine the sensing and computing tasks that can be performed by a single CMOS chip.
Both companies' achievements have startled industry experts because the new devices move far beyond the current industry standards for CMOS and for C.C.D. cameras, which until now have been able to achieve resolutions of 6 million pixels a square inch. The Foveon and Kodak sensors can pack 16.8 million pixels into a square inch.
"If you asked someone if this was achievable in either technology two weeks ago, they would have said it was impossible," said Michael Berger, an industry analyst at Frost & Sullivan, a market research firm in San Antonio.
The Foveon announcement is seen as a personal triumph for Mr. Mead, 66, who is regarded by many executives and engineers as the father of the modern semiconductor industry.
"Carver has tapped into something enormous," said Alexis Gerard, president of Future Image Inc., a digital-imaging research and consulting firm in San Mateo, Calif. "When digital imaging and the telecommunications infrastructure converge, they will enable a shift from a text-based communication model to an image-based model."
Throughout his career Mr. Mead has explored the idea of duplicating the human senses, including vision and hearing, by using silicon-based chip technologies. Several years ago, his earlier work led to the development of a smaller and more effective hearing aid now sold by Sonic Innovations of Salt Lake City.
Complex chips first became feasible in the 1970's after Mr. Mead, at the time a professor at the California Institute of Technology, teamed up with a Xerox computer scientist named Lynn Conway to invent a technique for placing thousands of transistors on a chip -- a technique known as Very Large Scale Integrated Circuit, or VLSI design.
Today, CMOS-based manufacturing -- which is used to carry out VLSI design -- is employed by virtually all microprocessor and memory makers. As a result, it has become extremely cost-efficient and can yield circuitry with more transistors and lower power requirements than most competing technologies.
Yet despite their promise, CMOS-based sensors have until now had just a tiny impact on the overall market for digital imaging because they have been unable to achieve the resolution and clarity of C.C.D. sensors. The global market in 1999 for C.C.D. sensors was $959 million, compared with only $14.2 million for CMOS sensors, according to Frost & Sullivan.
But even before Foveon's latest achievement, CMOS was gaining ground. Not only have companies including Kodak and Polaroid begun to offer inexpensive, low-resolution CMOS-based cameras, but telecommunications giants like Nokia of Finland and NTT DoCoMo of Japan are planning to include inexpensive CMOS sensors in millions of their next-generation cellular phones.
Foveon's contribution has been to improve the quality of CMOS images by continuing to put more computer processing power behind the task of capturing the digital image. The new 16.8 million pixel device has seven active transistors for each pixel. The benefits include less interference, better focusing and more precise exposure times. "When the pixels get smarter," Mr. Mead said, "that translates into better image quality."
Foveon's principal investor and the company's technology partner is National Semiconductor, a big Silicon Valley chip maker.
 National Semiconductor's manufacturing plant in Santa Clara is capable of etching chip circuitry only 0.18 micron wide -- a microscopic fineness that few other chip makers can equal. By contrast, most current low-cost CMOS sensors are made with circuitry of 0.35 or 0.5 microns, which allows for millions fewer transistors per chip.
National Semiconductor executives said the company was planning to take the technology that Foveon had developed for the priciest reaches of the professional photography market and make it economical enough for some new consumer electronics.
"National's interest is not in thousands of cameras a year but in hundreds of millions of cameras a year," said Brian L. Halla, the company's president and chief executive. "We could make the world's highest-resolution throwaway digital camera and sell it for the price of a similar Kodak system."
Foveon officials said they would demonstrate the new 16.8 million pixel sensor for the first time today. The sensor, which for now captures images in black and white, has almost 70 million transistors -- or about two and a half times the number of transistors used by a Pentium III microprocessor chip for computers. Foveon says it expects the new sensor to be on the market within a year.
Currently, Foveon sells a high-end camera using an earlier version of its sensor that has a resolution of 2048 x 2048 pixels, or 4.19 million in all. That camera uses three separate sensors and a prism array to separate color information. But Mr. Halla said the company was also working on a technique that would permit a single chip to capture precise color information.
Despite the advances now being made, Mr. Mead acknowledged that digital-image sensors are still a long way from matching the skills of the human eye.
An eye is movable, which enables it to scan various parts of an image and then allow the brain to compose a single, larger image. The eye is also remarkably diverse: elements that have high resolution are clustered at the center of the field of vision, while sensing elements that function well at low light levels are around the periphery of the eye, giving human vision a great flexibility of range in varying light conditions that no artificial imaging system can yet match.
Mr. Mead said that because of fundamental size limits in the wavelengths of light, it is unlikely that future digital sensors will gain much additional resolution. Instead, shrinking semiconductor circuit sizes will make it possible for companies like Foveon to add more and more intelligence to their digital-imaging systems, perhaps simulating more of the image-enhancement functions of the human brain.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: September 14, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Monday about a new digital camera chip made by Foveon misstated the type of film cameras that it might be able to challenge. Images made from the chip could one day be comparable to those made by so-called medium-format cameras, made by Hasselblad and others, which use film that is 6 by 6 centimeters. The chip images are not comparable to those made from film that is 4 by 5 inches, which produces a higher resolution. Hasselblad does not make a 4-by-5 camera.

HEADLINE: Island Insect Trove Could Spur Revival of Mainland Populations

BYLINE: By CORNELIA DEAN 

DATELINE: EDGARTOWN, Mass., Sept. 6

 BODY:
Ask people on Martha's Vineyard about insects and they are likely to talk about mosquitoes, no-see-ums and green-headed flies, all of which can make life miserable here. But the island's insect population comprises far more than pests. In fact, entomologists hope to use it to re-establish rare and endangered insect populations wiped out elsewhere in New England years ago.
This year, beach tiger beetles, tiny ivory insects with brown markings, were gathered on a stretch of private beach here and transported to Monomoy Island National Wildlife Refuge at the elbow of Cape Cod, where entomologists hope they have taken hold. 
 Next on the entomologists' list is the imperial moth, a yellow and brown insect once abundant throughout New England that was all but wiped out by DDT. Entomologists are studying it now, hoping to determine the best places to reintroduce it. After that, the scientists hope the Vineyard will provide still more moth species to repopulate their ancient New England habitats.
In all cases, said Tim Simmons, restoration ecologist for the Massachusetts Natural Heritage and Endangered Species Program, the idea is to identify past insect habitats that remain protected enough to enable transplants to survive.
The beach tiger beetle, only half an inch long but prized by collectors for its delicate spots and stripes and bright green abdomen, was eradicated from almost all of its New England range when four-wheel-drive vehicles began taking to the region's beaches. The beetle lays its eggs on the beach, and its larvae live in tubes the beetles dig in the sand -- no match for all-terrain vehicles.
Originally, entomologists planned to reintroduce the beetle to Monomoy last year, by digging larvae and transplanting them to beaches there. But when they went collecting, they discovered that the beetle's volatile population had declined, for reasons still uncertain. This year, the numbers were better, so the project went ahead.
Dr. Paul Goldstein, a biologist at the Field Museum in Chicago who is studying the state of Vineyard lepidoptera this summer along with ecologists at the Sheriff's Meadow Foundation, a major Vineyard conservation organization, said the work on the beetle was conducted by Dr. Phil Nothnagle, an entomologist who is an authority on it.
"He excavated about two dozen larvae, which is small for an insect population, but that's all we were comfortable taking," Dr. Goldstein said. He added: "Past experience shows introducing adults doesn't work. Either they don't find each other or they don't lay eggs."
Though it is too soon to say the effort is a success, Mr. Simmons said in a telephone interview that five adult beetles had already been spotted on Monomoy.
Widespread spraying of DDT did in the imperial moth, Mr. Simmons said. The moth, whose tan-spotted yellow wings stretch more than three inches, once ranged from Canada to Argentina, but now the only place in New England where it survives is Martha's Vineyard.
That the moth survives there is partly a legacy of the late Henry Beetle Hough, the longtime editor of The Vineyard Gazette and an ardent opponent of the use of insecticides, which he habitually referred to in editorials as "poison."
"The continued widespread use of poisons, particularly through aerial spraying, will lead to results that cannot be foreseen -- except that life, the indivisible wellspring of all life on earth, will never be the same again," Mr. Hough editorialized in 1958.
At his urging, residents of the island banded together to block widespread spraying, particularly of DDT. A few thousand Vineyard acres were sprayed, but only once, while elsewhere in New England hundreds of thousands of acres were routinely subjected to a fog of DDT and kerosene. As a result, species survive here that have vanished elsewhere in the Northeast, experts say.
Among them are the imperial moth and other moths that live in highly specialized habitats, like depressions called frost bottoms, that are also rare everywhere but the Vineyard.
Frost bottoms are a geological reminder of how Martha's Vineyard was formed more than 12,000 years ago as glaciers moved across New England, pushing rocks and soil before them. When they began to retreat, they left this material piled up in moraines, which gradually eroded and washed out to form sand plains. Much of Martha's Vineyard is formed of such sand plains. Glacial meltwater carved out the frost bottoms as it streamed south from moraines toward the sea.
Though frost bottoms may be only 20 or 30 feet lower than the surrounding landscape, Dr. Goldstein said, they can be much warmer during the day and colder at night; some can experience frost year-round.
Because few glacial outwash plains survive elsewhere, Martha's Vineyard's frost bottoms are extremely unusual.
The Vineyard is not the only source of endangered insects for repopulation efforts. For example, entomologists are using a small population of burying beetles on Block Island, R.I., in efforts to re-establish the species, whose range was once from Maine to Texas.
Dr. Goldstein concedes that the insects he and others are eager to re-establish probably have little economic importance, although, as with most endangered species, it is always possible that one or another will turn out to be a valuable source of drugs or other useful compounds. But as conservation becomes more sophisticated, he said, more attention is being paid to restoring as many of a conservation area's original inhabitants as possible.
Mr. Simmons put it almost the same way, speaking of the beach tiger beetle. "We suspect there are very few people who have ever experienced a wild beach that has all of its denizens," he said. "It's sort of a symbol of what's supposed to be."

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
AUSTRIA: SANCTIONS DECISION DUE
A decision on whether European Union partners will lift diplomatic sanctions against Austria is expected soon, according to France's European affairs minister, Pierre Moscovici. A European Commission panel said last week that continuing the sanctions would be counterproductive. Suzanne Daley (NYT) 

GERMANY: KOHL BACK TO POLITICS
After a 10-month absence, former Chancellor Helmut Kohl returned to a regular strategy session of his Christian Democratic Party's parliamentary group. Mr. Kohl, who retained his seat in Parliament after being ousted as chancellor in 1998, skipped all meetings after admitting last year that he had accepted illegal campaign donations. At the session in the Reichstag building, two colleagues began clapping when he appeared, but quickly stopped when no one joined in. Victor Homola (NYT)
 
SWITZERLAND: LAND MINE CAMPAIGN
The global campaign to ban land mines is urging governments to take steps to pressure or isolate countries that have yet to sign the 1997 treaty banning the devices. Campaigners have been urging NATO members to refuse to take part in military actions involving use of land mines, and so far France and the Netherlands have indicated a willingness to do so. Delegates from 138 countries that have signed the pact are meeting in Geneva. Elizabeth Olson (NYT)
 
TURKEY: I.M.F. PROTEST
Small groups of students protesting the policies of the International Monetary Fund were detained by the police in Istanbul and the southern city of Adana. At the urging of the I.M.F., Turkey has been taking tough measures to cut inflation, and the possibility of harsher steps arose over the weekend. About 50 protesters were stopped as they approached the American Consulate in Istanbul. Douglas Frantz (NYT)
 
GREECE: BID TO BAR LESBIANS
A mayor on Lesbos has asked a district court to bar entry to 100 British lesbians, saying their tour operator falsely advertised his town as "a paradise of gay love." Mayor Polydoras Abatzis said the operator had damaged the reputation of Eressos, the legendary birthplace of Sappho. A ruling is expected today. Anthee Carassava (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
PHILIPPINES: NEW ABDUCTIONS, RAPE REPORTS
Armed gunmen kidnapped three people from a Malaysian diving resort and took them to the southern Philippines, where Muslim rebels are holding 19 people, including an American, Jeffrey Schilling, 24. Meanwhile, one of the four European hostages freed last weekend said that some of the female hostages released earlier had been raped by the rebels. He said the male hostages were unable to defend them. (Agence France-Presse)
 
AFRICA
 
BURUNDI: TUTSI PARTY SIGNS PACT
One of four holdout Tutsi political parties signed a power-sharing pact with the Hutu majority, two days before the deadline for joining a peace plan intended to end the country's seven-year civil war. The Social Democratic Party, citing last-minute changes, refused to sign the accord on Aug. 28 in Arusha, Tanzania, in the presence of international leaders including President Clinton. (AP)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: HEALTH SPENDING
With elections expected by next spring, Prime Minister Jean Chretien offered to increase federal health spending transfers to provinces by 25 percent, or $15 billion, over the next five years. After heavy cuts in the late 1990's, Canadians now tell pollsters health care is their No. 1 concern. With a large surplus this year, Mr. Chretien would have a hard time winning an election without restoring funding to the national health system. James Brooke (NYT)
 
CANADA: RIGHTIST GAINS SEEN
The leaders of Canada's two right-wing parties faced voters in special elections expected to strengthen the voice of conservatives when Parliament reconvenes on Sept. 18. Stockwell Day, leader of the Canadian Alliance, is expected to win easily in British Columbia. Joe Clark, the Tories' leader, is also expected to win in Nova Scotia. James Brooke (NYT)
 
BARBADOS: STEMMING AIDS
Faced with the highest incidence of AIDS and H.I.V. infection outside sub-Saharan Africa, members of the Caribbean Community are meeting in Barbados for two days to try to develop a regional response to the disease. While Haiti and the Dominican Republic account for 85 percent of the H.I.V. and AIDS cases in the Caribbean, the virus is spreading in other countries. David Gonzalez (NYT)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: PROTESTERS JAILED
A court sentenced 24 people to prison terms of up to five years for their role in two days of rioting that erupted after elections in February, the official news agency said. The 24 were held in Khalkhal after the conservative Guardians Council annulled the results of the northwest town's vote, taking away the seat from the winning pro-reform candidate and gaving it to his conservative opponent. (Agence France-Presse)
