HEADLINE: In Akron, the Talk Is About Treads

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, Sept. 12

 BODY:
When the International Tire Exhibition and Conference opened here today, more than 2,500 people gathered in small meeting rooms to listen to scientists deliver papers on "Metallic Coagents for Bonding Rubber to Metal and Synthetic Fibers" or "Tire Shearography."
But try as they might to focus on such topics, they could not help talking about the Firestone controversy. 
 Though scientists and industry officials are gathering for this three-day conference to deliver papers that deal with tire failures and tread separation, which is at the heart of the huge recall, few will speculate about what went wrong.
Several participants said they were legally advised not to speak about Bridgestone/Firestone and even to delete the term "tread separation" from presentations.
Others said they had noticed a growing interest in X-ray and laser equipment that might be used to detect problems.
Several executives said tire makers use such equipment in plants only sporadically because it is too expensive to test every tire. But that may be changing, they said.
"The truck industry X-rays 100 percent of their tires, but the margins aren't in passenger tires to be able to X-ray each one," said Ted Neuhaus, a tire consultant at Laser Technology Inc. in Norristown, Pa. "Now, though, the fear is that if it happened to one company, it could also happen to others."
Conference organizers held a news briefing this afternoon calling for the creation of a commission made up of government and industry officials to gather information about tire safety.
Robert Simmons, publisher of Rubber and Plastics News, which organized the conference with its parent company, Crain Communications, said that creating such a commission would avoid greater government regulation.
"My concern is that if the tire industry does not take quick, responsible action, someone else will do it for us," Mr. Simmons said.
Many here said the Firestone brand name had been irreparably damaged.
"People are talking about sooner or later this name will disappear," said John Choi, who sells tire-making machinery in Korea. "People don't want tires made by Firestone."
Others suggested that the problem could be poor maintenance of the tires and the discrepancy between the inflation levels recommended by Firestone and Ford, which equipped its Explorers with the tires.
Many industry officials stressed how complicated the tire-making process was and how sophisticated tires had become.
In the exhibition hall, industry officials talked about how far the industry had come from the days when Charles Goodyear invented vulcanization, which helped transform Akron into the industry's birthplace.
"We have doubled the life of the tire and provided all-weather traction," a Goodyear Tire and Rubber spokesman told a television crew.
Many at the conference -- not naming names -- pointed the finger at automakers, which have pushed to keep tire prices low, and a public unwilling to pay top dollar.
"People here buy tires that are cheaper than sneakers and then drive 70 miles per hour on them," said Jorg Jetter, who was on duty at the exhibition booth of Jet Lasersysteme, which makes equipment for the industry.
Truck tires, many delegates said, are much more expensive and largely better made because of the liabilities associated with the industry.
Few, though, were willing to point too harshly at Firestone, at least publicly. Several meetings, after all, were held in the Harvey S. Firestone room, and the loudspeaker announced at noon that a complimentary luncheon was sponsored by Bridgestone/Firestone.
After delivering a paper on the bonding of steel cords to rubber -- the issue many investigators said might be the problem -- William J. van Ooij, a professor at the University of Cincinnati and an expert in rubber adhesion in tires, said he would not speculate about the cause of tread separation.
"It's theoretically possible, but I think it's highly unlikely that it was a design problem," he said. "I know Firestone, and it wouldn't be design."
Suresh Sethi, an executive at Modi, a tire equipment company in India, said that makers of autos and tires around the world were overly concerned about price and market share. Not enough thought had been given to safety, he said. "You buy a $30,000 vehicle," he said, "and what does the tire cost? The companies were trying to save $1 per tire because $1 per tire adds up to a lot. That is responsible for this."
Gunter Maass, an executive at Erhardt & Leimer, a tire equipment company in Germany, said the recall was about technology. He said this would not happen in Europe.
"As far as I understand, this is not the first time," he said, referring to a 1978 Firestone recall.

HEADLINE: The Latest Oil Shock

 BODY:
The high price of oil is both a testament to the current global economic boom and a threat to its continuation. The heartening news is that the oil-producing nations themselves seem to realize this, and are intent on trying to drive prices lower. Whether there is enough unused production capacity to accomplish this in the short run remains to be seen, but the political will to try is welcome.
Crude oil surged past the $35-a-barrel mark on Monday, its highest level in a decade. Protesters in Britain blockaded refineries, threatening to bring the nation to a standstill. They demanded that the government reduce fuel taxes. Images of panicked drivers seeking to hoard fuel before most service stations closed brought back painful memories of the 1970's oil crisis. 
 Prime Minister Tony Blair refused to follow the lead of the French government, which reduced its fuel taxes by 15 percent last week, but instead sought contingency powers to control the distribution of fuel. Largely because of high taxes, European consumers typically pay more than twice what Americans do to fill up their cars.
This week's rise in oil prices came despite a decision by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries over the weekend to increase output by 800,000 barrels a day, or 3 percent. The group's shaky credibility partly accounts for the market's skeptical reaction. Some of the cartel nations already produce more than their quota, and it is unclear how much additional oil will actually be pumped. The overheated global economy has left little production capacity underused outside of Saudi Arabia. As a result the OPEC president, Ali Rodriguez, who is also Venezuela's oil minister, warned yesterday that the world may be facing a severe energy crisis.
President Hugo Chavez of Venezuela, who will soon play host to a meeting of heads of state from the OPEC nations, has been aggressively pushing for a target price band between $22 and $28 a barrel. The idea is to have the cartel automatically adjust production when the price of crude oil moves above or below the band. Such a mechanism would require an unprecedented degree of coordination among OPEC members, and is not likely to work as smoothly as Mr. Chavez suggests. But it could help stem the volatility in oil pricing.
Inflation in the United States is showing signs of revival in response to higher oil prices, the one cloud in an otherwise rosy economic outlook. The promised increase in crude production from OPEC and an increase in global production capacity expected late this year may not be timely enough to alleviate what is expected to be a sharp rise in domestic heating oil prices this winter. President Clinton said yesterday the government would seek to counter rising heating costs.
The high crude oil prices seem all the more serious because the world enjoyed unusually low fuel prices for much of the past decade. But in real terms the price of oil is a third lower than it was in 1990, though that may prove of little comfort to European drivers forced to pay about $4 a gallon at the pump, or to those struggling developing nations that must import oil.
Predicting movements in oil prices is impossible, but there is reason to be hopeful the world is not confronting an oil crisis akin to that of the early 1970's. The industrialized world is less vulnerable to an oil shock, and retains some options to counter persistently high oil prices, at least temporarily. Europe could lower tax rates on fuel. America could draw oil from its strategic reserve. The best solution would be a steep increase in production by oil producers, especially Saudi Arabia.

HEADLINE: BANKING'S BIG DEAL: THE REACTION;
Real Estate Industry Gains Said to Eclipse Job Losses

BYLINE: By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
A union between Chase Manhattan and J. P. Morgan & Company would probably mean the elimination of only a few jobs and free much-needed real estate space, people in the industry say.
The deal ending the independence of J. P. Morgan, a storied New York firm that has built a strong reputation as an investment bank, would also probably mean the elimination of some jobs that are deemed to be duplicated after the merger. 
 But, according to government officials in New York who had limited knowledge of the plans, the impact would be minimal, and the acquisition was likely to have a positive impact on New York's already tight real estate market.
"Most of the consolidation will be at the higher levels and that banking talent will be redeployed because those people are quite resilient and skilled," said Mitchell Moss, a business professor at New York University, said, echoing the sentiments government officials. "And it will be very good for the New York real estate market, because it will open up space in a very tight market."
Government officials said that they were publicly taking a wait-and-see approach to the mergers of the two New York companies. But, privately, they said it would help strengthen the financial services industry in New York.
Mr. Moss said that the two companies have "complementary strengths" that will help a new company at a time when "the financial services industry is increasingly one that is becoming more integrated" and the lines between "investment banks, retail banks and other banks" were slowly being eliminated.
Mr. Moss added that in the end New York would "benefit from being the home of the merged banks."
The overall impacts of any acquisition on the economy, job market and the real estate industry are still unclear, but local leaders seem to be taking a positive attitude.
Carl Weisbrod, the president of the Downtown Alliance of New York, a group that represents businesses in the Wall Street area, said that the strength of a combined bank would help Manhattan solidify its international dominance in the financial services industry.
"Consolidation in today's economic climate does not have as much of an impact as it would have several years ago," Mr. Weisbrod said. "In a way, anything that is going to strengthen New York's role as the financial capital of the world is going to be encouraged, especially in this era of globalization."
Mr. Weisbrod said that the areas of Manhattan where both companies have their offices are in dire need of available commercial real estate and that any job loses would be offset quickly in this market.
"In the early 1980's, the consolidation of commercial banking did have an impact on occupancy rates on commercial real estate space and did contribute to the depression on Wall Street," he said. "But Lower Manhattan's economy is going extremely well, people can find jobs, the growth of Silicon Alley has really diversified things."
Mr. Moss, the New York University business professor, said that while some may worry about losing their jobs, few will be in a position to have to truly worry about finding employment. "The important thing is that no matter what happens in any merger, New York is going to be the home of one of the largest banks in the world," Mr. Moss said. "There will be a stronger, better bank in New York, as opposed to having two weaker ones."

HEADLINE: Europe Lifts Sanctions on Austria, but Vows Vigilance

BYLINE: By SUZANNE DALEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Sept. 12

 BODY:
The European Union lifted its sanctions against Austria today, seven months after hurriedly imposing a diplomatic freeze on Vienna for bringing a rightist party into its governing coalition.
But the Europeans said they remained deeply concerned about the Freedom Party's role in the government and vowed to maintain a "particular vigilance." 
 The lifting of the sanctions came four days after a panel of experts issued a report on human rights and political life in Austria. The report recommended an end to the sanctions, which had increasingly become an embarrassment to the European Union.
Austrian officials quickly welcomed the news.
"This is a great success for Austria resulting from our patience and firmness," Austria's chancellor, Wolfgang Schussel, said on national television soon after the sanctions were lifted.
Mr. Schussel said there had been efforts behind the scenes to suspend the measures rather than lift them and to keep them in place for a longer time or to set up a monitoring mechanism. Ultimately, all those efforts were dropped.
Although the sanctions were adopted unanimously by Austria's 14 European Union partners, enthusiasm for them waned quickly as they threatened to strengthen opposition to the group and to a common European currency, particularly in a crucial referendum on the euro in Denmark this month.
The sanctions -- which included a boycott of cultural exchange programs and military exercises -- did not amount to much more than a crimp in the social life of Austria's ambassadors. But critics said the sanctions went too far: they represented an unparalleled intrusion into the internal affairs of a member country and they infuriated the Austrians.
Predictions that the boycott would affect tourism or the Austrian economy never came to pass. But early on the sanctions did cause some awkward diplomatic moments as various officials did their best to avoid their Austrian counterparts. At a summit meeting of the European Union in Portugal, for instance, the usual group picture was done away with because various leaders, including France's president, Jacques Chirac, did not want to be seen standing next to Mr. Schussel.
In Washington today, a State Department official said that the United States was examining the European Union report but would maintain the modest diplomatic sanctions that it imposed in February to "limit" contacts with Austrian officials.
"Our policy has not changed," the official said. "We remain concerned about the Freedom Party's participation in the Austrian government."
 Canada followed the Europeans' lead, lifting its sanctions against Austria on the ground that it no longer feared Vienna would adopt policies that infringed on human rights, Reuters reported.
Throughout the weekend it seemed clear that many European Union members were eager for the sanctions to be lifted immediately. But France, which had led the move to impose the freeze and which now holds the group's rotating presidency, refused to be rushed. Its officials hinted that a monitoring system was still needed.
France, however, was apparently forced to settle for the vague promise of "vigilance."
In lifting the sanctions, the 14 members issued a joint statement in Paris this evening. "The measures taken by the 14 were useful," the statement said. "They can now be lifted." But the statement added: "The nature of the Freedom Party and its uncertain evolution remains cause for serious worry. The 14 consider that a particular vigilance should be exercised with regard to this party and the influence it exerts on the government it is a part of."
At the sanctions continued month after month, it became clear that some of the smaller European member countries felt threatened by what was happening to Austria. In Denmark, for instance, some experts believe that lifting the sanctions can help make sure that Danes vote to adopt the euro when the issue goes to a referendum on Sept. 28. Even before the joint statement was issued this evening, Danish officials were promising that the sanctions would be gone by the end of the day.
By the begining of summer, signs of a thaw were already apparent. On Bastille Day, the Austrian ambassador was among the dignitaries sharing a reviewing stand with Mr. Chirac. The Belgians extended a similar invitation to their Austrian ambassador. Meanwhile, European Commission officials, trying to build a face-saving way to wriggle out of the sanctions, appointed a three-member panel to assess human rights and political life in Austria before making a recommendation on lifting the freeze.
The report, issued last Friday, found that the sanctions had served a useful purpose by focusing attention on common values in the European Union and increasing the Austrian government's self-awareness. But the report said that prolonging the sanctions would be counterproductive by creating ill will from Austrians.
The three experts -- Prof. Jochen Frowein, the director of the Max Planck Institure in Germany; Martti Ahtisaari, the former president of Finland, and Marcelino Oreja, a former Spanish government minister -- also gave the Schussel government high marks for taking concrete steps to fight racism, xenophobia and anti-Semitism.
But they called the Freedom Party, which was led by the controversial Jorg Haider until he stepped aside in February, "a right-wing populist party with radical elements." Some of its members continued to use xenophobic, even racist, language and were not reproached in any way, they said.
Mr. Haider's party became part of the current Austrian government when Chancellor Schussel and his People's Party decided that a coalition was the only way to end months of a political stalemate after the October elections.
Since the sanctions were imposed, Mr. Haider has several times lashed out at Mr. Chirac. This weekend, he stepped up his attacks, calling Mr. Chirac "a pocket-sized Napoleon" who had just met his "Waterloo."
Mr. Chirac has not spoken on the issue, though other French officials have scoffed at the remarks.
"Whatever decision is made by the 14, it is not a question of giving absolution" to the Freedom Party, said the French minister for European affairs, Pierre Moscovi, on Monday. "I don't see how the party can be exonerated."
In their statement today, the 14 European Union members also noted that the panel of experts had recommended that they develop a mechanism within the group to monitor and evaluate the commitment and performance of individual member countries with respect to "common European values." And the members said they would continue to study how best to monitor, analyze and act in similar situations in the furure.

HEADLINE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL;
Knight Defends Himself; Indiana Names Coach

BYLINE: By STEVE POPPER 

 BODY:
Indiana University tried to look to the future yesterday, naming Mike Davis as the interim head basketball coach of the Hoosiers.
While Davis accepted his ascension from assistant to Bob Knight to successor to the controversial coach, it was clear from the remarks at Davis's news conference and from a nationally televised interview with Knight, that it will take a while to chip away at the Knight legacy in Bloomington. 
 Knight, who was fired on Sunday after 28 years as head coach at Indiana, spoke on ESPN last night, defending his behavior at the school, particularly since the administration put him on "zero tolerance" notice on May 15, and admitting that he had overstayed his welcome.
"I thought I would stay here and coach until I was done coaching, which I'm certainly not now," Knight said during the ESPN interview. "I'm not done coaching. But in recent years things have changed, the administration changed, the athletic department changed. For some people that may be good. For me, it wasn't.
"As recently as July I gave serious consideration to another job, and have in the last couple of years. I don't think that my thinking about another job quite overrode the feeling that I had for Indiana University and the kids we had here, the kids we had coming, what we had built. I wanted more than anything to see us get back. We've never been mediocre. always been really good or pretty good. I wanted to see us get back to really good. I kind of hung onto that thought for four or five years.
Knight added: "Probably I should have gone somewhere else. There's someone who's a better fit for these people and administration as a basketball coach. And there would be a place somewhere that's a better fit for me as a basketball coach than Indiana is right now."
He said he was not embarrassed to leave Indiana the way he did.
"Not at all," Knight insisted. "What I am is proud, proud of what our basketball program turned out."
Knight denied committing any of the violations that were detailed on Sunday by the university's president, Myles Brand.
And he said he would definitely coach somewhere else.
"I spent all summer with an offensive set in my mind while I'm fishing or traveling, thinking who's going to be here or there," he said. "Now I won't be able to do that with these kids. But I'm looking for kids that I can do it with. I haven't retired. I'm an unemployed teacher now, looking for a place to teach. There are too many things I have yet to explore about game of basketball."
He said he had already received calls inquiring about his interest.
Davis, who was an assistant to Knight for three seasons, serving as the lead recruiter for this year's prize class and the man who recruited most of the players he inherits, now steps into the spotlight.
While Knight no longer holds the entire state of Indiana in sway as he once did, he still had enough stature to prompt protests on campus and a threatened walkout by nearly the entire team if Davis were not named as coach.
But Davis, 39, who played at Alabama, then professionally in Europe and in the Continental Basketball Association, was named as interim head coach while another assistant, John Treloar, was named as interim associate head coach. The team stood behind Davis on the podium and expressed satisfaction.
"Coach Knight is the reason I'm here, but Indiana basketball is bigger than anyone," Davis said. "The players stood up for Coach Treloar and myself. I discussed the situation with their parents, and my son yesterday when I was leaving said, 'I hope you get the job.' I've gone to these kids homes and recruited them, convinced them to come here. They stood up for me, so there's no way I could turn it down."
"We definitely have something to prove," said the junior Dane Fife, who just one day earlier said he had already decided to leave. "We've been through a lot, and we have to come out and beat people."
Speaking of Knight, Fife said: "We owe it to him. This is his team. We're ready to go."
Davis said: "I don't think there was pressure from the players. For Mike Davis to be head coach at Indiana University is a miracle. If it wasn't September, this program could go out and get a big-time coach."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATIC RUNNING MATES;
Best Crowd-Pleaser For Gore Is Lieberman

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, Sept. 12

 BODY:
Before Vice President Al Gore set foot on the stage this afternoon in front of a raucous crowd of 2,000 supporters at Cincinnati State Technical and Community College, there came The Testimonial.
"Al Gore has been a friend of mine for almost 15 years, and he's a man of family and faith," Senator Joseph I. Lieberman told the already enthusiastic audience. "Al Gore is a man of courage." 
 This scene has quickly become a chestnut for the Democrats' national ticket, repeated with slight variations from city to city and very likely to be heard again Wednesday when the two men travel to Boston. More than any other presidential and vice-presidential nominee in recent memory -- with the possible exception of Mr. Gore and President Clinton in 1992 -- Mr. Gore and Mr. Lieberman have made a habit of appearing in tandem.
The practice defies the conventional wisdom that running mates should split up to cover as many electoral bases as possible. But campaign officials say it will continue through November, reflecting the benefits they believe Mr. Lieberman has brought to the ticket, benefits that Gore aides concede have exceeded their hopes.
The Democrats see tactical advantages in joint campaigning, but the most compelling factor may be the one Gore aides are least comfortable addressing openly: It is clear, they agree, that Mr. Lieberman loosens up the famously stiff vice president, making him a more effective candidate.
"They're good friends, and campaigning is a stressful experience that's easier when it's shared with someone," said Tad Devine, a senior strategist for Mr. Gore.
Donna Brazile, Mr. Gore's campaign manager, said, "They just enjoy each other. You may even see some foursomes out there, with the spouses."
His aides say that Mr. Gore may not be adept at whipping up a crowd, but that he performs best before groups that are already enthusiastic. Mr. Lieberman, they say, effectively gets audiences ready for the vice president.
Mr. Lieberman's easy manner and constant joking leaven Mr. Gore's tendency toward seriousness, and the vice president, like others on the campaign, has not escaped his teasing. At a recent forum in Portland, Ore., Mr. Gore, noting that his wife, Tipper, had a master's degree in psychology, said that in recent years, "Her psychology practice is almost entirely devoted to me."
"For which she is not adequately reimbursed, I might add," Mr. Lieberman interjected.
Today, the candidates rolled through Ohio aboard a pair of yellow school buses to highlight their plans for improving education in this critical swing state. They made no new proposals, choosing instead to re-emphasize long-held positions on reducing class sizes, increasing testing of both students and teachers, expanding the federal Head Start program to provide preschool for 4-year-olds and some 3-year-olds, and offering tax credits for college tuition.
The day was largely dedicated to stagecraft, as the candidates took questions from students at Anna K. Wantz Middle School in Miamisburg, basked in the adulation of cheerleaders and band members in the gymnasium at Middletown High School and spoke at a rally here. They were followed by the campaign's own camera crew, filming them together for possible use in future television ads.
"Even to those of us out here watching on TV, it's been striking how much they've campaigned together," said Theodore J. Lowi, a professor of political science at Cornell University.
Since the Democratic convention last month, Mr. Lieberman has made campaign appearances on 19 days. On 12 of those days, including the four-day boat tour he and Mr. Gore took down the Mississippi River, he has made at least one appearance with the vice president, and often two or three a day.
By contrast, in the same period, Dick Cheney, the Republican vice presidential nominee, has campaigned with Gov. George W. Bush on four days.
"A lot of people still have this feeling that Gore isn't quite sincere, that he's too serious, he's too cautious" Mr. Lowi said. "Lieberman brings that Hubert Humphrey-like joy to the experience of campaigning, and he sounds like he really believes what he's saying.
"And he's a living reminder to people that Gore can make a very bold, very well-received move," Mr. Lowi said. "That is, picking Lieberman."
Mr. Lieberman is best known for criticizing Mr. Clinton's private behavior, for opposing vulgarity and violence in popular entertainment, and for talking frequently about his own Jewish faith. Mr. Gore's aides have made no secret that it was his reputation as a morally upstanding man, as much as anything else, that appealed to the vice president, whose own image has been sullied somewhat by questions about improper fund-raising in the 1996 campaign.
"He can talk about Gore as a first-hand witness and credential him as a person and as a leader in a very credible way," Mr. Devine said.
Mr. Lieberman's main role in their joint appearances has been to introduce the vice president with boasts about his accomplishments. And he is performing an important service for a presidential candidate whose own bragging -- like his claim to having a hand in creating the Internet -- has sometimes been clumsy and, however accurate, widely mocked. Mr. Lieberman reminds audiences that Mr. Gore volunteered for service in Vietnam, that he supported an overhaul of welfare, that he voted for United States entry into the Persian Gulf war, and that he helped preside over a booming economy.
"I don't think anybody who is fair would disagree with this comment," Mr. Lieberman said today, "that Al Gore has been the most effective and successful vice president in the history of the United States of America."

HEADLINE: BANKING'S BIG DEAL: THE TRADITION;
Storied Bank Failed to Move With Times

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Nearly a century ago, the House of Morgan and its founder, J. Pierpont Morgan, preserved the American financial system in the midst of a widespread panic.
But despite the best efforts of the bank that bears J. P. Morgan's name, in recent years it could not preserve itself. 
 Over the last 20 years J. P. Morgan has undergone a remarkable renovation, infusing what had become a sleepy bank devoted simply to lending money to big governments and corporations with the pioneering spirit of the House of Morgan. Morgan was the first modern American commercial bank to break out of the restrictions imposed on banking in the 1930's during the Depression, becoming a contender on Wall Street by underwriting stock offerings and advising on gigantic mergers.
But as much as the company strained to reclaim its former glory, it was not able to find a comfortable position in the modern financial world. So Morgan put itself on the block, talking with a number of banks around the world before reaching a deal to be acquired by the Chase Manhattan Bank for about $31 billion.
In the end, analysts said, Morgan's downfall may be that it tried too hard to remain what its founder had built -- a behind-the-scenes adviser to the richest and most powerful, with a driven but insular culture. It shied away from the wave of banking mergers so prevalent in recent years. And Morgan found it had become an anachronism in a financial world dominated by mass rather than class.
"Nobody like them is succeeding," said Alden Toevs, an executive vice president of the First Manhattan Consulting Group. "The companies they are competing with are just much bigger in terms of capital and product lines."
Morgan is not alone. In just the last two months, two other midsize Wall Street firms -- Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and PaineWebber -- also agreed to be bought, both by huge diversified Swiss banks.
Paradoxically, J. P. Morgan is giving up its independence only a year after its biggest regulatory burden -- the Glass-Steagall Act -- was lifted. Passed in 1933, the law separated commercial and investment banking and forced the Morgan Stanley brokerage firm to be split from J. P. Morgan.
Through the 1970's, the Morgan bank was content to lend money to big governments and corporations and to manage the assets of the heirs to the fortunes of the turn-of-the-century robber barons and other wealthy individuals. But as its big corporate borrowers were able to raise money directly by issuing stocks and bonds, the company realized its traditional business was wasting away.
Given the choice of changing its clients or changing its products, declared its former chairman, Lewis Preston, in the 1980's, J. P. Morgan should offer its existing clients the ability to trade securities and agree to underwrite their financial offerings. This set in motion a 20-year game of cat and mouse with Congress and the banking regulators as Morgan found more and more regulatory loopholes that allowed it to act more and more like a brokerage firm. Indeed, when Congress finally repealed Glass-Steagall last year, Morgan had already become much more like its old partner, Morgan Stanley, than a traditional commercial bank.
But repeal freed Morgan's competitors to go after its business, even as it accelerated the mergers among its rivals. Morgan executives, in the bank's exhaustively deliberate style, studied and stewed over myriad possible combinations, but never were willing to dilute what they saw as the company's unique culture and heritage.
"This was the last bank on Wall Street that wanted to surrender its independence, and in retrospect this proved to be a real handicap," said Ron Chernow, the author of "The House of Morgan," the definitive history of the bank. "The other commercial banks weren't hampered by a sense of tradition and were able to grow at greater speed."
Ten years ago, Mr. Chernow noted, Morgan had the highest stock market value of any bank in the country. Now its value is one-tenth of the biggest, Citigroup.
The financial world is increasingly dominated by two kinds of institutions. On one side are investment banking powerhouses -- Goldman Sachs, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Merrill Lynch, perhaps Credit Suisse and Deutsche Bank -- that manage the raising of capital, brokering of mergers and trading of anything with a price. Competition in this business is so intense that even successful second-tier players are choosing to sell to larger rivals.
The second sort of giant that has evolved out of the commercial banks are financial conglomerates that sell all manner of investments, loans, deposits and insurance. The archetype of this company is now Citigroup, which incorporates Morgan's longtime rival Citibank, along with the Salomon Brothers and Smith Barney brokerage firms and the Travelers Insurance company. And the corporate ancestor of the entire conglomerate is the antithesis of everything Morgan: the Commercial Credit Corporation, which began by lending money to lower-income people before it was transformed into a global leader by the driven deal making of its leader, Sanford I. Weill.
While Morgan has managed to crack the the top 10 in annual score cards of underwriting and advisory deals, it has never been able to climb to the very top where the bulk of the profits are earned.
Morgan in some ways was trapped by its earlier success doing business with tycoons and Fortune 500 companies, Mr. Chernow said, and could not take advantage of the burgeoning markets managing the money of main street America.
"They felt their competitive advantage was to trade on the romanticism and illustrious tradition that no one could match," Mr. Chernow said. "But when the entire world of Wall Street was going down market, they felt that by lessening their standards they would water down their mystique."
Similarly, Morgan's focus on the very largest corporate customers left it with little involvement in the most dynamic sector of the economy recently, small technology companies.
In recent years, Morgan has tried to address these flaws with modest efforts. It started an Internet business meant to serve the affluent rather than the truly wealthy. And it tried to get involved in financing Internet companies. But the results have been mixed. One of Morgan's most prominent Internet deals was the financing of Boo.com, an ambitious attempt to create a global Web site selling women's sportswear. Morgan helped Boo gain investments from some of the most wealthy families in Europe, but after running through $135 million, Boo was liquidated earlier this year.
Morgan is now likely to see itself become a part of Chase, an agglomeration of banks that had hardly been in its league. To be sure, some of the ancestors of the current Chase have their own storied histories. The Bank of Manhattan Company, after all, was founded in 1799 as a water company. And Chase in the 1970's, run by David Rockefeller, was a leading banker to the Arab world. But the institution now using the Chase name was formed when two underperforming New York banks -- Chemical Bank and Manufacturers Hanover -- merged in 1991 as a way to preserve capital drained by a decade of overindulgent lending. In 1995, what was then called Chemical bought Chase, which itself was struggling to meet profit goals. Chemical was clearly in control but took the more prestigious name.
"They have a history of making acquisitions and integrating them successfully; that is enviable in an industry that has not done this well," Mr. Toevs said. Still, Chase, with its extensive branches and wide-ranging clientele, relies on a corporate culture drawn more from the streets of New York than of the rarefied air breathed by those at Morgan.
"The Morgan folks are always wearing their elite status on their sleeves," Mr. Toevs said. "That's got to help the Chase franchise."

1861 -- J. Pierpont Morgan founds J. P. Morgan & Company in New York.
 
1870 -- A Morgan bank lends 10 million to cash-starved France during the Franco-Prussian War, helping to establish the House of Morgan as a world-class bank.
 
1895 -- J. Pierpont Morgan unites its European and American operations, financing railroads, utilities and steelmakers.
 
1907 -- Panic prompts a run on banks and a collapse on Wall Street. The House of Morgan leads a rescue of the financial system. The incident prompts the creation of a true central bank, the Federal Reserve, in 1913.
 
1913 -- J. Pierpont Morgan dies. J. P. Morgan Jr. takes the helm and builds the headquarters at 23 Wall Street.
 
1929 -- The stock market crashes, ushering in the Depression. Morgan and other banks are blamed.
 
1933 -- The Glass-Steagall Act is passed, forcing the separation of banking and securities companies.
 
1935 -- The company splits into J. P. Morgan & Company, a commercial bank led by J. P. Morgan Jr., and Morgan Stanley, an investment bank led by Harry Morgan, his son.
 
1942 -- J. P. Morgan & Company sells shares to the public for the first time.
 
1959 -- Morgan buys Guaranty Trust Company, described as Jonah swallowing the whale because Guaranty is four times its size.
 
1969 -- J. P. Morgan creates a holding company to manage its assets.
 
1989 -- J. P. Morgan is the first bank allowed by the Federal Reserve to underwrite and sell corporate bonds. Morgan is allowed to deal in stocks shortly thereafter. The company builds a new headquarters at 60 Wall Street.
 
1997 -- J. P. Morgan buys 45 percent of American Century, one of America's biggest mutual fund companies.
 
2000 -- Unable to break through to the top tier of investment banking, J. P. Morgan agrees to be bought by Chase Manhattan Bank for about $31 billion, ending months of talks with some of the world's major banks.

HEADLINE: Republicans' Request to Cut Debt Surprises Democrats

BYLINE: By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 12

 BODY:
With the demise of their large-scale tax cut, Republican leaders in Congress met today with President Clinton at the White House to discuss unfinished legislation and request that he set aside 90 percent of this year's surplus to pay down the national debt.
"I think we're down here to find a fair middle ground and try to start to have some productivity and finish up the season," said Speaker J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois. 
 But Democratic leaders who attended the meeting quickly seized on the Republican request concerning the surplus, saying they were puzzled by the last-minute proposal. For two years, Republicans have made tax cuts their showcase issue, though they have often mentioned debt reduction and protecting Social Security and Medicare in the same breath.
President Clinton vetoed their two most popular tax-cutting bills in August as too expensive and too skewed toward the wealthy.
"Republicans spent their entire two years trying to pass these tax cuts and now they say they really want to pay down the debt," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader. "It's either a gimmick designed to get them out of town or a break from where they have been in the past, if you play it out over 10 years."
Mr. Clinton told Republicans he viewed paying down the debt as a priority, but said he was not sure it could be done in the 2001 fiscal budget, which is set to begin on Oct. 1.
Spending requests are also piling up, Mr. Clinton said. The government must send emergency money to Western states recovering from wildfires, and lawmakers want increases for military spending and to help farmers. "Whether we can do it this year or not depends upon what the various spending commitments are," Mr. Clinton said.
As the discussion veered off to other matters, Mr. Clinton said he hoped Congress would pass bills to overhaul managed care and classify violence against gays as hate crimes, an issue the House is expected to take up on Wednesday. Mr. Clinton said he hoped to reach a compromise on raising the minimum wage and providing some tax relief to small businesses, which Republicans want to see linked in the same bill.
But most of today's discussion revolved around the Republican proposal to reduce the debt.
For Republicans, the shift in emphasis from tax cuts and toward reducing the debt is an effort to take the money off the table, rein in spending and protect them from Mr. Clinton's attacks on their tax cuts. It is also a move to put Mr. Clinton in an awkward position, since he and Vice President Al Gore, the Democratic presidential nominee, both support paying down the debt.
"If you lock in the debt reduction, you don't spend it," Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, said.
But Democrats said a proposal to set aside 90 percent of the surplus for only one year would do nothing to pay down the debt. As it stands, they said, that figure is not so different from what already exists in the budget requests.
"The president's budget more than meets the 90 percent marker," said Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's top economic policy adviser. "But the real test is not a potentially artificial one-year number but whether or not there is a 10-year commitment to debt reduction and paying off the debt over exploding tax cuts."
Democrats portrayed the request as an effort to jump on a more popular bandwagon and as a split from the direction Gov. George W. Bush, the Republican nominee, is headed in with his large tax-cut package.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the surplus next year will total $268 billion. By setting aside 90 percent, nearly $30 billion would be available for extra spending and tax cuts.
"We smell a rat," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader. "If it's a one-year plan, it's a gimmick. If it's a 12-year plan, they're divorcing themselves from their presidential candidate, George Bush, because George Bush has committed all of that surplus to a tax cut."
A spokesman fpr Mr. Bush, Ari Fleischer, said that the Bush plan would eliminate the debt by 2016. The Gore plan would eliminate it by 2012.
Republican leaders said their proposal was no gimmick, simply a bid to make Mr. Clinton choose between increasing spending or reducing the debt. Michele Davis, the press secretary for Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said: "It's saying, 'O.K., Mr. President, you vetoed the marriage penalty. Fine. That money is going to debt reduction. You vetoed the death tax. That money goes to debt reduction and you don't get to spend it.' "
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, said that the meeting was most productive; Republicans, he said, established a direct line to Mr. Clinton, without interference from Democratic leaders, to discuss issues that would come up in the waning weeks of the session. "We were straightforward with him," Mr. DeLay said. "We didn't pull any punches."

To Buy Wasserstein Perella Wasserstein Perella is in advanced talks to be acquired by Dresdner Bank of Germany and, if the two can come to terms on price, a deal could be announced in three to five days, a person close to the talks said.

Fiorina, Hewlett-Packard's chief executive, hailed the new computer, called Superdome, as a symbol of the company's claim that it has been "reinvented" as a more customer-oriented vendor selling solutions rather than products. Creating a Supportive Atmosphere
Royal Farros, the chief executive of iPrint.com, an online printing service, says managing a company involves a lot of the same expectations and feelings as having pets. Creating a loving, affectionate home for pets is similar to fostering an active environment where employees feel important and influential. Building such a culture is not just critical to the personality of an organization, he says, but absolutely key to its livelihood. The Boss. C8.

Political Volunteers in White Collars
For all the fund-raising by Democrats and Republicans this year, candidates for offices from the the White House to the local school board know one thing is even more important than money: volunteers. And while these unpaid armies are made up mostly of students and retired people, it is business professionals who exhibit the qualities that political candidates value most: nuts-and-bolts organizational skills, management savvy and address books filled with contacts. Management. C8.

With estimates that business air fares, hotel rates and car rentals will rise by at least 5 percent next year, many travel departments are revamping travel policies or drafting new ones -- and insisting on more strict adherence to them. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C10.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE POLLS;
Poll Shows Gore Overcoming Voter Concerns on Likability

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE with JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore has shaken the persistent sense that he is not particularly likable and is now as highly regarded as Gov. George W. Bush on matters of character, leadership and overall personal popularity, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
Now that public opinion has settled somewhat since the Democratic convention nearly four weeks ago, and voters say they are far more interested in the race, the survey makes clear that Mr. Gore's enhanced fortunes are deeper and more sustained than a postconvention glow. 
 Mr. Gore has achieved substantial gains among women, independent voters and those from middle-income groups. While Mr. Bush's support has diminished somewhat over all, he retains the overwhelming support of men, Midwesterners and Southerners.
The poll shows that the presidential race is neck and neck and that Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore are facing off in the tightest competition just after Labor Day in 20 years.
Forty-two percent of registered voters said they would back Mr. Gore if the election were held today, and 39 percent said they would vote for Mr. Bush. Four percent said they would back Ralph Nader, the Green Party nominee, and 2 percent would favor Patrick J. Buchanan of the Reform Party.
Mr. Gore has gained on Mr. Bush in recent weeks, but not to a degree that is statistically significant. The nationwide telephone poll, conducted Saturday through Monday with 843 registered voters, has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
And there was some encouraging news for Mr. Bush in the numbers. Forty-seven percent of Mr. Gore's supporters said they had reservations about him; only 38 percent of Mr. Bush's backers registered concerns about their candidate.
By far the most pronounced shift in the survey is the marked improvement in the public's perceptions of Mr. Gore.
For months, Americans said they found Mr. Gore's positions on various issues more appealing than Mr. Bush's, but the vice president's most persistent problem was that voters said they had significant misgivings about him on issues of character.
Now, while Mr. Bush has held his own in retaining impressive favorability ratings, Mr. Gore's favorability ratings have increased substantially -- to the point where the two men are now equally popular. Forty-four percent of voters say they have a favorable view of Mr. Gore, while 29 percent have an unfavorable view. Mr. Gore has not done that well by this measure for years. In recent months, the public either had more negative views of Mr. Gore than positive ones, or, more recently, had given him positive ratings that equaled his negatives.
In a striking example of how perceptions have transformed, voters no longer view Mr. Bush as the runaway winner in the November election. They are now split on whether Mr. Gore or Mr. Bush will make it to the White House. As recently as two months ago, Mr. Bush led Mr. Gore on this question by more than 20 percentage points.
Voters are also more confident in Mr. Gore's ability to deal wisely with an international crisis. Forty-nine percent said they were confident in Mr. Gore, a gain from 43 percent in a Times/CBS poll in July. Mr. Bush's standing on that issue has remained steady at 46 percent.
While 63 percent of the public thinks Mr. Gore cares about the needs and problems of ordinary people -- a figure that has not changed since July -- Mr. Bush has shown some slippage. Forty-nine percent say that Mr. Bush cares about ordinary people, a decline from 55 percent in July.
It is not altogether clear what has prompted the more kindly feelings toward Mr. Gore. But in follow-up interviews yesterday, many voters who now back Mr. Gore said they were impressed by what they saw at the Democratic convention. Repeatedly, they said, Mr. Gore seemed to be coming into his own and moving out of President Clinton's shadow.
"At the convention, he did a better job of concealing anything that was negative, if he had anything to begin with," said Wilma Akins, 69, a retired office manager in Statesboro, Ga. "He made me feel hopeful and optimistic about the future."
Joyce Taylor, 46, a grocery store manager in Philadelphia, said: "He's become stronger and seems to be speaking out more since the convention. He's becoming his own man now, and he's not as stiff as he once was."
Although there is still not a single overwhelming issue that defines the race -- as the economy has in the past -- the survey found that the closest contender this year was health care, and the related matter of Medicare. Nearly two-thirds of voters said the high cost of prescription drugs for the elderly was quite important to them personally.
Voters said they thought the government -- not insurance companies -- would do a better job of providing coverage to the elderly for prescription drugs. Mr. Gore was seen as more likely than Mr. Bush to succeed in reducing the cost of prescription drugs for the elderly. Mr. Bush has proposed allowing private insurance companies to compete for Medicare clients, while Mr. Gore has proposed adding a subsidy for prescription drug coverage to the current Medicare plan.
While Mr. Bush has recently accused the administration of presiding over a weakening of the military, the issue did not register much with voters. And many seemed confused about the state of the nation's missile defense capability.
Half the voters agreed with Mr. Bush's assertion that the military has weakened under Mr. Clinton. Just under half said it had either strengthened or stayed the same over the last eight years.
But half the voters said they thought that the United States had a missile defense system, although it does not; only 28 percent knew that the country does not have one. One explanation may be that nearly 7 of 10 respondents said they had not heard or read much about the debate over proposals for a missile defense system.
Even so, 4 of 10 voters said it was very important that the United States try and build a missile defense system; two-thirds said they favored such an effort, even though the government has already spent $60 billion trying to develop one.
While Mr. Bush has repeatedly called upon Mr. Gore to elevate the discourse and not sink to harsh commercials, voters gave the vice president higher marks for his advertising campaign. Two-thirds of voters said Mr. Gore was spending more time explaining what he would do as president than he was spending attacking Mr. Bush; half said the same of Mr. Bush.
More than a third of voters have seen advertisements for Mr. Bush, and they are divided over whether they mostly explain things about Mr. Bush or attack Mr. Gore. About a third have seen advertisements for Mr. Gore. But those viewers, decisively, say Mr. Gore's commercials explain things about Mr. Gore rather than attack Mr. Bush.
In the voter interviews, many said Mr. Gore's selection of Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut spiced up the ticket, especially when Mr. Lieberman was compared with Dick Cheney, who even many Republicans say has not been as beneficial to Mr. Bush as a running mate.
"The move to choose Lieberman took a lot of guts and was brilliant," said Nati Gottlieb, 53, an insurance salesman in Philadelphia. "That move stopped Bush dead in his tracks and started his current momentum."
Despite such comments, the poll reinforced the accepted wisdom that running-mate choices do not matter much. Mr. Cheney and Mr. Lieberman are each well liked, and each is about twice as likely to be viewed favorably as unfavorably. But most people still have no opinion of them. And more than half of the voters said the selections did not make them any more, or less, inclined to vote for Mr. Bush or Mr. Gore.
Voters did not sound exercised about the frequent references to his faith by Mr. Lieberman, an Orthodox Jew. Voters said it was perfectly appropriate for candidates to discuss their religious beliefs, and a majority said none of the Democratic or Republican candidates had used their religion improperly.
On the topic of televised debates, a subject that has dominated much of the campaign news in recent weeks, 49 percent said they believed Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush wanted to debate; 21 percent said only Mr. Gore wanted to debate and 10 percent said only Mr. Bush wanted to take part. Eighty-six percent said the bipartisan Commission on Presidential Debates should hold the events; the Bush campaign had earlier sought other sponsors.
This is only the third time in 40 years that a presidential contest has been this close immediately after Labor Day, and that may be why more voters now say the race is interesting -- and not dull. Fifty-three percent say it is interesting; 39 percent say it is dull.
A continuation of such interest could spur turnout in the range of 50 percent to 55 percent, slightly higher than in 1996.
In 1980, the contest between Jimmy Carter and Ronald Reagan was a dead heat at this point, with Mr. Reagan pulling ahead only over the final weekend. In 1960, the match-up between Richard M. Nixon and John F. Kennedy was equally tight at this stage, and stayed that way until Mr. Kennedy's narrow victory.
"It's going to be one of the best horse races we've had in the country since Kennedy and Nixon," said Senator Peter G. Fitzgerald, Republican of Illinois. "The Bush campaign is going to have to do most everything right between now and November to win. And it will not be easy."
Paul Maslin, a Democratic pollster, put it this way: "This race is shaping up to be more like Kennedy-Nixon than anything else, mostly because of the closeness but also because of the dynamics of an incumbent hanging on with the country in pretty good shape but against a tough challenger."
 
How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Monday with 1,050 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 843 said they were registered to vote.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups, the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variations in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: FRESHMAN CLASS GROWS AT CUNY, REVERSING TREND

BYLINE: By KAREN W. ARENSON 

 BODY:
The number of new freshmen in the senior colleges at the City University of New York this fall has risen by 5 percent, and at some campuses by more than 20 percent, according to preliminary figures provided by the university.
The increase, the first in five years, comes despite predictions that CUNY's new policy of ending remedial instruction at CUNY's senior colleges would cut sharply into enrollment. This is the first year that the new policy is being applied on some campuses. 
 CUNY officials attributed the gain to better-educated applicants, more aggressive recruiting efforts and their efforts to rebuild CUNY's image. They said that students who might once have rejected CUNY as a remedial factory were now seeking admission and that 87 percent of the applicants -- up from 80 percent a year ago -- were able to pass the entrance examinations.
"This increase shows that the reputation of the university has improved and is attracting more and better students," said Louise Mirrer, CUNY's vice chancellor for academic affairs.
But there were more skeptical explanations as well.
Leaders of the faculty union said they feared that CUNY was bending its admissions guidelines to fill seats, and taking in unprepared students whom it could no longer serve well, and that the numbers did not reveal whether minority students were being squeezed out of the senior colleges.
"A large number of students came in at the last minute, and the first question is who these students are and whether they are prepared," said Steven London, the first vice president of the faculty and staff union, the Professional Staff Congress.
He said that many of the students who signed up at on-the-spot recruiting drives were admitted without providing academic or financial records. "How many of these students will be here in a month or two, I don't know," he said.
On at least one campus, Brooklyn College, where freshman enrollment rose by 24 percent, there was a sharp increase in the number of students admitted through its SEEK program for economically and educationally disadvantaged students who do not meet the college's regular entrance criteria. (SEEK stands for Search for Education, Elevation and Knowledge.)
While the SEEK students will not be taking remedial classes, their academic background is considered roughly equivalent to those admitted as remedial students in previous years. SEEK is mandated by the State Legislature. About two-thirds of the increase in Brooklyn's freshmen enrollment (to 1,315 from 1,057 last year) can be attributed to the increase in SEEK students.
But Dr. Mirrer maintained that an improvement in CUNY's rigor and reputation was responsible for the increased enrollment. She said that at the senior colleges, which have been raising their own entrance requirements in recent years, more students were arriving with stronger high school records.
She said that the number of students with four or more years of high school English, for example, had risen by 10 percent to 11,381 this year, while those with three or more years of college preparatory mathematics had climbed 6 percent, to 11,132. At the same time, she said, the number of students with grade point averages of 80 or higher (10,739) had risen by 6 percent.
She said that CUNY did not yet have data about the racial and ethnic composition of the incoming class and could not say yet whether it had changed since last year.
The increase in freshmen helped stabilize CUNY's overall enrollment, which has fallen since 1994, when it reached a recent peak of 212,634 students. Total enrollment late last week was 195,620, up three-tenths of 1 percent from last year. CUNY officials expect to revise the figures when they take their formal student census next month, but do not expect the trends to change.
"People are beginning to think of CUNY as not the school of last resort," said Larry Edwards, the liaison between CUNY and the Board of Education and deputy to both chancellors. "It's all perception, and perceptions are beginning to change."
Bernard Sohmer, president of the university faculty senate, said he expected the enrollment figures to be slightly lower in October when the formal student census occurs, but expected that the freshmen totals would still show gains.
"I don't think the increase will turn out to be 5 percent, but I do think something positive has happened," he said. "There seems to be a turnaround."
Many public universities, including the State University of New York, have shown enrollment gains in recent years as a college degree has become more important to earn a decent salary.
Tuition is $3,200 a year at CUNY's senior colleges, compared with $3,400 at SUNY. A SUNY spokesman said he did not yet have data on enrollments for this year, but that the number of freshmen at SUNY's four-year colleges grew 4 percent (to 29,007) last year.
CUNY began to lose enrollment in 1994, as it struggled with cutbacks in its state aid and growing attacks from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Gov. George E. Pataki and its own board members, including Herman Badillo -- now the chairman -- who asserted that the education it offered was second-rate.
"There was a lot of rancor and negativity," said Matthew Goldstein, CUNY's chancellor.
He said that CUNY lost students when it imposed a one-year limit on remedial work at the senior colleges in 1995; he also said it lost more than 20,000 students on public assistance when the city began to require welfare recipients to work.
In 1998, CUNY's trustees voted to stop admitting any remedial students to the senior colleges. Under its new policy, students who cannot demonstrate their readiness for college-level English and math may not enroll in bachelor's degree programs, but may enroll in the two-year community college programs. To demonstrate they do not need remediation, they have to either pass CUNY's own placement tests or show that they scored at least 75 on the English and math Regents or at least 480 out of 800 on each of the math and verbal sections of the College Board's SAT tests.
The new policy took effect on 7 of CUNY's 11 senior college campuses this year, and will take effect at the others next year.
Nearly all the colleges where the new policy is in effect showed increases in freshmen this year, many of them sizable. Baruch College showed an increase of 15 percent. Queens College was up 10 percent. Brooklyn was up 24 percent, including its bigger population of SEEK students.
Although the number of Hunter College freshmen declined by 3.6 percent this year, campus officials said they had to turn away applicants because their total enrollment had climbed.
"We could not accommodate any more freshmen," said Evangelos J. Gizis, the college's acting president.
Baruch College, too, said it shut its door to eligible transfer students seeking to enter its business program in early July because its classes were full.
"People working on Wall Street are knocking on our doors," said Jim Murphy, Baruch's executive director for admissions and financial aid.
He said that the college, which admits all eligible applicants, not only admitted more freshmen this year (2,992, up from 2,623 last year), but a slightly higher percent of those accepted for admission actually enrolled. He said the average combined College Board scores for the new students were 1,060, up 7 points from last year and up 50 points from 1997. A third of the freshmen had scores of 1,150 or higher.
At City College, where the new policy does not take effect until next year, freshmen enrollments are up 29 percent. Zeev Dagan, the college's provost, said he thought much of the increase resulted from improved services and recruitment.
"When we got our lists of admits, we started calling students, and we offered placement tests every weekend," he said. "They didn't even have to make an appointment."
More than 25,000 students have enrolled at CUNY as freshmen this year, up 5.4 percent from last year. The number jumped about 5 percent at both the four-year colleges and the community colleges.
Not all the colleges had increases in their freshmen classes. Besides Hunter, New York City Technical College, Lehman College and Medgar Evers all saw declines, ranging from 4 percent at New York City Tech to 18 percent at Medgar Evers.
Ricardo R. Fernandez, president at Lehman, said he and his staff were still trying to determine the reasons for the 12 percent decline in incoming freshmen. He said one question was whether the number of of high school graduates in the Bronx had changed now that students have to pass Regents exams to graduate.
Edison Jackson, Medgar Evers's president, said that the college had received many late registrants after the preliminary figures were gathered last week and that he now expected to show a 10 percent increase in freshmen.
"The average age of our students is 34," he said, "They have to get their kids into school first, and then they come to us."

HEADLINE: BANKING'S BIG DEAL: THE TREND;
A Deal Built on Weakness, and Strength

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
A generation ago, six major commercial banks dominated the financial world in New York, which itself was the financial capital of the world's largest economy.
Now J. P. Morgan -- the last of those six to stay independent -- is about to be bought, in the latest example of a trend toward financial concentration. If the planned takeover by Chase Manhattan is completed, it will bring together four of the six biggest banks in New York, circa 1980. And yet the combination reflects weakness as much as strength, as both institutions seek growth in areas where their previous efforts have not been especially successful. 
 Two decades ago, the commercial banks were dominant because they were the major financial intermediaries for both individuals and companies. Investment banks and insurance companies had their own niches, some quite profitable, but none of them seemed to be in a position to challenge the big banks as financial powerhouses.
What happened? Beginning in the 1970's, the commercial banks' dominance of their franchise diminished as corporations discovered they could save money by issuing securities rather than borrowing from banks. As the stock market boomed for years, investors' money flowed out of banks and into stocks and mutual funds.
And the commercial banks were hobbled by a series of loan debacles that damaged some severely and hurt all to some extent, whether in real estate or loans to third world countries. It took years for the banks to recover from those problems, and by then their competitors were ahead of them in many areas.
On top of that, Depression-era laws aimed at protecting banks from possible losses in securities made it difficult for them to move into other financial products. By the time those laws were largely repealed, it was the investment banks that were dominant.
At the close of trading yesterday, Chase Manhattan -- a company that includes the former Chemical New York and Manufacturers Hanover Banks -- had a market capitalization of $66 billion, and J. P. Morgan had shares valued at $29 billion.
By contrast, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, the investment banking company descended from J. P. Morgan, had a market capitalization of $121 billion. Morgan Stanley was split from Morgan after the Glass-Steagall Act of 1933 required the separation of investment banks and commercial banks. For decades no one doubted that J. P. Morgan itself had made the right decision by sticking to commercial banking. Now it will be subsumed, while Morgan Stanley is a dominant company.
The trend of financial consolidation, said H. Rodgin Cohen, a partner in Sullivan & Cromwell and a lawyer involved in many bank mergers -- but not in the Chase-Morgan talks -- can be traced largely to three factors: "convergence, globalization and technology."
By convergence, he refers to the fact that many financial institutions can now offer similar products, in contrast to the old days of protected turf. Globalization has put a premium on gaining strength in markets around the world, and the heavy costs of installing new technology have made it much more difficult for small players to compete.
There are many areas where Chase and Morgan would seem to complement each other. "They can fill in each other's gaps," said Ronald Mandle, an analyst for Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. Chase's strongest position is in equity securities is in technology stocks, thanks to its acquisition of Hambrecht & Quist. Morgan has a broader equity business, but is not strong in technology. "Morgan is stronger in Europe and Chase is a leader in syndicating U.S. loans," he said.
In 1980, the largest New York-based bank was Citibank. It still holds that position, but it is now part of Citigroup, which was formed by the merger of Citicorp, Citibank's parent, and Travelers, the large insurance and investment banking company run by Sanford I. Weill. While the Citi name survived, the bank is now part of a much larger company mainly run by executives who came from outside.
Chase ranked second among New York banks in 1980, followed by Manufacturers Hanover, Morgan, Chemical and Bankers Trust. Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover merged in 1991, and then acquired Chase (and its name) in 1995. Bankers Trust sold to Deutsche Bank, a German institution, in a deal annnounced in 1998.
The two non-New York banks in the top eight, as compiled by American Banker in 1980, have not fared much better. Bank of America, then No. 1, and Continental Illinois, then No. 7, have joined and both have been taken over by what was, in 1980, North Carolina National Bank, which ranked 26th in the nation.

INTERNATIONAL A3-14
 
Fuel Price Protests Are Squeezing Britain
Protests over high fuel prices all but halted gasoline deliveries across Britain, forcing most service stations to close for lack of fuel. Ambulance and fire services were cut back and many hospitals canceled all but essential procedures. Some diesel train lines were canceled. The protests continued to spread through Western Europe, where truck drivers, farmers and small-business people have formed impromptu coalitions to protest high fuel prices. A1
 
No Attack to Force Inspections
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, speaking with reporters after addressing the opening session of the United Nations General Assembly, said the United States would not use force to make Iraq allow international arms inspections to resume. A12

Sanctions on Austria Lifted
The European Union lifted its sanctions against Austria, seven months after hurriedly imposing a diplomatic freeze on Vienna for bringing a rightist party into its governing coalition. But the Europeans said they remained concerned about the party's role in the government and vowed to stay vigilant. A6

Race is Neck-and-Neck As Gore Gains, Poll Shows
A New York Times/CBS News Poll shows 42 percent of registered voters favoring Vice President Al Gore and 39 percent favoring Gov. George W. Bush. Mr. Gore is now as highly regarded as Mr. Bush on matters of character, leadership and personal popularity. HEADLINE: Caribbean, Badly Hurt, Is Promised Help on AIDS

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

DATELINE: BRIDGETOWN, Barbados, Sept. 12

 BODY:
With the Caribbean facing the highest rate of H.I.V. infection outside of sub-Saharan Africa, international donors and banks have pledged at least $120 million to support a regional strategy to combat the disease, they announced today.
The announcement, which included a World Bank proposal for $85 million to $100 million in loans, came at the end of a conference on AIDS in the Caribbean at which many speakers emphasized that the epidemic threatened to undo the social and economic development in the region. 
 Official estimates put the number of H.I.V. and AIDS cases at 360,000, but many health experts said the actual number exceeded 500,000 because of underreporting.
While the average rate of infection of the total population is about 2 percent -- compared with 8 percent in sub-Saharan Africa -- it has burdened the region's smaller economies. It has also forced political leaders to acknowledge the need to act, rather than to stay quiet because of fears of breaking taboos or scaring off the tourists that are a mainstay of many Caribbean economies.
"We do not have a choice in the matter -- we must act now," said Prime Minister Owen Arthur of Barbados. "The Caribbean has never lost a generation of its most talented young people because of war or natural disaster. It is in danger of doing so because of the pandemic of AIDS. With it goes the hope, promise and idealism of the best educated and most creative minds in the history of the Caribbean people."
The spread of the disease has been fueled by tourism, migration between islands, poverty, and religious and cultural resistance to the use of condoms and sex education. While Haiti and the Dominican Republic account for a vast majority of cases -- the infection rate is 12 percent in parts of Haiti -- growing concern about the spread of H.I.V. led the Caribbean Community to form an AIDS task force in 1998 to develop a regional plan to help members track and treat the disease.
More new cases of H.I.V. infection were diagnosed in the region between 1995 and 1998 than in all the previous years since the disease was first identified, and as in Africa it is spread largely by heterosexual contact. In the English-speaking Caribbean it has become the leading cause of death for men and women aged 15 to 44.
Yet many nations are spending only a fraction of what it costs for treatment and prevention. Current spending is about 10 percent of the estimated $258 million a year needed for effective regional treatment and prevention.
The financing pledged today would bolster existing efforts by the Caribbean Community and its regional partners, while individual nations would be expected to review their own spending to see what costs could be covered in existing budgets.
The United States, which has supported anti-AIDS programs in several of the worst-hit countries in the Caribbean, did not pledge a specific amount because of continuing budget discussions in Washington.
While international aid will help combat the disease, Mr. Arthur underscored the need for a regional approach to build on longstanding collaborations in health, research and economic matters.
"There has been stigma and discrimination," he said. "There has been the usual Caribbean serendipity that the solution to the problem will be found elsewhere and applied here."
This week's conference is the latest in a series of recent events in which AIDS has dominated regional discussions. In June, during a meeting of Caribbean finance ministers in Washington, officials from the World Bank and international health organizations placed the disease and its threat in sobering context.
The ministers learned of estimates that the cost of treating the disease, as well as the loss of life and income, could reduce gross domestic product in Jamaica by 6.4 percent and in Trinidad and Tobago by 4.2 percent by 2005.
