SECTION: Section 7; Page 41; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1122 words

HEADLINE: Saturday Gladiators

BYLINE: By Morris Berman; Morris Berman is the author of "The Twilight of American Culture" and "Wandering God: A Study in Nomadic Spirituality."

 BODY:

 BEER AND CIRCUS
 How Big-Time College Sports
 Is Crippling Undergraduate Education.
 By Murray Sperber.
 322 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $26. 
 THE title is from Juvenal: panem et circenses, bread and circuses (that is, public spectacles). Looking out over the bleak cultural landscape of Rome in the late first and early second centuries A.D., the great satirist concluded that these were the only two things that seemed to interest the majority of his countrymen. How different, Murray Sperber seems to be asking, are things for the American empire today?
It's an interesting question, and although Sperber doesn't pursue the comparison much beyond his Juvenalian title, the material he collects in "Beer and Circus" is very suggestive. American college students, particularly at big-time universities, are caught up in a triad of alcohol, spectator sports and partying, which, Sperber tells us, now occupies the "academic" career of vast numbers of undergraduates. This is in turn tied to the promotion of research at the expense of teaching; huge lecture classes (typically taught by teaching assistants); high levels of cheating; rampant grade inflation; and a cynical, if tacit, "nonaggression pact" between students and faculty to stay out of each other's way. In an argument that comes fairly close to conspiracy theory, Sperber asserts that none of this is accidental. Since the big-time universities aim to acquire status and prestige through expensive research programs, they can no longer afford to give the majority of their undergraduates a meaningful education. Hence, they substitute beer and circus to keep the students distracted and the tuition dollars rolling in, in a way that is perhaps no less cynical than the bread-and-circus constellation of ancient Rome.
The result? More than 56 percent of our college graduates are unable to calculate the change from $3 after buying a 60-cent bowl of soup and a $1.95 sandwich. Almost 40 percent take no courses in English or American literature, and 58 percent never study a foreign language. Nearly 31 percent have never taken a math course, and huge numbers of them cannot read and understand a simple set of directions. Add to this the fact that a de facto open admissions policy is now widespread throughout the United States, such that more than 80 percent of American colleges and universities admit virtually all their applicants, who are then processed through to what can only be called meaningless degrees.
How did we come to such a pass? asks Sperber, a professor of English and American studies at Indiana University. Sports, he claims, is the real culprit in this drama, in the form of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, which has the ability to force schools into enlarging their sports programs and facilities. By making a deal in 1979 with the new cable network, ESPN, the N.C.A.A. was able to generate "wall-to-wall media coverage of college sports," Sperber writes. "This marked a new phenomenon in higher education, one that subsequently became central to student life." Education, not surprisingly, got left behind in the dust.
It is hard to read Sperber's book without having a sinking feeling about the future of American culture. He has managed to document one facet of our national decline in painstaking detail, and the result is an admirable, timely and profoundly disturbing work. Yet in the end, the argument does not really show causation. It is more a case of confluence of factors than one of direct connection, and Sperber occasionally says as much. Thus at one point he refers to the link between sports and the sorry state of undergraduate education as one of "synergy," tells us that his results "should be regarded as anecdotal, not scientific, evidence" and states that it is impossible to separate cause and effect.
He also acknowledges that the "problems in American undergraduate education transcend big-time college sports," but says that he has chosen to focus on the latter rather than try to write about "the whole mess." These are important qualifications; the problem is that "the whole mess" cannot be ignored without obfuscating what the deeper causes -- which I believe are structural in nature -- really are. These causes emerge in a rather desultory fashion in the book, but at least they are there, ineluctably drawing the reader to a different conclusion than the one Sperber specifically intended.
The problem here is not sports, but the increasing domination of our educational system by the massive corporate-commercial culture that has consolidated itself during the last 15 or 20 years. When college enrollments began to drop in the late 1970's, schools started marketing themselves, and within a few years were referring to students as "customers" and then "consumers." Obtaining these "buyers" became paramount, and admissions recruiters began to use corporate language as a matter of course ("closing a deal" with a prospective student). Open admissions, grade inflation, big sports programs, huge lecture classes, the pursuit of research fame, the building of student entertainment centers on campus to the neglect of libraries and classrooms, the rapid expansion of university administrations -- all of this moves within the orbit of the new corporate-commercial paradigm that has come to define the United States over the last two decades.
That Sperber does not really regard the sports-education link as causal can be seen in his six proposals at the conclusion of the book: five of them have nothing whatever to do with sports. Thus he suggests that the large public universities should "slim down," losing millions of students, and "offer quality undergraduate education to all students who legitimately qualify for entrance"; that faculty should be hired and rewarded primarily for teaching undergraduates and that all undergraduates be required to attain a minimum score on the Graduate Record Examination before being allowed to graduate. The only proposal Sperber offers relevant to the sports question is that of eliminating athletic scholarships in favor of need-based grants.
Another quotation for which Juvenal became famous besides "bread and circuses," and one that is equally relevant to us today, is Quis custodiet ipsos custodes? Who will guard the guards themselves? This, I believe, is the real key to the situation Sperber describes, because beer and circus are only the byproduct of a culture that has been dumbed down by the triumph of the corporate-commercial way of life. Until we address Juvenal's question, very little of a substantive nature can be done about sports, education or indeed much else in America of the 21st century.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 25; Column 3; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 297 words

HEADLINE: Books in Brief: Fiction

BYLINE: By Maureen McLane

 BODY:

 WILD KIDS
 Two Novels About Growing Up.
 By Chang Ta-chun.
 Columbia University, $22.95. 
 In two jaunty, disturbing novellas from Taiwan, the author's first work to appear in English, Chang Ta-chun presents us with disaffected adolescents who roam city streets, complain about school, fantasize about gangster life and wear Chicago Bulls T-shirts. The global economy seems to have brought us a global literary type: the wily, bruised, commodity-loving, prematurely sophisticated teenager, with hapless parents and teachers in tow. These slim narratives, gracefully translated by Michael Berry, are related less by a unified authorial persona than by their similar settings in 1980's Taiwan, their knowing, offhanded dissection of family malaise and their notable fascination with storytelling. In "My Kid Sister," the 20-something narrator artfully reminisces about his lifelong friendship with his volatile sister, who as a child became his muse, critic and co-conspirator. The occasionally wisecracking tone does not diminish the delicacy of their relationship, and the story's end is stunningly, perfectly abrupt. "Wild Child" features a teenage runaway who stumbles into a gambling den and finds himself involved in gangster mayhem. Brutal, pointedly anesthetizing, jaggedly written and willfully disorienting, this second novella is heavily and knowingly indebted to gangster movies and pop culture. Whether these stories merely chronicle or more profoundly illuminate a slice of Taiwanese culture and fantasy is hard to say; Chang's scope and achievement will be more obvious for American readers when more of his work is translated. What is clear is that in Taipei, as elsewhere in contemporary fiction, the kids are not all right. Maureen McLane

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 9-17-00;
A Street Grows In Brooklyn

BYLINE: By Diane Cardwell; Diane Cardwell is an editor at the magazine.

 BODY:
A few years ago, when I moved near Smith Street -- a dusty stretch running through the Brooklyn neighborhoods of Boerum Hill and Carroll Gardens -- it seemed happily mired in the 1950's. Dotted with members-only social clubs and old men playing cards in front of shuttered storefronts, the area felt untouched by the relentless pace of Manhattan life. That's what persuaded me, and many people like me, to trade in a hip downtown address for space, charm and refuge across the river.
It wasn't an easy decision to make. In New York, more than in most cities, the neighborhood you choose plays a disproportionate role in the persona you project. But not only does the place you live influence the way you develop as a social being; the neighborhoods themselves are ever-changing entities as well, each with its own unfolding narrative. Moving from place to place, we play a kind of identity hopscotch, trying to figure out which area is likely to suit who we are, or who we hope someday to be, before the neighborhood morphs right out from under us and sets us to combing the real estate ads again. When I moved to SoHo, I was out all the time at the chic bistros and lounges that lined every street. But by the time I left for Carroll Gardens, being in the midst of of New York's throbbing nightlife no longer seemed as important; making a home with a measure of grace and quiet did. But those distinctions, as it turned out, weren't as far apart as I had anticipated. 
 Not long after moving, I noticed that a store called Refinery had opened up, a cool handbag shop of the sort you might have seen on Ludlow Street in the early 90's: small, idiosyncratic, lightly overpriced. A block away, there was Astro Turf, specializing in just-above-kitsch home furnishings. Soon came Patois, a small bistro that was the first place in the 'hood that served lettuces other than iceberg and romaine. Then Frida's Closet, where the designer herself sewed sweet little cotton dresses for -- imagine! -- under $200.
There was just enough gentrification to brighten the area, not enough to attract the tourists. By the end of last year, you could pop out for a microbrew at Quench, stop in for tuna tartare at Saul (or Grocery or Smith Street Kitchen), pick up a funky top at Crush or fall asleep during a myofacial aromatherapy massage at Area. It felt like the right place at the right time, an affordable neighborhood with just enough cachet to feel happening. Maybe things were starting to get a bit precious, but compared with Park Slope, which had gone this route a decade earlier, it was still an arty college town. And compared with Manhattan -- where the streets were clogged with S.U.V.'s, the restaurants filled with 27-year-old paper millionaires -- it was the frontier.
But then, somehow, the frontier receded, and my quasi-bohemian settlement began feeling less and less like a secret. Marquet Patisserie opened an elegant tea-and-madeleine salon that was indistinguishable from the one in Manhattan. Patois became so popular -- and not just with locals, either -- it expanded into the space next door.
And then there was Halcyon, a groovy cafe-nightclub-thrift-shop-bar-rec-room that attracted kids from the neighborhood and coolhunters from Manhattan and L.A. to observe them in their native environment. As soon as I saw them I knew it had all gone too far. I waited for the end.
It came, one summer morning, standing in the dappled sunlight on the corner of President and Smith, tall and blond and eyeing a map: Germans. My sublime little neighborhood had become just another tourist destination, a real estate category, a stop on the party train. It was as if the strip had barreled into awkward, paunchy middle age before it got its braces off.
I can't begrudge the local businesspeople their successes, or the local landlords, many of whom toughed it out during the 80's when the vacancy rate was 27 percent and the sidewalks were caving in. But how much longer will they be the beneficiaries of this boom? "What's nice is that it's still local people doing things on this street," says Elizabeth Beer, who owns Hoyt & Bond, a mother-child clothing shop. "But I really worry about the arrival of the chain stores."
Even Bette Stoltz, who, as executive director of the South Brooklyn Local Development Corporation, was instrumental in helping the area out of its economic slump, says she feels an occasional pang. "There's always this fear, as people retire and sell their buildings, that the next property owner, who paid a lot more for the building, needs to make more, gets greedier," she says. "But nothing stays the same. That's the way things are."
A year from now, who knows what Smith Street will look like? A town-house condo development is replacing a community garden, and lofts across from an old cheese factory are selling for $600,000. Barring a dot-com implosion, the pressure to create more high-yuppie, kid-friendly services will continue to mount.
I won't be there to see it. Smith Street has outgrown me. I no longer derive much satisfaction from living among the trendy hordes, and the area no longer qualifies for urban homesteading. Last month I gave up my apartment and found another in a less glamorous part of Brooklyn, one that seems resistant to the forces of runaway gentrification. But I could be wrong. Not far away lurks the Brooklyn Navy Yard. It's an aging blight at the moment, but an aging blight with a waterfront view of the Manhattan skyline, and, perhaps, cause for a twinkle in some developer's eye.

HEADLINE: Fare Wars in Australia's Skies

BYLINE: By SUSAN GOUGH HENLY

 BODY:
THE recent arrival of two new Australian carriers, Impulse Airlines and Virgin Blue, ending the longtime duopoly of Ansett and Qantas, has dramatically cut domestic air fares in the country. On a one-way flight between Sydney and Melbourne, the regular economy fare is $184, at 1.74 Australian dollars to the United States dollar; in recent weeks, seats on that route have been selling for as little as $38.
Besides government deregulation, the Sydney Olympic Games can also take a little credit for reducing the cost of flights. All four carriers advertised specials because business travel, the airlines' staple, was expected to dry up during the Games, which opened Friday and will close Oct. 1. 
 Until Oct. 8, the one-way fare between Sydney and Brisbane (as well as Sydney and Melbourne) can be as low as $38; and between Melbourne and Brisbane, $57, with no advance purchase and no round trip required. Those are far lower than the round-trip 14-day advance purchase fares of $173 between Sydney and Melbourne or $282 between Melbourne and Brisbane, both of which require a Saturday-night stay. Compared with regular economy fares, they are cheaper still.
Impulse Airlines has flown regional routes in New South Wales for seven years, but entered the major interstate routes only in June. Virgin Blue, a subsidiary of the Virgin Company, created by Richard Branson, started flights Aug. 31.
While the two newcomers have a range of fare schedules akin to those of Qantas and Ansett (all the lines use the same airports), they are also promoting some exceptional deals. Impulse set off the price war last month when it introduced its $38 one-way fare between Sydney and Melbourne.
Impulse has 11 daily round-trip flights between Sydney and Melbourne (fares range from $38 to $88 one way) and eight daily round-trip flights between Sydney and Brisbane ($38 to $94.50) on its five Boeing 717-200 jets. Tickets can be booked on www.impulseairlines.com.au, by telephone within Australia (13-1381) and through Flight Center's 500 retail travel agent outlets in Australia (13-1600).
While tickets on the company's regular fares are fully changeable and even transferable, the deeply discounted fares of $38 are nonrefundable and nonchangeable and can only be booked on the Internet.
Virgin Blue is starting with four daily round-trip Boeing 737 flights between Sydney and Brisbane (increasing to seven by Oct. 1), with at least half the seats available at the launch price of $57 one way. Its Melbourne-Brisbane route has three daily flights in each direction at $80 one way. Tickets at www.virginblue.com.au, by phone within Australia (13-6789) or with travel agents.
Qantas and Ansett both responded rapidly to the deep discounting by Impulse and Virgin Blue, matching the $38 fares between Sydney and Melbourne. Qantas and Ansett also took Impulse's Sydney-Brisbane fare and extended it until Oct. 28. Qantas tickets can be bought at www.qantas.com.au, at (800) 227-4500 or from travel agents. Ansett tickets are available at www.ansett.com.au, by phone within Australia (13-1300) or through travel agents.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 36; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1590 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
Mexican Modern: Back to a Future That Fell Behind

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG

 BODY:
THERE was a point between the two world wars when politics and economics pushed experimental modernism in the visual arts into a corner or simply squashed it in the Soviet Union, Germany, Italy and America. For a while in the 1920's the modernist adventure was still going full throttle. Although many artists in Europe and the United States pulled back toward stylistic reason and classicism immediately after the chaos of World War I, avant-garde experiments like Dada, Suprematism, abstraction and Surrealism continued to strike sparks in much of Europe and the U.S.S.R. in the 1920's and even in the 1930's where dictators did not forbid them or social causes overshadow them. Mexico was a special case. Early 20th-century art movements had a negligible influence there before the 1920's. Just when they began to have an effect, the Mexican muralist movement spread across the country's walls and by its artistic power, nationalistic appeal and its very size and visibility, marginalized the modernist currents pulsing through the country.
The muralist movement, set in motion by a government plan for the "Salvation and Regeneration of Mexico Through Culture" in 1920, ignored European currents like Cubism and abstraction. Diego Rivera, who had been a Cubist for several years in Europe before turning away from it, devised a mural style that combined realism, primitivism, myth and politics. Neither Jose Clemente Orozco nor David Alfaro Siqueiros paid any more attention to Cubism or abstraction than he did. 
 And yet experimentalism did spring up and never died in Mexico; it just stayed in the shade. A glimpse of vanguard modernism in photography, which has been studiously neglected (and probably largely unknown) by historians, may be caught in the gallery of the Mexican Cultural Institute on East 39th street, in a quiet and elegant little show called "Otras Cosas: Abstract Photography." Malin Barth is the curator of this exhibition of 27 images by Emilio Amero, Lola Alvarez Bravo, Manuel Alvarez Bravo, Augustin Jimenez and Rosa Covarrubias, most from the late 1920's and early 1930's, a few from the 1950's. A brief catalog is available.
Mr. Alvarez Bravo, born in 1902 and by far the best known of the five, is widely recognized as a major player in early modernist photography as well as a vital influence on Mexican photography. His most familiar images, taken on the street, distill the commonplace experiences of a Mexican city into moments pregnant with potential and resonant with mystery.
Less well known are his modernist experiments with abstraction and ambiguous details in the 1920's, which first brought him to public attention in Mexico in 1928. For a series of "Paper Games," Mr. Alvarez Bravo let his adding machine spew out paper tape that wound itself into unforeseeable shapes, and then photographed the results close up. In 1931 he won first prize in a contest sponsored by the Tolteca Cement Company with a photograph that is at once a geometric exercise and an index to information about the subject. A trapezoidal form, actually a cement wall that recedes too rapidly, stands on a slanted bed of crushed pebbles used for making cement. The dark background, punctuated by lighter diagonal lines, is the ceiling of the cement factory. Mr. Alvarez Bravo's lens turns both site and process into spare emblems of modernity.
He taught photography to his first wife, Lola Alvarez Bravo (1907-1993), and she made a career of it, keeping his name after they divorced. She is the late comer in this show; though she was photographing by the mid-1930's, most of her pictures then were portraits and street work. The selection here is of landscapes taken in the 1940's and 1950's; they are less devoted to the principles of abstraction than some of the other images in "Otras Cosas," though they immerse the viewer in roots and leaves and branches without horizon, beginning or end.
As a muralist, Emilio Amero (1901-1976) assisted Rivera and Orozco; later he made experimental films and earned most of his reputation as a lithographer. In the early 1930's he made photograms, a cameraless technique thought of as a pre-eminently modern way to make the familiar strange. Amero experimented with the process and produced an unusual range of tones by exposing the paper to light in the darkroom several times -- most photograms are exposed only once -- and changing the light's intensity. His rigorously constructed compositions, mostly of mass-manufactured objects like gears and springs, include cut-out shapes as well as actual objects placed on the emulsion and proclaim their modernism by technique, composition and the use of machine parts and utilitarian products.
Augustin Jimenez's (1901-1974) photographs were shown in America and London between 1929 and 1931 to good reviews. He subsequently devoted himself to cinema, collaborating with Sergei Eisenstein and working with Bunuel as well as making some films on his own. In this show, his photographs from around 1931 concentrate on repetitive elements that form patterns when ripped out of context: the spines of a cactus, a line of rifles on a rack, the open-work shadows of some sort of umbrella.
Rosa Covarrubias (1895-1970), wife of the painter and illustrator Miguel Covarrubias, played with photograms in a manner so different from Amero's that it might be called -- at risk of sounding politically incorrect -- feminine modern. Two of her images begin with drawings of herself in the nude and add emblematic objects like shells, a sunburst, a Mexican ceramic animal, a goblet turned upside down to make the outline of a full-skirted dress that does not obscure her naked body. One photogram of a glass, lace and a butterfly could certainly have been made by a man, but in the context of her other work it looks like a riff on feminine preoccupations. She won third prize in the Tolteca competition, reportedly with the most abstract composition of all.
Covarrubias was a striking woman even with her clothes on, and Edward Weston took her portrait more than once. He and Tina Modotti, who had moved to Mexico together in 1923, taught her photography. How well she learned the lesson is evident from her photogram of a halved cabbage, most likely made after Weston had left Mexico and certainly before his extreme close-up of a halved artichoke, which it strongly resembles.
All of this work follows modernist dictates, even regarding experiment, with an air of assurance, suggesting on the basis of limited material that photographic modernism had a respectable outpost in Mexico at the time. The surprise is that it exists in some quantity, since so little of it has been seen here.
Modernism came to Mexico from abroad. In photography, and to some degree in painting, Weston and Modotti were primary influences (though Covarrubias probably learned about photograms in Europe in 1926 when she became friends with Man Ray). In the 1920's and 1930's, several outstanding foreign photographers, including Weston, Modotti, Paul Strand and Henri Cartier-Bresson (and Eisenstein), worked for a time in Mexico, and their presence enriched the culture of that country, if not as greatly as it enriched the culture of the visitors.
The beginning of the 1920's, when modern art had its first appreciable impact on Mexico, was almost the exact moment of the muralist movement's embrace of goals quite unlike those of the European avant-garde. There was a divide between the two Mexican artistic impulses, with some artists feeling that no matter how passionate they were about their country's history, art had other purposes.
By the end of the 1920's the mural movement was so dominant that it had inspired a backlash; still, it got the lion's share of attention. Modern art was already too entrenched in the Western world to be stifled (except in the places where it was outlawed), but it could be pushed out of the spotlight. During the Depression, when the United States elevated documentary above all other forms of art and exalted realism, putting photography in a primary position, art for art's sake and much of modernism were shunted into the wings. Which is not to say that either modernism or abstraction vanished, only that they were relegated to the sidelines. Or worse. Photographers who did not direct their cameras at social ills sometimes found themselves on the defensive.
The issue of art for art's sake versus art as evangelism, education or propaganda recurs periodically. Realism overpowered abstraction and its relatives in the 1920's and 1930's wherever nationalism, social utopianism, propaganda -- even, sometimes, humanitarianism -- became primary objectives. In the Soviet Union, where art for art versus art for social ends was vigorously debated, there was a rare and mystical moment of belief, Malevich being its chief representative, that abstraction could change life for the masses in the new nation. The Soviets didn't buy it, and indeed it is not so easy today to imagine the peasants achieving a new society under the impetus of Malevich's colorful geometric forms.
Mexican artists opted for realism before the U.S.S.R. did, and for different reasons, yet in Mexico, as in most other places, there were otras cosas, art movements that persisted outside the mainstream. There are always brave souls stubbornly, persistently swimming against the current, and though history may inundate them and hide them from view for a time, it can also retrieve them once more from the deep.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 38; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 2199 words

HEADLINE: ART/ARCHITECTURE;
The Air-Conditioned Reverie of a Fundamentalist

BYLINE: By HERBERT MUSCHAMP

DATELINE: HOUSTON

 BODY:
SUMMERTIME in Houston. This is what it's like to be a martyr to city-love. Heat and mugginess drive the body into underground streets and climate-controlled rooms, behind sealed windows and closed doors. The mind feels trapped, too. Intellectually, you know that you're in a great American city. Physically, you feel absent.
The sensation of absence must be acute for Rafael Moneo, architect of the new Audrey Jones Beck Building at Houston's Museum of Fine Arts. In Moneo's native Spain, builders have been coping with heat for eons. Here in Texas, a one-time Spanish colony, architecture is for all practical purposes a network of sealed membranes, constructed around air-conditioning systems and linked together by cars chilled to bone-rattling discomfort. 
 The week I went to Houston, a photograph appeared on the front page of this newspaper depicting the apparent melting of the polar ice cap. Yes, Virginia, Santa's workshop is under water. Compared to this alarming piece of news, the Beck Building is scarcely worth mentioning. Nonetheless, the building is a good one. It deserves a positive story. But so does the link, however remote, between the Beck and our watery top of the world.
Usually, when I arrive in a city to look at a building, I spend some hours prowling the vicinity to orient myself to the site. In Houston, it was too hot to prowl, or even to inspect the Beck Building's exterior, except from the window of my hotel room across the street. From this perspective, the building's context was the window, the newspaper and a bowl of complimentary fruit. Still life with art museum. Nature morte.
Still, even a discouraged city-lover would risk dehydration to visit a building by Ludwig Mies van der Rohe. Two previous additions to the Museum of Fine Arts were designed by the great master, in 1958 and 1974. These have now been renovated, to coincide with the Beck Building's opening last May, when the weather may have been more conducive to architectural appreciation.
Moneo was an excellent choice to build on Miesian precedent. Like Mies, Moneo is a fundamentalist. He believes in essences, architectural values that endure. "I am committed," he said, "to an architecture that maintains faith in the principles and the mechanisms architecture has always had."
Like Mies, who preferred the term "building art"to architecture, Moneo embraces material construction as architecture's basic fact. He is not a structural expressionist. The stone surfaces of the Beck Building conceal load-bearing steel and concrete construction. But Moneo's forms and volumes do not violate the logic of the materials and methods used to fabricate them.
The Beck is a square, two-story box. It occupies an entire block in the museum district a few miles from downtown, across the street from the Mies expansion and the museum's original home, a 1924 Beaux Arts temple. All four sides of the Beck are covered with a light pink stone that shimmers with a lustrous, Mediterranean bloom. Only spare geometric cuts are made in the facades: some large windows framed in bronze; a wedge-shape trough that allows the sun to reach a skylight; air grilles. On the west side, a deep reveal shelters the main entrance.
The Beck's roof can be counted a fifth facade. It supports the building's most conspicuous urbanistic device: a grid of louvered light boxes that illuminate the galleries below. Night photographs taken from above suggest that the lanterns were intended to echo the downtown skyline some miles away. This effect is not apparent from the street. Nonetheless, the roofline makes an elegant night-time apparition.
Two entrances to the Beck cause anxious indecision, particularly since the main one is concealed in deep shadow beneath an overhang and separated from the street by a driveway. The driveway is partly screened by a thick cement wall that has been molded into scored letters forming the museum's name. The lettering, designed by Massimo Vignelli, is astonishingly unattractive. If the intention was to recall the thick walls of adobe construction, the gesture is hollow here.
Blast of conditioned air. Ticket lobby. Then, as the body adjusts, a vision of space-on-space: an atrium of an amplitude that you wouldn't believe possible in a two-story building, even with the little penthouse that enables the atrium to punch through the roofline. You are instantly relieved on entering, and not just by the coolness. The atrium's compressed, almost intimate monumentality states that Moneo knows everything there is to know about museum fatigue, including how to spare you from it.
CLASSICALLY composed yet dynamic, the atrium is animated by two diagonals that slice asymmetrically through it. A staircase to the left, an escalator to the right form two triangles that face each other in reverse -- two flipped halves of a divided square. The length and thinness of the two banks magnify the room's scale. The space is further enlivened by the eclectic array of antique sculptures that face you like a committee welcoming you to the history of art.
Take the escalator to the permanent collection. You may be halfway through it before your eye is drawn to the Beck's signal detail: a cubic convergence of planes and textures. A narrow strip of stone is set into the floor around the perimeter of each gallery. Playing against the stained, dark oak floor, the strips are light-catchers, horizontal frames that extend the wall's surface into the space of the room. Just above the stone, thin, louvered aluminum air-conditioning grilles are mounted at the base of the wall. The doorways between the classically proportioned galleries are framed with brushed bronze panels.
It may strike you that the entire building was designed to create a sympathetic environment for this device for framing space and light. While the skylights, with their louvered light boxes, are formally more assertive, the detailing in the galleries themselves defines the visitor's experience. They helped persuade me that the Museum of Fine Arts has the richest collection I've seen in many years.
On leaving the Beck, you get another slap in the face. The blast of heat is only part of the shock. There is also the abrupt transition from the visual to the physical, from the sphere of retinal experience to a world where eye and brain are but two organs in a wholly constituted body.
This is what an art museum is supposed to do, you might say: create a space ruled by the sense of sight. But to become aware of this specialized function is to see that Moneo's building is part of the general fragmentation of culture after all. And this awareness extends to the urban context. Like the Beck, the great majority of our buildings are dedicated to the creation of visual effects. In this sense, the Beck symbolizes architecture's role in the detachment of the eye from the rest of nature.
The interesting thing about fundamentalists is the many fundamentals that their thinking does not take into account. Architecture's obedience to the eye is a relatively recent phenomenon in the history of building. The ancient Mediterranean sculptures that greet visitors to the Beck building served a religious function. Greek sculpture, for example, was attached to the temple, which itself derived its meaning and value from the sacred earth site on which it stood. Differentiation -- into bodies, selves, disciplines, sites and cities -- was seen by the Greeks as a dreadful if necessary part of life. From it grew tragic theater.
The differentiation of space into the modern art museum is also wonderful and terrible. For the Greeks, art as well as religion supplied the connective tissue that prevents differentiation from pulling human life to pieces. For us, art is a thing apart. In a modern democracy, it is neither possible nor desirable to return to the Greek model. But it is possible to imagine how, working within the logic of art, the Beck Building might have articulated the tragic as well as the triumphal dimension of the modern art museum.
The museum's collection is traditionally organized by region, chronology and school. Overall, it traces a narrative of progressive abstraction, from funerary sculpture, created for the body and the earth, to the thin, gorgeous lines of an Agnes Martin painting and spare geometric shapes of the museum's sculpture garden, created in 1986 by Isamu Noguchi. Along the way, we pass through the Italian Renaissance and the modern transition from the sacred to the secular, from the content-laden form of the religious icon to the illusionary device of single-point perspective.
The museum's architecture tells a similar story. The Beaux Arts building is an abstraction of classical architecture. The Mies expansion pushes neoclassicism to the extreme reduction of glass and steel. The Moneo building, while clad in stone, recapitulates the Miesian ethic of formal reduction and spatial clarity. Even the stone -- a real material that provides the Beck's formal decoration -- represents the earth in abstract form. The story reaches a climax with "The Inner Light," an installation of artificial light created expressly for the Beck by James Turrell. Progressing from earth to sky, physical to ethereal, the story is fundamentally religious in nature, a ritual procession in the temple of art.
The story is still unfolding. The contemporary informational city is an ethereal zone, held aloft by streams of 0's and 1's generated by rapid electronic impulses. For now, however, its citizens still dwell in bodies, sealed buildings and cars, and these continue to create an invisible but highly unethereal substance: greenhouse gases.
Houston is the capital of the oil economy. That economy built the city, defined its shape and makes it habitable. Even the Museum of Fine Arts reminds us of the city's dependence on energy. Across the street from the Beck stands a second new building -- a shadow Beck -- which houses the museum's air-conditioning system and a parking garage. Unfortunately, the shadow Beck has been designed to conceal this infrastructure. It would have been better had Moneo chosen to aestheticize it.
The Museum of Fine Arts has a nice trove of sculptures by Jean Tinguely, including "La Bascule VII," a work from 1967. It is pictured in the museum's guide book, along with a bold-face quotation from the artist, "All machines are art." This is a fundamental modern tenet, one of the founding beliefs of New York's Museum of Modern Art. If Moneo's thinking were sufficiently elastic to incorporate this idea, the shadow Beck might have gained equal standing with its twin. This could have been achieved in four easy steps: eliminate the walls; install solar panels on the roof (an inverse of the Beck's lanterns); light up the interior (Turrell could have been turned loose on this); and declare the shadow Beck a new museum acquisition -- "Air-Conditioning, With Cars."
Peter Eisenman once said the function of architecture is to "problematize" things. That is partly true in the case of the Beck. It is possible to give the building high marks and still come away thinking that something is wrong. Has one toured the wrong building? Perhaps it is a mistake to think of the Beck's concrete walls as its structure. Its deeper structure may lie in the shadow building across the street. Without cars, the museum would be inaccessible. Without air-conditioning, it would be uninhabitable. Compared with this infrastructure, the Beck's structure is almost incidental.
ART museums traditionally put a fine gloss over the dark side of baron robbery. I see no reason to disparage this civilized practice. But the context of culture has changed dramatically in the quarter century since the Mies expansion was completed. Clients didn't habitually conduct global searches for architects. Before moon landings and satellite photography, the north pole seemed far, far away. It required a stretch to see any connection between an air-conditioning system in Houston and an ecological catastrophe on the polar extremities. Now, it takes a stretch to overlook one.
The ice caps were once purely natural phenomena. Now they are cultural phenomena as well, the product of an evolving global operating system that has drawn together the producers and consumers of buildings and cars to create what an art historian might reasonably describe as the most ambitious earthwork of historical time. Perhaps the time has come to uncreate this masterpiece. This will require a global effort, too. Cultural institutions have a pivotal role to play in it. We look to them for self-awareness and for traction -- for signs that the operating system can receive sufficient feedback to avoid the self-destructive explosive fate Tinguely sometimes planned for his exploding mechanical sculptures.
Our Shadow Beck would not reduce oil consumption by one drop. But it could work powerfully on the level of metaphor, the plane on which art museums and their contents communicate. Like Tinguely's sculptures, the Beck Building might have spoken metaphorically about its own civilization. I think it would say: "Houston, we have a problem."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
Escaping Leases Made By Sponsors

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO

 BODY:
LAST May, a Federal Appeals Court in Manhattan rendered a decision that could save some co-ops and condominiums hundreds of thousands of dollars, real estate experts say. The decision -- based on a 1980 federal law enacted to protect shareholders and unit owners from sponsors who give themselves lucrative, long-term leases on building amenities at the time of conversion -- has expanded a co-op's or condominium's ability to end such leases without the consent of the sponsor.
"What this means is that after 20 years, the Condominium and Cooperative Conversion Protection and Abuse Relief Act is still alive and well," said Walter D. Goldsmith, a Manhattan co-op lawyer who has brought several lawsuits under the act. "And there are still plenty of buildings around that can benefit from it." 
 Mr. Goldsmith said that although the act was passed by Congress 20 years ago, there had been relatively few cases litigated under its provisions. However, he said, co-ops and condominiums that stand to benefit from the law -- typically, those with garage or laundry-room spaces that are tied up in long-term leases with the original sponsor or his successor -- stand to benefit significantly.
"If a lease can be recaptured from a sponsor, that would result in a substantial financial benefit to the building," Mr. Goldsmith said, explaining that many garage and laundry room leases negotiated at the time of the conversion had terms extremely favorable to the sponsor. "These leases often go on for 50 or even 100 years. You could be talking about millions of dollars."
Scott E. Mollen, a Manhattan lawyer who wrote about the issue in the New York Law Journal earlier this month, said that the Condominium and Cooperative Conversion Protection and Abuse Relief Act was enacted by Congress in response to concerns that elderly residents who were buying co-ops and condominiums in retirement communities were being taken advantage of by sponsors.
"A number of years ago, when conversions were the hottest thing around, it became fairly common for sponsors to be very aggressive in carving out what they thought would be lucrative, long-term economic opportunities," Mr. Mollen said. "In a nutshell, they were giving themselves sweetheart leases on commercial retail space and parking facilities in the building at a time when they were still in control of the board."
The abuse relief act enabled co-op corporations and condominium associations to end such leases unilaterally by filing an action against sponsors who had negotiated long-term leases for amenities that were deemed to be "property serving the shareholders or unit owners," Mr. Mollen said, typically, garages and laundry rooms.
One catch in the law, Mr. Mollen added, was that the notice of termination of the lease must be brought within a specific f time.
"There is a two-year window within which the lease must be terminated," he said, explaining that the two-year time period began either when the sponsor relinquished control over the affairs of the building or when the sponsor's ownership of units in the building dropped to 25 percent or less, whichever occurred first.
Since most conversions in New York took place in the late 1970's and early 1980's, Mr. Mollen said, and since state law required a sponsor to relinquish control of a co-op or condominium's board of directors no more than five years after the conversion, co-op and condominium boards could reasonably believe that the two-year window had closed many years ago -- that is, two years after the sponsor relinquished control of the board.
In the case recently decided by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit and brought by a co-op at 136 East 56th Street, the court ruled that a sponsor could still be deemed to be in control of the building for purposes of triggering the two-year window under the act even after relinquishing apparent control of the board.
"The court found that even after the election of an independent board in 1988, the sponsor retained veto powers that allowed it to exercise control over the building," Mr. Mollen said, referring to a provision in the co-op's governing documents that gave the sponsor the right to veto any change in the co-op's certificate of incorporation or bylaws as long as he owned even one share in the co-op.
What that means, Mr. Mollen said, is that in buildings where a sponsor still owns more than 25 percent of the units -- and where the sponsor has a long-term lease for a laundry room or garage space -- there is a possibility that the two-year time period for ending the lease has not yet been triggered if the sponsor has retained some measure of control over the building.
" You have a number of older buildings where the relationship between the board members and the original sponsor has remained harmonious," he said. "And in such situations, the board may fail to consider hiring independent counsel to determine whether they have any potential rights with respect to lucrative, long-term leases held by the sponsor. In short, there are boards out there that have been lulled into sleeping on their rights."
Ted Poretz, the Manhattan lawyer who successfully represented the co-op at 136 East 56th Street, agreed.
"Most co-op boards and managers don't even know this law exists," Mr. Poretz said. "And those who do probably think that the window closed two years after the sponsor gave up control of the board."
In fact, he said, any co-op or condominium board that has a laundry room or parking garage tied up in a long-term lease with a sponsor -- or even a third party who bought such a lease from the sponsor -- should check their governing documents to determine whether the sponsor has retained control in the building.
For example, he said, if a building's certificate of incorporation or bylaws contains a provision requiring a unanimous vote or even an 80 percent or 90 percent supermajority of votes to change the bylaws, certificate of incorporation or proprietary lease, it is possible that a sponsor who still owns more than 25 percent of units in the building could be deemed to still have control over the building for purposes of the act.
"It's highly likely that there are provisions like these in many governing documents," Mr. Poretz said. "These are common bundles of protection that sponsors give themselves."
And if that is the case, he said, then the triggering of the two-year window for ending a sponsor's lease begins when the sponsor's ownership of units in the building drops to 25 percent. "And there are lots of buildings out there that are only now approaching 75 percent of ownership by tenant-shareholders or unit owners," Mr. Poretz said, adding that once the two-year window was open, it was not even necessary for the co-op or condominium to prove that a long-term lease was unconscionable or unfair.
"All you have to prove is that the sponsor essentially negotiated the terms of the lease with himself," Mr. Poretz said. "And since the sponsor is in control of the building at the time of the conversion, that's something that's usually easy to prove."

HEADLINE: Chasing Ever-Changing American Dream

BYLINE: By JOAN SWIRSKY

 BODY:
IN 1983, Jozsef Domeny bought a one-way ticket from communist Hungary to capitalist West Germany. The long road that he followed has led him, 17 years later, to Floral Park and a successful career as a builder.
At the time, Hungary allowed its citizens to buy only round-trip tickets, banning one-way trips to discourage defections. Mr. Domeny, who prefers to be called Joe, hoped that the authorities would not notice that he was never coming back, but he was promptly summoned by the Budapest police, "and I thought, 'That's it, it's all over,' " he said. 
 But the police only wanted to question him about payments he had received as an extra on television and in the movies.
Mr. Domeny's trip, from Budapest to Munich, was fraught with fear and anxiety. Mr. Domeny, a 24-year-old subway motorman who was divorced, agonized over leaving his 4-year-old son, Gabor, and his year-old daughter, Brigitte, and he was terrified that the border guards would check his papers and return him to Hungary, where he faced certain imprisonment.
"I was praying I wouldn't get caught," Mr. Domeny said in an interview, and praying did not come easily to a man whose family members had been forbidden to practice their Catholicism when they moved to Budapest 15 years earlier.
In West Germany, Mr. Domeny was granted refugee status, and he stayed for 11 months, "but they wouldn't let me get a work permit for two years," he said. Relying on the four years of German he had studied in school, he found work nevertheless, installing blinds and awnings on houses.
When he learned that the International Rescue Committee would help him leave Germany for South Africa, Australia, Canada or the United States, he said, the choice was easy: "Two were too far, one was too north, and I always used to hear in Hungary that America was the place of dreams where you could work hard and buy a house."
In 1984, the German government paid his air fare to New York, and the rescue committee paid three weeks' rent in a run-down hotel on 35th Street and Fifth Avenue and gave him a small amount of cash. With only $65 in his pocket and a bag of clothing, and unable to speak a word of English, "I was in bad shape, but I was free," he said.
"I didn't get on a subway for three days because I was scared of the homeless people," he said, but he was put in touch with a Hungarian bookstore on 82nd Street and Second Avenue. To save money, he walked the 50 blocks there every day, discovering a thriving Hungarian community that introduced him to a Sunday soccer league and a church, where he found his first work in construction.
"It was great to work," Mr. Domeny said, "but when my three weeks was up at the hotel, the I.R.C. gave me $100 and cab fare to Flushing. That's where I found the only room I could afford."
Alas, his boss went back to Hungary and his job was short-lived. But Mr. Domeny found work in a carwash.
"It was 7 days a week, 12 hours a day, for $3.50 plus tips," he said. But after a couple of weeks, his fierce work ethic paid off: he was offered the opportunity to become a foreman, a job that he held for two years and that ultimately allowed him to buy a used car.
"It was the first car I ever owned," he said, a broad smile betraying the pride he still feels about the purchase, a 1973 Buick Regal. That allowed him to travel to Bay Shore to supervise the owner's other carwash.
Then the carwash closed, and Mr. Domeny found work as an apprentice to a window installer. His boss, once again, was impressed by Mr. Domeny's hard work and offered him the chance to work by himself. But again, the job fell through, this time when Home Depot arrived on Long Island, driving many small home repair companies out of the market.
"At that time," explained Mr. Domeny, now 41, "I was married again, and it was during the gulf war. Gas prices were high and jobs were short. My wife was working as a teacher and I was staying home with our new baby, Eric, but I didn't like that. I decided to put ads in the Yellow Pages to start my own construction business."
The business started to take off but the marriage fizzled.
"It was a tough time for him," said his new wife, Dr. Lori Reeve Domeny, 35; they were married last year. "For a Central European man, it wasn't easy reversing traditional roles."
Dr. Domeny, who was also previously married, teaches psychology at Queens College and is a psychotherapist at a number of geriatric centers.
She said that when Mr. Domeny's marriage broke up, he became depressed. "But then one day he woke up and decided to get in shape" with rowing exercises at the Y.M.C.A. in Bellerose, where she teaches aerobics.
"That was it," she said of her instant attraction to Mr. Domeny.
But Mr. Domeny, who describes himself as shy, said it took him several weeks to ask her out. Finally he approached her, saying, "You have to come out for pizza with me because last night I drove my van into my garage door just thinking about you.
"The dent is still there," he added.
At first, Mr. Domeny's solo business venture. "I only made enough to get by," he said.
His first customer, a Great Neck resident who asked him to install an air-conditioner, was pleased with the work and hired Mr. Domeny to replace his roof and paint the inside and outside of his house.
"I just about broke even on that job," he said, "but from there it was word of mouth to people in Forest Hills, Whitestone and all over Long Island. What I learned is that owning your own business is a lot of struggling, but it's a good way to be independent. It's better than working for someone else."
Today, Mr. Domeny, who has permanent-resident status and plans to become a citizen soon, is the owner of Precision Master Inc. and says he has no need to advertise. He prefers to hire workers from Europe "because they care a lot about the work and how it comes out."
Mr. Domeny, whose parents are retired bus drivers in Hungary, has never been back, but he has stayed in touch with them and with his children, once meeting his son Gabor in Austria "because Hungary was still communist at the time," he said. Gabor, now 21, is visiting from Hungary to learn the construction business from his father.
Mr. Domeny said he applied the same principles to business that he did to learning English.
"I never took a course in English but I listened to the way people were speaking the language and I copied them," he said. "The same thing with building. No one ever explained to me what to do, but I watched what they were doing and I learned."
The Domenys are still pursuing their goals: to buy a home and have a family.
"But today the 'American dream' is not what I heard about in Hungary," he said. "That was when the husband works and the wife stays home and takes care of the kids. Today, we both have to work like crazy. The dream has changed."
Dr. Domeny expressed the couple's ambivalence: "We can't decide if we should save for a house, or travel and eat out. We've loved our trips -- to the Bahamas, Mexico, Florida, Aruba and Hawaii."
What advice does Mr. Domeny have for other immigrants who come to this country nearly penniless, unable to speak English and unsure of the future?
"Learn English and work hard," he said. "Find a job and keep it and work your way up. You have all the opportunities, if you're an American, to make something of yourself."
 
A Diverse Island
This series looks beyond the stereotypes that sometimes taint relations between immigrants and native Long Islanders, examining immigrants' lives and how they are being woven -- or not -- into the social and economic fabric. Previous articles described the aspirations of Muslims on the Island, a Korean nail salon owner and her American-raised son, a Colombian landscaping entrepreneur, an Indian liquor store owner and a Trinidadian woman who manages a convenience store.

HEADLINE: For Central Islip, a Renaissance

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN

DATELINE: CENTRAL ISLIP

 BODY:
THIRTY years ago, motorists driving north on Carleton Avenue past Central Islip State Hospital would have seen vacant and vandalized red-brick buildings and just up the street, abandoned and burned-out houses.
Now, drivers along this same stretch of road see a new gleaming white federal courthouse, a brick county court complex and just up the road, a new shopping center that's taking shape. 
 "I have seen changes in Central Islip that are unbelievable," said Judge Leonard Wexler of United States District Court, who acted as liaison in the construction of the new federal building. "Just across the street and a little north of here, they are putting in a large shopping center with a multiplex cinema. They are also renovating an old hospital and making it into an office building. Other new office buildings have gone up, and investors are buying up property around here and making improvements. A tremendous change has come over the area."
Nancy Manfredonia, the executive director of the Central Islip Civic Council, said the the federal courthouse, along with the adjacent Suffolk County court complex, the new stadium where the Long Island Ducks play and the new movie theater, has helped to turn Central Islip around.
"I don't think Central Islip ever expected to be a tourist attraction, but we sure are," she said. "The Long Island Ducks have made a big splash and have been very successful. Almost all its games were sold out. And people have been dying for a local movie theater. Now we won't have to go to Commack, Patchogue or Smithtown."
Much of this and other new development is happening on what had been the 788-acre site of the Central Islip State Hospital, which at its peak in the 1950's had as many as 10,000 patients. The 107-year-old hospital had been the lifeblood of the community, but after decades of deinstitutionalization, by 1994 the hospital had only 200 patients. The state has kept a core of about 100 acres at Central Islip, and as other psychiatric hospitals nearby were closed, it transferred patients here.
After the state began closing hospital buildings in the mid-1960's, it transferred 376 acres to the Town of Islip as part of an urban renewal project in 1977. Five years later, the town sold 356 acres to the New York Institute of Technology, which has recycled two dozen of the smaller hospital buildings for its use. Over the years, the institute has bought more hospital property from the state, for a total of 506 acres.
Three years ago, Touro College in Manhattan bought another 13 acres from the state for $1.5 million and plans to relocate its law school, now in Huntington. to the new site by 2002.
"I've been watching Central Islip for the last five or six years, and it's amazing what's going on there," the school's dean, Howard Glickstein, said. "There promises to be a lot more commercial development. It's inevitable that with more employees and students in the area, the community is going to need more shops and restaurants."
Judge Wexler estimated that 1,000 people a day will come to the federal courthouse. once the building is fully staffed. The $190 million, 850,000-square-foot-building, designed by Richard Meier & Partners, working with the Spector Group of North Hills, is one of the largest courthouses in the nation. Although the first trial was held there last month, Judge Wexler said the United States attorney's offices would not move from Hauppauge and Garden City until mid-October. The 11-story building will be dedicated Oct. 16.
This is the first time the Federal government has owned its own courthouse on Long Island, and all federal courts will be consolidated here from rented space in Westbury, Hauppauge and Uniondale.
Walking through the new courthouse, the judge showed off the woodwork in the courtrooms, birch in one and cherry in others. "Notice how the grain flows in each piece of wood so that it matches up, just as it came from the tree," he said. "It looks expensive, but it really isn't. Wood is wood -- it's just what you do with it."
As Judge Wexler walked into the ninth-floor hallway, he stopped and looked out the windows on either side. "This is my favorite spot in the building," he said. "Looking to the north you can see a good amount of Long Island. Looking to the south, you can see Fire Island, the Great South Bay, Robert Moses bridge, the lighthouse and the ocean."
He said that with the help of his wife, Barbara, an interior designer and painter, he and the General Services Administration selected Mr. Meier as the architect.
The building received mixed reviews from some lawyers who visited last month. Jonathan Sinnreich of Hauppauge called it a monstrosity. "I think it's ugly and totally out of context," he said. "It's sterile and completely inappropriate."
JoAnn Bodmer of Hauppauge said: "From the beach, it sticks out like a sore thumb.'. I was hoping that when you go inside there would be something embracing about it, something that would give it a warm and fuzzy feeling. But it didn't happen. It's sterile and cold."
Lisa Green, a spokeswoman for the Meier firm in Manhattan, disagreed with the critics. "The architecture clearly expresses the importance and dignity of the judicial branch," she said, "while at the same time being a welcoming and open building for both visitors and those who work there daily."
Although the courthouse may be the most visible symbol of the new Central Islip, other more mundane buildings may take on more importance for the people who live and work here. Jules Demchick, the president of the J. D. Carlisle Development Corporation of Manhattan, which is building the shopping center, to be called the Town Center of Central Islip, north of the courthouse, said, "We saw that a lot of things were going to happen at that one site, and we felt it was a good place for a shopping center."
King Kullen and the 20-screen, 4,400-seat multiplex will serve as the center's anchors, he said, and there will be as many as six restaurants, a video store, a pharmacy and an electronics store.
Martin R. Cantor, a consultant to the Central Islip Main Street Alliance, sees a bright economic future for the area. "The movie theater is planning on one million ticket purchases a year from a 12 1/2-mile radius," he said, "and the Long Island Ducks intend to bring in an average of 357,000 people. So from those two venues, you will bring in 1.4 million people who will hopefully spend money while they are here."
Mr. Demchick said his company was negotiating to buy property near the federal courthouse to build a hotel with a maximum of 225 rooms.
It may be facing some competition. Russell Mohr, the director of sales and leasing for Benjamin Development in Garden City, said that his company was negotiating with two hotel chains to open a seven-story, 140-room hotel with three restaurants on a nine-acre site at Courthouse Drive and Carleton Avenue. The plans would require town approval.
The hotel site is part of a 52-acre parcel a Benjamin subsidiary, the Arlen Contracting Corporation, bought from the state for $2.2 million last February. Located just north of the Cohalan court complex and adjacent to the ballpark, it includes six buildings from the psychiatric hospital, totaling 900,000 square feet.
One of the buildings, the former medical and surgical building on 11 acres on Carleton Avenue, is being renovated as a 175,000-square-foot office building, the Courthouse Corporate Center. Mr. Mohr said the building would be ready in the first quarter of 2001.
The hospital building Arlen is renovating is within a 1.6-square-mile economic development zone created to provide tax incentives to lure businesses to Central Islip and to encourage those there to expand. "The incentives involve sales taxes, income taxes, franchise tax credits and rebates," said William G. Mannix, the director of economic development for the Town of Islip.
In the previously blighted residential area north of the former hospital grounds, the town and private investors in recent years built single-family homes on the west side of Carleton Avenue, known as College Woods, and town houses on the other side in a development called Park Row.
Kenneth Parker, a private investigator who moved to Park Row two years ago, said he welcomed the federal courthouse and the development. "It will increase real estate prices and bring in more professionals here," he said. "This is becoming the jewel of Long Island."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 1; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1850 words

HEADLINE: High-Tech High School

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN KILEY

 BODY:
THE latest high-tech enterprise in Stamford doesn't have anything to do with venture capitalists or initial public offerings. But given the urgency with which Stamford went about creating the Academy of Information Technology, it is clear the city sees its new high school as a major investment. And if it delivers on its promises, the school could become a model to emulate statewide.
On Sept. 5, after just a year of preparation and planning, the academy opened its doors for the first time, admitting about 225 of the approximately 300 students who had sought admission. 
 It is the first high school in the state where the mission is to train students in information technology, the high-tech field that encompasses the Internet. The logic of the move was obvious. After all, the school is located in an area that has hundreds of high-tech companies and not enough workers to run them. The Connecticut Internet Association of Stamford estimates that one out of four high-tech jobs remain unfilled in the state. If anything, it is a wonder that the creation of such a school took so long.
"A.I.T. is unique and it's the first in the state to do something like this," said Tom Murphy, spokesman for the state Department of Education. "Connecticut schools are moving in the direction of providing more technology courses, but it's not as structured as A.I.T., it's more ad hoc."
Staples High School in Westport, for example, uses technology to teach and offers technology electives, such as programming. But its emphasis isn't on training people in technology, said Lynne Shain, assistant superintendent of curriculum and staff development. "We're not teaching technological skills to stand alone."
The academy, and its 15 classrooms, is located in the Rippowam Center, Stamford's magnet middle school. The students will have access to desktop and laptop equipment, where they can learn about computer graphics, Web design, programming and database and network administration. Students will design Web sites, build computers and computer networks and learn how to program. Students will have mentors from local high-tech companies and will be offered internships.
"It's a great way to get students started on a technology training track," said Terri Kochersperger, a senior vice president at Priceline.com of Stamford. "Why wait until they get to college?"
And some companies are willing to hire students with high-tech training before they even get to college. Barry Monies, president of Computronix, a network service provider in Stamford, said he might hire, fresh out of school, academy graduates who have advanced network training.
"It's a talent pool for us," he said. "I wish something like this was here when I was going to school."
The idea for the academy began last fall, when Anthony Mazzullo, superintendent of Stamford schools, was chatting with William Schwab, president of Norwalk Community College, about a possible joint project that would involve information technology.
After more discussion, between themselves and with others, including business people, politicians and educators, they came up with the idea to develop a high school that would not only integrate technology into teaching, but also offer heavy-duty technology courses. "This will hopefully help narrow the digital divide," Mr. Schwab said.
As with many high-tech startups, it's a race to turn concepts into tangible items, because in these Internet days, time is compressed. What used to take a year, now takes three months. So the luxury of waiting and debating a new concept is gone. Christine Casey, assistant superintendent of Stamford schools, seemed amenable to this approach. Like a hot startup selling to investors, she and her supporters were able to cut through the "political fog," as one supporter put it, and get the project approved in warp speed.
What makes it even more amazing is that it was a collaborative effort among community groups and businesses. "We're blurring the lines" Dr. Casey said. That isn't easy because the barriers dividing business and education tend to be rigid, she added. But as one colleague commented, "Chris doesn't know the meaning of 'no'."
The blurring is happening on many levels. Curriculum design was moving solely out of the hands of educators. The entire process of developing a curriculum, which at times can be an insular exercise, Dr. Casey said, was created with the help of local high-tech business leaders, Norwalk Community College, Stamford administrators and teachers.
"We went after a select number of small companies, because we needed help in developing the curriculum and getting internships that were meaningful," said Harry Orlick, chairman of the school's advisory board and a retired I.B.M. executive. "Plus we needed some teaching support from the outside."
While the initial focus will be on providing a high school education, with an emphasis on technology, Dr. Casey and others envision opening the academy to the public. By next year, the school will be able to accommodate more people when the middle school moves to another building. "There is a huge need to provide adult education in the community," she said.
Some involved with the project didn't think the school would get beyond the planning stage, mostly because there was no real model to convince people that it would work. "We pounded out the numbers around January and it was about a $1 million project, at the time, and I thought that would be the end of it," said John Lindquist, director of information technology for Stamford. "There was no real model, and they said, 'Let's do it.' "
Not having a template seemed a blessing, Dr. Casey said, because it may have forced decision-makers to become visionaries. "We had a vision to provide a place that would give the kids the opportunities to take the technology they already know and build upon it," she said. "Why start them on a keyboard learning to type when they already know how to build a Web site?"
That's an understatement. Some academy students are running PC repair shops out of their basements and taking high-level networking courses at the school. "It's about 50-50 in terms of their level of knowledge," said Jeanne Lauer, who left Westhill High School to teach a training program designed by Cisco Systems, a networking company in San Jose, Calif. at the academy. "Some have no knowledge, while others have tried to learn on their own, while others are taking the high-level Cisco networking course."
Although there were some technically savvy candidates that applied to the academy, they didn't have an advantage over those who had only a smattering of tech know-how. The academy considered all students, regardless of their school performance. The entrance requirements consisted of a 250-word essay explaining their interest in technology and a personal interview.
Henry Jones, student recruiter and consultant on the project, who has spent the bulk of his career developing youth programs, interviewed hundreds of students. "Many of these kids want to own their own businesses and be in charge of their own destiny," he said.
Some will realize it earlier than others. Nigel Johnson and James Simon, both 17 and seniors at the school, run a business called PC Junkies, a PC problem-solving enterprise, out of Mr. Johnson's basement. In addition, they are halfway through the first level of Cisco System's online networking training course.
"If they complete the first level of training, these kids could be making $50,000 to $70,000 right out of school," said Michael Pensiero, applications support manager for the city's information technology department.
The money is alluring, but the advanced placement seniors insist that isn't the only draw. "It's not really the money, but if you have to do something you might as well like it," Mr. Johnson said.
"Yeah," Mr. Simon added, "I didn't find out about what type of salary I could make until I was accepted at A.I.T."
As seniors, they already have all but one English course to meet graduation requirements, and they plan to load up on technology electives, they said. Mr. Simon is taking college-level English, which is being taught at the Academy by Norwalk Community College teachers and can be applied toward college credit or toward the academy's five-year high school and associate's degree program with the college.
They also have big plans for building the school's Web site, envisioning such things as a school newspaper, listings of internships, student of the month and student portfolios. And if they have time, both students may continue working throughout the school year. They were among the dozen summer interns hired by Stamford's information technology department to trouble-shoot and update computers in the city's 19 schools.
Some might argue that these teenagers are spreading themselves too thin, while others say the continuous mental stimulation is healthy. "Every day, you should try to keep feeding the mind," said Johnnye Mae Britt, grandmother and legal guardian of two of the academy's students.
Then there are students like Peter Telesco Jr., 14, a ninth grader at the academy. According to his father, Peter, his son has been an under performer. "It's very unusual, that he's motivated to go to school," Mr. Telesco said. "He's a bright kid, but if he loses interest, forget it."
But Peter is crazy about computers and his father hopes the academy can leverage that interest. "He and his friend Mike have a mock business, and they're on that computer all day and all night," Mr. Telesco said. "Now that he's working with computers, he might like science and other subjects."
Lt. Gov. Jodi Rell, who is responsible for developing a plan to modernize Connecticut schools and libraries, is also looking for that hook. After touring the state for four months last year, she said, "Not every school was wired, and not every school has access to Internet, and not all teachers are trained."
This view is supported by the Progressive Policy Institute, a Washington, D.C.-based research and policy maker, which ranked the 50 states in terms of economic indicators and overall readiness to compete in the new economy. Connecticut ranked fifth in economic indicators, but the state's schools ranked 42nd in their preparedness in using technology to teach.
To change this, the state recently earmarked $32 million to connect all classrooms to the Internet over the next few years and digitize the state's libraries. Other initiative also include encouraging businesses, via tax breaks, to donate used computers that are less than two years old.
Improving schools on this level, can't happen soon enough. With unemployment hovering at around 2 percent and the state becoming a home to more high-tech companies, businesses need more skilled labor, said Mark Pruner, president of the Connecticut Internet Association and Web Counsel, an interactive market agency for the legal community. "So what it comes down to is redefining education -- this is something that has to be done," he said.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 12; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk
