SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3339 words

HEADLINE: A High-Tech Vision Lifts Fidelity

BYLINE: By DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
CROSS HAIRS are trained on the green-and-yellow home page of DLJ Direct, the online brokerage firm. Literally. It is a Tuesday in late August at the new Fidelity Center for Applied Technology here, specifically, in a "usability" lab of the "human interface design department." This is where Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund manager, does some of its most important research and reconnaissance.
Today, Dawna Lovett is sitting in what looks like a bland office, with a desk, a lamp, a desktop computer and a window with partly drawn blinds. She is wearing a black headband with a white nodule placed above her left eye. A man with a Ph.D. in engineering psychology peeks over her shoulder. What looks like a Polaroid camera sits on a desk, between Ms. Lovett and the computer. It is actually a high-resolution infrared camera shooting beams of light into one of her eyes as she looks at the Web site. 
 Not to worry. The light simply monitors eyeball movements. Ms. Lovett seems fine.
So does Fidelity. Much has changed since this fund giant lost its aura of invincibility a few years ago. In 1996, Fidelity's top money manager, Jeffrey N. Vinik, led its flagship Magellan fund to the bottom tier of industry rankings after a disastrous bet on bonds, and few of Fidelity's other funds beat the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. Edward Crosby Johnson III, the company's longtime chief executive, was so stung by the headline "Has Fidelity Lost It?" on a cover of Fortune magazine in 1997, that he largely stopped speaking to the press.
A maelstrom of mergers and acquisitions, meanwhile, has transformed the financial services industry. But Fidelity has kept to a more insular path, partly by using a Japanese management philosophy, known as kaizen and followed by Mr. Johnson, that emphasizes continuous improvement and retooling from within.
One would be hard-pressed to call the strategy anything but a success. This year, revenue is growing at a robust 41 percent rate, and profits more than doubled in the first half of 2000, compared with the corresponding period of 1999. Assets under management grew 25 percent last year; the firm now manages a staggering $1 trillion and is custodian to an additional $608 billion.
Controlled by Mr. Johnson and his family, the privately held Fidelity manages the most retail and retirement mutual fund assets, has the most online brokerage customer accounts and runs the largest fund supermarket, where it sells its competitors' brands alongside its own. Fidelity also has a controlling stake in Colt Telecommunications, a $22 billion provider of local phone service in Paris and Frankfurt; runs the 426-room Seaport Hotel in Boston, and owns BostonCoach, a limousine service.
But what is most striking about Fidelity is its drive to mesh next-generation technology with customer service. If its funds do not shoot out the lights, as they once did, they perform decently now. And for a company entrenched in the retirement market, consistency and service are emphasized over top-tier performance.
"Performance continues to be extremely important," said Tracey Esherick, the Fidelity executive in charge of Powerstreet, the company's online brokerage firm. "But how you service a relationship is critical."
Technology workers now outnumber Fidelity fund managers, analysts and traders by more than 18 to 1. Spending on technology passed $1.5 billion last year -- far beyond the totals for many competitors.
So what is the new Fidelity seeking behind those infrared lights?
 
The Technology
Pixels, Pagers
And Customers
"Look at every pixel on the Web page as if it were a valuable piece of Boston real estate," Steve Elterich, the chief of Fidelity's e-business operations, recalled Mr. Johnson once instructing him.
The technology center, known as FCAT (and pronounced F-Cat) is not an operation that one might expect to find at an asset management firm. Built last year, it is a multipurpose laboratory and workshop, where Fidelity tests and demonstrates next-generation technologies. There are Palm Pilots set up for online trading. There are brokerage-ready pagers and cell phones of all shapes and sizes. There are even scanners that identify a user by his eyeballs or the shape of his head.
"It's an in-house think tank related to technology," said Robert L. Reynolds, who was appointed Fidelity's chief operating officer in June. "It's looking for new applications, but it's also a place where technology people around Fidelity can get together."
All manner of research is taking place -- there is even a prototype system to let its legion of 5,000 phone representatives peek onto the home computer screen of a customer if he or she asks for help. But the depth to which Fidelity seeks to understand its customers is most apparent in the usability lab.
The window with the Venetian blinds is actually a one-way mirror. On the other side is an observation room. It has seven monitors, lighted buttons, various levers and knobs, a seven-foot-high stack of audio-visual equipment, several videocassette recorders, a DVD player and some microphones.
While one of the monitors shows an image of DLJ Direct, the online brokerage firm owned by Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, another shows how Ms. Lovett, a Fidelity employee, is reading an article on Fidelity.com. Usually, the test subject would be a volunteer from Fidelity's customer base, but Ms. Lovett is filling in while a reporter visits.
Another monitor shows the Web page that Ms. Lovett is reading, but with a digital target superimposed and flickering across the screen.
The cross hairs show where Ms. Lovett is looking at any particular moment. A third monitor in the room displays an outsized blowup of her eye, tracking the exact pixels that she is viewing. The idea is to fine-tune the Web site to eliminate every wasteful click.
That level of usability testing "is incredibly, exceedingly rare," said Jakob Nielsen, a former Sun Microsystems engineer and founder of the Nielsen Norman Group, a Silicon Valley firm that consults with companies on Web site design. Mr. Nielsen said that while usability testing was common in many industries, he had heard of eye-tracking tests being conducted only at universities like Stanford, for Internet-related research, and by the Navy and a few technology companies.
"There's no doubt it pays off dramatically, particularly for a site where people do a huge amount of transactions," Mr. Nielsen said. "Errors are a disaster for that type of system. The return on the investment is so huge that you can't even discuss the cost of building a lab. It's trivial."
Fidelity's usability labs -- there are two at FCAT -- have produced thousands of hours of videotape that will be analyzed.
"We're embarking on some major redesigns of our site," Mr. Elterich said. "That's really been as a result of feedback we've gotten out of bringing in customers and having them interact with our site, and then trying and experimenting with different navigation approaches."
Thomas S. Tullis -- the man with the Ph.D. in engineering psychology -- is a Fidelity vice president who is in charge of the 14-person human interface design department. Fidelity built its first lab back in 1993, he said, but he has been in the field of usability testing since its infancy -- his dissertation, at Rice University, was on the layouts of computer screens. He also helped set up a usability lab at Bell Laboratories 20 years ago.
"Of course, back then, we were doing usability testing of mainframe screens," he said. "It was very different from what we do now."
Fidelity.com is a tightly woven collection of dozens of subsites, from Powerstreet to NetBenefits, which is used by Fidelity's retirement plan customers. Mr. Tullis is trying to make the site's total of 30,000 pages as easy to navigate as possible -- but he is also watching Fidelity's competition closely.
A monitor near Ms. Lovett is flashing images of Web sites run by various rivals: DLJ Direct, Prudential, E*Trade, Scottrade. These are recordings of previous tests, and the cross hairs are sweeping over each page.
"We have to follow Microsoft, we have to follow Intuit, we have to follow Schwab, we have to follow Citicorp," said Ms. Esherick, the head of Powerstreet. "Almost everybody's a competitor."
Ms. Esherick said that she had even been watching how Lands' End and Neiman Marcus were using instant messaging online to communicate with their customers, and that Fidelity planned to start a similar, pilot program in a few weeks.
It also plans to open a third lab for more infrared eyeball-testing, on cell phones, pagers and the like. "It's really a different environment," Ms. Esherick said of wireless devices. "How big is the screen for trading? Is it big enough for an active trader? How easy is the keyboard for transactions" when you use little two-way pagers?
It is no wonder that Fidelity spends so much on technology: Last year, the total was between $1.5 billion and $2 billion. By contrast, Stilwell Financial, the parent of the rival Janus Capital, spent about $75.8 million on capital expenditures, which includes technology, while Charles Schwab, the big discount and online broker, spent about $126 million on technology.
"It's notable for their size how quickly they've been able to migrate on the Web," Matthew L. Vetto, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, said of Fidelity. "Particularly in areas such as wireless devices, they've been at the forefront."
James Lowell, a former writer for Fidelity-owned publications who now publishes Fidelity Investor, a newsletter that tracks the company, said the big fund companies obviously "had to spend a few hundred million dollars to get online."
"But nobody comes close to Fidelity and its expenditures on its proprietary technological system," he added. "If there is one thing Fidelity has always been intensely paranoid about, it is being left out of the loop."
By most accounts, that fear starts at the top.
 
The Philosophy
Looking East
For Guidance
There is a small conference room on the 25th floor of Fidelity's fund operations office at 1 Federal Street in downtown Boston. Different building, different day in August. The conference room, about the size of two parking spaces, has a table and a few chairs. There is a large drawing pad on an easel at one end, covered with sketches of screen shots from Fidelity's Web site.
At the other end of the room, scrawled on a whiteboard, are a rough pie chart, along with arrows, circles, squiggles and financial lingo like "asset allocation."
Perched above the board is a stern notice: "PROTECT FIDELITY'S INFORMATION. Erase the whiteboard. Take documents with you."
Certainly, Fidelity is a private, secretive company. Even its nondescript headquarters, at 82 Devonshire Street, a few blocks away, whispers where others shout.
That building is around the corner from an office of Brown Brothers Harriman, a private bank, whose entrance is proudly announced by six faux columns and a fluttering crimson-and-white flag emblazoned with the firm's initials. By contrast, one could easily miss the entrance to 82 Devonshire, with only a small plaque that says simply "Fidelity Building."
The quiet approach has everything to do with the Boston family that founded the company 54 years ago and has run it ever since. At the top is Mr. Johnson, 70, the patriarch, who has been in charge since 1977, when his father, Edward Crosby Johnson II, handed the reins to him.
After a recent reshuffling of several top lieutenants, there was a fresh round of speculation on who might be in line to succeed Mr. Johnson: one of his deputies or his eldest daughter, Abigail P. Johnson, who owns the most shares and is an executive in Fidelity's fund management business.
Neither Fidelity nor the Johnsons would say for sure, though the bigger question may be how the company will change after Mr. Johnson is gone. By most accounts, Mr. Johnson, commonly known as Ned, is an idea man who leaves the day-to-day operations to top deputies but does not hesitate to insert himself into any area of his company. His is not the traditional approach to management, at least not in Boston and other parts of the Western world.
"We will embody kaizen -- each of us making small, gradual improvements in how we do our jobs," Mr. Johnson said in a letter to shareholders in Fidelity's 1999 annual report. "Taken together, these small steps can make a big difference in helping us become more productive and cost-efficient."
Japanese management philosophies enjoyed some popularity in the 1980's but were certainly out of fashion when the Asian economy went into free fall in the late 1990's. Still, like his father before him, Mr. Johnson was influenced by Eastern thinking -- he is also a collector of Asian art -- and he has stuck with kaizen (pronounced KI-zen).
"It is the typical Japanese management approach," said Masaaki Imai, who wrote a book called "Kaizen: The Keys to Japan's Competitive Success," published in 1986. Mr. Imai founded a global consulting firm, the Kaizen Institute, which briefly worked with Fidelity a few years back, and during which Mr. Imai gave speeches to a few hundred Fidelity employees.
Mr. Imai recalled that Mr. Johnson became so excited about kaizen that he commissioned a calligrapher to write the Japanese characters for the word and displayed them in his office.
"When we use the term in the manufacturing sector, it means continual improvement as well as involving everyone in the organization," Mr. Imai said. "Kaizen means making better use of the existing resources, and not necessarily using a lot of money."
By contrast, he added, the Western approach is more given to mergers and acquisitions.
Kaizen has characterized Fidelity's quick response to its competitors. Mr. Johnson, for example, did not buy an online brokerage firm; he built one himself. When Schwab popularized the mutual fund supermarket in the mid-1980's, Mr. Johnson countered with his own.
Now there is FCAT, Fidelity's new-economy research group.
Fidelity, of course, has spent heavily on technology for years -- from $8 billion to $10 billion in the last decade, with the pace doubling over the last five years. And for its money, Fidelity has attracted many new accounts and seen a rapid online migration of its existing customers. At the end of the second quarter, nearly 40 percent of Fidelity's brokerage customers were doing business online, up from 32 percent just six months earlier.
In addition, 57 percent of the contacts made by retirement-account customers have come online this year, compared with 16 percent in 1998.
The more technology, the cheaper the cost. Customer telephone calls to representatives cost Fidelity more than $13 each, on average. The average Internet interaction costs Fidelity about $4.
Because of the online migration of its customers, Fidelity has been able to slow down its hiring of phone representatives, who make up nearly one-sixth of the company's work force of more than 31,000. Even though the company added more than eight million new customer accounts last year, the company's phones handled, on average, 3.1 percent fewer calls a day than they did in 1998.
Perhaps most important, Fidelity's customers seem happy when they move online. Last month, Fidelity climbed past Schwab to reach the top of J. D. Power and Associates' ranking of investor satisfaction with online trading services.
The importance of pleasing the online audience is clear enough. From March to August, the number of American households making online trades grew 22 percent, according to the report. And investors are becoming more promiscuous: the percentage using more than one online broker doubled, to 38 percent, in six months, the report said. A chief reason was investor frustration during the stock market shocks of April.
"The industry as a whole, under that type of duress, achieved much lower levels of satisfaction over all," said Nancy Salk, research director at J. D. Power. "But Fidelity managed to drop less than some of its competitors. What has emerged as most important is service. If you don't deliver on customer service and information, regardless if they're paying $2 or $200, it doesn't matter."
Such studies do not take into account the returns of the mutual funds that are managed by Fidelity. While the results are certainly better than they were in 1996, Fidelity has an odd problem for a business so fixated on technology. During the run-up of technology stocks in 1998 and 1999, its growth funds did not keep pace with those of some of its more aggressive competitors, particularly Janus.
Fidelity made heavy bets that doubled the technology weightings of some of its most prominent funds, but its moves were tame in comparison to Janus's, as was the performance of its growth funds.
"The most significant factor, by far, behind the dip in our equity funds' relative peer performance can be summed up in three words: technology, technology, technology," said Robert C. Pozen, the Fidelity vice chairman who was chosen three years ago by Mr. Johnson to resurrect the firm's fund operations.
Over all, performance has been solid, if not blazing, during Mr. Pozen's tenure. Fidelity's large-company funds, on average, beat 62 percent of their peers and gained 18.8 percent annually, well ahead of the 16 percent return of the S.& P. 500, according to Morningstar. Given the jittery performance of the technology sector this year -- and that of Janus -- Fidelity's more cautious approach looks better in retrospect.
"They don't have to shoot for the stars," said Eric Kobren, a former Fidelity marketing executive who publishes Fidelity Insight, a newsletter that tracks the company. At the post-modern Fidelity, consistency is king.
"What they can't afford to do," Mr. Kobren added, "is strike out."
 
The Message
An Old-Line Firm
Gets a Digital Face
Much about Fidelity has not changed in the five decades since its founding. It is still privately held and has no plans to go public in the foreseeable future. It is still run by a man named Edward Crosby Johnson. And Peter Lynch, the legendary, puff-haired former fund manager is still Fidelity's public face.
But Mr. Lynch, now a vice chairman, has not managed money in years, and a more apt representative of the new Fidelity might be Thomas Tullis, the chief of the usability labs.
Mr. Tullis is not your typical suit. He is a bearded, benevolent-looking professorial type who speaks in thoughtful tones and dresses Silicon Valley casual. He holds eight patents, including No. 5,715,370, for "Method and Apparatus for Extracting Text from a Structured Data File and Converting the Extracted Text to Speech."
"The Web has created a new set of rules or a new set of expectations related to usability," Mr. Tullis said earlier this year, during a speech at an I.B.M. conference on Web design.
"Web pages have to be easier to use," he continued, "than some of the alternatives that people might have available to them. Many people would agree now that Web pages need to be works of art as well. They need to be beautiful."
The Fidelity of old and the Fidelity of Mr. Tullis are both on display just around the corner from the company's headquarters. There, a digital kiosk lets investors communicate with their trillion-dollar, bionic investment firm.
On the wall of the kiosk is a picture of Edward Crosby Johnson II. Through his old-fashioned circular eyeglasses, he stares down on automated-teller machines and digital display terminals. Nearby, posted on a monitor, is a letter from his son to Fidelity investors.
"When my father founded this company in 1946, a 'Web site' was where you were likely to find a spider and a 'home page' was a section of the local newspaper," the younger Mr. Johnson wrote.
"If my father could see the company today," the letter continued, "he would marvel at what we've become."

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Everyday Plastic, Spun Into Gold

BYLINE: By JANE TANNER

 BODY:
IT wasn't too long ago that credit cards were reserved primarily for major purchases like furniture, appliances or fine jewelry. But these days, many a consumer routinely pulls out plastic for a cup of coffee, a movie ticket or even a cab ride.
More people are using credit cards instead of cash or bank checks, and more card issuers are encouraging that behavior, offering reward points to customers for each dollar charged. Depending on the program, those points can be traded for airline tickets, hotel accommodations, gift certificates or even a Mario Lemieux hockey stick. Last year, nearly 17 percent of all consumer purchases were made with credit cards, according to Credit Card News, which tracks the industry, compared with 10 percent in 1993. 
 The card issuers are also reaping many rewards. Their earnings and stock prices are up, and their charge-offs are down, partly because of sustained low unemployment and declining personal bankruptcies. Industry analysts say three major indicators of a healthy credit card market may now be in place: a strong economy, stable interest rates and market consolidation.
"It's the magic elixir," said Michael J. Freudenstein, who follows the sector for J. P. Morgan Securities.
So far this year, stock prices of the top 10 credit card issuers have climbed 28.6 percent, on average, while the shares of companies engaged primarily in the credit card business rose 36 percent, according to a J. P. Morgan sector index.
The Internet is also helping the industry. Online retail sales reached $20 billion last year in the United States and are expected to grow to $144 billion in three years, according to Forrester Research. "The Internet and the credit card are a perfect match," said Bjorn J. Turnquist, a research director at SNL Securities.
And while some market experts suggest that the card industry may be dragged down by a saturation of offerings and an anticipated deterioration in credit quality next year, others predict that the industry will strengthen, partly because consumers are so comfortable with plastic. "The whole idea of 'buy now, pay later' is very appealing to the American public," said Michael Schneider, an analyst at Standard & Poor's Equity Group. "Consumer spending patterns have been strong and have surprised a lot of people."
In Standard & Poor's latest report on the sector, the favored players are American Express, Capital One Financial, Citigroup, MBNA, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Providian Financial. Earlier this month, Chase Manhattan was a favored stock, too, but the announcement last week of Chase's $30.9 billion plan to acquire J. P. Morgan prompted S.& P. to downgrade the stock.
Analysts say American Express -- whose stock, now at $59.31, is near a 52-week high -- has done well with new revolving credit products. Its earnings grew 14 percent in the first half of the year. Next month, it plans to offer new products geared toward online use, including one that provides shoppers with disposable account numbers for more secure Internet purchases.
Analysts added that American Express, as well as the the Discover card from Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, could benefit if the Justice Department prevails in its antitrust lawsuit against Visa and MasterCard. The government says the two, the world's largest credit card networks with a combined 75 percent of the $1.3 trillion market, limit competition through exclusive arrangements with bank networks. The trial ended last month, and a decision is expected next month. If Visa and MasterCard lose, banks in the networks would be free to issue American Express and Discover cards.
Standard & Poor's predicted that MBNA, an aggressive marketer of affinity cards, those aligned with clubs or organizations, would sign up more groups and grow through acquisitions, much as it did in August when it bought First Union's $5.5 billion credit card portfolio. S.& P. estimated that earnings per share would increase about 20 percent a year over the next three years.
But Vincent Daniel, an analyst at CIBC World Markets, was not as bullish. He said MBNA carried the most debt, which increased its risks.
Capital One Financial is considered the leader in mining databases for information about potential card holders. The company offers thousands of card options with varying interest rates, based on spending patterns and other consumer characteristics. "That is a key to this game and they know how to do it better than anyone else," said Mr. Turnquist of SNL Securities.
S.& P. expects Capital One to sign up at least a million new accounts this year through Internet marketing.
Providian Financial is also considered strong in scrutinizing large databases and offering cards based on profiles, including poor credit histories. S.& P. expects growth in the company's credit accounts as well as a 25 percent increase in annual earnings per share over the next two to three years.
CITIGROUP is favored by S.& P. because of its huge customer base, which is likely to expand further as a result of its recently announced deal to acquire Associates First Capital.
Mr. Schneider expects the strong competitors to take market share from other contenders, like Household International, CompuCredit, CIT Group and Metris. But Mr. Freudenstein likes the prospects of CompuCredit, which went public in 1999 and mines the niche of customers whose credit histories are slightly tarnished. CompuCredit has signed an agreement with Fleet Credit Card Services to look at Fleet's rejected card applicants and assess whether to give them CompuCredit cards. For each customer that CompuCredit signs on, Fleet gets a referral fee.

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
Guevara to Reagan, and Beyond

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

 BODY:
IN the 1960's, David A. Stockman borrowed a bus from his pastor to drive fellow Michigan State students to an antiwar protest. He got the bus free, but he charged his fellow travelers $18 a head. "We used the profits for a Che Guevara memorial fund to do good works," Mr. Stockman recalled.
So who was the young Dave Stockman? An anti-establishment protester or a nascent capitalist? 
 The answer, of course, was both. But the categorization process has not become any easier.
At 53, Mr. Stockman has already been a farmer, Congressman, author, investment banker and, most famously, director of the Office of Management and Budget in the Reagan administration. In May, he added another line to his resume: a founder of Heartland Industrial Partners, a buyout firm with dual headquarters in Greenwich, Conn., and Detroit. Heartland will buy small old-economy companies, aggregate them into behemoths and take them public again.
Last month, Heartland, which has raised $1.2 billion in private equity, bought its first company, MascoTech, a small metal forger that Mr. Stockman thinks can be the nucleus of a huge company that makes all the systems that go into a car.
"Lots of small manufacturers have survived decades of hard times," said Mr. Stockman, who spent the last 12 years as a partner at the Blackstone Group, another buyout firm. "Heartland will buy and combine those winners."
Wait a minute. David Stockman as old-economy champion? The same man who as a Congressman -- from Michigan, no less -- argued against the government's bailout of Chrysler in 1979? ("Lee Iacocca still hasn't forgiven me for that!" he said with a laugh.) Again, will the real David Stockman please stand up?
It is tempting to accuse Mr. Stockman of intellectual Zeligism. But those who know him say it would also be dead wrong. They describe him as an unusual combination of number cruncher and strategist whose opinion can always be swayed by facts. They say he can analyze reams of data and come up with an accurate view, not only of what a company is, but also of what it can become.
"David was wrong about Chrysler then, but that won't stop him from embracing the reindustrialization of America now," said Richard E. Dauch, chairman of American Axle and Manufacturing, an automotive parts company on whose board Mr. Stockman served until last month.
Clearly not. "I'm still against government bailing out businesses," Mr. Stockman said, "but the public markets aren't providing the capital that small businesses need. It's ironic, maybe, but that's why Heartland will succeed."
The oldest of five children, David Stockman grew up milking cows and picking fruit on the family farm in St. Joseph, Mich. He majored in horticulture at Michigan State, with an eye toward running the farm for life.
But Michigan State was a hotbed of 60's radicalism, "and I picked up the disease," he recalled. "I wore long hair, read long books, thought deep thoughts," he added. Soon, it was goodbye to farming, hello to Harvard Divinity School.
He quickly abandoned his radicalism. "It was hard to stay zealous when I saw allegedly peace-loving activists toting guns and burning buildings," Mr. Stockman said. In Cambridge, he bunked in Daniel Patrick Moynihan's attic, trading baby-sitting and chores for rent. Late-night debates came with the territory. "That house was a re-education camp for me," Mr. Stockman said.
He soon left Harvard and went to Washington, as an aide to Representative John Anderson. Though remaining a social liberal, he became a fiscal conservative and free-market economist.
He often demonstrated his penchant for data. When he ran for Congress himself in the mid-1970's, he used computers to catalog primary voters and their interests, and to focus his message accordingly. He won by a landslide.
(His computer skill has served him well personally, too: he married Jennifer Blei, the I.B.M. sales representative on his account. They have two teenage daughters and live in Greenwich.)
In his early days in Congress, Mr. Stockman recalled fondly, he hotly debated energy and environmental policy with another brash young freshman named Al Gore. "We argued incessantly, to the chagrin of the senior members, who felt the kids shouldn't talk at all," Mr. Stockman said.
His friends from those days said Mr. Stockman was a persuasive arguer. "Dave is shy, but he really knew how to use numbers to support his policies," said David Gerson, one of Mr. Stockman's Washington roommates and now executive vice president of the American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research.
 LATER, as the O.M.B. director, Mr. Stockman used the same techniques. Daniel P. Tredwell, a Washington aide in the 1970's and now a Heartland partner, recalled that Mr. Stockman came to Appropriations Committee meetings with black binders full of facts and figures.
"We staffers made a sport of trying to stump him, but he could answer any question within minutes," Mr. Tredwell said.
But while others saw Mr. Stockman as a just-the-facts guy, "I still saw myself as an intellectual and philosopher," Mr. Stockman said with genial self-mockery. So, perhaps inevitably after he left government, he wrote a book.
He said that book, "The Triumph of Politics: Why the Reagan Revolution Failed," was a treatise on Reaganomics. But he acknowledged that much of Washington saw it as a tell-all betrayal. "The press kept quoting the sound bites instead of the policy," he said.
Actually, although Mr. Stockman may never "eat lunch in that town again," it doesn't much matter. There are enough numbers to crunch in Rust Belt America to keep him occupied.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 5; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 914 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
A Political Rarity: Seven Weeks of Maybe

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
AMERICANS this year are getting a chance to see something rare: a presidential dead heat.
The last time polls showed a White House match-up that was this close at this point was when Ronald Reagan took on President Jimmy Carter in 1980. Before that, you have to reach back another 20 years, to the contest between Vice President Richard M. Nixon and Senator John F. Kennedy. 
 Usually, the nominee who is ahead in the polls just after Labor Day wins. This time, neither candidate is ahead. That is not to suggest that the race of 2000 will be a replay of those of 1960 or 1980. If anything, there are more similarities to 1988, when an incumbent governor took on an incumbent vice president.
Nevertheless, as Gov. George W. Bush and Vice President Al Gore sweat out the daily tracking polls, there may be some lessons for them in examining how Mr. Reagan and Mr. Kennedy managed to charge ahead in the final days -- or final hours, in Mr. Kennedy's case -- before the election.
Around this time 20 years ago, Mr. Reagan did many of the same things Mr. Bush has done recently: He declared himself the underdog; asserted that his rival, as the incumbent, had the advantage; pronounced the current administration's record a failure, and insisted that he was not deterred by the publicity about whether he had the brains to be in the Oval Office.
But in terms of the state of the nation, this year's race resembles 1960 much more than 1980. Twenty years ago, there was runaway inflation, the Iran hostage crisis was unresolved and there were interminable lines at the gas pumps. But in 1960, like today, voters seemed relatively content. Then, as now, the race was between a vice president from a fairly popular administration -- at least as far as issues were concerned -- and a more charismatic (and more youthful) opponent.
Mr. Kennedy sought to inspire the electorate with a vision of the nation's future. At a speech given in Mineola, N.Y., nearly 40 years ago, he said, "This is a contest between the contented and those who wish to move ahead, between those who are satisfied and those who want to do better." Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore have also made the case that while the economy might be thriving, that is not enough, and were either of them to repeat verbatim Mr. Kennedy's words, no one would find them surprising or out of place today.
This year, just as in 1960 and 1980, it appears that the televised presidential debates will prove critical to the campaign. Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Reagan faced questions about their capacity and preparedness to lead, as Mr. Bush does now. Such questions were largely put to rest by the debates.
THE 1960 debates allowed Mr. Kennedy to demonstrate that he had mastered the issues against his more seasoned competitor, Mr. Nixon. More important, Mr. Nixon, who had been recuperating from an infection, looked pallid, even menacing, in the first and most heavily watched encounter. By contrast, Mr. Kennedy looked vital, relaxed and confident.
The 1980 debates proved crucial for Mr. Reagan, who was able, with a smile and a shake of the head, to demonstrate that he could handle the presidency. "There you go again," he said to Mr. Carter after the president lambasted him as a threat to world stability.
Even the vexed relations between the incumbent president and his vice president recalls the contests of 1960 and 1980. Many of Mr. Kennedy's associates said that Mr. Nixon failed to take advantage of his partnership with a popular president, Dwight D. Eisenhower. Mr. Eisenhower, however, did not help matters when he said he would need a week to think of a major decision in which Mr. Nixon participated as vice president.
President Clinton has been much more helpful to his vice president, especially by giving him a substantial role in his administration. But, given Mr. Clinton's own troubles, the relationship is complicated and Mr. Gore seems not to have resolved how and how much he can make use of the president to support his candidacy.
Beyond these narrow analogies lies a broad lesson that Mr. Gore and Mr. Bush should learn from the past -- especially in a fight as closely contested as this one. And that is not to grow too confident.
In mid-October of 1980, polls suggested that Mr. Reagan's support was leveling off and that Mr. Carter was on the rise. That led Robert Strauss, Mr. Carter's campaign manager, to say to a reporter at the time, "I sleep like a baby these nights."
Not too long after that comment, Mr. Reagan began to gain ground. He won with only 50.8 percent of the vote. The Kennedy victory was even more of a squeaker: 50.1 percent.
Joseph Napolitan, who worked on the Kennedy campaign, said he often toiled blissfully unaware of how tight the race really was. "We didn't have tracking polls the way we have now," he said. "We probably would have been more frightened if we had."
Imagine how Mr. Napolitan would have felt had he known that the entire contest could have turned on Mr. Kennedy's victory in Illinois, which some people say was assured only through vote stealing engineered by Mayor Richard J. Daley and his Chicago political machine.
"It was decided election day, or if you believe the Daley story, the morning after," said Fred Dutton, who was a strategist for the Kennedy campaign.
The lessons? It is hard to pinpoint a single stroke that can turn an election. And don't expect to win, because often victory is beyond the control of even the most adept candidate.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
On the Farm, Subsidies Continue To Flourish

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
IN the spring of 1996, the zealous new Republican majority in Congress persuaded President Clinton to sign a farm bill intended to wean American farmers from the government subsidies on which they had relied so heavily for so long.
Given that price supports, land set-asides and other aid were then costing Washington $7.3 billion a year -- and today's budget surpluses were not yet a gleam in even the most optimistic eye -- it seemed like a good idea. It just hasn't worked out. 
 This year, the government is expected to pay farmers $22.7 billion, more than triple the pre-overhaul level, accounting for 40 percent of farmers' net cash income. Some self-reliance.
That 1996 bill, the Freedom to Farm Act, began the shift from New Deal-era price-support programs to a more free-market approach at a time when crop prices were at 10-year highs. The idea was to let farmers choose what to grow based on what could be sold in the United States or overseas, not what the government would promise to buy. But subsidies were not eliminated. And the law wound up simply encouraging the world's most productive farmers to produce even more bin-busting crops, sending prices into a deep slump.
Oddly, though, the government is also making more payments to farmers to compensate them for natural disasters that kept some of them from adding even more surplus crops to glutted markets, like the drought that has plagued Texas, other parts of the Southwest and portions of the Southeast this summer, hitting cotton and pecan crops especially hard. Farmers hold a special place in the American psyche, and Congress is particularly reluctant to stint on relief in a presidential election year. More than a third -- $8.9 billion -- of aid to farmers this year will be disaster relief.
But the larger factor in the bump-up in spending is the bumper crops, especially of corn and soybeans, which are both expected to be up nearly 10 percent, to record levels.
"There's been a lot written about the drought, but we're still going to have a big harvest," said Jonathon P. Braatz, a senior vice president at George K. Baum & Company, a brokerage house in Kansas City, Mo. (Another analyst in the Midwest, where growing conditions have been almost ideal, said one farmer had called this summer's conditions the "wettest drought" he had ever seen.)
The 1996 legislation "didn't do what the designers had hoped," said Jack Hervey, a senior economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago. "Each year we're seeing larger appropriations for agriculture," he said, because "the strength of the safety net is encouraging crop production."
With granaries still swollen with last year's crops and foreign demand far below what was envisioned by the 1996 legislation, grain prices are depressed for a fourth consecutive year. Specialists say the price of soybeans could slide to the lowest level since 1971. The wheat harvest did shrink slightly this year, but prices are nonetheless expected to approach 14-year lows.
THE low crop prices that distress farmers, of course, also save money for consumers, and help the Federal Reserve keep overall inflation at bay without raising interest rates further. Over the last 12 months, the food component of the Consumer Price Index -- accounting for 15 percent of the market basket -- has climbed just 2.7 percent, while other components have risen 3.4 percent.
This price restraint seems particularly timely as a partial offset to the cost of energy, mainly oil and natural gas, which has jumped 13.1 percent in the last year. Energy, which makes up 7 percent of the price index, is also a big cost to farmers.
But indirectly, consumers do share farmers' pain at low prices. "Consumers are also taxpayers, and taxpayers are to a certain degree bailing the farmers out" with support payments, Mr. Braatz said.
The farm equipment business also suffers. The stock of John Deere, a major producer of tractors and other agricultural equipment, has lost one-third of its value since its 52-week high in May. Last week, however, three Wall Street analysts, seeing a bottom, made fresh appraisals: Two called the stock a "buy," and one rated it "attractive."
Few analysts see a major farm-sector rebound on the horizon, and specialists are already wondering what fixes Washington will seek in the Freedom to Farm Act, which expires in 2002.
"We got rid of deficiency payments, which rise as commodity prices fall," said Fred Nelson, a Department of Agriculture economist. "But other price-sensitive payments have since become operational, as prices sagged in the late 90's."

PUB-DATE: September 17, 2000

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1161 words

HEADLINE: The World;
Even in Euroland, Money Isn't Everything

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

DATELINE: BERLIN

 BODY:
THE 15-member European Union, it has often been said, resembles a bicycle. If it does not move forward, it falls. Right now, the bicycle is wobbling dangerously as Europe's persistent push for ever deeper integration wavers.
The most visible recent sign of a reverse was a decision by 14 of the union's governments to abandon sanctions imposed on Austria for including Jorg Haider's rightist party in government. When the measures were imposed seven months ago, states from France to Germany hailed them as a sign that the union had passed from a purely economic grouping to a nascent political force bound by shared moral values. But the sanctions proved controversial, particularly in smaller European countries that felt they might one day get the Austrian treatment, and it now seems clear that Europe got ahead of itself. 
 "We attempted to define ourselves as a club of values, but what was revealed in the end was that the values were weak and the political entity behind them even weaker," said Dominique Moisi, a French political analyst. For Jacques Chirac, whom Mr. Haider has repeatedly mocked as a "pocket Napoleon," the lesson was particularly bitter.
It is not only Mr. Haider who has taken note that Europe's political cohesion remains tenuous. So have financial markets. The euro, the shared currency introduced last year that is the most visible symbol of the Franco-German determination to move toward a United States of Europe, continues to plunge and has now lost 25 percent of its value. Three more years of this, one joke goes, and the currency will disappear altogether.
There are several reasons for the euro's weakness. Among them are a broad conviction that the potential for growth in the United States is simply greater because of the country's relentless productivity gains and the pull of American equity markets. But a more basic reason is this: the spreading unease over what sort of political integration will accompany the birth of Euroland. As one worried German official put it, "What is the political project that goes with economic union?"
This question was inevitable. In the rush for economic union -- hurried to ensure that a Germany united in 1990 would be irrevocably bound to its European partners -- the fact that states adopting the euro were abandoning a central facet of sovereignty without any clear political plan was glossed over.
But Europe now stands at an awkward crossroads. It needs to achieve greater political cohesion on everything from taxation to labor policy if the euro's credibility is to be salvaged. But, as the Austrian episode shows, Europe is also facing growing doubts among its various electorates over anything that smacks of a superstate. In Denmark, for example, where the Sept. 28 referendum on whether to join the euro is too close to call, any mention of eventual political union in a European federation is anathema.
"There is a new hesitancy," said Karl Kaiser, a German sociologist. "Small states are beginning to realize that European integration is indeed about integration and so you give up sovereignty. What they wanted was union with their national identity intact. But that is not so straightforward."
"Euromuddles," an American observer might be forgiven for muttering -- the same old story. It is true that the union has always grown through difficulties, and has always muddled through. It is also true that with the cold war won, the division of Europe ended, and three central European states already inside NATO, the United States has less reason for fretting about the old continent.
But there is another side to the story that suggests the United States should pay heed. The European Union and its forebears have helped provide a half-century of peace and stability from which America has profited enormously. The union has now started an extraordinary experiment -- the introduction of a shared currency with no European government to back it -- that carries genuine, new risks. A crisis is not inconceivable.
Imagine the following chain of events: Oil prices continue to rise. The euro, buffeted by a no vote in Denmark, continues to fall, raising still further the cost of imported oil. Inflation stirs; Europe's growth, currently looking sturdy, evaporates and a new recession looms before the planned disappearance on Jan. 1, 2002 of the national currencies of the 12 states that have adopted the euro.
German public opinion, sullenly accepting of the euro until now, forms the conviction that the beloved symbol of their post-war nationhood, the Deutsche mark, has been pledged in a reckless political gamble, and rebels. The opposition Christian Democrats, solidly behind ever greater European integration under Helmut Kohl but now casting around desperately for a new platform, are tempted to back the rebellion.
Populist, nationalist leaders, among them Mr. Haider, Silvio Berlusconi in Italy, and Pia Kjaersgaard in Denmark, find new grist for anti-European tirades. The age of the center-left in Europe gives way to an age of a new right. Any hope of real political integration flounders, leaving the euro a threatened orphan.
It probably will not happen, at least not all at once. But even without such a crisis, the European Union is facing unusually difficult months. One factor weighing on the euro is the question of the European Union's enlargement. Who know where Europe ends and what geographical entity the euro will ultimately represent?
MORE than a decade has now gone by since the cold war's end, but not one post-Communist European state has been brought into Europe's elite club. Without the membership of states like Poland or the Czech Republic, however, the quest of Europe's Founding Fathers for a continent at one and at peace looks hollow. The union accepts this fact, but does not know what to do about it.
For if more members come in, and the current mechanisms of governance are not changed, the union is likely to become ungovernable. So France, which holds the union's rotating presidency, is looking at ways to streamline the union -- through more decision-making by qualified majorities and a reduction in the number of executive commissioners in Brussels. It is also trying to draft a European charter of the basic rights of the union's 375 million citizens. All this by the end of the year. To many, however, such moves smack again of a dilution of nationhood at a time when they are not ready for it.
"Progress will be slow," conceded Klaus Leggewie, a German political analyst. "But if you look at what was dreamed of for the union in the 1950's, we got it in the end. It took longer than expected, but we got there. In the same way we will get a charter of rights and majority voting and an expanded union. Not next year. But it will be done."
That is the optimistic view. If things go the other way, it is a safe bet that Europe will be hearing a lot more of the now buoyant Mr. Haider and his kind.
